The fetal heart is auscultated at the flanks. What is the most likely abnormality?

Contractions are 4 in 10 mins lasting for 40-45 seconds. The birth attendant who has accompanied the patient says she has been pushing since close to 2 hours What is the next best step?

  • ➤ In Primi or Multi with evidence of CPD/ obstructed labor: Emergency cesarean
  • ➤ In Multigravida with no evidence of CPD/ Obstruction: Vacuum

questions.question_text: A 28-year-old woman in labor presents with an occiput posterior position. What is a potential maternal complaint commonly associated with it?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Back pain

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is the most common complaint associated with the occiput posterior position. The back of the baby's head pressing against the mother's sacrum can cause intense lower back pain, often referred to as "back labor." This pain can persist throughout labor and is often exacerbated during contractions.
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B: While abdominal pain is common during labor regardless of the fetal position, the OP position does not specifically cause more severe abdominal pain than other positions. However, labor might be longer and more painful overall due to the suboptimal alignment of the baby's head with the maternal pelvis. Option C: Frequent urination is a common symptom of occipitoposterior Option D: Shoulder pain or discomfort during pregnancy might be related to changes in posture, stress on the spine, or could be referred pain from gallbladder issues, which can be more common in pregnancy, but it's not a symptom commonly linked to fetal position in labor.
  • • Option B: While abdominal pain is common during labor regardless of the fetal position, the OP position does not specifically cause more severe abdominal pain than other positions. However, labor might be longer and more painful overall due to the suboptimal alignment of the baby's head with the maternal pelvis.

questions.question_text: A 28-year-old woman in labor presents with a brow presentation. What is the characteristic attitude of the fetal head in a brow presentation, and what is the most appropriate mode of delivery for this presentation?

options.A: The fetal head is partially extended, vaginal delivery with chin posterior
options.B: The fetal head is partially extended, cesarean section
options.C: The fetal head is fully extended; assisted vaginal delivery
options.D: The fetal head is flexed, spontaneous vaginal delivery

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. The fetal head is partially extended; cesarean section

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • In a brow presentation, the fetal head is partially extended. This presentation is considered unstable, and the most appropriate mode of delivery is often a cesarean section due to the increased risk of complications during a vaginal delivery.
  • • In a brow presentation, the fetal head is partially extended. This presentation is considered unstable, and the most appropriate mode of delivery is often a cesarean section due to the increased risk of complications during a vaginal delivery.

options.B: The fetal head is flexed, cesarean section
options.C: The fetal head is partially extended; assisted vaginal delivery
options.D: The fetal head is flexed, spontaneous vaginal delivery

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. The fetal head is fully extended; vaginal delivery with chin anterior

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In a face presentation with the chin anterior (mento anterior), the fetal head is partially extended. In some cases, it may be possible to proceed with a vaginal delivery, if the chin is anterior and not posterior.

questions.question_text: A 34 yr G2P1 unbooked patient with a previous normal delivery presents to the OPD at 37 weeks. On examination, you find that the uterus is term size and the breech is occupying the lower pole of the uterus. What is the next best step?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ECV is an external maneuver to turn the baby from breech (or transverse lie) to cephalic presentation. ECV is ideally done at 36-37 weeks IT reduces the incidence of cesarean sections Absolute contra-indications do during an ECV are: Placenta Previa Contracted Pelvis Multiple Pregnancy Hyperextended head Anomaly Dead fetus Distressed fetus Denied consent. A previous scar on the uterus (like a previous cesarean) is a relative contra-indication Factors favoring an ECV are: Multiparity Non engaged presenting part Adequate liquor Non-Anterior placenta Factors associated with failure of ECV are: Nulliparity Extended breech Anterior placenta Liquor more or less Maternal obesity Posterior spine Short cord Breech in the pelvis Complications of an ECV are: Fetal distress Abruption PROM Rupture uterus AFE Rh isoimmunization (in Rh incompatible couples)
  • ➤ ECV is an external maneuver to turn the baby from breech (or transverse lie) to cephalic presentation.

  • ➤ IT reduces the incidence of cesarean sections

questions.question_text: Which are correct statements about Breech delivery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. 2,3,5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Etiology of Breech Presentation
  • ➤ Etiology of Breech Presentation
  • ➤ Prematurity: MC cause Factor preventing spontaneous version: Twins, Oligohydramnios, congenital malformation of uterus such as septate or bicornuate uterus, short cord. Favorable adaptation: Hydrocephalus : Placenta previa; Contracted pelvis and Cornu-fundal attachment of the placenta. Undue mobility of fetus: Hydramnios and Multiparas with lax abdomen. Fetal abnormalities: Trisomy 13, 18, 21; Anencephaly and myotonic dystrophy due to alteration of fetal muscular tone and mobility. Additionally, 6% of breech presentations are found to have congenital malformation, include congenital hip dislocation, hydrocephalus, anencephalous, familial dysautonomia, spina bifida, meningomyelocele, and chromosomal trisomy 13, 18, and 21, Thus, those conditions that alter fetal muscular tone and mobility increase the likelihood of breech presentation.
  • ➤ Prematurity: MC cause
  • ➤ Factor preventing spontaneous version: Twins, Oligohydramnios, congenital malformation of uterus such as septate or bicornuate uterus, short cord.
  • ➤ Favorable adaptation: Hydrocephalus : Placenta previa; Contracted pelvis and Cornu-fundal attachment of the placenta.
  • ➤ Undue mobility of fetus: Hydramnios and Multiparas with lax abdomen.
  • ➤ Fetal abnormalities: Trisomy 13, 18, 21; Anencephaly and myotonic dystrophy due to alteration of fetal muscular tone and mobility.
  • ➤ Additionally, 6% of breech presentations are found to have congenital malformation, include congenital hip dislocation, hydrocephalus, anencephalous, familial dysautonomia, spina bifida, meningomyelocele, and chromosomal trisomy 13, 18, and 21, Thus, those conditions that alter fetal muscular tone and mobility increase the likelihood of breech presentation.

questions.question_text: You are conducting an assisted breech delivery of a primigravida who presented in active labor at 38 weeks. Which of the following will you NOT do?

options.B: Do not do any manipulation till the umbilicus is born
options.C: The arms are delivered once the nape of the neck is seen
options.D: Using Piper forceps to deliver the head reduces the risk of intracranial hemorrhage

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. The arms are delivered once the nape of the neck is seen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Conduct of an Assisted breech delivery:
  • ➤ Conduct of an Assisted breech delivery:
  • ➤ Bring patient to edge of table once breech is seen to climb the perineum Liberal medio-lateral episiotomy Ask the woman to bear down Do not manipulate till the umbilicus Keep back anterior If legs extended (frank breech), they can be delivered by pressure on popliteal fossa Wrap the fetus in a warm towel Deliver the arms once lower body of scapula is seen Delivery of after coming head: Once nape of neck is seen: Supra pubic pressure applied to keep the head flexed and deliver by Burns Marshall Technique Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique Piper forceps Reduces incidence of fetal intracranial hemorrhage (prevents sudden compression/ decompression of fetal head) Promotes flexion of the head Avoids cervical spine injuries (traction is on the head not the neck)

questions.question_text: A 32-year-old woman in labor presents with a footling breech presentation. What is a potential concern with a footling breech presentation that can make it less suitable for vaginal delivery?

options.A: Increased risk of umbilical cord prolapse
options.D: Lower chance of successful forceps delivery

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Increased risk of umbilical cord prolapse

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In a footling breech, because the presenting part does not completely occlude the cervix as a head would, there is more space for the umbilical cord to slip past and prolapse, which can lead to cord compression and compromised fetal blood flow. This is one of the main concerns with footling breech presentations.
  • • In a footling breech, because the presenting part does not completely occlude the cervix as a head would, there is more space for the umbilical cord to slip past and prolapse, which can lead to cord compression and compromised fetal blood flow. This is one of the main concerns with footling breech presentations.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Shoulder dystocia is a specific complication of vaginal delivery where the baby's head is delivered but the shoulders become stuck inside the mother's pelvis. This is more commonly associated with cephalic (head-first) presentations, especially with macrosomic (large) babies, babies of diabetic mothers, and is not a primary concern with a breech delivery. While there can be a risk of entrapment of the fetal head in a breech delivery, this is not specifically a higher risk in a footling breech compared to other types of breech. The main concern with a footling breech is the potential for cord prolapse and the difficulty in delivering the after-coming head because it must pass through the birth canal last and is large. Forceps are typically used to assist the delivery of the head in cephalic presentations, and they are not commonly used in breech deliveries. Though they may be used for aftercoming head.
  • • Shoulder dystocia is a specific complication of vaginal delivery where the baby's head is delivered but the shoulders become stuck inside the mother's pelvis. This is more commonly associated with cephalic (head-first) presentations, especially with macrosomic (large) babies, babies of diabetic mothers, and is not a primary concern with a breech delivery.
  • • While there can be a risk of entrapment of the fetal head in a breech delivery, this is not specifically a higher risk in a footling breech compared to other types of breech. The main concern with a footling breech is the potential for cord prolapse and the difficulty in delivering the after-coming head because it must pass through the birth canal last and is large.
  • • Forceps are typically used to assist the delivery of the head in cephalic presentations, and they are not commonly used in breech deliveries. Though they may be used for aftercoming head.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The highest incidence of cord prolapse is in transverse lie followed by footling breech

questions.question_text: A 30-year-old woman in labor presents with her baby in a transverse lie. What is the initial management step for this presentation?

options.A: Administer tocolytic agents to relax the uterus
options.B: Attempt external cephalic version to reposition the baby
options.D: Encourage the patient to change positions to facilitate fetal movement

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Perform an emergency cesarean section

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Tocolytics are medications used to relax the uterus and stop contractions, typically in the case of preterm labor. They would not be used for a transverse lie in a woman who is in labor. Option B: An external cephalic version (ECV) is a procedure where the doctor attempts to turn the fetus from outside the mother's body. It is usually performed before labor begins (preferably at 36 -37 weeks) and is not recommended once labor has commenced. Option D: While changing maternal positions can be a strategy used in pre-labor to encourage a baby to move into a better position for birth, it is unlikely to be effective once labor has started with a transverse lie. The risk of cord prolapse, fetal distress, and other complications increases with ruptured membranes and labor progression.
  • • Option A: Tocolytics are medications used to relax the uterus and stop contractions, typically in the case of preterm labor. They would not be used for a transverse lie in a woman who is in labor.
  • • Option A:
  • • Option B: An external cephalic version (ECV) is a procedure where the doctor attempts to turn the fetus from outside the mother's body. It is usually performed before labor begins (preferably at 36 -37 weeks) and is not recommended once labor has commenced.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option D: While changing maternal positions can be a strategy used in pre-labor to encourage a baby to move into a better position for birth, it is unlikely to be effective once labor has started with a transverse lie. The risk of cord prolapse, fetal distress, and other complications increases with ruptured membranes and labor progression.
  • • Option D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a woman who is in labor with a transverse lie, management is:
  • ➤ External cephalic version (ECV) if presents between 36 - 37 weeks with no contra-indications to ECV Cesarean section if the patient presents after 38 weeks/ in labor as the success of ECV reduces with advanced gestational age and ECV cannot be done in labor
  • ➤ External cephalic version (ECV) if presents between 36 - 37 weeks with no contra-indications to ECV
  • ➤ Cesarean section if the patient presents after 38 weeks/ in labor as the success of ECV reduces with advanced gestational age and ECV cannot be done in labor
  • ➤ Ref: Page 453, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.question_text: A 33-year-old woman in labor presents with a cord prolapse. Despite elevating the presenting part, the cord remains visible outside the vagina. What is the next recommended step in managing this situation?

options.A: Administer tocolytic agents to reduce uterine contractions
options.B: Attempt to gently push the cord back into the uterus
options.C: Prepare for an emergency cesarean section
options.D: Place the patient in a knee-chest position to relieve cord compression

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Prepare for an emergency cesarean section

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A: While tocolytics may be used temporarily to reduce contractions and potentially decrease compression of the prolapsed cord, they do not solve the underlying issue and are not a definitive treatment. Option B: Attempt to gently push the cord back into the uterus is not typically recommended as it can be difficult to perform, could potentially cause further distress or injury to the fetus, and may not be successful. Moreover, even if the cord is repositioned, the risk of re-prolapse and compression remains, and it does not address the immediate need for delivery. Option D: While placing the patient in the knee-chest position (or Trendelenburg position) can help to relieve pressure on the prolapsed cord and is a good immediate response, it is not a definitive treatment. This position should be used as a temporary measure to relieve pressure on the cord while preparations for an emergency cesarean section are being made.
  • • Option A: While tocolytics may be used temporarily to reduce contractions and potentially decrease compression of the prolapsed cord, they do not solve the underlying issue and are not a definitive treatment.
  • • Option A:
  • • Option B: Attempt to gently push the cord back into the uterus is not typically recommended as it can be difficult to perform, could potentially cause further distress or injury to the fetus, and may not be successful. Moreover, even if the cord is repositioned, the risk of re-prolapse and compression remains, and it does not address the immediate need for delivery.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option D: While placing the patient in the knee-chest position (or Trendelenburg position) can help to relieve pressure on the prolapsed cord and is a good immediate response, it is not a definitive treatment. This position should be used as a temporary measure to relieve pressure on the cord while preparations for an emergency cesarean section are being made.
  • • Option D:
  • • The definitive management of cord prolapse in a baby who is alive is prompt delivery of the baby which can best be achieved by an immediate cesarean section
  • • The definitive management of cord prolapse in a baby who is alive is prompt delivery of the baby which can best be achieved by an immediate cesarean section

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cord prolapse is an obstetric emergency If the FHR is +, immediate delivery is the RULE, and this has to be achieved as quickly as possible Till the time the cesarean s being arranged for/ being done, the pressure over the cord has to be relieved by knee chest or lateral position/ pushing presenting part away from the cord/ tocolytic/ filling the urinary bladder/ Trendelenburg position

questions.question_text: A 26-year-old woman in labor has a transverse lie presentation. What maternal position is often recommended to encourage fetal repositioning into a more favorable presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Lateral recumbent position

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The lateral recumbent position is often recommended for a patient with a transverse lie presentation to encourage fetal repositioning into a more favorable presentation to relieve pressure off the cord. Other recommended positions are: knee-chest and Trendelenburg positions
  • • The lateral recumbent position is often recommended for a patient with a transverse lie presentation to encourage fetal repositioning into a more favorable presentation to relieve pressure off the cord.
  • • Other recommended positions are: knee-chest and Trendelenburg positions
  • • Other recommended positions are: knee-chest and Trendelenburg positions
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B. Supine position: This is generally not recommended, especially in later stages of pregnancy, because lying flat on the back can cause the weight of the uterus to compress the inferior vena cava, reducing blood return to the heart and decreasing blood flow to the uterus and fetus. This is known as supine hypotensive syndrome.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Semi-Fowler's position: This position, where the woman is partially sitting up at a 30 to 45-degree angle, can sometimes be comfortable for the mother, but it does not specifically encourage the fetus to turn from a transverse lie to a cephalic or breech position.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Prone position: Pregnant women are generally advised against lying in a prone position (lying flat on the stomach) due to the discomfort and pressure it places on the uterus and fetus.
  • • Option D.

Ans. B. Obstructed labor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is a scenario of obstructed labor
  • • Clinical features of Obstructed labor are
  • • Maternal dehydration and exhaustion Tachycardia Abdominal exam Tonically contracted upper segment Relaxed thinned out lower segment Bandl ring Taut round ligaments Fetal parts not well felt FHR absent Vaginal exam Cervix fully dilated or loosely hanging Caput +++ Molding +++

  • • Management of Obstructed Labor: Emergency Cesarean Section; catheter is kept for upto 2 weeks following cesarean to prevent formation of a Vesico vaginal fistula
  • • Management of Obstructed Labor:
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A: The latent phase of labor refers to the early part of labor up to about 4 cm dilatation (as per the WHO modified partograph). This phase can last for several hours; however, the question suggests that the duration has exceeded what is typically expected for the latent phase, and the presence of maternal exhaustion indicates that this situation is likely not a normal latent phase. Option C: Uterine rupture is typically associated with intense abdominal pain, maternal shock, abnormal fetal heart rate patterns, loss of station of the fetal head (i.e., the head retracts upward), and sometimes bleeding. It doesn’t typically present merely a lack of progress in labor without these other clinical signs. Option D: The occiput anterior is considered the most favorable position for vaginal delivery and does not by itself lead to a lack of progress in labor.

questions.question_text: A 28-year-old woman in labor reports severe lower abdominal pain, uterine tenderness, and a visible mass in her abdomen. On examination, the uterus is palpable above the umbilicus, and fetal parts are not engaged in the pelvis. The FHR is not localized. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Uterine rupture

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Other options :
  • • Other options
  • • Option A: A ruptured ovarian cyst can cause acute abdominal pain, often on one side, and can sometimes be associated with signs of internal bleeding if the cyst is large or if there is significant hemorrhage. However, the presence of a visible mass in the abdomen and the palpable uterus above the umbilicus with the labor context, make a ruptured ovarian cyst less likely Option C: Obstructed labor typically presents with a failure of the labor to progress, with the fetal head not descending into the pelvis. While it can lead to severe complications, the presence of a visible abdominal mass and a uterus palpable above the umbilicus is not characteristic of obstructed labor unless it has led to a uterine rupture. Option D: Ectopic pregnancy typically manifests much earlier in pregnancy, leading to medical or surgical intervention before reaching term.
  • • Option A: A ruptured ovarian cyst can cause acute abdominal pain, often on one side, and can sometimes be associated with signs of internal bleeding if the cyst is large or if there is significant hemorrhage. However, the presence of a visible mass in the abdomen and the palpable uterus above the umbilicus with the labor context, make a ruptured ovarian cyst less likely
  • • Option A:
  • • Option C: Obstructed labor typically presents with a failure of the labor to progress, with the fetal head not descending into the pelvis. While it can lead to severe complications, the presence of a visible abdominal mass and a uterus palpable above the umbilicus is not characteristic of obstructed labor unless it has led to a uterine rupture.
  • • Option C:
  • • Option D: Ectopic pregnancy typically manifests much earlier in pregnancy, leading to medical or surgical intervention before reaching term.
  • • Option D:
  • • Hence, given the details provided, the most likely diagnosis is (B) Uterine rupture.

  • • Other options
  • • Option B: Placental abruption is the premature separation of the placenta from the uterus, which can also cause abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. However, fetal parts are not palpable outside the uterus in this condition. Option C: Obstructed labor occurs when the baby cannot progress through the birth canal despite strong contractions. It does not typically present with abdominal pain and bleeding unless it leads to a secondary complication like uterine rupture. Option D: A cervical laceration can cause significant vaginal bleeding, but it usually occurs during the passage of the baby through the birth canal, often in the second stage of labor or during delivery. It would not explain the abdominal pain or the palpation of fetal parts outside the uterus, nor would it typically lead to fetal distress unless there is significant blood loss.

questions.question_text: Match the maneuver used in shoulder dystocia with the description:
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Shoulder Dystocia Maneuvers
  • ➤ Shoulder Dystocia Maneuvers
  • ➤ McRoberts maneuver: - Hyperflexion of mother’s legs onto the abdomen during child birth This widens the pelvis, and flattens the lumbar spine. Suprapubic pressure: directional (45° downward) pressure to the maternal abdomen just above the pubic symphysis. This pressure should be applied to the posterior aspect of the anterior shoulder, pushing toward the opposite side from where the attendant is positioned. Suprapubic pressure is often used concomitantly with the McRoberts maneuver. Rubin II or posterior pressure on the anterior shoulder, which would bring the fetus in an oblique position with head somewhat towards the vagina Woods’ screw maneuver which leads to turning the anterior shoulder to the posterior and vice versa (somewhat the opposite of Rubin II maneuver) Gaskin maneuver involves moving the mother to an all fours position with the back arched, widening the pelvic outlet. Zaninelli’s maneuver, which involves pushing the fetal head back in with performing a cesarean section. or internal cephalic replacement followed by Cesarean section. Intentional fetal clavicular fracture, which reduces the diameter of the shoulder girdle that requires to pass through the birth canal. Maternal symphysiotomy, which makes the opening of the birth canal laxer by breaking the connective tissue between the two pubes bones facilitating the passage of the shoulders. Abdominal rescue, described by O’Shaughnessy. where a hysterotomy facilitates vaginal delivery of the impacted shoulder

questions.question_text: A 32-year-old woman is in labor and begins experiencing shoulder dystocia. What is the initial FIRST step in managing this obstetric emergency?

options.D: Attempt gentle traction on the baby's head

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Call for additional help

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Other options :
  • • Other options
  • • Option A: Applying fundal pressure is not recommended in cases of shoulder dystocia. Fundal pressure can increase the risk of injury to both the mother and the baby, including the risk of uterine rupture or worsening the impaction of the shoulder against the maternal pelvis. Option B: An episiotomy may be performed to aid delivery of the shoulders, but it is not the first step in managing shoulder dystocia. While it can sometimes help, the primary issue in shoulder dystocia is the impaction of the shoulder above the pubic symphysis, not the size of the vaginal opening. Option D: Gentle traction may be attempted, but excessive or improper traction can lead to brachial plexus injuries or clavicular fractures in the newborn. The key is to avoid excessive force and use maneuvers designed to relieve the dystocia by repositioning the baby's shoulders.

questions.question_text: A 30-year-old woman in labor develops shoulder dystocia, and the McRoberts maneuver and suprapubic pressure are unsuccessful. The fetal head is visible, but the shoulders are not descending. What is the next step in managing this situation?

options.A: Attempt to deliver the posterior shoulder first
options.B: Apply vacuum extraction to facilitate delivery
options.C: Continue with gentle traction on the fetal head

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Attempt to deliver the posterior shoulder first

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B: Using vacuum extraction is not indicated for shoulder dystocia and can be dangerous. The difficulty in shoulder dystocia is not with the delivery of the head, which the vacuum assists with, but with the delivery of the shoulders. Using a vacuum can increase the risk of neonatal injury without resolving the underlying problem. Option C: Continuing with gentle downward traction may be a component of the initial management, but if the standard maneuvers have not been successful, continuing to pull without changing strategy is inappropriate and can cause brachial plexus injury or clavicular fracture. Option D: An IUPC is used to measure the strength and frequency of uterine contractions and is not useful in the management of shoulder dystocia. Shoulder dystocia is a mechanical problem that requires physical maneuvers to resolve, not something that can be assisted by increasing uterine contractions.
  • • Option B: Using vacuum extraction is not indicated for shoulder dystocia and can be dangerous. The difficulty in shoulder dystocia is not with the delivery of the head, which the vacuum assists with, but with the delivery of the shoulders. Using a vacuum can increase the risk of neonatal injury without resolving the underlying problem.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option C: Continuing with gentle downward traction may be a component of the initial management, but if the standard maneuvers have not been successful, continuing to pull without changing strategy is inappropriate and can cause brachial plexus injury or clavicular fracture.
  • • Option C:

Shoulder dystocia is a mechanical problem that requires physical maneuvers to resolve, not something that can be assisted by increasing uterine contractions.

questions.question_text: A 24-year-old G1P1 woman presents to the emergency department 2 hours after a spontaneous vaginal delivery with a complaint of continuous bright red vaginal bleeding despite a well-contracted uterus. She denies any dizziness or syncope. On pelvic examination, the physician notes a 4-cm laceration extending from the vaginal mucosa into the right side of the vestibule and involving the bulbocavernosus muscle. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Surgical repair of the laceration

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A: Observation and expectant management is inappropriate for the management of postpartum bleeding when an active laceration has been identified. Continuous bleeding requires intervention to achieve hemostasis. Option B: While oxytocin is useful for uterine atony (when the uterus is not contracting well after delivery), it would not be effective in this case as the uterus is well-contracted. Oxytocin will not stop the bleeding from laceration. Option C: Manual exploration of the uterus is indicated if there is a suspicion of retained placental fragments or clots inside the uterus causing bleeding. However, since the uterus is well-contracted and the source of bleeding is identified as laceration, this option is not appropriate.

questions.question_text: An hour after giving birth, a 30-year-old woman complains of severe chest pain, shortness of breath, and tachycardia. She had a vaginal delivery with an episiotomy. What is the most likely complication, and what diagnostic test is indicated?

options.A: Pulmonary embolism; perform a computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA)

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Pulmonary embolism; perform a computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The symptoms of severe chest pain, shortness of breath, and tachycardia in a postpartum woman can be alarming and suggest a cardiovascular or pulmonary origin. Given the symptomatology of severe chest pain and shortness of breath along with tachycardia, pulmonary embolism (PE) is a leading concern. Pregnancy and the postpartum period increase the risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE), making PE a more likely complication in this context. A CTPA is the most appropriate and definitive test for diagnosing a PE as it allows direct visualization of the pulmonary arteries to detect any emboli.
  • • The symptoms of severe chest pain, shortness of breath, and tachycardia in a postpartum woman can be alarming and suggest a cardiovascular or pulmonary origin. Given the symptomatology of severe chest pain and shortness of breath along with tachycardia, pulmonary embolism (PE) is a leading concern. Pregnancy and the postpartum period increase the risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE), making PE a more likely complication in this context. A CTPA is the most appropriate and definitive test for diagnosing a PE as it allows direct visualization of the pulmonary arteries to detect any emboli.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B: Atelectasis involves collapse of part of the lung and is common after anesthesia or due to immobility. It usually presents with mild to moderate dyspnea and occasionally tachypnea. Atelectasis is typically not associated with severe chest pain. A chest X-ray is the standard imaging modality for identifying atelectasis but given the severity of the symptoms, atelectasis is less likely to be the primary issue here. Option C: Postpartum pneumonia could present with shortness of breath, chest pain, fever, and a productive cough. A sputum culture can be helpful in identifying the causative organism if pneumonia is suspected. However, pneumonia is generally less likely to present so acutely with severe chest pain and without other respiratory infection symptoms like fever and cough. Option D: Peripartum cardiomyopathy is a form of heart failure that can occur during the last month of pregnancy or the months following delivery. It can present with shortness of breath, fatigue, and signs of heart failure. An echocardiogram is used to diagnose this condition by assessing the heart's function and structure. While peripartum cardiomyopathy can cause dyspnea and tachycardia, the sudden onset of severe chest pain is less characteristic of this condition.
  • • Option B: Atelectasis involves collapse of part of the lung and is common after anesthesia or due to immobility. It usually presents with mild to moderate dyspnea and occasionally tachypnea. Atelectasis is typically not associated with severe chest pain. A chest X-ray is the standard imaging modality for identifying atelectasis but given the severity of the symptoms, atelectasis is less likely to be the primary issue here.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option C: Postpartum pneumonia could present with shortness of breath, chest pain, fever, and a productive cough. A sputum culture can be helpful in identifying the causative organism if pneumonia is suspected. However, pneumonia is generally less likely to present so acutely with severe chest pain and without other respiratory infection symptoms like fever and cough.
  • • Option C:
  • • Option D: Peripartum cardiomyopathy is a form of heart failure that can occur during the last month of pregnancy or the months following delivery. It can present with shortness of breath, fatigue, and signs of heart failure. An echocardiogram is used to diagnose this condition by assessing the heart's function and structure. While peripartum cardiomyopathy can cause dyspnea and tachycardia, the sudden onset of severe chest pain is less characteristic of this condition.
  • • Option D:
  • • In this scenario, the most likely complication based on the acute presentation and symptoms is a pulmonary embolism. Hence, the indicated diagnostic test is a CTPA, which would provide rapid and clear evidence for or against the presence of a PE, which is essential given the potential for rapid deterioration and the need for prompt treatment in such cases.

  • • Uterine atony, the most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage, occurs when the uterus fails to contract adequately after the baby’s delivery. The initial management involves administering uterotonic medications (e.g., oxytocin) and performing uterine massage to stimulate uterine contractions.

questions.question_text: A 30-year-old woman experiences a sudden drop in blood pressure, tachycardia, and confusion after delivering her baby. On examination, her uterus is well contracted with no active bleeding. She has no significant medical or surgical history. What is the most likely complication, and what is the initial treatment?

options.B: Amniotic fluid embolism; provide supportive care
options.C: Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC); initiate anticoagulation therapy
options.D: Uterine rupture; prepare for surgical repair

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Amniotic fluid embolism; provide supportive care

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation of a sudden drop in blood pressure, tachycardia, and confusion after delivery with a firm uterus and no active bleeding is suggestive of a non-hemorrhagic shock, which does not fit with the typical signs of postpartum hemorrhage or uterine rupture. Amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) is a rare but serious and potentially fatal condition that can occur during labor or after delivery. It's characterized by a sudden onset of hypotension, respiratory distress, and coagulopathy, often accompanied by neurological symptoms such as confusion or seizures due to an embolic event. The diagnosis is clinical and one of exclusion. There's no specific treatment, so supportive care is critical. This includes maintaining oxygenation and hemodynamic support, as well as addressing any coagulopathy that may arise.
  • • The clinical presentation of a sudden drop in blood pressure, tachycardia, and confusion after delivery with a firm uterus and no active bleeding is suggestive of a non-hemorrhagic shock, which does not fit with the typical signs of postpartum hemorrhage or uterine rupture.
  • • Amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) is a rare but serious and potentially fatal condition that can occur during labor or after delivery. It's characterized by a sudden onset of hypotension, respiratory distress, and coagulopathy, often accompanied by neurological symptoms such as confusion or seizures due to an embolic event. The diagnosis is clinical and one of exclusion. There's no specific treatment, so supportive care is critical. This includes maintaining oxygenation and hemodynamic support, as well as addressing any coagulopathy that may arise.
  • • Other options :
  • • Other options
  • • Option A: Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) is characterized by heavy bleeding of more than 500 mL after vaginal delivery or 1000 mL after cesarean delivery. The clinical signs would typically include a drop in blood pressure and an increase in heart rate. However, the uterus may often be atonic, although it can be firm in cases of retained placental fragments or genital tract tears. Initial treatment would focus on identifying the source of bleeding and managing it with uterotonics, repair of any lacerations, and blood transfusions if necessary. Option C: DIC is a secondary condition that can occur as a complication of several obstetric emergencies, such as severe PPH, sepsis, or AFE. It's characterized by activation of clotting in the small blood vessels throughout the body, which can lead to a paradoxical increase in bleeding due to the consumption of clotting factors and platelets. Treatment is primarily focused on treating the underlying cause and supporting the coagulation system with blood products as necessary. Option D: Uterine rupture involves a tear in the wall of the uterus and is typically accompanied by severe abdominal pain, loss of fetal station, and sometimes vaginal bleeding. The uterus would not be described as firm in such a case. If the rupture is complete, there would often be signs of fetal distress or even maternal hemodynamic instability if there is significant intra-abdominal bleeding. Surgical repair is necessary for uterine rupture, and it's an obstetric emergency that requires immediate intervention.
  • • Option A: Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) is characterized by heavy bleeding of more than 500 mL after vaginal delivery or 1000 mL after cesarean delivery. The clinical signs would typically include a drop in blood pressure and an increase in heart rate. However, the uterus may often be atonic, although it can be firm in cases of retained placental fragments or genital tract tears. Initial treatment would focus on identifying the source of bleeding and managing it with uterotonics, repair of any lacerations, and blood transfusions if necessary.
  • • Option A:
  • • Option C: DIC is a secondary condition that can occur as a complication of several obstetric emergencies, such as severe PPH, sepsis, or AFE. It's characterized by activation of clotting in the small blood vessels throughout the body, which can lead to a paradoxical increase in bleeding due to the consumption of clotting factors and platelets. Treatment is primarily focused on treating the underlying cause and supporting the coagulation system with blood products as necessary.
  • • Option C:
  • • Option D: Uterine rupture involves a tear in the wall of the uterus and is typically accompanied by severe abdominal pain, loss of fetal station, and sometimes vaginal bleeding. The uterus would not be described as firm in such a case. If the rupture is complete, there would often be signs of fetal distress or even maternal hemodynamic instability if there is significant intra-abdominal bleeding. Surgical repair is necessary for uterine rupture, and it's an obstetric emergency that requires immediate intervention.
  • • Option D:
  • • Given the clinical presentation the most likely diagnosis is amniotic fluid embolism.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amniotic Fluid Embolism should be suspected in a patient who has cardio-respiratory collapse immediately following delivery or anytime in labor.
  • ➤ Criteria for diagnosing Amniotic Fluid Embolism
  • ➤ Clinical onset during labor or within 30 minutes of placenta delivery
  • ➤ Abrupt onset of cardiorespiratory arrest, or both hypotension and respiratory compromise
  • ➤ Overt disseminated intravascular coagulopathy.
  • ➤ No fever > 30°C

questions.question_text: A 28-year-old woman has delivered her baby, and the placenta is delivered intact. Shortly after, she reports severe lower abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and a feeling of "something coming out." What is the likely complication, and what is the next step in management?

options.A: Uterine inversion; manually reposition the uterus
options.D: Uterine rupture; prepare for emergency surgery

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Uterine inversion; manually reposition the uterus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Management of acute uterine inversion:
  • • Management of acute uterine inversion:
  • • Call for help. Resuscitation and reposition go hand in hand if inversion occurs in labour room. It is best reposited in the labour room itself and immediately after giving analgesics. The part of uterus which comes out last goes in first. Keep your first inside the uterus till the oxytocic is given and the uterus contracts. Keep the patient on oxytocics for 24 hours post reposition. Avoid pressing on the fundus post reposition to prevent recurrence.
  • • Call for help.
  • • Resuscitation and reposition go hand in hand if inversion occurs in labour room.
  • • It is best reposited in the labour room itself and immediately after giving analgesics.
  • • The part of uterus which comes out last goes in first.
  • • Keep your first inside the uterus till the oxytocic is given and the uterus contracts.
  • • Keep the patient on oxytocics for 24 hours post reposition.
  • • Avoid pressing on the fundus post reposition to prevent recurrence.
  • • Other options :
  • • Other options
  • • Uterine atony, a condition where the uterus fails to contract after delivery, is the most common cause of pph. It typically presents with bleeding and a soft, boggy uterus on palpation. If the placenta or fragments of it are retained inside the uterus, this can also cause PPH since the uterine muscles cannot contract effectively. However, the scenario described indicates that the placenta was delivered intact, ruling out retained placental tissue as the cause of the symptoms. Uterine rupture involves a tear in the muscular wall of the uterus, which is an obstetric emergency. It can result in severe abdominal pain and bleeding, and the fetus may be expelled into the abdominal cavity. However, uterine rupture is unlikely in this case as the placenta has been delivered intact, and there's no mention of fetal distress or loss of fetal station, which would be indicative of such a rupture.

  • • If the placenta or fragments of it are retained inside the uterus, this can also cause PPH since the uterine muscles cannot contract effectively. However, the scenario described indicates that the placenta was delivered intact, ruling out retained placental tissue as the cause of the symptoms.
  • • Uterine rupture involves a tear in the muscular wall of the uterus, which is an obstetric emergency. It can result in severe abdominal pain and bleeding, and the fetus may be expelled into the abdominal cavity. However, uterine rupture is unlikely in this case as the placenta has been delivered intact, and there's no mention of fetal distress or loss of fetal station, which would be indicative of such a rupture.
  • • Given the symptoms described and the fact that the placenta was already delivered, the most likely complication is uterine inversion

Keep the patient on oxytocics for 24 hours post reposition. Avoid pressing on the fundus post reposition to prevent recurrence.

questions.question_text: A 26-year-old woman delivers her first baby vaginally. She begins to complain of severe rectal pain and inability to pass urine. On examination, the perineum is swollen and ecchymotic. What is the likely complication, and what is the initial treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Vaginal hematoma; surgical drainage

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Other options :
  • • Other options
  • • Option B: Urethral injury is less common and might not directly lead to swelling and ecchymosis of the perineum. However, an injury to the urethra might cause difficulty with urination. Management of a suspected urethral injury typically includes urethral catheterization to ensure bladder drainage and to help define the injury. Option C: Uterine atony is a condition where the uterus fails to contract after delivery, leading to postpartum hemorrhage. The primary symptoms would be bleeding and a soft, boggy uterus on palpation, rather than rectal pain and difficulty with urination. Option D: A rectovaginal fistula is an abnormal connection between the rectum and vagina that can occur as a complication of childbirth, especially after a traumatic delivery. While a rectovaginal fistula could cause fecal matter to pass through the vagina, it would not typically present with acute urinary retention or severe rectal pain immediately postpartum. The management involves surgical repair, but this is not done immediately postpartum and would not be the first-line treatment for the symptoms described.
  • • Option B: Urethral injury is less common and might not directly lead to swelling and ecchymosis of the perineum. However, an injury to the urethra might cause difficulty with urination. Management of a suspected urethral injury typically includes urethral catheterization to ensure bladder drainage and to help define the injury.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option C: Uterine atony is a condition where the uterus fails to contract after delivery, leading to postpartum hemorrhage. The primary symptoms would be bleeding and a soft, boggy uterus on palpation, rather than rectal pain and difficulty with urination.
  • • Option C:
  • • Option D: A rectovaginal fistula is an abnormal connection between the rectum and vagina that can occur as a complication of childbirth, especially after a traumatic delivery. While a rectovaginal fistula could cause fecal matter to pass through the vagina, it would not typically present with acute urinary retention or severe rectal pain immediately postpartum. The management involves surgical repair, but this is not done immediately postpartum and would not be the first-line treatment for the symptoms described.

  • • Based on the given symptoms - severe rectal pain, inability to pass urine, and a swollen, bruised perineum - the most likely complication in this scenario is a vaginal hematoma.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The clinical presentation of severe rectal pain, inability to pass urine, perineal swelling, and vulval swelling and ecchymosis soon after delivery is consistent with a vaginal hematoma. The initial treatment is surgical drainage to relieve the hematoma and prevent complications.

questions.question_text: A 45-year woman presents to the OPD for evaluation of irregular menstrual bleeding. The patient had inter-menstrual bleeding for the past 8 months and this has now become progressively prolonged such that she has been bleeding on almost all days of the month. The patient previously used an LNG-IUS for contraception for 10 years but had it removed a year earlier after her husband underwent a vasectomy. She takes no medication and is a non-smoker. Her BMI is 38. Abdominal exam is normal and bimanual exam is also normal. There are no cervical or vaginal lesions. A hysteroscopic biopsy is done which shows simple endometrial hyperplasia. Which is the most likely cause of this condition?

options.C: Peripheral aromatization of androgens to estrogen
options.D: Invasion of endometrial tissue into the myometrium

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient most likely has endometrial hyperplasia due to hyperestrogenism. A possible reason for the hyperestrogenism is the high BMI where there is peripheral aromatization of androgens to estrogen
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A: Continuous exposure to progesterone: continupis exposure to progesterone would lead to endometrial atrophy. This woman had an LNG IUD for 10 years. This would have led to endometrial atrophy but she has stopped using it for a year and this would have led to endometrial hyperplasia. If he had continued to be on the LNG IUD, she would not have developed this condition Option B: Ectopic implantation of endometrial glands: This is endometriosis; and will not present with AUB. Endometriosis would present with pain and dysmenorrhoea. A Option D: Invasion of endometrial tissue into the myometrium: This is adenomyosis; this presents as menorrhagia and dysmenorrhoea. Also in adenomyosis, there would be a regularly enlarged uterus.
  • • Option A: Continuous exposure to progesterone: continupis exposure to progesterone would lead to endometrial atrophy. This woman had an LNG IUD for 10 years. This would have led to endometrial atrophy but she has stopped using it for a year and this would have led to endometrial hyperplasia. If he had continued to be on the LNG IUD, she would not have developed this condition
  • • Option A:
  • • Option B: Ectopic implantation of endometrial glands: This is endometriosis; and will not present with AUB. Endometriosis would present with pain and dysmenorrhoea. A
  • • Option B:
  • • Option D: Invasion of endometrial tissue into the myometrium: This is adenomyosis; this presents as menorrhagia and dysmenorrhoea. Also in adenomyosis, there would be a regularly enlarged uterus.
  • • Option D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endometrial hyperplasia is because of continuous estrogen exposure (hyper-estrogenism) This is seen in Women with PCOS Nulliparous women Early menarche/ late menopause Obesity In the scenario given above, the main clue is her BMI. In obese women, there is more peripheral aromatization i.e. androgens being converted to estrogens
  • ➤ Endometrial hyperplasia is because of continuous estrogen exposure (hyper-estrogenism)
  • ➤ This is seen in Women with PCOS Nulliparous women Early menarche/ late menopause Obesity

questions.question_text: A 32-year P3 comes to OPD with AUB. Menarche was at age 13 years, and she has had regular cycles till 1 year ago. She then began to have delayed periods every 45-60 days with heavy bleeding, clots but no cramping. She has not had her period in 4 months. She has no hot flushes, acne, or abnormal hair growth. She takes levo-thyroxine for hypothyroidism and has had a tubal ligation done. Height is 160 cm, weight is 120kg. P/S is normal. Bimanual exam is limited by body habitus. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Lab tests are as follows: TSH- 2.9, Prolactin: 16, LH: 15 What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This patient is having anovulatory cycles. This is because She is obese and this causes insulin resistance and hyperglycemia with decreased production of SHBG causing elevated androgen levels. This androgen gets aromatized to estrone which leads to persistent elevated estrogen levels. This results in anovulation due to the imbalance in LH and FSH (High LH: FSH ratio in PCOS which is the commonest cause of anovulatory cycles)
  • • This patient is having anovulatory cycles. This is because She is obese and this causes insulin resistance and hyperglycemia with decreased production of SHBG causing elevated androgen levels. This androgen gets aromatized to estrone which leads to persistent elevated estrogen levels. This results in anovulation due to the imbalance in LH and FSH (High LH: FSH ratio in PCOS which is the commonest cause of anovulatory cycles)
  • • She is obese and this causes insulin resistance and hyperglycemia with decreased production of SHBG causing elevated androgen levels. This androgen gets aromatized to estrone which leads to persistent elevated estrogen levels. This results in anovulation due to the imbalance in LH and FSH (High LH: FSH ratio in PCOS which is the commonest cause of anovulatory cycles)
  • • She is obese and this causes insulin resistance and hyperglycemia with decreased production of SHBG causing elevated androgen levels.
  • • This androgen gets aromatized to estrone which leads to persistent elevated estrogen levels.
  • • This results in anovulation due to the imbalance in LH and FSH (High LH: FSH ratio in PCOS which is the commonest cause of anovulatory cycles)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • This is not primary ovarian insufficiency as there are no hot flushes which mean estrogen levels are normal/ high Her TSH levels are normal so this is not hypothyroidism Leiomyoma presents as heavy bleeding in regular cycles.
  • • This is not primary ovarian insufficiency as there are no hot flushes which mean estrogen levels are normal/ high
  • • Her TSH levels are normal so this is not hypothyroidism
  • • Leiomyoma presents as heavy bleeding in regular cycles.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anovular cycles are common in women with high BMI
  • ➤ Anovular cycles are common in women with high BMI
  • ➤ Ref: Page 376, DC Duttas’s Textbook of Gynecology 8 th edition

questions.question_text: A 52y woman who has been menopausal for more than a year presents to the OPD with complains of bleeding since 3 days. She thinks it may be a part of menopause but is a little concerned as she used to have heavy bleeding during her periods several years earlier. She is on anti-hypertensives. On examination, her vitals are stable. Abdominal exam is unremarkable. A speculum exam shows a normal cervix with blood visible at the os. The uterus is normal in size. A transvaginal scan shows an endometrial thickness of 8mm with b/l normal ovaries. What is the next best step?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • This is a woman who is having post-menopausal bleeding (PMB) The most common causes of PMB is endometrial atrophy but also it is important to rule out malignancies in this age group As the cervix appears normal and the TVS shows an increased endometrial thickness (it should be < 5mm in the post-menopausal age group), the next best step would be to take an endometrial biopsy. This can be done by Office biopsy (Endometrial aspiration) Dilatation and curettage Hysteroscopic guided biopsy (gold standard)
  • • This is a woman who is having post-menopausal bleeding (PMB)
  • • The most common causes of PMB is endometrial atrophy but also it is important to rule out malignancies in this age group
  • • As the cervix appears normal and the TVS shows an increased endometrial thickness (it should be < 5mm in the post-menopausal age group), the next best step would be to take an endometrial biopsy. This can be done by Office biopsy (Endometrial aspiration) Dilatation and curettage Hysteroscopic guided biopsy (gold standard)
  • • Office biopsy (Endometrial aspiration) Dilatation and curettage Hysteroscopic guided biopsy (gold standard)
  • • Office biopsy (Endometrial aspiration)
  • • Dilatation and curettage
  • • Hysteroscopic guided biopsy (gold standard)
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A: Antifibrinolytics: This is indicated in women with heavy menstrual bleeding. However in post menopausal bleeding, the main aim is to rule out a malignancy Option B: Hysterectomy: This won't be the initial step. The initial step is to diagnose the cause of post menopsuasal bleeding Option C: Trans-cervical resection of the endometrium: This is a type of endometrial ablation and is recommended in heavy menstrual bleeding. It is however c/i in premalignant and malignant lesions and those need to be ruled out by an endometrial biopsy
  • • Option A: Antifibrinolytics: This is indicated in women with heavy menstrual bleeding. However in post menopausal bleeding, the main aim is to rule out a malignancy
  • • Option A: Antifibrinolytics:
  • • Option B: Hysterectomy: This won't be the initial step. The initial step is to diagnose the cause of post menopsuasal bleeding
  • • Option B: Hysterectomy:
  • • Option C: Trans-cervical resection of the endometrium: This is a type of endometrial ablation and is recommended in heavy menstrual bleeding. It is however c/i in premalignant and malignant lesions and those need to be ruled out by an endometrial biopsy
  • • Option C:

questions.question_text: A 15y girl is brought to the emergency room by her mother. She has been bleeding heavily since 20 days. There is no dysmenorrhea. She attained menarche about 2 years ago and since then she has been having periods every 45-60 days. On examination, she appears pale. Her vitals are stable. Her BMI is 18. Abdomen is soft. An ultrasound reveals a normal uterus with an endometrial thickness of 4mm. Both the ovaries are normal on the scan. Her Hb is 9g%. TSH is 2.5 and a coagulation profile is normal. The next best management is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. High dose progesterone

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This is a case of puberty menorrhagia It is seen in puberty due to an immature HPO axis and anovulation After initial management, if bleeding doesn’t stop and it is primarily due to anovulation, high dose progesterone help to stop the bleeding (Medroxy-progesterone acetate or nor-ethisterone acetate)
  • • This is a case of puberty menorrhagia
  • • It is seen in puberty due to an immature HPO axis and anovulation
  • • After initial management, if bleeding doesn’t stop and it is primarily due to anovulation, high dose progesterone help to stop the bleeding (Medroxy-progesterone acetate or nor-ethisterone acetate)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Dilatation and curettage: This is not an initial step in management of puberty menorrhagia. It is considered only when medical management fails to control the bleeding. Option C: Blood transfusion: This is indicated in severe anemia. This patients Hb is 9g%. Option D: Inj GnRH agonist: This is indicated for precocious puberty and not puberty menorhagia
  • • Option A: Dilatation and curettage: This is not an initial step in management of puberty menorrhagia. It is considered only when medical management fails to control the bleeding.

questions.question_text: A 20-year-old girl presents to the OPD with excess facial hair for 6 months and delayed menstrual cycles. On evaluation, levels of free testosterone are increased. An ultrasound reveals normal uterus and normal ovaries on USG. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Polycystic ovarian syndrome/ disease (PCOS/PCOD) is a disorder of chronically abnormal ovarian function (oligo/anovulation) and hyperandrogenism frequently associated with hyperinsulinemia and insulin resistance, resulting in menstrual irregularity, infertility, and hirsutism. Rotterdam 2003 criteria is used to diagnose PCOS/PCOD: As per this criterion, at least 2 of 3 should be present :
  • • Polycystic ovarian syndrome/ disease (PCOS/PCOD) is a disorder of chronically abnormal ovarian function (oligo/anovulation) and hyperandrogenism frequently associated with hyperinsulinemia and insulin resistance, resulting in menstrual irregularity, infertility, and hirsutism.
  • • Rotterdam 2003 criteria is used to diagnose PCOS/PCOD: As per this criterion, at least 2 of 3 should be present :
  • • Rotterdam 2003 criteria is used to diagnose PCOS/PCOD:
  • • Oligo/anovulation (causes oligomenorrhea, 2 0 amenorrhea, and infertility) Hyperandrogenism: Biochemical or clinical (increased serum androgens or acne, hirsutism) 12 or more than 12 follicle 2-9 mm in size present within 1 or both ovaries on USG and/or ovarian volume > 10 mL (pearl necklace pattern).
  • • Oligo/anovulation (causes oligomenorrhea, 2 0 amenorrhea, and infertility)
  • • Hyperandrogenism: Biochemical or clinical (increased serum androgens or acne, hirsutism)
  • • 12 or more than 12 follicle 2-9 mm in size present within 1 or both ovaries on USG and/or ovarian volume > 10 mL (pearl necklace pattern).
  • • USG appearance of polycystic ovaries
  • • As the patient in the question satisfies first 2 criteria, she is a case of PCOS
  • • As the patient in the question satisfies first 2 criteria, she is a case of PCOS
  • • let's consider the other options:
  • • let's consider the other options:
  • • Option. A. Adrenal Hyperplasia : Adrenal hyperplasia, particularly congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), can cause symptoms similar to PCOS, including hirsutism and menstrual irregularities, due to elevated androgens. However, it is usually diagnosed earlier in life and often has other associated adrenal hormone abnormalities.
  • • Option. A.
  • • Adrenal Hyperplasia
  • • Option. B. Idiopathic Hirsutism : Idiopathic hirsutism refers to hirsutism (excess hair growth) in the absence of any identifiable hormonal imbalance or ovarian/adrenal gland disorder. Given the increased free testosterone levels in this patient, idiopathic hirsutism is less likely.
  • • Option. B.
  • • Idiopathic Hirsutism
  • • Option. D. Testosterone Secreting Tumor : While a testosterone-secreting tumor can cause increased androgen levels and symptoms like hirsutism, these tumors are rare. The more common presentation of such tumors would include rapid onset of symptoms and markedly elevated testosterone levels.
  • • Option. D.
  • • Testosterone Secreting Tumor

questions.question_text: Presence of the SRY gene will cause what important development in embryology?

options.C: Differentiation of the gonad into the testes

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Differentiation of the gonad into the testes

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Normal Sex Development
  • • Normal Sex Development
  • • Sex development starts in utero and continues in adult life with attainment of sexual maturity and reproductive capability Major determinants of sex development are Chromosomal Sex (46XX or 46XY) Gonadal sex (Testes or ovary) Phenotypic sex (External genitalia) Sex determination primarily begins by the presence or absence of the Y chromosome On the Short arm of the Y chromosome, there is located the SRY gene (Sex Determining Region) – Yp11.3 and is the most important genetic aspect for sex determination and its presence or absence determines the direction of gonadal differentiation. SRY activates several other genes that promote testis development. These include SOX 9 Fgf 9 In 46 XX embryos, genes responsible include Wnt4 and Rspo 1. The chromosomal sex determines the gonadal sex (i.e. whether the gonads will become testes or ovaries) in the embryo. The gonads are BIPOTENT (Undifferentiated) till 5 weeks, they then differentiate into testes or ovaries based on whether the karyotype is 46XX or 46XY

questions.question_text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her mother. She is of normal height, at the top of her class but her mother is concerned because of a sudden increase in hair growth and hoarseness of voice. She also mentions that she hasn’t yet attained menarche. On examination, there is absent breast development and minimal presence of pubic and axillary hair. There is also increased facial hair growth and on local examination, there is an enlarged clitoris. An ultrasound reveals an absent uterus with the presence of gonad-like structures in the inguinal canal. Suspecting 5 alpha reductase deficiency, testosterone and DHT level is done. What is the expected finding in 5 alpha reductase deficiency?

options.C: No change in the testosterone/ DHT ratio

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Increased testosterone/ DHT ratio

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • 5 α Reductase Deficiency
  • • 5
  • • α
  • • Reductase Deficiency
  • • Autosomal recessive Karyotype: 46XY Defective conversion of Testosterone to DHT (which is mediated by the enzyme 5 alpha reductase) Testosterone (in fetal life): causes development of the internal male genitalia DHT is responsible for external male genital development: Hence this does not develop as the enzyme mediating the conversion is absent/ deficient Classical presentation: External genitalia: predominantly Female at birth Internal genitalia: Male (The epididymis, the vas deferens, seminal vesicles and ejaculatory ducts form but empty into a short blind vagina) Testis: Located in the inguinal canal At Puberty: Virilization of varying degrees Affected men develop a normal muscle mass, libido, deepening of voice (Testosterone dependent) but have less body hair, less temporal hairline recession, no acne (All these are DHT dependent) Diagnosis: Suspect in infants with genital ambiguity Suspect in adolescence with the characteristic phenotype and a serum hormonal profile showing normal male level testosterone and an increased testosterone/ DHT ratio

questions.question_text: A 23y primi delivers a baby. The pediatrician examines the baby and mentions that the genitalia is ambiguous and appears as shown. The gonads are not palpable. A karyotype done shows 46 XX karyotype. What is the next best step?

options.D: Diagnostic laparoscopy to look at the gonads

Ans. A. Perform 17 hydroxyprogesterone levels

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This is a case of suspected congenital adrenal hyperplasia It is the most common cause of ambiguous genitalia at birth In females (46 XX), there is excessive virilization. It presents as Genital ambiguity, varying degrees of clitoral enlargement and labial fusion Internal genitalia: Normal because the excess androgens derive from the adrenals and the ovaries are normal (No AMH, no local high androgen)

questions.question_text: Assertion : To define anemia in pregnancy, high cutoff of Hb is taken than the non-pregnant scenarios. Reason : Physiological hemodilution is seen in pregnancy

options.B: Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
options.C: Assertion is true, but the reason is false
options.D: The assertion is false but reason is true

questions.explanation:
Ans. D. The assertion is false but reason is true

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • In pregnancy, there is a disproportionate increase in plasma (50%) compared to the RBC volume (20%) This produces a state of hemodilution during pregnancy This reflects as a fall in Hb by about 2g% leading to physiological anemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Physiological changes associated with pregnancy: Blood volume increases progressively from 6-8 weeks gestation (pregnancy) and reaches a maximum at approximately 32-34 weeks with little change thereafter. Renal plasma flow and glomerular filtration rate begin to increase progressively during the first trimester . Increases in blood volume and cardiac output . Elevations in plasma flow and glomerular filtration result in an elevation in creatinine clearance. Blood urea and serum creatinine are reduced by 40%. Here is also an increase in filtered sodium, but tubular absorption is increased by an increase in aldosterone secretion, via the renin-angiotensin mechanism. There is also a decrease in plasma osmolarity . RBC & Haemoglobin: RBC volume is increased to the extent of 20-30%. Total increase in volume is about 350ml ; the amount to be regulated by the increased demand of oxygen transport during pregnancy . Disproportionate increase in plasma and RBC volume produces a state of haemodilution during pregnancy. Thus, even though the total haemoglobin mass increases during pregnancy to the extent of 18-20 percent, there is apparent fall in haemoglobin concentration. At term the fall is about 2 gms from the non-pregnant value . There is simultaneous fall in number of red cells by 15-20% and the hematocrit level.

questions.question_text: Which of the following hormones is primarily secreted by fetal adrenal cortex?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. DHEAS

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fetoplacental Unit
  • ➤ Fetoplacental Unit
  • ➤ The fetus and the placenta interact in the formation of steroid hormones . The placenta synthesizes pregnenolone and progesterone from cholesterol. Some of the progesterone enters the fetal circulation and provides the substrate for the formation of cortisol and corticosterone in the fetal adrenal glands. Some of the pregnenolone enters the fetus and, along with pregnenolone synthesized in the fetal liver , is the substrate for the formation of dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEAS) and 16-hydroxydehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (16-OHDHEAS) in the fetal adrenal. Some 16-hydroxylation also occurs in the fetal liver . DHEAS and 16-OHDHEAS are transported back to the placenta, where DHEAS forms estradiol and 16-OHDHEAS forms estriol. The principal estrogen formed is estriol, and since fetal 16-OHDHEAS is the principal substrate for the estrogens, the urinary estriol excretion of the mother can be monitored as an index of the state of the fetus.
  • ➤ The fetus and the placenta interact in the formation of steroid hormones .

questions.question_text: Which of the following best describes the function of pregnancy associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A)?

options.A: Carrier protein for estrogen and progesterone
options.D: Maintains colloid osmotic pressure in maternal blood

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Immunosuppression against fetal antigens

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A) largest of the pregnancy associated proteins is produced by both the embryo and the placenta (syncytio-cytotrophoblasts) during pregnancy. This protein is thought to have several different functions, including preventing recognition of the fetus by the maternal immune system, matrix mineralization and angiogenesis. Levels of PAPP-A rise from first detection in the first trimester until term. Maternal serum concentrations are related to subsequent fetal growth and this relationship has suggested that it can be used as a diagnostic test for adverse pregnancy outcomes ( intrauterine growth restriction, premature birth, preeclampsia, and stillbirth ).

questions.question_text: W hich of the following hormones is primarily responsible for the physiological increase in maternal insulin resistance during pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Progesterone is the hormone primarily responsible for the physiological increase in maternal insulin resistance during pregnancy . This resistance helps divert glucose to the developing fetus , ensuring an adequate energy supply . The combination of elevated progesterone and other hormones like human placental lactogen contributes to this insulin resistance .

questions.question_text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 32 weeks of gestation presents with lower extremity edema. She is concerned about the swelling and asks the physician about the reason for this condition. Which of the following physiological changes in pregnancy primarily contributes to peripheral edema?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary physiological change in pregnancy contributing to peripheral edema is increased capillary permeability. Hormones like progesterone and estrogen cause the dilation of small blood vessels and increased capillary permeability . This allows for the escape of fluid and proteins into the extracellular space , leading to edema , particularly in the lower extremities.

options.B: Beta hCG to be done with serial monitoring

  • • : (Option A, B and D)
  • • A very early pregnancy. An intrauterine gestational sac is visible on ultrasound only when the serum beta hCG crosses a certain value. This is called the discriminatory zone and is 6000IU/ml for transabdominal scans and 1500 IU/ml for transvaginal scans. If the beta hCG is below 1500, a gestational sac will not be seen An ectopic pregnancy: The image seen is only of the uterus. An ectopic pregnancy which is very early also may not be apparent on ultrasound A pregnancy of unknown location: This is when there is no evidence of pregnancy on the ultrasound despite the urine pregnancy test being positive. Serial beta hCG tests are done in such scenarios
  • • A very early pregnancy. An intrauterine gestational sac is visible on ultrasound only when the serum beta hCG crosses a certain value.   • • Option C. In a missed abortion, on ultrasound, there will be an intrauterine gestational sac seen on ultrasound. A missed abortion is diagnosed when an earlier cardiac activity is not seen or when the CRL is 7 mm but no cardiac activity is seen.

questions.question_text: A 26-year-old woman with a history of ectopic pregnancy presents with abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She suspects she might be pregnant. Which diagnostic test is essential in this situation to rule out an ectopic pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Transvaginal ultrasound

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • In a woman with a history of ectopic pregnancy and symptoms of abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding, it is crucial to rule out another ectopic pregnancy. Transvaginal ultrasound is the preferred diagnostic test as it can visualize the uterus and adnexa and determine the location of the pregnancy, which is essential in cases of suspected ectopic pregnancy. If the TVS is inconclusive, then the next best step would be to do a serum bhCG doubling (0h and 48h)
  • • In a woman with a history of ectopic pregnancy and symptoms of abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding, it is crucial to rule out another ectopic pregnancy. Transvaginal ultrasound is the preferred diagnostic test as it can visualize the uterus and adnexa and determine the location of the pregnancy, which is essential in cases of suspected ectopic pregnancy.
  • • If the TVS is inconclusive, then the next best step would be to do a serum bhCG doubling (0h and 48h)
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A: Serum hCG will not be the initial test do diagnose an ectopic. Only if the ultrasound is inconclusive, do we check the serum bhCG at 0h and 48h Option B: Urine bhCG just confirm pregnancy. It does not tell us the site of pregnancy Option D: Serum progesterone levels increase in pregnancy
  • • Option A: Serum hCG will not be the initial test do diagnose an ectopic. Only if the ultrasound is inconclusive, do we check the serum bhCG at 0h and 48h
  • • Option A:
  • • Option B: Urine bhCG just confirm pregnancy. It does not tell us the site of pregnancy
  • • Option B:
  • • Option D: Serum progesterone levels increase in pregnancy
  • • Option D:

  • • 2 formulas
  • • 2 formulas
  • • 1. G __ P __ L __ A ___
  • • 1. G __ P __ L __ A ___
  • • Gravida (G): The number of times a woman has conceived including the present pregnancy irrespective of the gestational age or the outcome. Para (P): The number of times a pregnancy has crossed the period of viability (taken as 28 weeks for all practical purposes) EXCLUDING the present pregnancy. Living (L): The total number of living children the woman has. Abortion (A): The total number of times the pregnancy has resulted in an abortion/ pregnancy has not crossed the period of viability.

  • • Living (L): The total number of living children the woman has.
  • • Abortion (A): The total number of times the pregnancy has resulted in an abortion/ pregnancy has not crossed the period of viability.
  • • In this patient, this is her 4 th pregnancy, so she is G4; she has 1 pregnancy who was born at term, so she is P1; she has 2 abortions so she is A2 and she has 1 living child so she is L1.

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Pawlick grip

Explanation:

  • • Explanation

  • • The image shows the #rd Leopold maneuver; also called the 1 st pelvic grip; also called the Pawlik grip.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ There are 4 Leopold Maneuvers:
  • ➤ Fundal grip (A): to assess which fetal pole (cephalic or podalic) occupies the fundus. The breech gives the sensation of a large nodular mass; the head feel hard, round and mobile The Lateral grip (B): determines the side of the back (hard, resistant) and the limbs (numerous, small irregular mobile parts) The 1 st pelvic grip (3 rd maneuver aka Pawlik grip - C): determining fetal presentation. The 2 nd pelvic grip (4 th maneuver - D): determines the degree of descent. This maneuver is done facing the feet of the patient and trying to approximate the hands of the examiner. IF the hands approximate; the head has not descended into the pelvis. If the hands diverge, the head has descended into the pelvis.

questions.question_text: A pregnant woman had a previous baby with history of neural tube defect. Which routine antenatal screening test should be offered?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) screening

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) screening is a routine antenatal test typically offered around 15-20 weeks of gestation to assess the risk of neural tube defects and other fetal anomalies. Abnormal AFP levels may indicate the need for further diagnostic tests, such as amniocentesis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. NST : This is a test of antepartum fetal assessment and is usually done after 32 weeks Option B. Amniocentesis : Diagnostic amniocentesis is usually done for detecting fetal chromosomal anomalies Option D. Fetal kick count : This is a test of antepartum fetal assessment and is advised after 28 weeks
  • • Option A. NST : This is a test of antepartum fetal assessment and is usually done after 32 weeks

Ans. B) Tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine
