This vaccine helps protect the mother from tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis (whooping cough), and it also provides passive immunity to the newborn, as pertussis can be severe in infants.

questions.question_text: Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing (NIPT) is?

options.A: Amniocentesis for evaluation of fetal chromosomal anomalies
options.B: Pre-conceptional gene testing of an ova
options.C: Maternal serum for evaluation of Down syndrome

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Maternal serum for evaluation of Down syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • NIPT or cell free DNA screening: Salient features:
  • • Introduced in 2011 It is a screening test (NOT DIAGNOSTIC) In 2020 (Oct), ACOG guidelines state that along with serum analytes and NT, cell free DNA can be offered to all women as the initial screening modality for Down syndrome. Prior to this the indications were Age ≥ 35 y A positive 1 st /2 nd trimester analyte-based screening test USG with minor (soft) aneuploidy marker Prior pregnancy with autosomal trisomy Known carriage of a balanced translocation Identification of DNA fragments that are derived primarily from apoptotic trophoblasts. Done after 9 – 10 weeks Results in 7 – 10 days 99% Detection rate for Down syndrome Limitations: Cost The DNA component may not actually reflect fetal DNA and instead may reflect: Placental mosaicism Early demise of an aneuploid twin Maternal mosaicism Occult maternal malignancy Limited role in multiple pregnancy In 4 – 8%: No result due to low fetal fraction of DNA
  • • Introduced in 2011
  • • It is a screening test (NOT DIAGNOSTIC)
  • • In 2020 (Oct), ACOG guidelines state that along with serum analytes and NT, cell free DNA can be offered to all women as the initial screening modality for Down syndrome. Prior to this the indications were Age ≥ 35 y A positive 1 st /2 nd trimester analyte-based screening test USG with minor (soft) aneuploidy marker Prior pregnancy with autosomal trisomy Known carriage of a balanced translocation
  • • Age ≥ 35 y A positive 1 st /2 nd trimester analyte-based screening test USG with minor (soft) aneuploidy marker Prior pregnancy with autosomal trisomy Known carriage of a balanced translocation
  • • Age ≥ 35 y
  • • A positive 1 st /2 nd trimester analyte-based screening test
  • • USG with minor (soft) aneuploidy marker
  • • Prior pregnancy with autosomal trisomy
  • • Known carriage of a balanced translocation
  • • Identification of DNA fragments that are derived primarily from apoptotic trophoblasts.

questions.question_text: Which of the following aneuploidies is most likely to be missed in prenatal screening?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Klinefelter Syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Let’s Discuss all the Options
  • • Let’s Discuss all the Options
  • • Option A and B. Prenatal aneuploidy screening is primarily used to detect Down syndrome (Trisomy 21). It can also detect Trisomy 18 (Edward) and Trisomy 13 (Patau). Option C. Turner Syndrome: Nuchal Translucency (NT) is used in prenatal aneuploidy screening and is increased in several conditions other than Down syndrome, and this includes Turner’s syndrome. Turner syndrome also has several other ultrasound features like Cystic hygroma Non-immune fetal hydrops Cardiac anomalies (mostly compromising the left outflow tract - CoA, HLHS, bicuspid aortic valve) Renal anomalies Pleural effusions Brachycephaly IUGR Option D. Klinefelter’s syndrome does not have any significant USG finding especially in the 1 st and 2 nd trimesters and hence potentially can be easily missed on prenatal screening.

options.A: It is the most commonly performed prenatal diagnostic procedure
options.B: Chromosomal microarray can be performed on uncultured amniocytes
options.C: Blood-tinged amniotic fluid is seen in transplacental passage of the needle
options.D: Procedure related loss rate is 1 -2% when performed by an experienced provider

questions.question_text: All are true regarding prenatal Down syndrome screening except?

options.A: The risk of a woman carrying a Down syndrome baby is about 1 in 70 at 40 years
options.B: Ultrasound features of Down syndrome at 11 – 14 weeks include increased NT and an absent nasal bone
options.C: Combined test includes an NT measurement and the dual marker
options.D: Ultrasound at 18 – 20 weeks will miss about 50% of Down syndrome fetuses

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ultrasound at 18 – 20 weeks will miss about 50% of Down syndrome fetuses

  • • Let’s Discuss all the Options
  • • Let’s Discuss all the Options

At 11-14 weeks, ultrasound features of Down syndrome include An increased nuchal translucency An absent nasal bone Tricuspid regurgitation An abnormal flow in the ductus venosus Option C. Combined test refers to a combination of the NT and Dual marker Option D. An ultrasound at 18-20 weeks will detect upto 70% of Down syndrome babies. Hence this option is correct

  • • Option B.

questions.question_text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman presents for her first prenatal visit. She is concerned about her risk of carrying a baby with a genetic disorder due to a family history of cystic fibrosis. What prenatal screening test should be offered to assess the risk of cystic fibrosis in this pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Carrier screening for cystic fibrosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disease. Cystic Fibrosis is caused due to a mutation in the CFTR gene located on chromosome 7 and affects chloride channels. To assess the risk of carrying a baby with cystic fibrosis, carrier screening for cystic fibrosis is appropriate. This test analyzes the parents' carrier status for the cystic fibrosis gene mutations and provides information about the risk of having an affected child. If both parents are carriers, invasive tests such as CVS and amniocentesis should be offered.
  • • Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disease.
  • • Cystic Fibrosis is caused due to a mutation in the CFTR gene located on chromosome 7 and affects chloride channels.
  • • To assess the risk of carrying a baby with cystic fibrosis, carrier screening for cystic fibrosis is appropriate.
  • • This test analyzes the parents' carrier status for the cystic fibrosis gene mutations and provides information about the risk of having an affected child.
  • • If both parents are carriers, invasive tests such as CVS and amniocentesis should be offered.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cystic fibrosis has an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance and hence only if both partners are carriers, is diagnostic testing (CVS or amniocentesis) warranted
  • ➤ Cystic fibrosis has an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance and hence only if both partners are carriers, is diagnostic testing (CVS or amniocentesis) warranted

questions.question_text: Maternal use of which of the following hormone may cause hypospadias in a male child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Diethylstilbesterol

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Diethylstilbestrol (DES) is a synthetic nonsteroidal estrogen that was used to prevent miscarriage and other pregnancy complications between 1938 and 1971 In the United States. In 1971, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration issued a warning about the use of DES during pregnancy after a relationship between DES and the development of clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina and cervix was found in women whose mothers had taken diethylstilbestrol while they were pregnant. Effects of DES exposure in utero on girls Cervix: hypoplastic cervix, Cockscomb cervix, cervical collar, pseudo polyp Vagina: Clear cell adenocarcinoma, adenosis Uterus: T-shaped uterus Effects of DES exposure in utero on boys: Epididymal cysts Microphallus Undescended testes and small testes. Hypospadias

  • • In the United States. In 1971, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration issued a warning about the use of DES during pregnancy after a relationship between DES and the development of clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina and cervix was found in women whose mothers had taken diethylstilbestrol while they were pregnant.
  • • Effects of DES exposure in utero on girls Cervix: hypoplastic cervix, Cockscomb cervix, cervical collar, pseudo polyp Vagina: Clear cell adenocarcinoma, adenosis Uterus: T-shaped uterus

questions.question_text: A pregnant woman with a known cardiac disease presents to you in the first trimester. She gives a history of warfarin intake. What should be advised now?

options.D: Replace warfarin with heparin in the 1 st trimester

questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Replace Warfarin with heparin in the 1sttrimester

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • A patient who is on warfarin is at risk of warfarin embryopathy so she should be shifted to heparin in the 1 st trimester. In the 2 nd trimester, warfarin can be re-started. In the 3 rd trimester, we again must shift to heparin.
  • • Other options
  • • Other options
  • • Option A. Continue warfarin throughout pregnancy: Warfarin is unsafe in the 1 st trimester (risk of warfarin embryopathy) and in the 3 rd trimester (Risk of intra-cranial hemorrhage in the fetus) Option B. Give coumarin: Warfarin is a coumarin Option C. Stop warfarin: This will increase her risk of thrombo-embolism so it should not be stopped
  • • Option A. Continue warfarin throughout pregnancy: Warfarin is unsafe in the 1 st trimester (risk of warfarin embryopathy) and in the 3 rd trimester (Risk of intra-cranial hemorrhage in the fetus)

  • • Option B. Give coumarin: Warfarin is a coumarin
  • • Option B. Give coumarin:

  • • Option C. Stop warfarin:

  • ➤ Warfarin is known to crosses the placenta and is teratogenic and causes warfarin embryopathy Warfarin embryopathy - stippled epiphysis and nasal hypoplasia It can also cause CNS defects and developmental delay Results from fetal exposure between the 6 th and 9 th weeks In the 3 rd trimester there is a risk of hemorrhage into fetal structures Hence, switch over to heparin preconceptionally or in the first trimester and then again in the third trimester.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Isotretinoin is contraindicated during pregnancy as one of the stronger teratogen Retinoic acid embryopathy— involve the CNS, face, heart, and thymus. Specific anomalies may include ventriculomegaly, maldevelopment of the facial bones or cranium, microtia or anotia, micrognathia, cleft palate, conotruncal heart defects, and thymic aplasia or hypoplasia Two reliable forms of birth control must be used at the same time (unless abstinence is the chosen method) for 1 month before, during, and for at least 1 month after concluding treatment with isotretinoin. The most recent, and most stringent, system aimed to avoid exposure to isotretinoin is an Internet-based, performance-linked system called iPLEDGE Isotretinoin and its active metabolites cross the human placenta. Isotretinoin is one of the strongest human teratogens known today. The prevalence of birth defects after exposure during embryogenesis is as high as 30%.

questions.question_text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman seeks advice about alcohol consumption during pregnancy. What is the most appropriate recommendation regarding alcohol use during pregnancy?

options.A: Occasional moderate alcohol consumption is safe during pregnancy.
options.B: Heavy alcohol use is safe in the first trimester.
options.C: Alcohol consumption should be completely avoided during pregnancy.
options.D: Alcohol is safe to consume after the first trimester.

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Alcohol consumption should be completely avoided during pregnancy.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The most appropriate recommendation regarding alcohol use during pregnancy is that it should be completely avoided. Prenatal alcohol exposure can lead to a range of developmental and behavioral issues, collectively known as fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD). These include defects of the cardiac, skeletal, renal system as well as eye and ear defects.

questions.question_text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman with a history of uncontrolled diabetes is concerned about the potential teratogenic effects of her condition on her developing fetus. What is the common teratogenic risk associated with maternal diabetes during pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Cardiac malformations

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Maternal diabetes during pregnancy is associated with an increased risk of cardiac malformations in the developing fetus. The most common anomaly seen in pregestational (overt) diabetes is cardiovascular anomalies (VSD). Poorly controlled maternal blood glucose levels can lead to structural heart defects, making it important to manage diabetes rigorously during pregnancy to reduce this risk.

questions.question_text: Identify the condition as shown in the image below:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Posterior Placenta Previa – Partial

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is an Obstetric ultrasound showing the lower uterine segment with the bladder anteriorly. The cervix is seen and the placenta is seen posteriorly (as it is opposite to the bladder). It is seen to partially cover the os. So, this is Post placenta previa (partial).
  • • This is an Obstetric ultrasound showing the lower uterine segment with the bladder anteriorly. The cervix is seen and the placenta is seen posteriorly (as it is opposite to the bladder). It is seen to partially cover the os. So, this is Post placenta previa (partial).

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Placenta previa is classified as follows:
  • ➤ Placenta previa is classified as follows:
  • ➤ Type 1 ---Mild degree ----- Type 2 Type 3--- Major degree ----- Type 4
  • ➤ Type 1: Low lying: implantation in lower uterine segment but not touching the os.
  • ➤ Type 2: Marginal: placenta is at the edge of the os but not covering it
  • ➤ Type 3: Partial Placenta Previa: Placenta partially covering the internal os.
  • ➤ Type 4: Complete Placenta Previa: Placenta completely covering the internal os.
  • ➤ Placenta previa can also be classified on USG as (Newer system) True placenta previa : the placenta covers the internal os either partially or completely Low lying placenta: placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment such that the edge does not reach the os but remains outside a 2 cm wide perimeter around the os.
  • ➤ Placenta previa can also be classified on USG as (Newer system) True placenta previa : the placenta covers the internal os either partially or completely Low lying placenta: placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment such that the edge does not reach the os but remains outside a 2 cm wide perimeter around the os.
  • ➤ True placenta previa : the placenta covers the internal os either partially or completely Low lying placenta: placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment such that the edge does not reach the os but remains outside a 2 cm wide perimeter around the os.
  • ➤ True placenta previa : the placenta covers the internal os either partially or completely
  • ➤ Low lying placenta: placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment such that the edge does not reach the os but remains outside a 2 cm wide perimeter around the os.

questions.question_text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman presents for a fetal ultrasound at 7 weeks of gestation. What is the most appropriate type of ultrasound for dating the pregnancy accurately?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Transvaginal ultrasound

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Transvaginal ultrasound is the most appropriate type of ultrasound for dating the pregnancy accurately in the first trimester. It provides better resolution and access to the developing embryo. The CRL is most accurate for estimation of age in the first trimester.

It is alwso very helpful in diagnosing Mullerian anomalies Option D: Doppler ultrasound is commonly used to assess placental and fetal blood flow, as well as fetal oxygenation during pregnancy.

questions.question_text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman in her second trimester presents for a routine prenatal ultrasound. What is the primary purpose of this mid-pregnancy ultrasound?

options.A: To assess for neural tube defects
options.B: To evaluate fetal growth and anatomy

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. To evaluate fetal growth and anatomy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The primary purpose of a mid-pregnancy ultrasound (typically performed between 18-22 weeks) is to evaluate fetal growth and anatomy, including assessing the development of various organs and structures in the fetus. This scan may also be referred to as anomaly scan/ malformation scan/ Targeted imaging for fetal anomaly (TIFFA scan)

questions.question_text: Spermiogenesis includes all the following components except:

This occurs in the fallopian tube.

questions.question_text: The incorrect statement regarding fertilization is:

options.A: Completion of the 2 nd meiotic division of the oocyte happens at ovulation
options.B: The fertilizable life span of an oocyte is 12-24 hours and that of a sperm is 48 – 72 hours
options.C: Penetration of the zona pellucida is facilitated by release of hyaluronidase from the acrosomal cap of the sperm
options.D: Zona reaction prevents the entry of other sperms

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Completion of the 2ndmeiotic division of the oocyte happens at ovulation.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Completion of the 2 nd meiotic division of the oocyte happens at ovulation : This is an incorrect statement. Completion of the 2 nd meiotic division occurs at the time of fertilization resulting in a female pronucleus and the 2 nd polar body .

Penetration of the zona pellucida is facilitated by release of hyaluronidase from the acrosomal cap of the sperm. More than 1 sperm may penetrate the zona pellucida but soon after sperm fusion, penetration of other sperms is prevented by zona reaction (hardening) or oolemma block due to release of cortical granules by exocytosis from the oocyte.

questions.question_text: In females, what is the outcome of meiosis I in oogenesis?

options.C: Formation of one secondary oocyte and one polar body

questions.question_text: A 34y G3P2 presents to the OPD at 34 weeks. She has had 2 previous lower segment cesarean sections and an done at 28 weeks shows an anterior low-lying placenta. She does not complain of bleeding. On examination, the uterus is 32 weeks, cephalic presentation and the FHR is 145 bpm. What is the next best step?

options.A: Order an ultrasound with a Doppler

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • She is at an increased risk of placental accrete syndromes as she has 2 previous cearean sections and an anterior placenta previa The risk of placenta accreta increases with the number of previous cesareans Any patient with a previous cesarean, with placenta previa in the current pregnancy is at an increased risk for placenta acrrete syndromes The investigation of choice in placenta accreta syndromes is an ultrasound doppler and this should be done in this patient
  • • She is at an increased risk of placental accrete syndromes as she has 2 previous cearean sections and an anterior placenta previa
  • • The risk of placenta accreta increases with the number of previous cesareans
  • • Any patient with a previous cesarean, with placenta previa in the current pregnancy is at an increased risk for placenta acrrete syndromes
  • • The investigation of choice in placenta accreta syndromes is an ultrasound doppler and this should be done in this patient
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Opton B: As the patient does not have to be delivered right now, steroids are not indicated Option C: An Elective cesarean section may have to be planned if placenta previa (At 37 weeks) or if placenta acrrete syndromes (between 34 - 37 weeks) but the question asked is the next best step and this is to rule out placenta acrrete syndromes by doing a Doppler Option D: A repeat ultrasound may have to be done but that again is not the next best step.
  • • Opton B: As the patient does not have to be delivered right now, steroids are not indicated
  • • Option C: An Elective cesarean section may have to be planned if placenta previa (At 37 weeks) or if placenta acrrete syndromes (between 34 - 37 weeks) but the question asked is the next best step and this is to rule out placenta acrrete syndromes by doing a Doppler
  • • Option D: A repeat ultrasound may have to be done but that again is not the next best step.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The risk of placenta acrrete syndromes (PAS) increases with the number of prior cesarean sections. A patient with placenta previa with a h/o previous cesarean section should be investigated for placenta accrete syndromes (PAS)
  • ➤ The risk of placenta acrrete syndromes (PAS) increases with the number of prior cesarean sections.
  • ➤ A patient with placenta previa with a h/o previous cesarean section should be investigated for placenta accrete syndromes (PAS)
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1967, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1967, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.question_text: Which is incorrect regarding the pathophysiology of placenta accrete syndromes?

options.A: The abnormal adherence is due to partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer
options.B: Microscopically, the placental villi are found attached to smooth muscle fibers
options.C: There is a close relationship between cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and later development of Placenta accrete syndromes in the same pregnancy
options.D: About 15% of all accrete syndromes are placenta percreta

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The ratio of occurrence of placenta accreta: increta: percreta is 80:15:5; i.e. 5% of all adherent placentas are placenta percreta and hence this statement is incorrect The term placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) describes aberrant placentation characterized by abnormally implanted, invasive, or adhered placenta. It is also referred to as morbidly adherent placenta, The major problem if placenta accreta syndrome occurs is failure of placenta tto separate normally from the myometrium after fetal delivery. Attempts to seperate an adherent placenta can lead to torrential hemorrhage This abnormal adherence stems in part from partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer If the decidual spongy layer is lacking either partially or totally, the physiological line of cleavage is absent, and some or all cotyledons are densely anchored. Microscopically, placental villi attach to smooth muscle fibers rather than to decidual cells. Factors implicated in the pathogenesis An antecedent “constitutional endometrial defect” in most cases is found like a history of a previous cesarean section Some tissue specimens show immunologically mediated “hyperinvasiveness” Some genes that code for remodeling and for adherence may be highly expressed There is a close relationship between cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and later development of PAS in the same pregnancy.
  • • The ratio of occurrence of placenta accreta: increta: percreta is 80:15:5; i.e. 5% of all adherent placentas are placenta percreta and hence this statement is incorrect
  • • The term placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) describes aberrant placentation characterized by abnormally implanted, invasive, or adhered placenta.
  • • It is also referred to as morbidly adherent placenta,
  • • The major problem if placenta accreta syndrome occurs is failure of placenta tto separate normally from the myometrium after fetal delivery. Attempts to seperate an adherent placenta can lead to torrential hemorrhage
  • • This abnormal adherence stems in part from partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer
  • • If the decidual spongy layer is lacking either partially or totally, the physiological line of cleavage is absent, and some or all cotyledons are densely anchored.
  • • Microscopically, placental villi attach to smooth muscle fibers rather than to decidual cells.
  • • Factors implicated in the pathogenesis An antecedent “constitutional endometrial defect” in most cases is found like a history of a previous cesarean section Some tissue specimens show immunologically mediated “hyperinvasiveness” Some genes that code for remodeling and for adherence may be highly expressed There is a close relationship between cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and later development of PAS in the same pregnancy.
  • • An antecedent “constitutional endometrial defect” in most cases is found like a history of a previous cesarean section Some tissue specimens show immunologically mediated “hyperinvasiveness” Some genes that code for remodeling and for adherence may be highly expressed There is a close relationship between cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and later development of PAS in the same pregnancy.
  • • An antecedent “constitutional endometrial defect” in most cases is found like a history of a previous cesarean section
  • • like a history of a previous cesarean section
  • • Some tissue specimens show immunologically mediated “hyperinvasiveness”
  • • Some genes that code for remodeling and for adherence may be highly expressed
  • • There is a close relationship between cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and later development of PAS in the same pregnancy.

questions.question_text: Match the condition with the time of delivery:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Abruption is an acute emergency situation and requires immediate delivery Placenta previa should be delivered at 37 weeks unless there is an acute episode of bleeding leading to maternal and/or fetal distress Placenta Accreta should also be delivered between 34-37 weeks before a woman goes into labor.
  • • Abruption is an acute emergency situation and requires immediate delivery
  • • Placenta previa should be delivered at 37 weeks unless there is an acute episode of bleeding leading to maternal and/or fetal distress
  • • Placenta Accreta should also be delivered between 34-37 weeks before a woman goes into labor.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Delivery in different scenarions of APH
  • ➤ Delivery in different scenarions of APH
  • ➤ In Abruption: Delivery is asap irrespective of Period of gestation as it is an acute emrgency; Route of delivery depends on the situation at hand. If Bishop score is favourbale and maternal and fetal condition are good, induction of labor can be done. However in the event of maternal shock or fetal distress, cesarean is preferred In Placenta previa: Elective LSCS at 37 weeks (For minor degree placenta previas, vaginal delivery can be attempted). Delivery may be done earlier if there is excessive bleeding or fetal distress In Placenta accreta, Delivery is ALWAYS by casearan (classical cesarean) which is preferably done electively between 34-37 weeks and this is followed by a hysterectomy without seperating the placenta.
  • ➤ In Abruption: Delivery is asap irrespective of Period of gestation as it is an acute emrgency; Route of delivery depends on the situation at hand. If Bishop score is favourbale and maternal and fetal condition are good, induction of labor can be done. However in the event of maternal shock or fetal distress, cesarean is preferred
  • ➤ In Placenta previa: Elective LSCS at 37 weeks (For minor degree placenta previas, vaginal delivery can be attempted). Delivery may be done earlier if there is excessive bleeding or fetal distress
  • ➤ In Placenta accreta, Delivery is ALWAYS by casearan (classical cesarean) which is preferably done electively between 34-37 weeks and this is followed by a hysterectomy without seperating the placenta.

questions.question_text: A 24y G2P1 with a previous LSCS presented at 28 weeks with painless mild vaginal bleeding. She had a previous similar episode 2 weeks earlier. A scan done was suspicious for placenta accreta and this was confirmed on a Doppler. What is the next best step in management?

options.A: Plan an elective LSCS at 37 weeks
options.B: Plan an elective classical section at 37 weeks

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Management of placenta accreta involves Planning delivery between 34-37 weeks Delivery is usually by a classical cesarean (upper segment) to avoid the placenta Following delivery of the baby, a hysterectomy is carried out with the placenta in situ Conservative approaches like leaving the placenta in situ and resection and repair of uterus are less commonly done.
  • • Management of placenta accreta involves Planning delivery between 34-37 weeks Delivery is usually by a classical cesarean (upper segment) to avoid the placenta Following delivery of the baby, a hysterectomy is carried out with the placenta in situ

  • • Other options
  • • Other options
  • • Option A & C: Lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) is not done for placenta accreta syndromes as the placenta is usually adherent in the lower segment Option D: As the patient is currently stable and bleeding is mild, immediate cesarean is not indicated

questions.question_text: Ligation of which of the following vessels in the retroperitoneum will reduce the pulse pressure in a patient who is bleeding during surgery for placenta accreta syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Internal iliac artery ligation is performed in obstetric hemorrhage like PPH and placenta accreta syndromes It is part of devascularization surgeries to reduce blood loss in massive obstetric hemorrhage along with uterine artery and utero-ovarian artery ligation The most important mechanism of action with internal iliac artery ligation is an 85-percent reduction in pulse pressure in those arteries distal to the ligation and a 50% reducition in blood flow to the uterus This converts an arterial pressure system into one with pressures approaching those in the venous circulation. This creates vessels more amenable to hemostasis via pressure and clot formation.
  • • Internal iliac artery ligation is performed in obstetric hemorrhage like PPH and placenta accreta syndromes
  • • It is part of devascularization surgeries to reduce blood loss in massive obstetric hemorrhage along with uterine artery and utero-ovarian artery ligation
  • • The most important mechanism of action with internal iliac artery ligation is an 85-percent reduction in pulse pressure in those arteries distal to the ligation and a 50% reducition in blood flow to the uterus
  • • This converts an arterial pressure system into one with pressures approaching those in the venous circulation. This creates vessels more amenable to hemostasis via pressure and clot formation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Uterine artery ligation is the 1st vessel ligated in devascularization surgery but it does not reduce the pulse pressure as effectively as does internal iliac artery ligation
  • • Option C: External iliac artery: Is not ligated as part of devascularization as it does not supply the uterus
  • • Option D: utero-ovarian anastomoses ligation is done as part of devasculariazation surgery but it does not reduce the pulse pressure as effectively as does internal iliac artery ligation

questions.question_text: Which immunoglobulin is involved in maternal-fetal immune reactions, and may lead to hemolytic disease of the newborn if the mother is Rh-negative and the baby is Rh-positive?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. IgG

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The prevalence of red cell alloimmunization in pregnancy approximates 1% Most cases of severe fetal anemia requiring antenatal transfusion are attributable to anti-D, anti-Kell, anti-c, or anti-E alloimmunization Maternal blood type and antibody screen are routinely assessed at the first prenatal visit. Unbound antibodies in maternal serum are detected with an indirect Coombs test If the result is positive, the specific antibodies are identified; their immunoglobulin subtype is determined as either immunoglobulin G (IgG) or M (IgM); and the titer is quantified. Only IgG antibodies are concerning because IgM antibodies do not cross the placenta

questions.question_text: How does Immunoglobulin G (IgG) cross the placenta?

options.B: It does not cross the placenta
options.D: Facilitated diffusion involving calcium binding protein

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Placental Transfer
  • • Most substances with a molecular mass < 500Da pass readily through placental tissue by simple diffusion These include CO2, water, most electrolytes and anesthetic gases Insulin, steroid hormones and thyroid hormones cross the placenta but very slowly Hormones synthesized in the syncytiotrophoblasts (hCG and hPL) enter both maternal and fetal circulation but concentration is higher in maternal circulation High molecular weight substances do not traverse the placenta EXCEPT IgG (molecular weight is 160,000) – This is transferred by a specific trophoblastic receptor mediated mechanism IgG is the only immunoglobulin to cross the placenta

  • • High molecular weight substances do not traverse the placenta EXCEPT IgG (molecular weight is 160,000) – This is transferred by a specific trophoblastic receptor mediated mechanism
  • • IgG is the only immunoglobulin to cross the placenta

questions.question_text: What is the uteroplacental blood flow at term?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Maternal blood within the intervillous space is the primary source of maternal–fetal transfer. Blood from the maternal spiral arteries directly bathes the trophoblast layer that surrounds the villi. Substances transferred from mother to fetus first enter the intervillous space and are then transported to the syncytiotrophoblasts Intervillous and uteroplacental blood flow increases throughout pregnancy At term, uteroplacental blood flow near term ranges from 700 to 900 mL/min, and most of this blood apparently goes to the intervillous space
  • • Maternal blood within the intervillous space is the primary source of maternal–fetal transfer.
  • • Blood from the maternal spiral arteries directly bathes the trophoblast layer that surrounds the villi.
  • • Substances transferred from mother to fetus first enter the intervillous space and are then transported to the syncytiotrophoblasts
  • • Intervillous and uteroplacental blood flow increases throughout pregnancy
  • • At term, uteroplacental blood flow near term ranges from 700 to 900 mL/min, and most of this blood apparently goes to the intervillous space

Blood from the maternal spiral arteries directly bathes the trophoblast layer that surrounds the villi. Substances transferred from mother to fetus first enter the intervillous space and are then transported to the syncytiotrophoblasts Intervillous and uteroplacental blood flow increases throughout pregnancy At term, uteroplacental blood flow near term ranges from 700 to 900 mL/min, and most of this blood apparently goes to the intervillous space

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about leptin is true?

options.A: It is produced exclusively by the placenta
options.B: Concentrations peak in amniotic fluid at term
options.C: 95% of placental production enters the fetal circulation
options.D: Abnormal levels have been associated with FGR

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Leptin is a polypeptide hormone which was originally identified as a product of adipocytes and a regulator of energy homeostasis by curbing appetite. It also contributes to angiogenesis, hemopoiesis, osteogenesis, pulmonary maturation, and neuroendocrine, immune, and reproductive functions Leptin is produced by the mother, fetus, and placenta. It is expressed in syncytiotrophoblasts and fetal vascular endothelial cells. Of placental production, 5% enters the fetal circulation & 95 percent is transferred to the mother. Leptin concentrations peak in amnionic fluid at mid-pregnancy Fetal serum leptin levels begin increasing at approximately 34 weeks and are correlated with fetal weight. This hormone is involved in the development and maturation of the heart, brain, kidneys, and pancreas, and its levels are decreased with fetal-growth restriction. Abnormal levels are also associated with fetal-growth disorders, gestational diabetes, and preeclampsia, but not maternal obesity

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements of the fetal thyroid gland is true?

options.A: The fetal thyroid starts to make hormones starting at 36 weeks
options.B: By 12 weeks, the fetal thyroid is concentrating iodide more avidly than the maternal thyroid
options.C: After birth, cooling to room temperature causes a sudden and marked decrease in secretion of TSH which results in low serum T4 with a nadir at 24-36h of life
options.D: Maternal and fetal levels of TBG decrease throughout pregnancy

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Let us discuss all the options
  • • Option A: The fetal thyroid starts to make hormones starting at 36 weeks: This is incorrect; the feta thyroid starts secreting hormones at 1- - 12 weeks Option B: By 12 weeks, the fetal thyroid is concentrating iodide more avidly than the maternal thyroid: Ths is correct. The placenta actively concentrates iodine on the fetal side, and by 12 weeks and throughout pregnancy, the fetal thyroid concentrates iodine more avidly than does the maternal thyroid. Option C: After birth, cooling to room temperature causes a sudden and marked decrease in secretion of TSH which results in low serum T4 with a nadir at 24-36h of life: This is incorrect. Immediately after birth, thyroid function and metabolism undergo major change. Cooling to room temperature evokes a sudden and marked increase in TSH secretion. This in turn causes a progressive increase in serum T4 levels that are maximal 24 to 36 hours after birth. Option D: Maternal and fetal levels of TBG decrease throughout pregnancy. This is incorrect. Normal fetal levels of free thyroxine (T4), free triiodothyronine (T3), and TBG rise steadily throughout gestation
  • • Option A: The fetal thyroid starts to make hormones starting at 36 weeks: This is incorrect; the feta thyroid starts secreting hormones at 1- - 12 weeks

The placenta actively concentrates iodine on the fetal side, and by 12 weeks and throughout pregnancy, the fetal thyroid concentrates iodine more avidly than does the maternal thyroid.
  • • Option B:

This in turn causes a progressive increase in serum T4 levels that are maximal 24 to 36 hours after birth.
  • • Option C: After birth, cooling to room temperature causes a sudden and marked decrease in secretion of TSH which results in low serum T4 with a nadir at 24-36h of life:
  • • Option D: Maternal and fetal levels of TBG decrease throughout pregnancy. This is incorrect. Normal fetal levels of free thyroxine (T4), free triiodothyronine (T3), and TBG rise steadily throughout gestation

questions.question_text: Which of the following gives meconium its greenish-black color?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Fetal bowel contents consist of various products of secretion, such as glycerophospholipids from the lung, desquamated fetal cells, lanugo, scalp hair, and vernix. It also contains undigested debris from swallowed amnionic fluid. The dark greenish-black color forms from bile pigments, especially biliverdin. Meconium can pass from normal bowel peristalsis in the mature fetus or from vagal stimulation. It can also pass when hypoxia stimulates arginine vasopressin (AVP) release from the fetal pituitary gland. AVP stimulates colonic smooth muscle to contract, resulting in intra-amnionic defecation Meconium is toxic to the respiratory system, and its inhalation can result in meconium aspiration syndrome.
  • • Fetal bowel contents consist of various products of secretion, such as glycerophospholipids from the lung, desquamated fetal cells, lanugo, scalp hair, and vernix.
  • • It also contains undigested debris from swallowed amnionic fluid.

  • • It can also pass when hypoxia stimulates arginine vasopressin (AVP) release from the fetal pituitary gland. AVP stimulates colonic smooth muscle to contract, resulting in intra-amnionic defecation
  • • Meconium is toxic to the respiratory system, and its inhalation can result in meconium aspiration syndrome.

questions.question_text: Where does the biosynthesis of surfactant take place?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Biosynthesis of surfactant takes place in the type II pneumocytes. Phospholipid is the primary surface tension–lowering component of surfactant, whereas the apoproteins aid the forming and reforming of a surface film. The major apoprotein is surfactant A (SP-A), which is a glycoprotein with a molecular weight of 28,000 to 35,000 Da. It is synthesized in the type II cells, and its content in amnionic fluid increases with gestational age and fetal lung maturity Antenatal betamethasone and dexamethasone increase surfactant production when administered antenatally (given in women expected to deliver preterm) and are given for antenatal lung maturation.
  • • Biosynthesis of surfactant takes place in the type II pneumocytes.
  • • Phospholipid is the primary surface tension–lowering component of surfactant, whereas the apoproteins aid the forming and reforming of a surface film.
  • • The major apoprotein is surfactant A (SP-A), which is a glycoprotein with a molecular weight of 28,000 to 35,000 Da. It is synthesized in the type II cells, and its content in amnionic fluid increases with gestational age and fetal lung maturity
  • • Antenatal betamethasone and dexamethasone increase surfactant production when administered antenatally (given in women expected to deliver preterm) and are given for antenatal lung maturation.

questions.question_text: Approximately what percentage of the total hemoglobin is hemoglobin F in a term fetus?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Hb is composed of two copies of two different peptide chains, which determine the type of hemoglobin produced Hemoglobin types transition throughout pregnancy. Alpha (α) and zeta (ζ) globin chains are interchangeable. The beta (β) globin chain can be replaced by epsilon (ε), gamma (γ), or delta ( δ) globin chains. In embryonic life (stage I), ζ and ε globin chains exist In fetal life (stage 2): Hemoglobin F is the main type (α and γ globin chains) After birth (stage III), HbA1 predominates (α and β chains)
  • • Hb is composed of two copies of two different peptide chains, which determine the type of hemoglobin produced

During the first 6 to 12 months of life, the hemoglobin F proportion continues to decline and eventually reaches the low levels found in adult erythrocytes

questions.question_text: A pregnant woman at 39 weeks' gestation presents for a routine antenatal checkup. The clinician performs a non-stress test (NST), which shows the absence of accelerations in the fetal heart rate tracing. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Biophysical profile (BPP) assessment

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • In the absence of accelerations on a non-stress test (NST), ideally the NST should be extended till another 20 mins. If there are still no accelerations, a biophysical profile (BPP) assessment is the next best step to evaluate fetal well-being more comprehensively. The BPP includes additional parameters on USG (fetal breathing movements, fetal tone, fetal movements, and amniotic fluid volume) The BPP gives a score (Manning score) and based on this score, further management is advised
  • • In the absence of accelerations on a non-stress test (NST), ideally the NST should be extended till another 20 mins.
  • • If there are still no accelerations, a biophysical profile (BPP) assessment is the next best step to evaluate fetal well-being more comprehensively.
  • • The BPP includes additional parameters on USG (fetal breathing movements, fetal tone, fetal movements, and amniotic fluid volume)
  • • The BPP gives a score (Manning score) and based on this score, further management is advised
  • • Other options
  • • Other options
  • • The decision for delivery (induction of labor/ cesarean) cannot be taken on a non-reactive NST as there is a high false positive rate with an NST Continue routine prenatal care: If the NST is non-reactive, a BPP should be offered and confirmed that the fetus is doing ok.

questions.question_text: A pregnant woman with gestational diabetes is scheduled for an elective cesarean section at 39 weeks' gestation. During the procedure, the infant appears lethargic and is not feeding well. What is the most likely cause of the infant's condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Hypoglycemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Infants born to mothers with gestational diabetes are at risk of hypoglycemia due to the abrupt cessation of the continuous glucose supply from the mother. This is called as Pederson Hypothesis Hypoglycemia can lead to lethargy and respiratory distress in the newborn. Pederson Hypothesis as shown below describes the complications in a neonate of a diabetic mother
  • • Infants born to mothers with gestational diabetes are at risk of hypoglycemia due to the abrupt cessation of the continuous glucose supply from the mother. This is called as Pederson Hypothesis
  • • Hypoglycemia can lead to lethargy and respiratory distress in the newborn.
  • • Pederson Hypothesis as shown below describes the complications in a neonate of a diabetic mother
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B: Neonatal hyperbilirubinemia, which is seen in infants of diabetic mothers, will present as icterus Option C: Hypocalcemia is seen in infants of diabetic mothers Option D: Meconium aspiration presents as respiratory distress
  • • Option B: Neonatal hyperbilirubinemia, which is seen in infants of diabetic mothers, will present as icterus
  • • Option B:
  • • Option C: Hypocalcemia is seen in infants of diabetic mothers
  • • Option C:

  • • Option D:

questions.question_text: A 45-year old presents for a routine gynecological checkup. She is having regular cycles with normal flow and mild dysmenorrhea on the 1 st day. She is a non-smoker and has no history of hypertension or diabetes. Her last pap smear was 2 years back which was reported to be normal. An ultrasound shows the presence of a 4 x 4 cm intramural fibroid with a sub-serosal component. She is very anxious and seeks your opinion on what should be done.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Review ultrasound after 1 year

Explanation:

  • • This is an asymptomatic fibroid Asymptomatic fibroids (irrespective of size) do not require treatment and just need an annual evaluation. Symptomatic fibroids can be managed medically/ surgically/ non invasive techniques based on several factors like the age of the patient, the size and number of fibroids and the location of fibroid
  • • This is an asymptomatic fibroid
  • • Asymptomatic fibroids (irrespective of size) do not require treatment and just need an annual evaluation.
  • • Symptomatic fibroids can be managed medically/ surgically/ non invasive techniques based on several factors like the age of the patient, the size and number of fibroids and the location of fibroid
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A: GnRH agonists: This can be given to women with symptomatic fibroids to reduce the size and also control symptoms. It is also given to women pre-operatively to reduce the size of the fibroid Option B: Laparoscopic hysterectomy: There is no indication for surgical managment in a patient with an asymptomatic fibroid. Following menopause, fibroids usually shrink in size due to hypo-estrogenism. Option C: Laparoscopic myomectomy: There is no indication for doing a myomectomy in a patient with an asymptomatic fibroid.
  • • Option A: GnRH agonists: This can be given to women with symptomatic fibroids to reduce the size and also control symptoms. It is also given to women pre-operatively to reduce the size of the fibroid

questions.question_text: A 23-year primi is presents at 16 weeks pregnancy with acute abdominal pain. On examination, the uterus is 20 weeks size and there is tenderness over the abdomen. An ultrasound reveals, a 6 cm fibroid in the anterior wall. What is the next best management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Analgesia and hydration

Explanation:

  • • This is most likely a red degeneration of fibroid which is commonly seen in pregnancy. Red degeneration occurs in a large fibroid mainly during 2 nd half of pregnancy and puerperium. Pain is the predominant symptom. Treatment is supportive and pain usually settles with analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs
  • • This is most likely a red degeneration of fibroid which is commonly seen in pregnancy.
  • • Red degeneration occurs in a large fibroid mainly during 2 nd half of pregnancy and puerperium.
  • • Pain is the predominant symptom.

  • • Other Options
  • • Option A: Advise MTP: This is usually never advised in red degeneration as majority of red degenerations will symotomatically improve Option B: Laparoscopic myomectomy: Not indicated during pregnancy Option C: Hysterotomy and myomectomy: Nor indicated in red degeneration of fibroid
  • • Option A: Advise MTP: This is usually never advised in red degeneration as majority of red degenerations will symotomatically improve
  • • Option B: Laparoscopic myomectomy: Not indicated during pregnancy

questions.question_text: A 34-year nulliparous woman presents to the OPD. She complains of pelvic heaviness. She also mentions that her periods have been increasingly heavy in amount and she has to take a pain killer on the 1 st 2 days of her period due to excessive pain. The periods are otherwise regular. On examination, there is an irregular mass palpated abdominally which is about the size of an 18 weeks gravid uterus. On bimanual exam, the same irregular mass is felt and there is transmitted mobility. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Leiomyoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This patient has symptoms of heavy menstrual bleed and dysmenorrhea which are seen in adenomyosis, fibroids (leiomyoma) and polyp. On examination, this is a fibroid (probably multiple fibroids) The uterus is significantly enlarged and irregular There is transmitted mobility i.e. the mass is arising from the uterus (transmitted mobility is absent in ovarian masses) The woman is nulliparous
  • • This patient has symptoms of heavy menstrual bleed and dysmenorrhea which are seen in adenomyosis, fibroids (leiomyoma) and polyp.
  • • On examination, this is a fibroid (probably multiple fibroids) The uterus is significantly enlarged and irregular There is transmitted mobility i.e. the mass is arising from the uterus (transmitted mobility is absent in ovarian masses) The woman is nulliparous
  • • The uterus is significantly enlarged and irregular There is transmitted mobility i.e. the mass is arising from the uterus (transmitted mobility is absent in ovarian masses) The woman is nulliparous
  • • The uterus is significantly enlarged and irregular
  • • There is transmitted mobility i.e. the mass is arising from the uterus (transmitted mobility is absent in ovarian masses)
  • • The woman is nulliparous
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • In adenomyosis, the uterus is regularly enlarged (max size of 12-14 weeks size) In fibroid polyp, the uterus will be normal or slightly enlarged in size and on speculum exam, a polyp may be seen extruding from the os. Fibroid polyps usually present with inter menstrual bleeding or irregular bleeding In ovarian mass, there usually won't be any menstrual symptoms, also transmitted mobility will be absent (i.e. on moving the mass, the cervix will not be felt to move)
  • • In adenomyosis, the uterus is regularly enlarged (max size of 12-14 weeks size)

  • • In ovarian mass, there usually won't be any menstrual symptoms, also transmitted mobility will be absent (i.e. on moving the mass, the cervix will not be felt to move)

questions.question_text: A 27-year woman who is anxious to conceive visits the OPD with her husband. They have been trying to conceive for 2 years. She has regular periods with heavy flow. There is associated dysmenorrhea. A transvaginal scan shows a submucosal fibroid of about 2 cm in size. What is the best management option?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Hysteroscopic myomectomy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient is infertile and has a submucosal fibroid. The fibroid has to be removed. Type 0 and 1 submucosal fibroids are best removed hysteroscopically
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A: Laparoscopic myomectomy: Is indicated usually in intramural and subserosal fibroids Option B: Reassurance: Whenever an infertile patient has a submucosal fibroid or a large intra-mural fibroid, it has to be removed. Option C: GnRH agonist: Could have been tried if the patient did not have infertility.
  • • Option A: Laparoscopic myomectomy: Is indicated usually in intramural and subserosal fibroids

  • • Option B: Reassurance: Whenever an infertile patient has a submucosal fibroid or a large intra-mural fibroid, it has to be removed.

  • • Option C:

options.B: At the level of round ligaments
options.C: At the level of the internal os
options.D: At the level of the fibroid

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. At the level of the internal os

  • • Explanation
  • • This is a Bonney’s myomectomy clamp It is applied at the level of the uterine arteries (level of internal os) during abdominal myomectomy to reduce the intra-operative blood loss by occluding the uterine arteries temporarily

questions.question_text: A 45-year lady presents with heavy menstrual bleeding for 3 months. On examination, she does not appear to be pale. Her BP is 150/90mmHg. An abdominal and pelvic exam is normal. A transvaginal scan shows a 2 cm Intramural fibroid and an endometrial thickness of 15mm. both the ovaries appear normal What is the next best step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Endometrial Biopsy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • At 45y, heavy bleeding during periods could be because of endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy. It is important to rule out precancerous lesions and cancerous lesions at this age. A small 2 cm fibroid is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms but her increased endometrial thickness on the ultrasound (15 mm is a thick endometrium for her age) could be alikely cause. Th is thickened endometrium warrants an endometrial biopsy to tule out endometrial hyperplasia and cancer
  • • At 45y, heavy bleeding during periods could be because of endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy.
  • • It is important to rule out precancerous lesions and cancerous lesions at this age.
  • • A small 2 cm fibroid is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms but her increased endometrial thickness on the ultrasound (15 mm is a thick endometrium for her age) could be alikely cause.
  • • Th is thickened endometrium warrants an endometrial biopsy to tule out endometrial hyperplasia and cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fibroids and endometrial hyperplasia/ malignancy usually coexist as both are hyperestrogenic states Women in the peri-menopausal age group with fibroids with heavy menstrual bleeding should be evaluated for endometrial hyperplasia and cancer

options.D: Small submucosal fibroid in an infertile woman

questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Small submucosal fibroid in an infertile woman

Explanation:

  • • The indications of medical management in fibroid uterus is
  • • Patients not desirous of fertility but wanting uterine preservation Small symptomatic fibroids Improving anemia Peri-menopausal Pre-op to shrink the size of the fibroid
  • • Patients not desirous of fertility but wanting uterine preservation
  • • Small symptomatic fibroids
  • • Improving anemia
  • • Peri-menopausal
  • • Pre-op to shrink the size of the fibroid
  • • In an infertile woman, any submucosal fibroid, even if small has to be removed
  • • In an infertile woman, any submucosal fibroid, even if small has to be removed

questions.question_text: A 28-year woman comes to the OPD due to discomfort due to urination in the last 3 months. Antibiotics for UTI were prescribed but her symptoms persisted. She has also noted increasing pain with passage of stools for 1 year particularly during menses. Bowel movements occur daily and are soft and not watery. Her symptoms have not improved with decrease in alcohol and caffeine and increased dietary fiber. The patient also has intermittent abdominal pain for 7 months. She is on no medication and has no surgical history. BMI is 19kg/m2. Abdominal exam reveals suprapubic tenderness. On pelvic exam, the uterus is immobile and retroverted. Rectovaginal exam reveals nodularity in the post cul de sac. Urine analysis is normal. Surgical biopsy of the nodules will most likely show?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Endometrial glands and stroma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is endometriosis which is ectopic endometrium hence the histopathology of the nodules will show endometrial glands and stroma. Clues in this clinical question which point towards endometriosis are: Complaints of painful defecation Abdominal pain Nodularity in the POD
  • • This is endometriosis which is ectopic endometrium hence the histopathology of the nodules will show endometrial glands and stroma.
  • • Clues in this clinical question which point towards endometriosis are: Complaints of painful defecation Abdominal pain Nodularity in the POD
  • • Complaints of painful defecation Abdominal pain Nodularity in the POD
  • • Complaints of painful defecation
  • • Abdominal pain
  • • Nodularity in the POD

questions.question_text: Which of the following theories is the most widely accepted as the cause of endometriosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Retrograde menstruation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The definitive cause of endometriosis remains unknown, but theories have been proposed.
  • • Retrograde menstruation through the fallopian tubes: Most favored theory
  • • Retrograde menstruation through the fallopian tubes: Most favored theory
  • • All the other options are less favoured theories. These include:
  • • All the other options are less favoured theories. These include:
  • • The stem cell theory: implicates undifferentiated endometrial cells that initially reside in the endometrium’s basalis layer. These cells differentiate into epithelial, stromal, and vascular cells as the endometrium is routinely regenerated each cycle. If displaced to an ectopic location, such as by retrograde menstruation, these stem cells may give rise to endometriosis Aberrant lymphatic or vascular spread of endometrial tissue has also been implicated. Coelomic metaplasia and suggests that the parietal peritoneum is pluripotent and can undergo metaplastic transformation to tissue histologically identical to normal endometrium.
  • • The stem cell theory: implicates undifferentiated endometrial cells that initially reside in the endometrium’s basalis layer. These cells differentiate into epithelial, stromal, and vascular cells as the endometrium is routinely regenerated each cycle. If displaced to an ectopic location, such as by retrograde menstruation, these stem cells may give rise to endometriosis
  • • Aberrant lymphatic or vascular spread of endometrial tissue has also been implicated.
  • • Coelomic metaplasia and suggests that the parietal peritoneum is pluripotent and can undergo metaplastic transformation to tissue histologically identical to normal endometrium.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common theory of endometriosis is the theory of retrograde menstruation
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 231, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 231, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.question_text: Persistence of endometriosis is directly dependent on which of the following hormones?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Estrogen

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Endometriosis is a hyperestrogenic state

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endometriosis is a Hyperestrogenic state. Estrogen facilitates the growth of the ectopic endometrial glands. Endometriosis is an estrogen-dependent, chronic inflammatory disease with aberrant growth of ectopic endometrial tissue. The disturbed molecular mechanisms in this disease are yet to be completely defined. However, suspected underpinnings include an environment estrogen dominance, estrogen dependence, and progesterone resistance within implants; inflammation; escape from immune clearance; local invasion and neurovascular development; and genetic predisposition.
  • ➤ Endometriosis is a Hyperestrogenic state.
  • ➤ Estrogen facilitates the growth of the ectopic endometrial glands.
  • ➤ Endometriosis is an estrogen-dependent, chronic inflammatory disease with aberrant growth of ectopic endometrial tissue.
  • ➤ The disturbed molecular mechanisms in this disease are yet to be completely defined. However, suspected underpinnings include an environment estrogen dominance, estrogen dependence, and progesterone resistance within implants; inflammation; escape from immune clearance; local invasion and neurovascular development; and genetic predisposition.

questions.question_text: Which of the following environmental toxins has been implicated in the development of endometriosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. TCDD-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Several studies have shown that exposure to the dioxin 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin (TCDD) is associated with an increased prevalence and severity of endometriosis. Further animal experiments have implicated dioxin and dioxin-like compounds in this disease

questions.question_text: Which of the following manifestations is most likely encountered during the physical examination of a patient with endometriosis?

options.C: Powder burn lesions on the cervix during speculum examination.
options.D: Uterosacral ligament nodularity during bimanual examination

questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Uterosacral ligament nodularity during bimanual examination

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Uterosacral ligament nodularity during bimanual examination is a characteristric finding of endometriosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For the most part, endometriosis is a disease confined to the pelvis. Signs may not be present in all patients on examination During bimanual examination, pelvic organ palpation often reveals suggestive anatomic abnormalities. Uterosacral ligament nodularity and tenderness may reflect active disease or scarring along the ligament. An enlarged, cystic adnexal mass may represent an ovarian endometrioma, which can be mobile or adhered to other pelvic structures. A retroverted, fixed, tender uterus and a firm, fixed posterior cul-de-sac are among other findings. Pelvic nodularity secondary to endometriosis may be more easily detected by bimanual examination during menses Rectal examination may reveal rectovaginal septum nodularity or tenderness Rarely, blue or red powder burn lesions are seen on the cervix or the posterior vaginal fornix. These lesions can be tender or bleed with contact.

questions.question_text: Which of the following methods can reliably assist in making the diagnosis of endometriosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Laparoscopy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Although imaging can add clinical information, laparoscopy is the primary method used or diagnosing endometriosis (American College o Obstetricians and Gynecologists, 2014b).
  • • Although imaging can add clinical information, laparoscopy is the primary method used or diagnosing endometriosis (American College o Obstetricians and Gynecologists, 2014b).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A (sonography): This is useful when there is an ovarian cyst (endometriotic cyst) but may not pick up other endometriotic lesions Option C: (CT scan): This is again useful only for adnexal lesions but may not pick up smaller endometriotic lesions Option D (MRI): This imaging can pick up several endometriotic lesions but the investigation of choice remains a laparoscopy
  • • Option A (sonography): This is useful when there is an ovarian cyst (endometriotic cyst) but may not pick up other endometriotic lesions
  • • Option A (sonography):
  • • Option C: (CT scan): This is again useful only for adnexal lesions but may not pick up smaller endometriotic lesions
  • • Option C: (CT scan):
  • • Option D (MRI): This imaging can pick up several endometriotic lesions but the investigation of choice remains a laparoscopy
  • • Option D (MRI):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Although imaging can add clinical information, laparoscopy is the primary method used or diagnosing endometriosis Surgical findings vary and may include discrete endometriotic lesions, endometrioma, or adhesions. Implants are typically round on pelvic organ serosa and pelvic peritoneum. Lesions are variably colored and can be red (red, red-pink, or clear), white (white or yellow-brown), and black (black or black-blue) White and red lesions most commonly correlate with the characteristic histologic findings of endometriosis Dark lesions are pigmented by hemosiderin deposition rom trapped menstrual debris. In addition to color differences, endometriotic lesions may differ morphologically. They can appear as smooth blebs on peritoneal surfaces, as holes or defects within the peritoneum, or as flat stellate lesions whose points are formed by surrounding scar tissue. Endometriotic lesions may be superficial or may deeply invade the peritoneum or pelvic organs. Endometriomas are easily identified during laparoscopy.

questions.question_text: Women seeking immediate fertility and who suffer from endometriosis would most likely benefit from which of the following treatments?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Laparoscopic ablation of lesions

Explanation:

  • • Treatment of endometriosis is by both medical or surgical management If pain is prominent and conception is not currently desired, then medical therapy is typically selected. Available agents include NSAIDs, OCPs, progestins, GnRH agents, and aromatase inhibitors. In general, suitable starting regimens are NSAIDS alone or combined with oral contraceptive pills or with a progestin. Although medical treatment improves pain, relapse rates are high with therapy discontinuation. If infertility is the presenting symptom, then laparoscopic management should be considered (ablation/ excision of endometriotic implants)
  • • Treatment of endometriosis is by both medical or surgical management

questions.question_text: For surgical treatment of endometriomas, which of the following approaches is superior?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Cystectomy

Explanation:

  • • Endometriomas are typically treated surgically to exclude malignancy or treat associated pain. Cystectomy lowers endometrioma recurrence rates and pain symptoms and improves subsequent spontaneous pregnancy rates During surgery, ideally normal ovarian tissue is preserved as much as possible
  • • Endometriomas are typically treated surgically to exclude malignancy or treat associated pain.
  • • Cystectomy lowers endometrioma recurrence rates and pain symptoms and improves subsequent spontaneous pregnancy rates
  • • During surgery, ideally normal ovarian tissue is preserved as much as possible

questions.question_text: A 25-year woman is undergoing a diagnostic laparoscopy for unexplained infertility. The following is seen. What is the best management option?

Explanation:

questions.question_text: A 20-year-old nulligravida with a last menstrual period 5 days ago presents to the emergency department with generalized lower abdominal pain and fever. She reports a new sexual partner. Physical examination demonstrates guarding and bilateral adnexal fullness. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis, and transvaginal sonography reveals no visible ovaries, but bilateral adnexal masses as shown here. The diagnosis most consistent with these findings is which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Tuboovarian abscess

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This is a tubo-ovarian abscess which is seen in Pelvic Inflammatory Disease It is an inflammatory mass involving the fallopian tube, ovary, and often surrounding structures. If an ovary adheres to the fallopian tube, but is still visualized, it is called a tubo-ovarian complex. A tuboovarian abscess results from a complete breakdown ovarian and tubal architecture such that the separate structures are no longer identified. Affected women usually have lower abdominal pain, fever, leukocytosis, and unilateral or bilateral adnexal masses. Initial treatment of a tubo-ovarian abscess is by In patient antibiotic treatment If no response to medical management observed, surgical management is considered
  • • This is a tubo-ovarian abscess which is seen in Pelvic Inflammatory Disease
  • • It is an inflammatory mass involving the fallopian tube, ovary, and often surrounding structures.
  • • If an ovary adheres to the fallopian tube, but is still visualized, it is called a tubo-ovarian complex.
  • • A tuboovarian abscess results from a complete breakdown ovarian and tubal architecture such that the separate structures are no longer identified.
  • • Affected women usually have lower abdominal pain, fever, leukocytosis, and unilateral or bilateral adnexal masses.
  • • Initial treatment of a tubo-ovarian abscess is by In patient antibiotic treatment
  • • If no response to medical management observed, surgical management is considered
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Endometriosis: This commonly presents as dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, dull aching abdominal pain and infertility. Examination will reveal a retroverted fixed uterus and nodularoty may be present. An ultrasound will show a chocolate cyst Option B: Ovarian torsion will present as acute abdominal pain and this will increase and not be relieved by medication. A Doppler best diagnosis this condition where the classical whirlpool sign will be seen Option D: Malignant ovarian neoplasm: This usually presents in the older age group with GI symptoms. Ultrasound will show a complex ovarian mass with solid areas, papillary projections, ascites and metastases
  • • Option A: Endometriosis: This commonly presents as dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, dull aching abdominal pain and infertility. Examination will reveal a retroverted fixed uterus and nodularoty may be present. An ultrasound will show a chocolate cyst
  • • Option B: Ovarian torsion will present as acute abdominal pain and this will increase and not be relieved by medication. A Doppler best diagnosis this condition where the classical whirlpool sign will be seen
  • • Option D: Malignant ovarian neoplasm: This usually presents in the older age group with GI symptoms. Ultrasound will show a complex ovarian mass with solid areas, papillary projections, ascites and metastases

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A tubo-ovarian abscess, seen in Pelvic Inflammatory Disease is an inflammatory mass involving the fallopian tube, ovary, and often surrounding structures. If an ovary adheres to the fallopian tube, but is still visualized, it is called a tubo-ovarian complex. In contrast, a tuboovarian abscess results from a complete breakdown ovarian and tubal architecture such that the separate structures are no longer identified.

questions.question_text: A 32-year woman presents with acute abdominal pain & vomiting. On examination, there is abdominal tenderness. Ultrasound shows an ovarian cyst. Laparoscopic image is shown. Which is incorrect?

options.A: Ovarian dermoid are commonly associated with this
options.B: The ovary can undergo infarction if surgery is delayed
options.C: Detorsion and ovarian cystectomy should be done
options.D: USG Doppler is not a useful test in diagnosing torsion

questions.explanation:
Ans. D. USG Doppler is not a useful test in diagnosing torsion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This is an image showing torsion of the ovary/ ovarian cyst
  • • Let us discuss all the options:
  • • Let us discuss all the options:
  • • Option A: Ovarian dermoid are commonly associated with this: Ovarian dermoids are commonly associated with torsion. As they are light in weight due to sebaceous material, they easily undergo torsion Option B: The ovary can undergo infarction if surgery is delayed: If the surgery is delayed, the vascular supply to the ovary is cut off and this can cause necrosis of the ovary Option C: Detorsion and ovarian cystectomy should be done: Laparoscopic detorsion and ovarian cystectomy is the preferred method of treatment. However on detorsion, if the color (vascularity) does not return, then ovariectomy may have to be done. Option D: USG Doppler is not a useful test in diagnosing torsion: This is incorrect as USG + Doppler is the investigation of choice for diagnosing ovarian torsion
  • • Option A: Ovarian dermoid are commonly associated with this: Ovarian dermoids are commonly associated with torsion. As they are light in weight due to sebaceous material, they easily undergo torsion
  • • Option A:
  • • Option B: The ovary can undergo infarction if surgery is delayed: If the surgery is delayed, the vascular supply to the ovary is cut off and this can cause necrosis of the ovary
  • • Option B:
  • • Option C: Detorsion and ovarian cystectomy should be done: Laparoscopic detorsion and ovarian cystectomy is the preferred method of treatment. However on detorsion, if the color (vascularity) does not return, then ovariectomy may have to be done.
  • • Option C:
  • • Option D: USG Doppler is not a useful test in diagnosing torsion: This is incorrect as USG + Doppler is the investigation of choice for diagnosing ovarian torsion
  • • Option D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adnexal Torsion
  • ➤ Adnexal Torsion
  • ➤ Torsion involves the twisting of adnexal components. Most often, the ovary and fallopian tube rotate as a single entity. Infrequently, an ovary may alone turn about its mesovarium, and rarely a fallopian tube twists alone about the mesosalpinx. Most commonly occurs during the reproductive years Common in pregnancy. Risk Factors Adnexal masses with increased mobility Excessively mobile mesovaria or fallopian tubes and may increase the risk in even normal adnexa. Pathologically enlarged ovaries with a diameter > 6 cm (Rt ovary more common) Dermoid cysts are light and tend to undergo torsion easily C/F Classically, the woman with adnexal torsion complains of sharp lower abdominal pain with sudden onset that worsens intermittently over several hours. The pain usually is localized to the involved side, with radiation to the aflnk, groin, or thigh. Low-grade fever suggests adnexal necrosis. Nausea and vomiting frequently accompany the pain. Adnexal mass may not be palpable. Diagnosis Ultrasound D/D: Ectopic pregnancy, tuboovarian abscess, hemorrhagic ovarian cyst, and endometrioma. The twisted pedicle may also appear as a bull’s-eye target, whirlpool, or snail shell, that is, a rounded hyperechoic structure with multiple, inner, concentric hypoechoic rings. Transvaginal color Doppler sonography may show disruption of normal adnexal blood ow. disruption Management Laparoscopy and detorsion: Management of choice If ovarian cyst: Cystectomy can be done at same or separate sitting If no return to vascularity: Can consider adnexectomy/ ovariectomy To minimize recurrence: unilateral or bilateral oophoropexy

options.B: Transmitted mobility is present in an ovarian mass.

questions.question_text: A 44-year-old woman undergoes a total hysterectomy for painful fibroids. The ovaries will not be removed during the procedure. Which of the following ligaments must be preserved?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Infundibulopelvic  ligament

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The ovaries are held in place by the ovarian ligaments medially (attach ovary to the uterus) and the infundibulopelvic ligaments laterally (attach the ovary to the lateral pelvic wall) In a hysterectomy if the ovaries are to be preserved, the ovarian ligament is clamped, cut and ligated (i.e. infundibulopelvic ligament is preserved) In a hysterectomy, if the ovaries are to be removed, the infundibulopelvic ligament is clamped, cut and ligated. Hence to preseve the ovaries, the Infundibulopelvic ligament needs to be preserved
  • • The ovaries are held in place by the ovarian ligaments medially (attach ovary to the uterus) and the infundibulopelvic ligaments laterally (attach the ovary to the lateral pelvic wall)
  • • In a hysterectomy if the ovaries are to be preserved, the ovarian ligament is clamped, cut and ligated (i.e. infundibulopelvic ligament is preserved)
  • • In a hysterectomy, if the ovaries are to be removed, the infundibulopelvic ligament is clamped, cut and ligated.
  • • Hence to preseve the ovaries, the Infundibulopelvic ligament needs to be preserved
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B: Ovarian ligament : When the ovary needs to be preseved, the ovarian ligament is CUT, not preserved Option C: Uterosacral ligaments: These are ligaments that support the uterus posteriorly and are not related to the ovaries Option D: Transverse cervical ligaments: These provide lateral supports to the uterus
  • • Option B: Ovarian ligament : When the ovary needs to be preseved, the ovarian ligament is CUT, not preserved
  • • Option B: Ovarian ligament
  • • Option C: Uterosacral ligaments: These are ligaments that support the uterus posteriorly and are not related to the ovaries
  • • Option C:
  • • Option D: Transverse cervical ligaments: These provide lateral supports to the uterus
  • • Option D:

questions.question_text: A 24-year-old patient at 12 weeks presents to the emergency department with complaints of pelvic pain. Transabdominal sonography reveals these bilateral multilocular cystic ovarian masses as shown in the image. Which of the following commonly associated conditions must be excluded in pregnancies with this finding? A. Fetal hydrops B. Gestational trophoblastic disease C. Gestational Diabetes D. Macrosomia E. Multifetal gestation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 1,2,5

Explanation:

  • • This image is showing theca lutein cysts. These are an uncommon type of follicular cyst, characterized by luteinization and hypertrophy of their theca interna layer. Bilateral, multiple smooth-walled cysts form and range in size from 1 to 4 cm in diameter. Also called Hyperreactio lutealis Due to elevated LH or β-hCG levels. Commonly associated conditions include Gestational trophoblastic disease Multiple pregnancy Placentomegaly (As is seen in fetal hydrops, syphilis etc) Ovarian hyperstimulation during assisted reproductive techniques These cysts typically resolve spontaneously following removal o the stimulating hormone source. These are prone to ovarian torsion
