questions.question_text: The USG finding of “tip of the iceberg” sign corresponds to the site within a mature cystic teratoma where the most varied tissue types, such as hair and fatty secretions, are found. Pathologically, what is this area called?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Rokitansky protuberance

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts) are benign tumors comprising 10 to 25 percent of all ovarian neoplasms and 60 percent of all benign ovarian neoplasms These cystic tumors are typically slow growing, and most measure between 5 and 10 cm They are bilateral in approximately 10 percent When sectioned, most cysts appear unilocular and typically contain one area of localized growth, which protrudes into the cystic cavity. Alternatively designated as Rokitansky protuberance, dermoid plug, dermoid process, dermoid mamilla, or embryonal rudiment, this protuberance can be absent or multiple.
  • • Mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts) are benign tumors comprising 10 to 25 percent of all ovarian neoplasms and 60 percent of all benign ovarian neoplasms

  • • When sectioned, most cysts appear unilocular and typically contain one area of localized growth, which protrudes into the cystic cavity. Alternatively designated as Rokitansky protuberance, dermoid plug, dermoid process, dermoid mamilla, or embryonal rudiment, this protuberance can be absent or multiple.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Homunculus: Very rarely, a dermoid may contain a fetal like structure called homunculus Option B: Struma ovarii: This is used to describe an ovarian dermoid containing primarily thyroid tissue Option C: Hydatid of Morgagni: Hydatids of Morgagni are benign, pedunculated, cystic structures arising from müllerian vestiges below the fallopian tube near the fimbria

questions.question_text: A 26-year G2P1 at 16 weeks pregnancy, presents to the emergency department with complaints of worsening right pelvic pain. She states that she had the sudden onset of sharp pain after bending. She experienced intense nausea with the pain. The pain did not respond to analgesics at home and has in fact worsened. On examination, the uterus is 16 weeks, and she has guarding. An ultrasound reveals a single live pregnancy of 16 weeks with an 8cm enlarged right ovary with high impedance arterial flow of the ovary on color Doppler. What is the next best step in management?

options.C: Laparoscopy with detorsion of the ovary

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Laparoscopy with detorsion of the ovary

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This is pregnancy with ovarian torsion Ovarian torsion is common in pregnancy and is managed in a similar way As the patient is in the 2 nd trimester, the best management option would be a laparoscopy and attempt at detorsion of the ovary. Laparoscopy is safe in the 2 nd trimester.
  • • This is pregnancy with ovarian torsion
  • • Ovarian torsion is common in pregnancy and is managed in a similar way
  • • As the patient is in the 2 nd trimester, the best management option would be a laparoscopy and attempt at detorsion of the ovary.
  • • Laparoscopy is safe in the 2 nd trimester.

However the management of choice is a laparoscopy and ovarian detorsion Option D: Observe: As the patient is in severe pain and there is torsion, immediate surgery is essential else the ovary can undergo necrosis and due to release of inflammatory markers, the pregnancy can also be affected (increased risk of abortion)

questions.question_text: Which of the following vulvar dermatoses commonly presents with oral lesions, such as the one shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Lichen Planus

Explanation:

  • • Lichen planus is an uncommon disease involves both cutaneous and mucosal surfaces and affects genders equally between ages 30 and 60 years Women typically complain of chronic vaginal discharge with intense vulvovaginal pruritus, burning pain, dyspareunia, and postcoital bleeding. On inspection, papules classically are brightly erythematous or violaceous, flat topped, shiny polygons most commonly round on the trunk, buccal mucosa, or flexor sur aces of the extremities Lacy, white striations (Wickham striae) are frequently found in conjunction with the papules and may also be present on the buccal mucosa Deep, painful erosions in the posterior vestibule can extend to the labia, resulting in agglutination. With speculum insertion, vulvar skin and vaginal mucosa bleed easily. Vaginal erosions can produce adhesions and synechiae, which may lead to vaginal obliteration. Women with suspected lichen planus require a thorough dermatologic survey looking or extragenital lesions. Nearly one quarter of women with oral lesions will have vulvovaginal involvement, and most with erosive vulvovaginal lichen planus will have oral involvement. Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy. Treatment: Erosive vulvar lichen planus is treated initially with ultrapotent topical corticosteroid ointments, such as 0.05-percent clobetasol propionate applied daily or up to 3 months, and then slowly tapered

  • • With speculum insertion, vulvar skin and vaginal mucosa bleed easily.

questions.question_text: Treatment of vaginal lichen planus is challenging, and symptomatic relief has been reported using which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Vaginal corticosteroid suppositories

Explanation:

  • • Suppositories containing 25 mg of hydrocortisone used vaginally are helpful Combining local corticosteroid therapy with vaginal dilator use may help restore coital function in patients with moderate vaginal synechiae. If topical medications fail, systemic treatment with prednisone 40 to 60 mg daily or up to 4 weeks may modulate symptoms

questions.question_text: An 18-year girl presents with a painful enlarged Bartholin cyst. She is a 1 st year medical student and is curious as to how this developed. Bartholin gland duct cysts form in direct response to which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Gland duct obstruction

Explanation:

  • • Mucus produced to lubricate the vulva originates in part from the Bartholin glands. Obstruction of this gland’s duct is common and may follow infection, trauma, mucus changes, or congenitally narrowed ducts. In some cases, cyst contents may become infected and lead to abscess formation. Escherichia coli is the most common isolate, but various other gram-positive and gram-negative aerobes and anaerobes are found Infrequently, Neisseria gonorrhoeae or Chlamydia trachomatis is identified

questions.question_text: The image below best represents which of the following vulvar disorders?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Bartholin gland duct cyst

Explanation:

  • • This is a Bartholin gland duct cyst Most Bartholin gland cysts are small and asymptomatic except or minor discom ort during sexual contact. With larger or infected cysts, however, patients may complain of severe vulvar pain that precludes walking, sitting, or sexual activity On physical examination, cysts typically are unilateral, round or ovoid, and fluctuant or tense. I If infected, they display surrounding erythema and are tender. The mass is usually located in the inferior labia majora or lower vestibule. Whereas most cysts and abscesses lead to labial asymmetry, smaller cysts may be detected only by palpation. Small, asymptomatic Bartholin gland duct cysts require no intervention except exclusion of neoplasia in women older than 40 years. However, a symptomatic cyst may be managed with one of several techniques. These include: Incision and drainage (I&D) Marsupialization Bartholin gland excision

questions.question_text: According to the October 2003 ISSVD World Congress, which of the following terms most often describes burning vulvar pain occurring in the absence of relevant visible findings or specific, clinically identifiable disorders?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Vulvodynia

Explanation:

  • • In 2003, the ISSVD defined vulvodynia as “vulvar discomfort, most often described as burning pain, occurring in the absence of relevant visible findings or a specific, clinically identifiable, neurologic disorder” The term vestibulitis was eliminated from ISSVD terminology since inflammatory changes have not been consistently documented. Vulvar pain is described as spontaneous (unprovoked), triggered by physical pressure (provoked), or mixed. Vulvar pain described by most patients as burning, stinging, or a raw irritation is further categorized as localized or generalized

questions.question_text: A 33-year woman presents to the OPD. She complains of difficulty in inserting a tampon and says she feels something in the vagina. O/e, a vaginal swelling is seen arising from the anterolateral vaginal wall as shown. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Gartner duct cyst

Explanation:

  • • Most vaginal cysts are epidermoid cysts, urethral diverticula, or Gartner duct cysts. Gartner duct cysts develop from mesonephric (wolffian) duct remnants. They are typically asymptomatic and found within the lateral vaginal wall during routine examination. C/F: Dyspareunia, vaginal pain, and difficulty inserting tampons. Examination reveals a tense cyst that is palpable or seen to bulge from beneath the vaginal wall. Observation is reasonable in most cases, although marsupialization or excision may be appropriate or symptomatic Gartner duct cysts.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements regarding placental abruption is true? Abruption begins with the rupture of a decidual spiral artery and haemorrhage into the decidua basalis External (revealed) haemorrhage is more common than concealed haemorrhage The likelihood of consumptive coagulopathy is increased with concealed haemorrhage because of the association with preeclampsia Most blood in the retroplacental hematoma in a placental abruption is fetal
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1,2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Let us look at each statement:
  • • Let us look at each statement:
  • • Abruption Begins with the Rupture of a Decidual Spiral Artery and Haemorrhage into the Decidua Basalis: True. External (Revealed) Haemorrhage is More Common than Concealed Haemorrhage: True The Likelihood of Consumptive Coagulopathy is Increased with Concealed Haemorrhage Because of the Association with Preeclampsia: This statement is not entirely accurate. While it's true that consumptive coagulopathy (a condition where clotting factors are consumed faster than they are produced) can be a complication of placental abruption, its increased likelihood is not specifically associated with the type of hemorrhage (concealed or revealed). The relationship between consumptive coagulopathy and preeclampsia is complex, and preeclampsia can occur independently of the type of hemorrhage in placental abruption. Most Blood in the Retroplacental Hematoma in a Placental Abruption is Fetal: This statement is false. In a retroplacental hematoma (a collection of blood behind the placenta), the majority of the blood is maternal.
  • • Abruption Begins with the Rupture of a Decidual Spiral Artery and Haemorrhage into the Decidua Basalis: True.
  • • True.
  • • External (Revealed) Haemorrhage is More Common than Concealed Haemorrhage: True
  • • True
  • • The Likelihood of Consumptive Coagulopathy is Increased with Concealed Haemorrhage Because of the Association with Preeclampsia: This statement is not entirely accurate. While it's true that consumptive coagulopathy (a condition where clotting factors are consumed faster than they are produced) can be a complication of placental abruption, its increased likelihood is not specifically associated with the type of hemorrhage (concealed or revealed). The relationship between consumptive coagulopathy and preeclampsia is complex, and preeclampsia can occur independently of the type of hemorrhage in placental abruption.
  • • This statement is not entirely accurate. While it's true that consumptive coagulopathy (a condition where clotting factors are consumed faster than they are produced) can be a complication of placental abruption, its increased likelihood is not specifically associated with the type of hemorrhage (concealed or revealed). The relationship between consumptive coagulopathy and preeclampsia is complex, and preeclampsia can occur independently of the type of hemorrhage in placental abruption.
  • • Most Blood in the Retroplacental Hematoma in a Placental Abruption is Fetal: This statement is false. In a retroplacental hematoma (a collection of blood behind the placenta), the majority of the blood is maternal.
  • • This statement is false. In a retroplacental hematoma (a collection of blood behind the placenta), the majority of the blood is maternal.
  • • Given this analysis, the correct answer is B. 1,2 .

questions.question_text: Which is NOT a predisposing factor for abruption?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Post term pregnancy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Risk Factors for Abruption
  • • Prior Abruption Increased age and parity Preeclampsia, chronic HTN Chorioamnionitis PROM Multifetal pregnancy FGR Polyhydramnios Cigarette smoking Cocaine use Uterine leiomyoma Single umbilical artery Subchorionic hematoma

  • • Cigarette smoking

  • • Single umbilical artery
  • • Subchorionic hematoma
  • • Let us look at each option :
  • • Let us look at each option :
  • • Option A. Advanced Maternal Age: As maternal age increases, particularly beyond 35 years, the risk of various complications, including placental abruption, tends to increase due to a range of factors including altered vascular conditions and increased likelihood of preexisting conditions.
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • Advanced Maternal Age:
  • • Option B. Multiparity: Multiparity,is also associated with an increased risk of placental abruption. The reasons for this are not entirely clear, but it may be related to changes in the uterine wall or scarring from previous deliveries.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Multiparity:
  • • Option C. Polyhydramnios: The increased volume of fluid can create additional pressure and strain on the placenta and uterine wall, potentially leading to detachment.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Polyhydramnios:
  • • Option D. Post-term Pregnancy: Contrary to the other options, post-term is not commonly listed as a risk factor for placental abruption. The major concerns with post-term pregnancy usually relate to other complications, such as fetal macrosomia (large baby) or oligohydramnios (low amniotic fluid), rather than an increased risk of placental abruption.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Post-term Pregnancy:

questions.question_text: A 23-year G2 with a previous LSCS presents at 30 weeks with vaginal bleeding. On examination, her PR is 80/ min, and her BP is 120/80 mmHg. Abdominal examination reveals a 32 weeks uterus which is relaxed, non-tender and the FHR is 130 bpm. What is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Transabdominal ultrasound

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical scenario presented is one of antepartum haemorrhage Points in favor of placenta previa No pain h/o prev LSCS vital signs normal Uterus relaxed FHR normal Placenta previa is confirmed by a transabdominal ultrasound
  • • The clinical scenario presented is one of antepartum haemorrhage
  • • Points in favor of placenta previa No pain h/o prev LSCS vital signs normal Uterus relaxed FHR normal
  • • No pain h/o prev LSCS vital signs normal Uterus relaxed FHR normal
  • • No pain
  • • h/o prev LSCS
  • • vital signs normal
  • • Uterus relaxed
  • • FHR normal
  • • Placenta previa is confirmed by a transabdominal ultrasound
  • • Let us look at each option:
  • • Let us look at each option:
  • • Option A. Biophysical Profile: A biophysical profile is a combination of an ultrasound and a non-stress test to assess fetal well-being. It's typically used in cases where there is a concern about fetal health, especially in situations like fetal growth restriction or decreased fetal movements. In this case, the fetus seems to be doing well based on the FHR
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • Biophysical Profile:
  • • Option B. Corticosteroids: Administering corticosteroids is recommended for fetal lung maturity in cases of preterm labor or when early delivery is anticipated. However, it doesn't address the immediate need to evaluate the cause of the bleeding.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Corticosteroids:
  • • Option C. Emergency LSCS: An emergency lower segment cesarean section might be considered in cases of acute fetal distress or life-threatening maternal conditions. However, given the stable vital signs of both the mother and the fetus, this does not appear to be the immediate requirement.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Emergency LSCS:
  • • Option D. Transabdominal Ultrasound: This is the most appropriate next step. A transabdominal ultrasound will help assess the placental position, amniotic fluid volume, fetal growth, and activity. It's crucial in this case to rule out placental abnormalities, such as placenta previa or vasa previa, which could be causing the bleeding. Additionally, the ultrasound can help clarify why the uterus is measuring larger than expected for the gestational age.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Transabdominal Ultrasound:
  • • Given the information provided, the next best step in management is D. Transabdominal ultrasound .
  • • D. Transabdominal ultrasound

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a pregnant patient with a history of cesarean delivery presenting with vaginal bleeding and a stable condition, the initial step should be to perform a transabdominal ultrasound to assess the placenta, fetus, and amniotic fluid, and to investigate the cause of bleeding
  • ➤ In a pregnant patient with a history of cesarean delivery presenting with vaginal bleeding and a stable condition, the initial step should be to perform a transabdominal ultrasound to assess the placenta, fetus, and amniotic fluid, and to investigate the cause of bleeding

questions.question_text: A 35-year G2 with placenta previa presents at 32 weeks with an episode of bleeding. On examination, her vital signs are stable and abdominal exam reveals a relaxed uterus. Expectant management (McAfee Johnson) is initiated. This includes all except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Weekly NST

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Components of Expectant Management (MacAfee & Johnson)
  • • Components of Expectant Management (MacAfee & Johnson)
  • • Bed rest Hb and Blood group Hematinics/ Blood transfusion Avoid tocolysis Inj Anti-D for Rh negative women Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity (< 34 weeks): Inj Betamethasone 12 mg 2 doses 24 h apart
  • • Bed rest
  • • Hb and Blood group
  • • Hematinics/ Blood transfusion
  • • Avoid tocolysis
  • • Inj Anti-D for Rh negative women
  • • Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity (< 34 weeks): Inj Betamethasone 12 mg 2 doses 24 h apart
  • • Let's examine each option:
  • • Let's examine each option:
  • • Option A. Bed Rest: This is to reduce physical activity and minimize the risk of triggering further bleeding. It is a standard component of expectant management in such cases.
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • Bed Rest:
  • • Option B. Corticosteroids: The purpose is to accelerate fetal lung maturity in case an early delivery becomes necessary, which is a significant concern in pregnancies complicated by placenta previa.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Corticosteroids:
  • • Option C. Hematinics: Hematinics, such as iron supplements, are often given to pregnant women with placenta previa, especially if they have experienced bleeding. They help in maintaining or improving the hemoglobin levels, which can be critical if the patient loses blood.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Hematinics:
  • • Option D. Weekly NST (Non-Stress Test): While fetal monitoring is important in the management of high-risk pregnancies, including those with placenta previa, weekly NSTs are not a standard component of the McAfee Johnson protocol for expectant management of placenta previa. NSTs are used to monitor the fetal heart rate and look for signs of fetal distress. However, their frequency and use would be determined based on individual clinical scenarios and may not necessarily be conducted on a weekly basis as a standard protocol.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Weekly NST (Non-Stress Test):

questions.question_text: The most common obstetric cause of consumptive coagulopathy in obstetrics is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Abruptio placentae

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Placental abruption is the most common cause of clinically profound consumptive coagulopathy in obstetrics DIC happens because of placental thromboplastin entering the maternal circulation. Other causes of DIC in obstetrics: Preeclampsia/ eclampsia Sepsis Post-Partum hemorrhage Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy Amniotic Fluid Embolism Intra Uterine Death Features of DIC Reduced fibrinogen levels (< 150 mg/dl) Raised levels of FDPs and D-Dimers Thrombocytopenia Prolonged PT and aPTT
  • • Placental abruption is the most common cause of clinically profound consumptive coagulopathy in obstetrics
  • • DIC happens because of placental thromboplastin entering the maternal circulation.
  • • Other causes of DIC in obstetrics: Preeclampsia/ eclampsia Sepsis Post-Partum hemorrhage Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy Amniotic Fluid Embolism Intra Uterine Death
  • • Preeclampsia/ eclampsia Sepsis Post-Partum hemorrhage Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy Amniotic Fluid Embolism Intra Uterine Death
  • • Preeclampsia/ eclampsia
  • • Sepsis
  • • Post-Partum hemorrhage
  • • Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy
  • • Amniotic Fluid Embolism
  • • Intra Uterine Death
  • • Features of DIC Reduced fibrinogen levels (< 150 mg/dl) Raised levels of FDPs and D-Dimers Thrombocytopenia Prolonged PT and aPTT
  • • Reduced fibrinogen levels (< 150 mg/dl) Raised levels of FDPs and D-Dimers Thrombocytopenia Prolonged PT and aPTT
  • • Reduced fibrinogen levels (< 150 mg/dl)
  • • Raised levels of FDPs and D-Dimers
  • • Thrombocytopenia
  • • Prolonged PT and aPTT
  • • Let's examine each option:
  • • Let's examine each option:
  • • Option A. Abruptio Placentae: This is the most common obstetric cause of consumptive coagulopathy. In abruptio placentae, or placental abruption, the placenta detaches from the uterine wall before delivery, which can lead to significant internal bleeding. This bleeding can trigger a cascade of coagulation, leading to DIC.
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • Abruptio Placentae:
  • • Option B. Eclampsia: Eclampsia, a severe complication of preeclampsia characterized by seizures, can be associated with coagulation abnormalities. The primary concern in eclampsia is the management of seizures and hypertension.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Eclampsia:
  • • Option C. Amniotic Fluid Embolism: Amniotic fluid embolism is a rare but serious condition where amniotic fluid, fetal cells, hair, or other debris enter the maternal bloodstream, potentially leading to an allergic-like reaction and cardiorespiratory collapse. While it can lead to DIC, it is not the most common cause.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Amniotic Fluid Embolism:
  • • Option D. Postpartum Hemorrhage (PPH): PPH is excessive bleeding following childbirth. While severe PPH can lead to coagulopathy, it is more often a consequence of other factors like uterine atony, trauma, retained placental tissue, or coagulation disorders, rather than the primary cause of consumptive coagulopathy.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Postpartum Hemorrhage (PPH):

questions.question_text: A 25-year primi with preeclampsia and fetal distress underwent an emergency LSCS. Following delivery of the baby, this was the appearance of the uterus. What could have been the reason for fetal distress?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Abruptio Placenta

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is Couvelaire uterus. It is seen following concealed abruption and is the appearance of the uterus during a cesarean section. Points about Couvelaire uterus:
  • • Also called as uteroplacental apoplexy Seen in severe concealed abruption Occurs due to intravasation of blood into uterine musculature The uterus appears dark bluish like a bruise The blood may also seep into the leaves of the broad ligament, in the ovaries or in the peritoneal cavity. It is not an indication for a hysterectomy.
  • • Also called as uteroplacental apoplexy
  • • Seen in severe concealed abruption
  • • Occurs due to intravasation of blood into uterine musculature
  • • The uterus appears dark bluish like a bruise
  • • The blood may also seep into the leaves of the broad ligament, in the ovaries or in the peritoneal cavity.
  • • It is not an indication for a hysterectomy.
  • • Let us look at the other options:
  • • Let us look at the other options:
  • • Option B. Cephalopelvic Disproportion (CPD): CPD occurs when the baby's head is too large or the mother's pelvic opening is too small for vaginal delivery. While CPD can cause labor complications and potentially lead to fetal distress, it would not typically result in noticeable changes to the appearance of the uterus during a cesarean section.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Cephalopelvic Disproportion (CPD):
  • • Option C. Meconium-Stained Amniotic Fluid: Meconium-stained amniotic fluid occurs when the baby passes meconium (early feces) into the amniotic fluid before or during labor. This can be a sign of fetal distress, but it is not directly related to the appearance of the uterus after delivery.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Meconium-Stained Amniotic Fluid:
  • • Option D. Utero-Placental Insufficiency: This condition occurs when the placenta is not able to provide adequate nutrients and oxygen to the fetus, leading to fetal distress. However, utero-placental insufficiency is a chronic condition and may not directly correlate with the physical appearance of the uterus during a cesarean section.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Utero-Placental Insufficiency:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Ref: Page no 753, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.question_text: A 21-year primigravida at 36 weeks with chronic hypertension presents with vaginal bleeding with abdominal pain. On examination, her BP is 140/100. The uterus is tense and contracting. The Fetal heart rate is not auscultated. PV examination reveals the cervix is 5 cm dilated and well effaced. What is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Augment labor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is a patient with abruption with fetal demise Management of Abruption: Blood and blood products to be transfused Immediate Delivery is the rule If fetal distress/maternal shock – expedite (Cesarean delivery unless patient in advanced labor) If no fetal distress or fetal demise has already occurred: Induce/ Augment (ARM ± Oxytocin) This patient is in labor and fetal demise has occurred. The best management would be to augment labor (ARM + Oxytocin)
  • • This is a patient with abruption with fetal demise
  • • Management of Abruption: Blood and blood products to be transfused Immediate Delivery is the rule If fetal distress/maternal shock – expedite (Cesarean delivery unless patient in advanced labor) If no fetal distress or fetal demise has already occurred: Induce/ Augment (ARM ± Oxytocin)
  • • Blood and blood products to be transfused Immediate Delivery is the rule If fetal distress/maternal shock – expedite (Cesarean delivery unless patient in advanced labor) If no fetal distress or fetal demise has already occurred: Induce/ Augment (ARM ± Oxytocin)
  • • Blood and blood products to be transfused
  • • Immediate Delivery is the rule
  • • If fetal distress/maternal shock – expedite (Cesarean delivery unless patient in advanced labor)
  • • If no fetal distress or fetal demise has already occurred: Induce/ Augment (ARM ± Oxytocin)
  • • This patient is in labor and fetal demise has occurred. The best management would be to augment labor (ARM + Oxytocin)
  • • Let us explore each option:
  • • Let us explore each option:
  • • Option A. Augment Labor: Given the signs suggestive of placental abruption and the indication of fetal demise augmenting labor is appropriate if the patient is already in labor.It can be done with artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) and oxytocin to facilitate vaginal delivery, which is generally preferable in the case of fetal demise.
  • • Option A. Augment Labor:
  • • Option B. Emergency LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section): While emergency cesarean section is a critical intervention in cases of placental abruption with a viable fetus and maternal or fetal distress, it may not be the most appropriate choice in the event of confirmed fetal demise, especially if the patient is already in advanced labor.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Emergency LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section):
  • • Option C. Tocolysis: Tocolysis, the would be contraindicated in this scenario. There is a need for delivery, not delaying it, especially considering the signs of abruption and fetal demise.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Tocolysis:
  • • Option D . Urgent Ultrasound: While an ultrasound can confirm the diagnosis and assess the situation, the clinical signs (absence of fetal heart rate, vaginal bleeding, and uterine contractions) strongly suggest placental abruption with fetal demise. In this case, the immediate priority is the management of the mother's condition and the delivery.
  • • Option
  • • D
  • • Urgent Ultrasound:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Blood and blood products to be transfused Immediate Delivery is the rule If fetal distress/maternal shock – expedite (Cesarean delivery unless patient in advanced labor) If no fetal distress or fetal demise has already occurred: Induce/ Augment (ARM ± Oxytocin)
  • ➤ Blood and blood products to be transfused
  • ➤ Immediate Delivery is the rule
  • ➤ If fetal distress/maternal shock – expedite (Cesarean delivery unless patient in advanced labor)
  • ➤ If no fetal distress or fetal demise has already occurred: Induce/ Augment (ARM ± Oxytocin)

questions.question_text: A 35-year Primigravida presents at 30 weeks with abdominal pain for 2 hours. Her BP is 160/100 mmHg. On examination there is pallor. The uterus corresponds to 36 weeks and is tender. The most probable diagnosis is.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Abruption

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Points in favor of abruption Abdominal pain Pallor High BP Uterine height > POG In all the other choices, the uterine height > POG but pallor and high BP favors the diagnosis of abruption (concealed type).
  • • Points in favor of abruption Abdominal pain Pallor High BP Uterine height > POG
  • • Abdominal pain Pallor High BP Uterine height > POG
  • • Abdominal pain
  • • Pallor
  • • High BP
  • • Uterine height > POG
  • • In all the other choices, the uterine height > POG but pallor and high BP favors the diagnosis of abruption (concealed type).
  • • Let us look at the other option:
  • • Let us look at the other option:
  • • Option B. Polyhydramnios: Polyhydramnios refers to an excessive amount of amniotic fluid. While it can cause the uterus to measure larger than the gestational age, it typically does not present with severe abdominal pain and high blood pressure or pallor.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Polyhydramnios:
  • • Option C. Multiple Pregnancy: A multiple pregnancy (e.g., twins or triplets) can cause the uterus to measure larger than the gestational age. However, it is less likely to present with severe abdominal pain, high blood pressure, and pallor without other accompanying complications.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Multiple Pregnancy:
  • • Option D. Red Degeneration of Fibroid: This refers to the degeneration of a uterine fibroid, which can cause acute abdominal pain and a tender uterus. While it could be a consideration, the presence of high blood pressure and the specific pattern of symptoms make placental abruption a more likely diagnosis in this scenario.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Red Degeneration of Fibroid:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a pregnant woman presenting with severe abdominal pain, high blood pressure, a tender uterus that measures larger than the gestational age, and pallor, placental abruption is the most likely diagnosis.
  • ➤ In a pregnant woman presenting with severe abdominal pain, high blood pressure, a tender uterus that measures larger than the gestational age, and pallor, placental abruption is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.question_text: The following type of abnormal placenta is most often associated with placenta previa.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Succenturiate placenta

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is a succenturiate placenta ( Placenta with smaller accessory lobe)
  • • succenturiate placenta (
  • • Succenturiate lobe and big placentas are associated with placenta previa Succenturiate lobe is also associated with vasa previa
  • • Succenturiate lobe and big placentas are associated with placenta previa
  • • Succenturiate lobe is also associated with vasa previa
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • This is a circumvallate placenta
  • • circumvallate placenta
  • • Circumvallate placenta is associated with abruptio placenta, FGR, preterm labor and fetal demise. This condition involves a thickened, raised ring around the placenta.
  • • Circumvallate placenta is associated with abruptio placenta, FGR, preterm labor and fetal demise.
  • • This condition involves a thickened, raised ring around the placenta.
  • • This is a velamentous insertion (insertion of the cord into into the membranes)
  • • Velamentous insertion is associated with vasa previa
  • • Velamentous insertion is associated with vasa previa
  • • This is a Battledore Placenta (eccentrically inserted cord).It is also known as marginal insertion.It has no obstetric significance.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Succenturiate placenta, characterized by additional lobes connected to the main placenta, is most associated with placenta previa due to the increased spatial occupation of the placenta within the uterus.

options.B: Conservative management is indicated if the woman is < 37 weeks and hemodynamically stable
options.C: Adherent placenta is best diagnosed with an MRI
options.D: A transvaginal ultrasound can be safely done to diagnose placenta previa

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Adherent placenta is best diagnosed with an MRI

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The situation described is of placenta previa Adherent placenta is best diagnosed by USG and Doppler. MRI is reserved for doubtful cases like in posterior placenta TVS is safe in diagnosing placenta previa Conservative treatment is indicated in a patient less than 37 weeks who is otherwise stable High parity and increasing maternal age are risk factors for placenta previa

  • • A.

  • • Option C. Adherent Placenta is Best Diagnosed with an MRI: This statement is not entirely accurate. While MRI can be used in the diagnosis of placenta accreta (a condition where the placenta abnormally adheres to the uterine wall), ultrasound, particularly color Doppler ultrasound, is often the first-line imaging modality. MRI may be used as a supplementary tool in complex cases or when ultrasound results are inconclusive.
  • • Option

questions.question_text: The investigation of choice for placenta accreta is?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • USG with Color Flow Doppler: Investigation of choice for adherent placenta MRI: If Diagnosis is doubtful; especially useful in posterior placenta or to see invasion into adjacent structures
  • • USG with Color Flow Doppler: Investigation of choice for adherent placenta
  • • MRI: If Diagnosis is doubtful; especially useful in posterior placenta or to see invasion into adjacent structures
  • • Let us look at each option:
  • • Let us look at each option:
  • • Option A. Ultrasound: Standard ultrasound imaging can provide initial insights into placental positioning and its relationship to the uterine wall. However, it might not always provide sufficient detail to diagnose placenta accreta accurately.
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • Ultrasound:
  • • Option B. Ultrasound with Color Doppler: This is considered the investigation of choice for diagnosing placenta accreta. Color Doppler ultrasound adds the ability to visualize blood flow, which can help in identifying abnormal vascular patterns suggestive of placenta accreta.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Ultrasound with Color Doppler:
  • • Option C. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): MRI can be used as an adjunct to ultrasound, particularly in cases where ultrasound results are inconclusive or when more detailed information about the depth of placental invasion is required. However, it is not typically the first-line investigation due to its higher cost and less availability compared to ultrasound.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging):
  • • Option D. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography): CECT is not typically used in the investigation of placenta accreta, especially during pregnancy, due to concerns about radiation exposure to the fetus and the use of contrast agents.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography):

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.question_text: A 30-year woman presents to the labor room at 29 weeks with severe abdominal pain. There is no history of vaginal bleeding. Her BP on admission is 130/90 mmHg and abdominal examination reveals uterine height at 36 weeks. An ultrasound reveals the following. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Abruptio placentae

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows separation of the placenta seen in abruptio placenta
  • • The image shows separation of the placenta seen in abruptio placenta
  • • Points in favor of abruption
  • • This is concealed abruption as there is no bleeding BP: 130/90 mmHg (Abruption is commonly associated with pre-eclampsia) Uterine height > POG The image is of an ultrasound showing retroplacental clots seen in concealed abruption
  • • This is concealed abruption as there is no bleeding
  • • BP: 130/90 mmHg (Abruption is commonly associated with pre-eclampsia)
  • • Uterine height > POG
  • • The image is of an ultrasound showing retroplacental clots seen in concealed abruption
  • • Let us look at each option based on the symptoms:
  • • Let us look at each option based on the symptoms:
  • • Option A. Abruptio Placentae: Placental abruption is a condition in which the placenta detaches from the uterine wall prematurely. It can present with abdominal pain, and sometimes, especially in cases of concealed abruption, there may be no visible vaginal bleeding. The larger uterine size could be due to a collection of blood behind the placenta. Given the symptoms and the ultrasound findings, this is a likely diagnosis.
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • Abruptio Placentae:
  • • Option B. Polyhydramnios: Polyhydramnios refers to an excessive amount of amniotic fluid. While it can cause the uterus to measure larger than normal, it typically does not present with severe abdominal pain without other accompanying symptoms, such as difficulty breathing or significant swelling.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Polyhydramnios:
  • • Option C. Preterm Labor: Preterm labor involves the onset of labor contractions and changes in the cervix before 37 weeks of gestation. While it can cause abdominal pain and changes in uterine size, the description of severe pain and the ultrasound findings are more suggestive of a complication like placental abruption.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Preterm Labor:
  • • Option D. Multiple Pregnancy: A multiple pregnancy can lead to a larger uterine size than normal for gestational age. However, it does not typically present with severe abdominal pain unless there are additional complications.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Multiple Pregnancy:

questions.question_text: A 35-year woman who is a known hypertensive presents at 34 weeks gestation with abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding since an hour. Her BP is 130/90 mmHg and on examination the uterus is tense and tender. The fetal heart rate is 100 bpm. How will you manage this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Emergency LSCS

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The diagnosis in this patient is abruptio placentae with fetal distress (in view of raised BP, painful vaginal bleeding, fetal distress and a tense and tender uterus) Immediate Delivery is the rule If fetal distress/maternal shock – expedite (Cesarean delivery unless patient in advanced labor) If no fetal distress or fetal demise has already occurred OR no maternal distress: Induce/ Augment (ARM ± Oxytocin)
  • • The diagnosis in this patient is abruptio placentae with fetal distress (in view of raised BP, painful vaginal bleeding, fetal distress and a tense and tender uterus)
  • • Immediate Delivery is the rule
  • • If fetal distress/maternal shock – expedite (Cesarean delivery unless patient in advanced labor)
  • • If no fetal distress or fetal demise has already occurred OR no maternal distress: Induce/ Augment (ARM ± Oxytocin)
  • • Let's look at each option:
  • • Let's look at each option:
  • • Option A. ARM + Oxytocin (Artificial Rupture of Membranes + Oxytocin): This approach is used to induce or augment labor. Given the patient's symptoms and the potential for a serious obstetric emergency, this would not be an appropriate initial management step.
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • ARM + Oxytocin (Artificial Rupture of Membranes + Oxytocin):
  • • Option B. Emergency LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section): Most appropriate. The combination of hypertension, abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, a tense and tender uterus, and a concerning fetal heart rate suggests a high likelihood of placental abruption where the health of both mother and baby could be at risk. An emergency cesarean section is indicated to deliver the baby promptly and manage any complications effectively.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Emergency LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section):
  • • Option C. Emergency Ultrasound: While an ultrasound can provide valuable information about the status of the pregnancy, the urgency of the situation with potential fetal distress and maternal hemorrhage necessitates immediate action, likely beyond the immediate utility of an ultrasound.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Emergency Ultrasound:
  • • Option D. Do a CTG (Cardiotocography): CTG is used to monitor the fetal heart rate and uterine contractions. While it's a critical tool in assessing fetal well-being, the severity of the situation, as described, warrants immediate intervention, and there may not be sufficient time for CTG interpretation before taking action.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Do a CTG (Cardiotocography):

questions.question_text: A 36-year-old lady with multiple pregnancy conceived through IVF presents at 32 weeks with painless vaginal bleeding. This is the 2nd such episode and ultrasound revealsplacenta previa. Her PR is 80/min and BP is 110/70 mmHg. FHR 1 is 140 bpm and FHR 2 is 156 bpm. How will you manage this patient?

options.C: Arrange blood and plan cesarean at 34 weeks

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Expectant management

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Management of placenta previa is as described below: This patient can be given expectant management as she is preterm and maternal and fetal condition are stable
  • • Management of placenta previa is as described below:
  • • This patient can be given expectant management as she is preterm and maternal and fetal condition are stable
  • • Management
  • • Management
  • • Let's explore each option:
  • • Let's explore each option:
  • • Option A. Immediate Cesarean Delivery: While cesarean delivery is often necessary in cases of placenta previa, immediate delivery at 32 weeks may not be the best choice if the mother and fetuses are stable. Early delivery increases the risk of neonatal complications due to prematurity.
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • Immediate Cesarean Delivery:
  • • Option B. Expectant Management: This approach involves careful monitoring of the mother and fetuses while delaying delivery to allow for further fetal maturation, as long as the bleeding is not severe and the mother and fetuses remain stable.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Expectant Management:
  • • Option C. Arrange Blood and Plan Cesarean at 34 Weeks: Planning for a cesarean delivery at a specific future date (like 34 weeks) could be considered if the situation remains stable. However, it's important to continually assess the condition of the mother and fetuses, as the situation can change rapidly.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Arrange Blood and Plan Cesarean at 34 Weeks:
  • • Option D. Induction of Labor: Inducing labor in a case of placenta previa, especially with twins, is generally contraindicated due to the risk of severe bleeding.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Induction of Labor:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the case of a stable patient with placenta previa (even if multiple pregnancy) expectant management is often the preferred approach, allowing for continued fetal maturation while closely monitoring the mother's condition to ensure timely intervention if the situation changes.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 776, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 776, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.question_text: All are true regarding morbidly adherent placenta except.

options.A: There is absence of the decidua basalis and Nitabuch layer
options.B: MRI is useful in diagnosing accreta in posterior placentas
options.C: During cesarean a gentle attempt is made at delivering the placenta and abandoned if there is no separation
options.D: Upper segment cesarean is usually performed to deliver the baby

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) During cesarean a gentle attempt is made at delivering the placenta and abandoned if there is no separation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In morbidly adherent placenta (placenta accreta syndromes)
  • • There is absence of the decidua basalis and Nitabuch layer Delivery is by cesarean and these are very high risk due to the increased risk of haemorrhage. During cesarean, the baby is delivered by a classical cesarean No attempt is made at delivering the placenta in a known case of adherent placenta. Hysterectomy is usually performed once the baby is delivered or if conservative management, the placenta is left in situ.
  • • There is absence of the decidua basalis and Nitabuch layer
  • • Delivery is by cesarean and these are very high risk due to the increased risk of haemorrhage.
  • • During cesarean, the baby is delivered by a classical cesarean
  • • No attempt is made at delivering the placenta in a known case of adherent placenta.
  • • Hysterectomy is usually performed once the baby is delivered or if conservative management, the placenta is left in situ.
  • • Let us look at each statement:
  • • Let us look at each statement:
  • • Option A. There is Absence of the Decidua Basalis and Nitabuch Layer: True. In cases of morbidly adherent placenta, there is an absence or deficiency of the decidua basalis layer and the Nitabuch layer (a fibrinoid layer important for placental separation). This abnormality leads to the placenta adhering more deeply into the uterine wall.
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • There is Absence of the Decidua Basalis and Nitabuch Layer:
  • • Option B. MRI is Useful in Diagnosing Accreta in Posterior Placentas: True. MRI can be particularly helpful in diagnosing placenta accreta, especially when the placenta is located posteriorly in the uterus. MRI provides detailed imaging, allowing for a clearer view of the depth of placental invasion and its relationship to surrounding structures.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • MRI is Useful in Diagnosing Accreta in Posterior Placentas:
  • • Option C. During Cesarean a Gentle Attempt is Made at Delivering the Placenta and Abandoned if There is No Separation: This statement is not entirely true. In cases of suspected morbidly adherent placenta, active attempts to remove the placenta during cesarean can lead to significant bleeding and is generally avoided. Instead, the management may involve leaving the placenta in situ and opting for a conservative approach or planning a hysterectomy if necessary.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • During Cesarean a Gentle Attempt is Made at Delivering the Placenta and Abandoned if There is No Separation:
  • • Option D. Upper Segment Cesarean is Usually Performed to Deliver the Baby: True. In cases of morbidly adherent placenta, a classical cesarean section may be performed. This approach can help avoid the lower segment where the abnormal placental attachment is located, thereby reducing the risk of bleeding.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Upper Segment Cesarean is Usually Performed to Deliver the Baby:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

During cesarean, the baby is delivered by a classical cesarean No attempt is made at delivering the placenta in a known case of adherent placenta. Hysterectomy is usually performed once the baby is delivered or if conservative management, the placenta is left in situ.

  • • Loss (absence) of normal hypoechoic retroplacental myometrial zone Thinning and disruption of the uterine serosa-bladder interface with placenta protruding into posterior bladder wall Focal exophytic masses invading the bladder

  • • Thinning and disruption of the uterine serosa-bladder interface with placenta protruding into posterior bladder wall
  • • Focal exophytic masses invading the bladder
  • • Color Flow Doppler:
  • • Color Flow Doppler:
  • • Hypervascularity of serosa-bladder interface Placental vascular lacunae
  • • Hypervascularity of serosa-bladder interface
  • • Placental vascular lacunae
  • • USG with Color Flow Doppler: Investigation of choice for adherent placenta
  • • USG with Color Flow Doppler: Investigation of choice for adherent placenta
  • • MRI: If Diagnosis is doubtful; especially useful in posterior placenta
  • • MRI: If Diagnosis is doubtful; especially useful in posterior placenta
  • • Let's examine each option:
  • • Let's examine each option:
  • • Option A. Hypervascularity of the Uterine Serosa-Bladder Wall Interface: This is a characteristic feature of placenta accreta on ultrasound and Doppler. It indicates abnormal vascular connections and increased blood flow between the uterus and the placenta, often extending towards the bladder, suggesting deep placental invasion.
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • Hypervascularity of the Uterine Serosa-Bladder Wall Interface:
  • • Option B. Presence of Hypoechoic Retroplacental Zone Between the Placenta and the Uterus: In normal pregnancies, there is usually a clear hypoechoic (dark on ultrasound) zone between the placenta and the uterine wall, representing the decidua basalis. In placenta accreta, this zone is typically absent or irregular, as the placenta invades into the uterine wall. Therefore, the presence of a normal hypoechoic retroplacental zone would argue against placenta accreta.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Presence of Hypoechoic Retroplacental Zone Between the Placenta and the Uterus:
  • • Option C. Placental Vascular Lacunae: These are irregular vascular spaces within the placenta, appearing as clear areas on ultrasound. Their presence is a common and significant feature of placenta accreta, indicating abnormal blood vessels and blood flow within the placenta.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Placental Vascular Lacunae:
  • • Option D. Placental Bulging into the Posterior Bladder Wall: This finding suggests that the placenta has invaded beyond the uterine wall and is encroaching on the bladder. This is a more advanced form of placenta accreta, known as placenta percreta, and is a serious complication.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Placental Bulging into the Posterior Bladder Wall:

questions.question_text: Match the following:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A-4, B-3, C-5, D-2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Subcostal vessels and nerve run along the inferior border of the 12th rib . They are not directly associated with any of the specific diaphragmatic openings but are related to the area just below the ribcage . The sympathetic trunk runs vertically along the vertebral column . It is located posteriorly in the abdomen and is not directly associated with the diaphragmatic openings but lies behind the medial arcuate ligament. Superior epigastric vessels are continuations of the internal thoracic (mammary) artery and vein . They travel through the space of Larrey , which is a gap between the sternal and costal attachments of the diaphragm on either side. The thoracic duct is the main lymphatic duct of the body . It ascends through the aortic opening of the diaphragm at the level of T12 . The phrenic nerve provides the main motor supply to the diaphragm . The right phrenic nerve enters the thoracic cavity and passes through the caval opening ( IVC opening ) in the diaphragm .

questions.question_text: Fetal skin keratinizes by?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 22 – 24 weeks

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Fetal skin keratinizes by 22 – 25 weeks following which water transport across the fetal skin stops After keratinization of the fetal skin, transport of fluids across the skin is no longer a major contributor to amniotic fluid formation.
  • • Fetal skin keratinizes by 22 – 25 weeks following which water transport across the fetal skin stops
  • • After keratinization of the fetal skin, transport of fluids across the skin is no longer a major contributor to amniotic fluid formation.
  • • Let us look at each option :
  • • Let us look at each option :
  • • Option A. 12 – 14 weeks : At this stage, the fetus is still in the early stages of development. The epidermis, which is the outermost layer of skin, begins to form, but it's not fully developed yet. Keratinization has not started at this stage.
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • 12 – 14 weeks
  • • Option B. 16 – 18 weeks : By this time, the fetal skin has developed more layers. However, the process of keratinization is still not complete. The skin at this stage is relatively thin and transparent.
  • • Option B.
  • • 16 – 18 weeks
  • • Option C. 22 – 24 weeks (Correct Answer): This is the stage where fetal skin keratinizes. Keratinization involves the maturation of keratinocytes (skin cells) as they move from the basal layer to the surface of the skin. By this stage, the fetus has a well-formed epidermis with multiple layers, and the skin starts to become more opaque and less translucent, largely due to the accumulation of keratin.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • 22 – 24 weeks
  • • Option D . 28 – 30 weeks : The fetal skin is now more similar to postnatal skin, with a fully developed epidermal barrier. This development is crucial for the survival of the fetus outside the womb, as it plays a key role in protecting against infections and fluid loss.
  • • Option
  • • D
  • • 28 – 30 weeks

  • ➤ Ref: page no 225, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.question_text: In comparison to fetal plasma, the osmolality of amniotic fluid is
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hypo-osmolar

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Fetal urine/ amniotic fluid osmolality is about 260 mosm/l) It is less than maternal and fetal plasma (280 mosm/l) It is hypotonic This hypotonicity accounts for significant intramembranous fluid transfer across fetal vessels on the placental surface (400ml/day)
  • • Fetal urine/ amniotic fluid osmolality is about 260 mosm/l)
  • • It is less than maternal and fetal plasma (280 mosm/l)
  • • It is hypotonic
  • • This hypotonicity accounts for significant intramembranous fluid transfer across fetal vessels on the placental surface (400ml/day)
  • • Let's explore each option:
  • • Let's explore each option:
  • • Option A . Hypo-osmolar (Correct Answer): This means that the concentration of solutes in amniotic fluid is lower than in fetal plasma. The osmolality of fetal urine and amniotic fluid is approximately 260 mosm/l, which is less than that of maternal and fetal plasma (typically around 280 mosm/l).
  • • Option
  • • A
  • • Hypo-osmolar
  • • Option B. Hyper-osmolar : False. In a healthy pregnancy, amniotic fluid is less concentrated than fetal plasma.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Hyper-osmolar
  • • Option C. Same Osmolality : False. Amniotic fluid is typically hypo-osmolar compared to fetal plasma.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Same Osmolality
  • • Option D. Osmolality Increases with Gestational Age : While the composition of amniotic fluid can change throughout pregnancy, the osmolality of amniotic fluid generally remains hypo-osmolar compared to fetal plasma throughout gestation.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Osmolality Increases with Gestational Age
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Amniotic fluid is hypo-osmolar compared to fetal plasma (Option A), which plays a key role in fetal development and fluid balance across the placenta.
  • • Ref: Page no 226, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • • Ref: Page no 226, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.question_text: At term, the major contributor of amniotic fluid is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fetal urine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Let's examine each option for the major contributor of amniotic fluid at term:
  • • Option A. Fetal Urine (Correct Answer): By the time of term pregnancy, fetal urine is the primary contributor to amniotic fluid. The fetal kidneys produce urine, which is then excreted into the amniotic sac.
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • Fetal Urine (Correct Answer):
  • • Option B. Intramembranous Transfer : This refers to the movement of fluid across the membranes surrounding the fetus. While intramembranous transfer is a significant contributor to amniotic fluid volume earlier in pregnancy, its contribution is less at term compared to fetal urine.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Intramembranous Transfer
  • • Option C. Respiratory Tract Secretions : Fetal respiratory tract secretions do contribute to amniotic fluid, particularly as the fetus practices "breathing" movements in utero. However, this is not the major source of amniotic fluid at term.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Respiratory Tract Secretions
  • • Option D. Transfer Across Fetal Skin : Early in pregnancy, when the fetal skin is not fully keratinized, there can be significant fluid transfer across the skin. However, by term, the fetal skin has keratinized, significantly reducing its permeability.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Transfer Across Fetal Skin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ At term, the primary contributor to the volume of amniotic fluid is fetal urine. This reflects the maturity and functionality of the fetal kidneys, which play a crucial role in maintaining the appropriate amount and composition of amniotic fluid surrounding the fetus.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 226, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 226, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.question_text: Sonographic estimation of Amniotic fluid by Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI) is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Semi-quantitative

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Correct quantitative measurement is done only in research settings using dye-dilution method, In clinical settings - We do semiquantitative measurement by ultrasound. This is done by 2 methods: Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI) Single deepest vertical pocket measurement
  • • Correct quantitative measurement is done only in research settings using dye-dilution method,
  • • In clinical settings - We do semiquantitative measurement by ultrasound. This is done by 2 methods: Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI) Single deepest vertical pocket measurement
  • • Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI) Single deepest vertical pocket measurement
  • • Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI)
  • • Single deepest vertical pocket measurement
  • • Let us look at each option:
  • • Let us look at each option:
  • • Option A. Quantitative : A quantitative measurement would imply a precise, numerical estimation of the amniotic fluid volume. While AFI does provide numerical values, it's not a direct measurement of the exact volume but rather an index based on ultrasound findings.
  • • Option
  • • A. Quantitative
  • • :
  • • Option B. Qualitative: Qualitative measurements are descriptive and non-numerical.
  • • Option
  • • B. Qualitative:
  • • Option C. Semi-quantitative (Correct Answer): AFI is considered semi-quantitative because it provides a numerical estimate based on the depth of fluid pockets in four quadrants of the uterus. It gives a numerical value but is not a direct or precise measurement of total fluid volume, hence 'semi-quantitative'.
  • • Option
  • • C. Semi-quantitative (Correct Answer):
  • • Option D. Semi-qualitative: This term would imply a combination of numerical and descriptive assessment. Since AFI is primarily focused on providing a numerical index rather than a descriptive analysis, this term is less accurate in describing it.
  • • Option
  • • D. Semi-qualitative:

questions.question_text: A 26-year primi undergoes an ultrasound at 37 weeks for fetal wellbeing. The report says the amniotic fluid index is normal. What is a normal AFI?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 5 – 25

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI)
  • • Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI)
  • • The ultrasound transducer is held perpendicular to the floor and parallel to the long axis of the woman The uterus is divided into 4 equal quadrants – rt and left upper and lower quadrants The AFI is the sum of the single deepest pocket from each quadrant. So the unit of measurement is mm/ cm Normal value: 5 – 25 (ACOG)
  • • The ultrasound transducer is held perpendicular to the floor and parallel to the long axis of the woman
  • • The uterus is divided into 4 equal quadrants – rt and left upper and lower quadrants
  • • The AFI is the sum of the single deepest pocket from each quadrant.
  • • So the unit of measurement is mm/ cm
  • • Normal value: 5 – 25 (ACOG)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ A normal Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI) ranges from 5 to 25 cm. This range is important for assessing fetal wellbeing, as it indicates a sufficient volume of amniotic fluid for the fetus to move freely and develop properly .
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 227, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 227, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.question_text: Single deepest pocket of amniotic fluid can be used to estimate the amniotic fluid volume. The normal value is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 2 – 8 cm

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Single Deepest Pocket
  • • Single Deepest Pocket
  • • Or Maximal vertical pocket The ultrasound probe is held perpendicular to the floor and parallel to the long axis of the woman. The largest vertical pocket of fluid is identified and measured. Unit of measurement: cm/ mm The single deepest pocket of liquor is considered normal if between 2 - 8 cm More useful in 2 nd trimester assessment of amniotic fluid and in multiple gestation.
  • • Or Maximal vertical pocket
  • • The ultrasound probe is held perpendicular to the floor and parallel to the long axis of the woman.
  • • The largest vertical pocket of fluid is identified and measured.
  • • Unit of measurement: cm/ mm
  • • The single deepest pocket of liquor is considered normal if between 2 - 8 cm
  • • More useful in 2 nd trimester assessment of amniotic fluid and in multiple gestation.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The single deepest pocket (SDP) method is a valuable tool for estimating amniotic fluid volume in pregnancy, with the normal range being 2 to 8 cm. This measurement helps in assessing the adequacy of amniotic fluid, which is crucial for the normal development and wellbeing of the fetus.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 227, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.question_text: The image below shows measurement of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Amniotic fluid index

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI)
  • • Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI)
  • • The ultrasound transducer is held perpendicular to the floor and parallel to the long axis of the woman. The uterus is divided into 4 equal quadrants – right and left upper and lower quadrants
  • • The AFI is the sum of the single deepest pocket from each quadrant.
  • • So the unit of measurement is mm/ cm
  • • Normal value: 5 – 25 (ACOG)
  • • Let us look at the other options:
  • • Let us look at the other options:
  • • Option B. Deepest Vertical Pocket (DVP) of Liquor : The DVP method measures the single deepest vertical pocket of amniotic fluid without fetal parts or umbilical cord. This measurement is taken as a single deepest unobstructed vertical length. In the image, if only one pocket is being measured for its vertical length, it could represent the DVP.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Deepest Vertical Pocket (DVP) of Liquor
  • • :
  • • Option C. BPD and HC (Biparietal Diameter and Head Circumference) : These are measurements of fetal head size. BPD is the diameter between the two sides of the head, and HC is the circumference around the head. These measurements are not related to amniotic fluid and are typically not assessed in the same ultrasound view that is used for AFI or DVP.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • BPD and HC (Biparietal Diameter and Head Circumference) :
  • • Option D. Cervical Length : This measures the length of the cervix, usually to assess the risk of preterm labor. This is not what is shown in the image, as cervical length measurements are taken by transvaginal ultrasound and focus solely on the cervix, not the amniotic fluid.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Cervical Length :

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ In ultrasound assessment of a pregnant woman, the Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI) is calculated by summing the depths of the largest pockets of amniotic fluid in four quadrants of the uterus. It is a crucial parameter for assessing the well-being of the fetus, as both low and high volumes of amniotic fluid can have clinical implications.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 227, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

  • • Let us look at each option:
  • • Option A. Bartter Syndrome : This is a group of rare inherited disorders that affect the kidneys and can result in an imbalance of electrolytes, among other issues. While it's not a direct and common cause of polyhydramnios, any severe imbalance in the fetal environment that affects urine production or fluid balance could potentially contribute to polyhydramnios.
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • Bartter Syndrome
  • • Option B. Ebstein Anomaly : This is a congenital heart defect where the tricuspid valve is malformed and positioned lower than normal in the right ventricle. It can lead to heart failure and hydrops in the fetus, which can cause polyhydramnios due to an increase in fetal plasma volume and urine production.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Ebstein Anomaly
  • • Option C. Fetal Myotonic Dystrophy : This is a form of muscular dystrophy that can present in the fetus or at birth. Affected infants may have a poor swallowing reflex and decreased fetal movements, leading to polyhydramnios because the fetus is unable to swallow and absorb the amniotic fluid adequately.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Fetal Myotonic Dystrophy
  • • Option D. Posterior Urethral Valve (PUV) : This is an obstructive congenital anomaly found in males, where there is a blockage in the urethra caused by excess tissue growth. This condition typically causes oligohydramnios (reduced amniotic fluid) rather than polyhydramnios, due to the obstruction of urinary flow out of the bladder, leading to less fluid being contributed to the amniotic sac.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Posterior Urethral Valve (PUV)

questions.question_text: A 20-year primigravida is diagnosed to have duodenal atresia on her routine level 2 scan done at 20 weeks. Which of the following would NOT have been seen on the ultrasound?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Macrosomia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Duodenal atresia is associated with other anomalies (Cardiac, renal & vertebral in 10%) On ultrasound – Double bubble sign Polyhydramnios
  • • Duodenal atresia is associated with other anomalies (Cardiac, renal & vertebral in 10%)
  • • On ultrasound – Double bubble sign Polyhydramnios
  • • Double bubble sign Polyhydramnios
  • • Double bubble sign
  • • Polyhydramnios
  • • Double bubble sign
  • • Duodenal atresia is a congenital defect in which there is a closure or absence of a portion of the lumen of the duodenum. It can be diagnosed prenatally during a routine level 2 scan at around 20 weeks of gestation. Let's look at each option:
  • • Option A. Associated Cardiac Anomalies : Duodenal atresia is commonly associated with other anomalies, including cardiac anomalies. About 30% of infants with duodenal atresia also have congenital heart disease.
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • Associated Cardiac Anomalies
  • • Option B. Double Bubble Sign : This sign refers to two distinct fluid-filled areas seen on ultrasound, representing the stomach and the proximal duodenum. It is a classic sign of duodenal atresia as the duodenum is distended due to the obstruction.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Double Bubble Sign
  • • Option C. Macrosomia : This term refers to a newborn who is significantly larger than average, often defined as a birth weight of more than 4,000 to 4,500 grams. Macrosomia would not be a finding in the case of duodenal atresia, especially at 20 weeks, since it generally refers to the condition of a newborn at birth. Duodenal atresia may cause growth issues due to nutrient malabsorption, but it is not associated with an increased fetal size in utero.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Macrosomia
  • • Option D. Polyhydramnios : Since the fetus is unable to properly process and absorb amniotic fluid due to the atresia, this can lead to an accumulation of fluid in the amniotic sac.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Polyhydramnios

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ On a prenatal ultrasound, the "double bubble" sign is indicative of duodenal atresia, and associated cardiac anomalies may also be present. Polyhydramnios can occur due to the fetus's inability to swallow and absorb amniotic fluid properly. Macrosomia, which describes a newborn with a significantly larger than average birth weight, is not related to duodenal atresia and would not be seen on the ultrasound at 20 weeks of gestation
  • ➤ Page no 229, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • ➤ Page no 229, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

  • • Loss of Amniotic fluid

  • • Others

  • • Idiopathic
  • • Idiopathic
  • • Let us look at each option:
  • • Let us look at each option:
  • • Option A. Prelabor Rupture of Membranes (PROM) : PROM refers to the breaking of the amniotic sac and leakage of amniotic fluid before the onset of labor. This can lead to a significant decrease in the amount of amniotic fluid, causing oligohydramnios. This condition is more common in the later stages of pregnancy but can occur at any time after the mid-second trimester.
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • Prelabor Rupture of Membranes (PROM) :
  • • Option B. Bilateral Multicystic Dysplastic Kidneys : This is a condition where the kidneys develop cysts and are nonfunctional from birth. Since the kidneys are responsible for producing urine, which contributes significantly to amniotic fluid, their dysfunction can lead to reduced fluid production and oligohydramnios.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Bilateral Multicystic Dysplastic Kidneys :
  • • Option C. Prematurity (Correct Answer): Prematurity, per se, is not a direct cause of oligohydramnios. Oligohydramnios is more typically associated with specific fetal or maternal conditions rather than the gestational age of the fetus. Prematurity may be a consequence of other complications in pregnancy but is not a cause of oligohydramnios.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Prematurity (Correct Answer):
  • • Option D. Posterior Urethral Valve : This condition is an obstruction of the male urethra. It can lead to a decrease in the amount of urine reaching the amniotic sac, which in turn can result in oligohydramnios.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Posterior Urethral Valve :

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Oligohydramnios, a condition marked by insufficient amniotic fluid, can be caused by factors such as the prelabor rupture of membranes, renal abnormalities like bilateral multicystic dysplastic kidneys, and obstructive uropathies like posterior urethral valve. Prematurity itself is not a cause of oligohydramnios; rather, it may be a result of complications including oligohydramnios during pregnancy. Early detection and management of oligohydramnios are crucial for optimizing fetal outcomes .

questions.question_text: A 36-yearprimigravida presented for an anomaly scan at 20 weeks. The following image was noted on the ultrasound along with polyhydramnios. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Duodenal atresia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Duodenal atresia is associated with other anomalies (Cardiac, renal & vertebral in 10%) On ultrasound – Double bubble sign (as seen in the image in the question) Polyhydramnios Posterior urethral valve and rena l agenesis will have Oligohydrmanios Cystic hygroma will appear as a septated swelling:
  • • Duodenal atresia is associated with other anomalies (Cardiac, renal & vertebral in 10%)
  • • On ultrasound – Double bubble sign (as seen in the image in the question) Polyhydramnios
  • • Double bubble sign (as seen in the image in the question) Polyhydramnios
  • • Double bubble sign (as seen in the image in the question)
  • • Polyhydramnios
  • • Posterior urethral valve and rena l agenesis will have Oligohydrmanios
  • • Cystic hygroma will appear as a septated swelling:
  • • Let us look at each option :
  • • Let us look at each option :
  • • Option A. Cystic Hygroma : This is a fluid-filled sac that results from a blockage in the lymphatic system. It typically appears as a large, cystic mass in the neck region of the fetus. While cystic hygroma can be associated with other abnormalities, it does not directly cause polyhydramnios .
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • Cystic Hygroma :
  • • Option B. Duodenal Atresia (Correct Answer): This is characterized by a blockage in the duodenum, which is part of the small intestine. On an ultrasound, duodenal atresia is suggested by the "double bubble" sign – two distinct fluid-filled areas seen in the fetal abdomen, representing the stomach and the proximal duodenum. Polyhydramnios is often present because the fetus cannot swallow and absorb amniotic fluid normally due to the intestinal obstruction.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Duodenal Atresia
  • • (Correct Answer):
  • • Option C. Posterior Urethral Valve : This condition, which occurs only in males, is characterized by a blockage in the urethra due to abnormal tissue growth. The key ultrasound finding is typically a dilated bladder and, in some cases, hydronephrosis (swelling of the kidneys). This condition is more likely to lead to oligohydramnios (reduced amniotic fluid) rather than polyhydramnios.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Posterior Urethral Valve :
  • • Option D. Renal Agenesis : This is the absence of one or both kidneys. When both kidneys are absent (bilateral renal agenesis), there is usually oligohydramnios because the fetus cannot produce urine to contribute to the amniotic fluid.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Renal Agenesis :

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The diagnosis of duodenal atresia is suggested by the presence of a "double bubble" sign on ultrasound. This finding, combined with polyhydramnios, is indicative of an obstruction in the fetal gastrointestinal tract, specifically at the duodenum, leading to an accumulation of amniotic fluid.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 229, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

Detecting PUV is critical because it can lead to significant morbidity if not addressed promptly after birth

questions.question_text: Potter's sequence is seen in all the following except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Tracheoesophageal fistula

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Potter's sequence is the effect chronic oligohydramnios has on the fetus. It includes
  • • Growth restriction Pulmonary hypoplasia Potter facies (low set ears, flattened nose and micrognathia) Limb contractures and club foot.
  • • Growth restriction
  • • Pulmonary hypoplasia
  • • Potter facies (low set ears, flattened nose and micrognathia)
  • • Limb contractures and club foot.
  • • Causes of early onset oligohydramnios like bilateral fetal renal anomalies or very preterm rupture of membranes can cause Potters sequence. Tracheo-esophageal fistula causes polyhydramnios
  • • Causes of early onset oligohydramnios like bilateral fetal renal anomalies or very preterm rupture of membranes can cause Potters sequence.
  • • Tracheo-esophageal fistula causes polyhydramnios
  • • Let's look at each option :
  • • Let's look at each option :
  • • Option A. Bilateral Polycystic Kidney Disease : This condition can cause the kidneys to be nonfunctional due to the replacement of normal kidney tissue with multiple cysts. It can result in oligohydramnios and lead to the development of Potter's sequence .
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • Bilateral Polycystic Kidney Disease
  • • Option B. Renal Agenesis : This refers to the congenital absence of one or both kidneys. Bilateral renal agenesis is directly associated with Potter's sequence because without kidneys, the fetus cannot produce urine, leading to a significant reduction in amniotic fluid.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Renal Agenesis
  • • Option C. Early Preterm Premature Rupture of Membranes (PPROM) : PPROM can lead to the leakage of amniotic fluid long before the pregnancy has reached term, which can result in prolonged oligohydramnios. This can cause the physical deformities characteristic of Potter's sequence due to the lack of cushioning fluid around the fetus.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Early Preterm Premature Rupture of Membranes (PPROM)
  • • Option D. Tracheoesophageal Fistula : This is a congenital anomaly where there is an abnormal connection (fistula) between the trachea and the esophagus. While this condition can result in polyhydramnios due to the inability of the fetus to swallow and absorb amniotic fluid, it does not cause oligohydramnios.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Tracheoesophageal Fistula

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Potter's sequence is associated with conditions that lead to oligohydramnios, such as bilateral renal agenesis, bilateral polycystic kidney disease, and situations causing chronic leakage of amniotic fluid like early PPROM. It is characterized by a set of physical deformities that arise due to the lack of amniotic fluid and the resulting compression of the developing fetus.
  • ➤ Ref: page no 231, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: page no 231, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

Faintly alkaline Low specific gravity (1.010) Hypotonic at term; osmolarity; 250mOsm /I at term (decreases with increasing age) Color Contains lanugo, exfoliated squamous epithelial, vernix caseosa etc.
