  • • Color
  • • Contains lanugo, exfoliated squamous epithelial, vernix caseosa etc.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The normal pH of amniotic fluid is slightly alkaline, usually around 7.2. Amniotic fluid pH is a vital sign of the fetal environment, and deviations from the normal range can indicate potential clinical concerns that may necessitate further investigation and intervention.

questions.question_text: A 25 -year primi is diagnosed to have polyhydramnios. She complains of severe discomfort due to the over distended abdomen. You decide to start indomethacin to reduce the liquor. Which of the following is a contra indication for using this drug?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gestational age > 32 weeks

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Indomethacin and sulindac are used in the treatment of severe polyhydramnios However, if given after 32 weeks: there is risk of premature closure of the ductus arteriosus and hence are contra-indicated after 32 weeks
  • • Indomethacin and sulindac are used in the treatment of severe polyhydramnios
  • • However, if given after 32 weeks: there is risk of premature closure of the ductus arteriosus and hence are contra-indicated after 32 weeks
  • • Premature closure can lead to pulmonary hypertension and heart failure in the fetus.
  • • Let's look at the other options:
  • • Let's look at the other options:
  • • Option B. Polyhydramnios due to anencephaly : Polyhydramnios can occur in this setting because the fetus cannot swallow amniotic fluid normally, leading to its accumulation. While indomethacin may be used to reduce fluid volume, it doesn't address the underlying condition, which is incompatible with life outside the womb.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Polyhydramnios due to anencephaly
  • • Option C. Muscular dystrophy in the fetus : Fetal muscular dystrophy may be associated with polyhydramnios due to decreased fetal swallowing and movement. Indomethacin would not be a contraindication unless the gestational age is beyond 32 weeks or other specific risks are identified.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Muscular dystrophy in the fetus
  • • Option D . Non-immune hydrops : This is a condition characterized by abnormal accumulation of fluid in two or more fetal compartments. While indomethacin may reduce the amniotic fluid component, it's not the treatment for the underlying causes of non-immune hydrops. Indomethacin use is not strictly contraindicated by the presence of hydrops itself .
  • • Option
  • • D
  • • .
  • • Non-immune hydrops

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Indomethacin is contraindicated for use in reducing amniotic fluid volume in the context of polyhydramnios when the gestational age is greater than 32 weeks due to the increased risk of adverse fetal effects, such as premature closure of the ductus arteriosus .
  • ➤ Indomethacin is contraindicated for use in reducing amniotic fluid volume in the context of polyhydramnios when the gestational age is greater than 32 weeks due to the increased risk of adverse fetal effects, such as premature closure of the ductus arteriosus .

questions.question_text: A 30-year G3 is in labor at 37 weeks. At 5cm cervical dilatation, an amniotomy is done. Golden color of amniotic fluid is seen. What could be a possible cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rh isoimmunization

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Color of liquor –
  • • In early pregnancy: It is colorless Straw colored: Near term Deep yellow/ golden color: Fetal anemia Green (meconium stained): fetal distress or post-maturity Red: Abruption Dark colored/ tobacco like: Fetal demise
  • • In early pregnancy: It is colorless
  • • Straw colored: Near term
  • • Deep yellow/ golden color: Fetal anemia
  • • Green (meconium stained): fetal distress or post-maturity
  • • Red: Abruption
  • • Dark colored/ tobacco like: Fetal demise
  • • Now, let us look at each option:
  • • Option A. Fetal Demise : Amniotic fluid may become discolored due to the breakdown of fetal red blood cells and the release of bile pigment. The fluid is more likely to appear dark or brownish, often referred to as "port-wine" colored due to hemolysis.
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • Fetal Demise
  • • Option B. Fetal Distress : Fetal distress can lead to the passage of meconium into the amniotic fluid, which typically gives the fluid a greenish tint.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Fetal Distress
  • • Option C. Rh Isoimmunization : This occurs when an Rh-negative mother becomes sensitized to Rh-positive fetal red blood cells. The immune response leads to hemolysis of the fetal red blood cells, and the release of bilirubin, which can give the amniotic fluid a yellow or golden color. This condition is also known as hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN).
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Rh Isoimmunization
  • • Option D. Post Maturity : Post maturity refers to a pregnancy that extends beyond 42 weeks. Post maturity is more commonly associated with oligohydramnios (low amniotic fluid volume) and the presence of meconium, which would make the fluid greenish if the fetus has passed stool.
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • Post Maturity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Color of liquor –
  • ➤ In early pregnancy: It is colorless Straw colored: Near term Deep yellow/ golden color: Fetal anemia Green (meconium stained): fetal distress or post-maturity Red: Abruption Dark colored/ tobacco like: Fetal demise
  • ➤ In early pregnancy: It is colorless
  • ➤ Straw colored: Near term
  • ➤ Deep yellow/ golden color: Fetal anemia Green (meconium stained): fetal distress or post-maturity Red: Abruption Dark colored/ tobacco like: Fetal demise
  • ➤ Green (meconium stained): fetal distress or post-maturity Red: Abruption Dark colored/ tobacco like: Fetal demise
  • ➤ Green (meconium stained): fetal distress or post-maturity
  • ➤ Red: Abruption
  • ➤ Dark colored/ tobacco like: Fetal demise

It would typically present with a smaller uterine size relative to gestational age, not larger. Fetal parts may be more easily palpable due to the decreased cushioning from the amniotic fluid, and the FHR would not necessarily be distant or faint.

questions.question_text: A 34y G3P2 presents to the OPD at 34 weeks. She has had 2 previous lower segment cesarean sections and an done at 28 weeks shows an anterior low-lying placenta. She does not complain of bleeding. On examination, the uterus is 32 weeks, cephalic presentation and the FHR is 145 bpm. What is the next best step?

options.A: Order an ultrasound with a Doppler

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • She is at an increased risk of placental accrete syndromes as she has 2 previous cearean sections and an anterior placenta previa The risk of placenta accreta increases with the number of previous cesareans Any patient with a previous cesarean, with placenta previa in the current pregnancy is at an increased risk for placenta acrrete syndromes The investigation of choice in placenta accreta syndromes is an ultrasound doppler and this should be done in this patient
  • • She is at an increased risk of placental accrete syndromes as she has 2 previous cearean sections and an anterior placenta previa
  • • The risk of placenta accreta increases with the number of previous cesareans
  • • Any patient with a previous cesarean, with placenta previa in the current pregnancy is at an increased risk for placenta acrrete syndromes
  • • The investigation of choice in placenta accreta syndromes is an ultrasound doppler and this should be done in this patient
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Opton B: As the patient does not have to be delivered right now, steroids are not indicated Option C: An Elective cesarean section may have to be planned if placenta previa (At 37 weeks) or if placenta acrrete syndromes (between 34 - 37 weeks) but the question asked is the next best step and this is to rule out placenta acrrete syndromes by doing a Doppler Option D: A repeat ultrasound may have to be done but that again is not the next best step.
  • • Opton B: As the patient does not have to be delivered right now, steroids are not indicated
  • • Option C: An Elective cesarean section may have to be planned if placenta previa (At 37 weeks) or if placenta acrrete syndromes (between 34 - 37 weeks) but the question asked is the next best step and this is to rule out placenta acrrete syndromes by doing a Doppler
  • • Option D: A repeat ultrasound may have to be done but that again is not the next best step.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The risk of placenta acrrete syndromes (PAS) increases with the number of prior cesarean sections. A patient with placenta previa with a h/o previous cesarean section should be investigated for placenta accrete syndromes (PAS)
  • ➤ The risk of placenta acrrete syndromes (PAS) increases with the number of prior cesarean sections.
  • ➤ A patient with placenta previa with a h/o previous cesarean section should be investigated for placenta accrete syndromes (PAS)
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1967, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.question_text: Which is incorrect regarding the pathophysiology of placenta accrete syndromes?

options.A: The abnormal adherence is due to partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer
options.B: Microscopically, the placental villi are found attached to smooth muscle fibers
options.C: There is a close relationship between cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and later development of Placenta accrete syndromes in the same pregnancy
options.D: About 15% of all accrete syndromes are placenta percreta

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The ratio of occurrence of placenta accreta: increta: percreta is 80:15:5; i.e. 5% of all adherent placentas are placenta percreta and hence this statement is incorrect The term placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) describes aberrant placentation characterized by abnormally implanted, invasive, or adhered placenta. It is also referred to as morbidly adherent placenta, The major problem if placenta accreta syndrome occurs is failure of placenta tto separate normally from the myometrium after fetal delivery. Attempts to seperate an adherent placenta can lead to torrential hemorrhage This abnormal adherence stems in part from partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer If the decidual spongy layer is lacking either partially or totally, the physiological line of cleavage is absent, and some or all cotyledons are densely anchored. Microscopically, placental villi attach to smooth muscle fibers rather than to decidual cells. Factors implicated in the pathogenesis An antecedent “constitutional endometrial defect” in most cases is found like a history of a previous cesarean section Some tissue specimens show immunologically mediated “hyperinvasiveness” Some genes that code for remodeling and for adherence may be highly expressed There is a close relationship between cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and later development of PAS in the same pregnancy.
  • • The ratio of occurrence of placenta accreta: increta: percreta is 80:15:5; i.e. 5% of all adherent placentas are placenta percreta and hence this statement is incorrect
  • • The term placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) describes aberrant placentation characterized by abnormally implanted, invasive, or adhered placenta.
  • • It is also referred to as morbidly adherent placenta,
  • • The major problem if placenta accreta syndrome occurs is failure of placenta tto separate normally from the myometrium after fetal delivery. Attempts to seperate an adherent placenta can lead to torrential hemorrhage
  • • This abnormal adherence stems in part from partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer
  • • If the decidual spongy layer is lacking either partially or totally, the physiological line of cleavage is absent, and some or all cotyledons are densely anchored.
  • • Microscopically, placental villi attach to smooth muscle fibers rather than to decidual cells.
  • • Factors implicated in the pathogenesis An antecedent “constitutional endometrial defect” in most cases is found like a history of a previous cesarean section Some tissue specimens show immunologically mediated “hyperinvasiveness” Some genes that code for remodeling and for adherence may be highly expressed There is a close relationship between cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and later development of PAS in the same pregnancy.
  • • An antecedent “constitutional endometrial defect” in most cases is found like a history of a previous cesarean section Some tissue specimens show immunologically mediated “hyperinvasiveness” Some genes that code for remodeling and for adherence may be highly expressed There is a close relationship between cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and later development of PAS in the same pregnancy.
  • • An antecedent “constitutional endometrial defect” in most cases is found like a history of a previous cesarean section
  • • like a history of a previous cesarean section
  • • Some tissue specimens show immunologically mediated “hyperinvasiveness”
  • • Some genes that code for remodeling and for adherence may be highly expressed
  • • There is a close relationship between cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and later development of PAS in the same pregnancy.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Placenta Accrete Syndromes, the abnormal adherence stems in part from partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1974, Williams Obstetric 26 th edition

questions.question_text: A 34y G2P1 with a previous LSCS presented at 30 weeks with painless vaginal bleeding. The following image was seen on ultrasound doppler. Which of the following is not seen in placenta accreta?

questions.question_text: Match the condition with the time of delivery:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Abruption is an acute emergency situation and requires immediate delivery Placenta previa should be delivered at 37 weeks unless there is an acute episode of bleeding leading to maternal and/or fetal distress Placenta Accreta should also be delivered between 34-37 weeks before a woman goes into labor.
  • • Abruption is an acute emergency situation and requires immediate delivery
  • • Placenta previa should be delivered at 37 weeks unless there is an acute episode of bleeding leading to maternal and/or fetal distress
  • • Placenta Accreta should also be delivered between 34-37 weeks before a woman goes into labor.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Delivery in different scenarions of APH
  • ➤ Delivery in different scenarions of APH
  • ➤ In Abruption: Delivery is asap irrespective of Period of gestation as it is an acute emrgency; Route of delivery depends on the situation at hand. If Bishop score is favourbale and maternal and fetal condition are good, induction of labor can be done. However in the event of maternal shock or fetal distress, cesarean is preferred In Placenta previa: Elective LSCS at 37 weeks (For minor degree placenta previas, vaginal delivery can be attempted). Delivery may be done earlier if there is excessive bleeding or fetal distress In Placenta accreta, Delivery is ALWAYS by casearan (classical cesarean) which is preferably done electively between 34-37 weeks and this is followed by a hysterectomy without seperating the placenta.
  • ➤ In Abruption: Delivery is asap irrespective of Period of gestation as it is an acute emrgency; Route of delivery depends on the situation at hand. If Bishop score is favourbale and maternal and fetal condition are good, induction of labor can be done. However in the event of maternal shock or fetal distress, cesarean is preferred
  • ➤ In Placenta previa: Elective LSCS at 37 weeks (For minor degree placenta previas, vaginal delivery can be attempted). Delivery may be done earlier if there is excessive bleeding or fetal distress
  • ➤ In Placenta accreta, Delivery is ALWAYS by casearan (classical cesarean) which is preferably done electively between 34-37 weeks and this is followed by a hysterectomy without seperating the placenta.

questions.question_text: A 24y G2P1 with a previous LSCS presented at 28 weeks with painless mild vaginal bleeding. She had a previous similar episode 2 weeks earlier. A scan done was suspicious for placenta accreta and this was confirmed on a Doppler. What is the next best step in management?

options.A: Plan an elective LSCS at 37 weeks
options.B: Plan an elective classical section at 37 weeks

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Management of placenta accreta involves Planning delivery between 34-37 weeks Delivery is usually by a classical cesarean (upper segment) to avoid the placenta Following delivery of the baby, a hysterectomy is carried out with the placenta in situ Conservative approaches like leaving the placenta in situ and resection and repair of uterus are less commonly done.
  • • Management of placenta accreta involves Planning delivery between 34-37 weeks Delivery is usually by a classical cesarean (upper segment) to avoid the placenta Following delivery of the baby, a hysterectomy is carried out with the placenta in situ

  • • Following delivery of the baby, a hysterectomy is carried out with the placenta in situ
  • • Conservative approaches like leaving the placenta in situ and resection and repair of uterus are less commonly done.
  • • Other options
  • • Other options
  • • Option A & C: Lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) is not done for placenta accreta syndromes as the placenta is usually adherent in the lower segment Option D: As the patient is currently stable and bleeding is mild, immediate cesarean is not indicated
  • • Option A & C: Lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) is not done for placenta accreta syndromes as the placenta is usually adherent in the lower segment

questions.question_text: Ligation of which of the following vessels in the retroperitoneum will reduce the pulse pressure in a patient who is bleeding during surgery for placenta accreta syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Internal iliac artery ligation is performed in obstetric hemorrhage like PPH and placenta accreta syndromes It is part of devascularization surgeries to reduce blood loss in massive obstetric hemorrhage along with uterine artery and utero-ovarian artery ligation The most important mechanism of action with internal iliac artery ligation is an 85-percent reduction in pulse pressure in those arteries distal to the ligation and a 50% reducition in blood flow to the uterus This converts an arterial pressure system into one with pressures approaching those in the venous circulation. This creates vessels more amenable to hemostasis via pressure and clot formation.
  • • Internal iliac artery ligation is performed in obstetric hemorrhage like PPH and placenta accreta syndromes
  • • It is part of devascularization surgeries to reduce blood loss in massive obstetric hemorrhage along with uterine artery and utero-ovarian artery ligation
  • • The most important mechanism of action with internal iliac artery ligation is an 85-percent reduction in pulse pressure in those arteries distal to the ligation and a 50% reducition in blood flow to the uterus
  • • This converts an arterial pressure system into one with pressures approaching those in the venous circulation. This creates vessels more amenable to hemostasis via pressure and clot formation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Uterine artery ligation is the 1st vessel ligated in devascularization surgery but it does not reduce the pulse pressure as effectively as does internal iliac artery ligation
  • • Option C: External iliac artery: Is not ligated as part of devascularization as it does not supply the uterus
  • • Option D: utero-ovarian anastomoses ligation is done as part of devasculariazation surgery but it does not reduce the pulse pressure as effectively as does internal iliac artery ligation

questions.question_text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman, G4P3 at 28 weeks of gestation, presents with recurrent episodes of painless vaginal bleeding over the past 1 week. Her medical history is significant for 1 previous cesarean delivery and 1 dilatation and curettage of a previous incomplete abortion. On examination, her vital signs are stable, and the fetal heart rate is reassuring. Abdominal ultrasound reveals a placenta located near the cervix with multiple hypoechoic areas and irregular vascular spaces within the placenta. Laboratory results show an Hb of 8g%. Which of the following is the most appropriate management option?

options.A: Immediate cesarean followed by bilateral internal iliac artery ligation
options.B: Administration of corticosteroids, transfuse blood, followed by a planned cesarean at 37 weeks.
options.C: Serial ultrasound monitoring with plans of delivery if evidence of increasing vascularity in the placenta
options.D: Admit, transfuse blood, give steroids and plan an elective cesarean delivery with hysterectomy at 36 weeks of pregnancy

questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Admit, transfuse blood, give steroids and plan an elective cesarean delivery with hysterectomy at 36 weeks of pregnancy.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is a clinical scenario of placenta accreta syndromes as the history of previous cesarean and D & C with the current ultrasound findings support this diagnosis Treatment of placenta accreta syndromes includes Stabilization of the patient Planning an elective cesarean delivery (preferably a classical cesarean) at 34-37 weeks, leaving the placenta in situ followed by a hysterectomy as any attempts to remove an adherent placenta result in severe hemorrhage
  • • This is a clinical scenario of placenta accreta syndromes as the history of previous cesarean and D & C with the current ultrasound findings support this diagnosis
  • • Treatment of placenta accreta syndromes includes Stabilization of the patient Planning an elective cesarean delivery (preferably a classical cesarean) at 34-37 weeks, leaving the placenta in situ followed by a hysterectomy as any attempts to remove an adherent placenta result in severe hemorrhage
  • • Stabilization of the patient Planning an elective cesarean delivery (preferably a classical cesarean) at 34-37 weeks, leaving the placenta in situ followed by a hysterectomy as any attempts to remove an adherent placenta result in severe hemorrhage

  • • Other options
  • • Other options
  • • Option A: As the patient is stable currently, immediate cesarean is not warranted as she is only 29 weeks Option B: This would have been correct but option D is a better option in the scenario of accreta. If only placenta previa, this would have been the preferred option Option C: There is no role of looking at increasing vascularity on ultrasound and it will not change the management.

questions.question_text: What is the best management option for a patient diagnosed with placenta increta at 36 weeks pregnancy?

options.A: Planned elective classical cesarean at 37 weeks; placenta to be left in situ
options.B: Planned elective classical cesarean at 37 weeks followed by hysterectomy
options.C: Emergency classical cesarean section now followed by hysterectomy
options.D: Emergency classical cesarean section now; placenta to be left in situ

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Placenta accrete syndromes includes placenta accreta, placenta increta and placenta percreta As the placenta is adherent to the myometrium, any attempt at separation of the placenta at delivery leads to torrential hemorrhage The best management option thus is to plan an elective cesarean between 34-37 weeks (before the patient goes into labor). Avoid an emergency cesarean unless really required. The cesarean is usually a classical cesarean (upper segment) as the most common site of adherence is in the lower segment (usually at the site of a previous cesarean section) After delivery of the baby, the cord is clamped; no attempt at separation of placenta is done and a hysterectomy is done. Leaving the placenta in situ is not preferred to be done but has been occasionally reported by a few. It may lead to secondary haemorrhage and/ or infection thereby necessitating hysterectomy.
  • • Placenta accrete syndromes includes placenta accreta, placenta increta and placenta percreta
  • • As the placenta is adherent to the myometrium, any attempt at separation of the placenta at delivery leads to torrential hemorrhage
  • • The best management option thus is to plan an elective cesarean between 34-37 weeks (before the patient goes into labor). Avoid an emergency cesarean unless really required.
  • • The cesarean is usually a classical cesarean (upper segment) as the most common site of adherence is in the lower segment (usually at the site of a previous cesarean section)
  • • After delivery of the baby, the cord is clamped; no attempt at separation of placenta is done and a hysterectomy is done.
  • • Leaving the placenta in situ is not preferred to be done but has been occasionally reported by a few. It may lead to secondary haemorrhage and/ or infection thereby necessitating hysterectomy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Planned elective classical cesarean at 37 weeks; placenta to be left in situ: Although the 1 st part is correct, leaving the placenta in situ isn’t advocated as most studies say that the incidence of secondary hemorrhage/ infection is very high Option C: Emergency classical cesarean section now followed by hysterectomy There is no indication for doing an emergency cesarean section. An elective planned cesarean is always preferred in placenta accrete syndromes Option D: Emergency classical cesarean section now; placenta to be left in situ There is no indication for an emergency and as mentioned above the placenta should not be left in situ
  • • Option A: Planned elective classical cesarean at 37 weeks; placenta to be left in situ: Although the 1 st part is correct, leaving the placenta in situ isn’t advocated as most studies say that the incidence of secondary hemorrhage/ infection is very high
  • • Option A:
  • • Although the 1 st part is correct, leaving the placenta in situ isn’t advocated as most studies say that the incidence of secondary hemorrhage/ infection is very high
  • • Although the 1 st part is correct, leaving the placenta in situ isn’t advocated as most studies say that the incidence of secondary hemorrhage/ infection is very high
  • • Option C: Emergency classical cesarean section now followed by hysterectomy There is no indication for doing an emergency cesarean section. An elective planned cesarean is always preferred in placenta accrete syndromes
  • • Option C:
  • • There is no indication for doing an emergency cesarean section. An elective planned cesarean is always preferred in placenta accrete syndromes
  • • There is no indication for doing an emergency cesarean section. An elective planned cesarean is always preferred in placenta accrete syndromes
  • • Option D: Emergency classical cesarean section now; placenta to be left in situ There is no indication for an emergency and as mentioned above the placenta should not be left in situ
  • • Option D:
  • • There is no indication for an emergency and as mentioned above the placenta should not be left in situ
  • • There is no indication for an emergency and as mentioned above the placenta should not be left in situ

  • ➤ The best management option for Placenta Accrete Syndromes (PAS) is to plan an elective cesarean between 34-37 weeks (before the patient goes into labor). Avoid an emergency cesarean unless really required. The cesarean is usually a classical cesarean (upper segment) as the most common site of adherence is in the lower segment (usually at the site of a previous cesarean section) After delivery of the baby, the cord is clamped; no attempt at separation of placenta is done and a hysterectomy is done.
  • ➤ The best management option for Placenta Accrete Syndromes (PAS) is to plan an elective cesarean between 34-37 weeks (before the patient goes into labor). Avoid an emergency cesarean unless really required.

questions.question_text: A 23y primi presents in labor. She is an unbooked patient and by her LMP, she is 42 weeks and 4 days. On examination she is 6 cm dilated, well effaced and the vertex is at 0 station. A CTG taken is as shown below. What could be the reason for the findings in the CTG shown below?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The patient is post term, in labor and the CTG is showing variable decelerations (As there is no relation between the decelerations and the uterine contractions) Variable decelerations occur because of cord compression which is seen in oligohydramnios which is seen in post term pregnancy

  • • Other options

  • • Option A: Cord prolapse will usually present with prolonged deceleration/ fetal bradycardia/ fetal death. Option B: Meconium, if associated with fetal hypoxia will present with later decelerations. Option D: Uteroplacental insufficiency will present as late decelerations.

Contraception : One of the primary uses of LNG-IUS is contraception. questions.question_text: A 19y unmarried nulliparous girl comes to the OPD. She is sexually active and wants to know more about the contraceptive options available to her. All can be recommended to her except?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Contraceptive of choice in adolescents is dual method i.e condom + any other form of contraception (Condom prevents against STI’s) Methods commonly used in adolescence: Barrier (male condom, female condom) Hormonal contraception: Combined OCPs Extended cyclic pills Progestin only pills Transdermal patches Vaginal contraceptive ring (Nuva ring) Injectable hormonal contraceptives DMPA Progestin implants (Implanaon, Norplant) Intra-Uterine Devices
  • • Contraceptive of choice in adolescents is dual method i.e condom + any other form of contraception (Condom prevents against STI’s)
  • • Methods commonly used in adolescence: Barrier (male condom, female condom) Hormonal contraception: Combined OCPs Extended cyclic pills Progestin only pills Transdermal patches Vaginal contraceptive ring (Nuva ring) Injectable hormonal contraceptives DMPA Progestin implants (Implanaon, Norplant) Intra-Uterine Devices
  • • Barrier (male condom, female condom) Hormonal contraception: Combined OCPs Extended cyclic pills Progestin only pills Transdermal patches Vaginal contraceptive ring (Nuva ring) Injectable hormonal contraceptives DMPA Progestin implants (Implanaon, Norplant) Intra-Uterine Devices
  • • Barrier (male condom, female condom)
  • • Hormonal contraception: Combined OCPs Extended cyclic pills Progestin only pills Transdermal patches Vaginal contraceptive ring (Nuva ring) Injectable hormonal contraceptives DMPA Progestin implants (Implanaon, Norplant)
  • • Combined OCPs Extended cyclic pills Progestin only pills Transdermal patches Vaginal contraceptive ring (Nuva ring) Injectable hormonal contraceptives DMPA Progestin implants (Implanaon, Norplant)

  • • Extended cyclic pills
  • • Progestin only pills
  • • Transdermal patches
  • • Vaginal contraceptive ring (Nuva ring)
  • • Injectable hormonal contraceptives DMPA
  • • DMPA
  • • DMPA
  • • Progestin implants (Implanaon, Norplant)
  • • Intra-Uterine Devices
  • • Ulipristal acetate is a Selective Progesterone Receptor Modulator and is used as an emergency contraceptive.
  • • Let us look at each option:
  • • Option A: Depot Medroxyprogesterone Acetate (DMPA) : This is an injectable form of contraception that is administered every three months. It is a progestin-only method, making it suitable for women who may not be able to use estrogen-containing contraceptives. DMPA is highly effective and convenient for those who prefer not to take a daily pill. Option B: Vaginal Contraceptive Ring : The vaginal ring is a small, flexible ring that a woman inserts into her vagina. It releases estrogen and progestin, similar to combination oral contraceptives, but requires less frequent attention as it is typically changed monthly. It is a convenient and effective form of contraception. Option C: Progestin Implants : These are small rods implanted under the skin of the arm that release a steady dose of progestin. They can provide long-term contraception for up to three to five years. The implant is a highly effective, low-maintenance option. Option D: Ulipristal Acetate (Correct Answer): Ulipristal acetate is used as an emergency contraceptive, not a regular method of contraception. It is intended for use after unprotected intercourse or contraceptive failure (like a broken condom) to prevent pregnancy. It's not designed for ongoing, regular use as a contraceptive method.

It is a progestin-only method, making it suitable for women who may not be able to use estrogen-containing contraceptives. DMPA is highly effective and convenient for those who prefer not to take a daily pill.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When advising a sexually active young woman on contraceptive options, it is important to discuss a range of choices, including hormonal methods like depot medroxyprogesterone acetate injections, vaginal contraceptive rings, and progestin implants. Each of these offers long-term contraception with varying administration methods to suit different preferences. Ulipristal acetate, however, is an emergency contraceptive and is not suitable for regular contraceptive use.

questions.question_text: A 23y woman has been using the transdermal patch as a contraceptive method. She visits the OPD with the complaint that the patch was partially detached for more than a day. What will you advise her?

options.A: To reapply the patch with another adhesive
options.C: To apply a new patch and use a condom for 1 week
options.D: To remove the patch and use a condom till her next period

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • If the patch was detached for less than 24 h, the same patch can be reattached or a replaced with a new one. If a patch is partially or completely detached for more than one day (24 hours or more) OR if the woman is not sure how long the patch has been detached, she may not be protected from pregnancy. She should stop the current contraceptive cycle and start a new cycle immediately by applying a new patch. Back-up contraception, such as a condom, spermicide, or diaphragm, must be used for the first week of the new cycle.
  • • If the patch was detached for less than 24 h, the same patch can be reattached or a replaced with a new one.
  • • If a patch is partially or completely detached for more than one day (24 hours or more) OR if the woman is not sure how long the patch has been detached, she may not be protected from pregnancy. She should stop the current contraceptive cycle and start a new cycle immediately by applying a new patch. Back-up contraception, such as a condom, spermicide, or diaphragm, must be used for the first week of the new cycle.
  • • OR

questions.question_text: All the following can be given as contraceptives in a lactating mother except?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • In lactating women, Estrogen containing contraceptives are not preferred to be given as they reduce the quantity and quality of breast milk. Progesterone containing contraceptives and non – hormonal contraceptives can be safely given. Amongst the given options Implanon – contains etonorgestrel Minipill – contains progesterone (Norethisterone OR Levonorgestrel OR Desogestrel) LNG-IUS contains Levonorgestrel Nuva Ring – contains both Estrogen and Progesterone (ethinyl estradiol and etonorgestrel)
  • • In lactating women, Estrogen containing contraceptives are not preferred to be given as they reduce the quantity and quality of breast milk.
  • • Progesterone containing contraceptives and non – hormonal contraceptives can be safely given.
  • • Amongst the given options Implanon – contains etonorgestrel Minipill – contains progesterone (Norethisterone OR Levonorgestrel OR Desogestrel) LNG-IUS contains Levonorgestrel Nuva Ring – contains both Estrogen and Progesterone (ethinyl estradiol and etonorgestrel)
  • • Implanon – contains etonorgestrel Minipill – contains progesterone (Norethisterone OR Levonorgestrel OR Desogestrel) LNG-IUS contains Levonorgestrel Nuva Ring – contains both Estrogen and Progesterone (ethinyl estradiol and etonorgestrel)
  • • Implanon – contains etonorgestrel
  • • Minipill – contains progesterone (Norethisterone OR Levonorgestrel OR Desogestrel)
  • • LNG-IUS contains Levonorgestrel
  • • Nuva Ring – contains both Estrogen and Progesterone (ethinyl estradiol and etonorgestrel)
  • • Let's review each option:
  • • Option A: Implanon (Nexplanon) : Implanon is a progestin-only contraceptive implant that is inserted under the skin of the upper arm. It releases a small amount of hormone over time. Progestin-only methods are generally considered safe for use during lactation as they have minimal effect on milk production and are unlikely to harm the nursing infant. Option B. Minipill : The minipill is a progestin-only oral contraceptive. Like Implanon, it is generally safe for use during breastfeeding. The progestin-only formulation is less likely to affect milk supply compared to combined oral contraceptives that contain both estrogen and progestin. Option C: LNG-IUS (Levonorgestrel-releasing Intrauterine System) : The LNG-IUS, like Mirena, releases levonorgestrel, a type of progestin, and is inserted into the uterus. It is considered safe for use in breastfeeding mothers as it has minimal systemic hormonal effects and primarily acts locally on the uterine lining. Option D: NuvaRing (Correct Answer): The NuvaRing is a combined hormonal contraceptive that contains both estrogen and progestin. Estrogen-containing contraceptives are typically not recommended for breastfeeding mothers, especially in the early postpartum period.
  • • Option A: Implanon (Nexplanon) : Implanon is a progestin-only contraceptive implant that is inserted under the skin of the upper arm. It releases a small amount of hormone over time. Progestin-only methods are generally considered safe for use during lactation as they have minimal effect on milk production and are unlikely to harm the nursing infant.
  • • Option A: Implanon (Nexplanon)
  • • Option B. Minipill : The minipill is a progestin-only oral contraceptive. Like Implanon, it is generally safe for use during breastfeeding. The progestin-only formulation is less likely to affect milk supply compared to combined oral contraceptives that contain both estrogen and progestin.
  • • Option B.
  • • Minipill
  • • Option C: LNG-IUS (Levonorgestrel-releasing Intrauterine System) : The LNG-IUS, like Mirena, releases levonorgestrel, a type of progestin, and is inserted into the uterus. It is considered safe for use in breastfeeding mothers as it has minimal systemic hormonal effects and primarily acts locally on the uterine lining.
  • • Option C:
  • • LNG-IUS (Levonorgestrel-releasing Intrauterine System)
  • • Option D: NuvaRing (Correct Answer): The NuvaRing is a combined hormonal contraceptive that contains both estrogen and progestin. Estrogen-containing contraceptives are typically not recommended for breastfeeding mothers, especially in the early postpartum period.
  • • Option D: NuvaRing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For lactating mothers (< 6 months post-partum), estrogen containing contraceptives are contra-indicated.

questions.question_text: A 20 y P2L2 who delivered 2 months back has decided to take progesterone only pill as a contraceptive. What important advice should be given?

options.B: Take the tablet at the same time everyday
options.D: It can be used as emergency contraception

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Progesterone only pills (POP) are also known as mini-pills They can be started after delivery in lactating/ non lactating women or within the first 5 days (preferably 1 st day) of the periods. POPs are safe in lactation. Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs) containing both estrogen (E) and progesterone (P) reduce the quantity and quality of breast milk and thus are contraindicated in lactation Mini pills are best taken at the same time everyday. If there is a dose delay of > 3 h, a backup method should be used for 48h but for desogestrel (Cerazette) containing POPs, the safety margin is 12 hours No other contraceptive is required with POP unless there has been a dose delay. It cannot be used as an emergency contraception. High dose OCPs (E + P) can be used as emergency contraception.
  • • Progesterone only pills (POP) are also known as mini-pills
  • • They can be started after delivery in lactating/ non lactating women or within the first 5 days (preferably 1 st day) of the periods.
  • • POPs are safe in lactation. Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs) containing both estrogen (E) and progesterone (P) reduce the quantity and quality of breast milk and thus are contraindicated in lactation
  • • Mini pills are best taken at the same time everyday.
  • • If there is a dose delay of > 3 h, a backup method should be used for 48h but for desogestrel (Cerazette) containing POPs, the safety margin is 12 hours
  • • No other contraceptive is required with POP unless there has been a dose delay.
  • • It cannot be used as an emergency contraception. High dose OCPs (E + P) can be used as emergency contraception.
  • • Let us look at each option:
  • • Option A: Stop Breastfeeding : This advice is not appropriate. The progesterone-only pill is actually a preferred choice for breastfeeding mothers because it does not affect milk supply as estrogen-containing contraceptives can. It is safe to use while breastfeeding. Option B: Take the Tablet at the Same Time Every Day (Correct Answer): This is crucial advice for a woman taking the progesterone-only pill. The effectiveness of the POP depends on consistent daily intake at the same time each day. The time window for taking the POP is narrower than for combined oral contraceptives; a delay of even a few hours can decrease its effectiveness and increase the risk of pregnancy. Option C: Use Barrier Contraception Also : While using barrier methods in addition can provide extra protection against sexually transmitted infections (STIs), it is not a requirement for the effectiveness of the POP. Option D: It Can be Used as Emergency Contraception : The regular progesterone-only pill is not intended for use as emergency contraception. There are specific emergency contraceptive pills available for that purpose.
  • • Option A: Stop Breastfeeding : This advice is not appropriate. The progesterone-only pill is actually a preferred choice for breastfeeding mothers because it does not affect milk supply as estrogen-containing contraceptives can. It is safe to use while breastfeeding.
  • • Option A: Stop Breastfeeding
  • • Option B: Take the Tablet at the Same Time Every Day (Correct Answer): This is crucial advice for a woman taking the progesterone-only pill. The effectiveness of the POP depends on consistent daily intake at the same time each day. The time window for taking the POP is narrower than for combined oral contraceptives; a delay of even a few hours can decrease its effectiveness and increase the risk of pregnancy.
  • • Option B:
  • • Take the Tablet at the Same Time Every Day
  • • Option C: Use Barrier Contraception Also : While using barrier methods in addition can provide extra protection against sexually transmitted infections (STIs), it is not a requirement for the effectiveness of the POP.
  • • Option C: Use Barrier Contraception Also
  • • Option D: It Can be Used as Emergency Contraception : The regular progesterone-only pill is not intended for use as emergency contraception. There are specific emergency contraceptive pills available for that purpose.
  • • Option D: It Can be Used as Emergency Contraception

questions.question_text: Amongst the following, which has the lowest failure rate?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • **Remember: Implants (Implanon) have the lowest failure rate
  • • **Remember: Implants (Implanon) have the lowest failure rate
  • • Let's review the options provided :
  • • Let's review the options provided
  • • Option A: LNG-IUS (Levonorgestrel-releasing Intrauterine System) : The LNG-IUS, such as Mirena, is a highly effective form of contraception with a failure rate of less than 1%. It works by releasing levonorgestrel, a type of progestin, into the uterus, which thickens cervical mucus and thins the endometrial lining. Option B: Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs) : These pills contain both estrogen and progestin. When taken correctly, they have a low failure rate, typically around 0.3% with perfect use. However, the failure rate can be higher (around 7-9%) with typical use, due to missed pills or incorrect timing of intake. Option C: Progesterone-Only Pills (Minipill) : The minipill has a slightly higher failure rate than combined OCPs, typically around 0.3% with perfect use but up to 9% with typical use. This increased failure rate with typical use is partly due to the need for strict adherence to taking the pill at the same time every day. Option D: Implanon (Nexplanon) : This is a subdermal contraceptive implant that releases etonogestrel, a type of progestin. Implanon/Nexplanon is one of the most effective forms of contraception available, with a failure rate of less than 0.05%. Its effectiveness is not reliant on daily compliance, which contributes to its high success rate.
  • • Option A: LNG-IUS (Levonorgestrel-releasing Intrauterine System) : The LNG-IUS, such as Mirena, is a highly effective form of contraception with a failure rate of less than 1%. It works by releasing levonorgestrel, a type of progestin, into the uterus, which thickens cervical mucus and thins the endometrial lining.

  • • Option B: Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs) : These pills contain both estrogen and progestin. When taken correctly, they have a low failure rate, typically around 0.3% with perfect use. However, the failure rate can be higher (around 7-9%) with typical use, due to missed pills or incorrect timing of intake.

This increased failure rate with typical use is partly due to the need for strict adherence to taking the pill at the same time every day.

  • • Progesterone-Only Pills (Minipill)
  • • Option D: Implanon (Nexplanon) : This is a subdermal contraceptive implant that releases etonogestrel, a type of progestin. Implanon/Nexplanon is one of the most effective forms of contraception available, with a failure rate of less than 0.05%. Its effectiveness is not reliant on daily compliance, which contributes to its high success rate.
  • • Option D: Implanon (Nexplanon)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The contraceptive implant (Implanon/Nexplanon) has the lowest failure rate among the options listed, making it one of the most effective forms of birth control available. Its high effectiveness is due to the constant release of hormones and the elimination of the need for daily adherence, unlike oral contraceptive pills.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 392. DC Dutta’s Textbook og Gynecology, 7 th edition

questions.question_text: What is the earliest time when breastfeeding women can start taking Progestin only Pills (POPs) after delivery?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Progesterone only pills (POP) are also known as mini-pills They can be started after delivery in lactating/ non lactating women or within the first 5 days (preferably 1 st day) of the periods. POPs are safe in lactation. Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs) containing both estrogen (E) and progesterone (P) reduce the quantity and quality of breast milk and thus are contraindicated in lactation Mini pills are best taken at the same time every day. If there is a dose delay of > 3 h, a backup method should be used for 48h but for desogestrel containing POPs, the safety margin is 12 hours No other contraceptive is required with POP unless there has been a dose delay. It cannot be used as an emergency contraception. High dose OCPs (E + P) can be used as emergency contraception.
  • • Progesterone only pills (POP) are also known as mini-pills
  • • They can be started after delivery in lactating/ non lactating women or within the first 5 days (preferably 1 st day) of the periods.
  • • POPs are safe in lactation. Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs) containing both estrogen (E) and progesterone (P) reduce the quantity and quality of breast milk and thus are contraindicated in lactation
  • • Mini pills are best taken at the same time every day.
  • • If there is a dose delay of > 3 h, a backup method should be used for 48h but for desogestrel containing POPs, the safety margin is 12 hours
  • • No other contraceptive is required with POP unless there has been a dose delay.
  • • It cannot be used as an emergency contraception. High dose OCPs (E + P) can be used as emergency contraception.
  • • Let us look at each option:
  • • Let us look at each option:
  • • Option A: After 6 weeks postpartum : Traditionally, many types of contraception, particularly those containing estrogen, are recommended to start after 6 weeks postpartum to avoid interfering with lactation . However, this is not the earliest time for POPs. Option B: Immediately after giving birth (Correct Answer): Progestin-only pills can be started immediately after delivery. They are safe to use during breastfeeding as they do not affect milk supply or quality. Their immediate use postpartum can be beneficial for providing effective contraception without a gap. Option C: After 6 months postpartum : Waiting 6 months is unnecessary for POPs. Option D: Cannot start POPs while breastfeeding : This statement is incorrect. POPs are recommended for breastfeeding women because they do not contain estrogen, which can interfere with milk supply.
  • • Option A: After 6 weeks postpartum : Traditionally, many types of contraception, particularly those containing estrogen, are recommended to start after 6 weeks postpartum to avoid interfering with lactation . However, this is not the earliest time for POPs.
  • • Option A: After 6 weeks postpartum
  • • Option B: Immediately after giving birth (Correct Answer): Progestin-only pills can be started immediately after delivery. They are safe to use during breastfeeding as they do not affect milk supply or quality. Their immediate use postpartum can be beneficial for providing effective contraception without a gap.
  • • Option B:
  • • Immediately after giving birth
  • • Option C: After 6 months postpartum : Waiting 6 months is unnecessary for POPs.
  • • Option C:
  • • After 6 months postpartum
  • • Option D: Cannot start POPs while breastfeeding : This statement is incorrect. POPs are recommended for breastfeeding women because they do not contain estrogen, which can interfere with milk supply.
  • • Option D: Cannot start POPs while breastfeeding

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Progestin-only pills are a safe and effective contraceptive option for breastfeeding women and can be started immediately after childbirth. They do not affect breast milk supply or quality, making them a suitable choice for postpartum contraception. This immediate initiation helps in providing effective contraceptive coverage without any gap post-delivery.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 403, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 403, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7 th edition

questions.question_text: The primary mechanism of action of the Combined Oral Contraceptives is:

options.A: Preventing ovulation by suppressing FSH and LH
options.C: Helping prevent implantation by suppressing development of the endometrium
options.D: Hampering sperm transport by thickening cervical mucus

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The main action of combined oral contraceptives is: Ovulation suppression: Most important Other effects Endometrial atrophy Cervical mucus thickening Alteration of ovum transport
  • • The main action of combined oral contraceptives is: Ovulation suppression: Most important
  • • Ovulation suppression: Most important
  • • Ovulation suppression: Most important
  • • Other effects Endometrial atrophy Cervical mucus thickening Alteration of ovum transport
  • • Endometrial atrophy Cervical mucus thickening Alteration of ovum transport
  • • Endometrial atrophy
  • • Cervical mucus thickening
  • • Alteration of ovum transport
  • • Since the main mechanism of action is asked; the answer is Prevention of ovulation
  • • Let's explore each option:
  • • Let's explore each option:
  • • Option A . Preventing ovulation by suppressing FSH and LH (Correct Answer): COCs primarily prevent ovulation. They achieve this by suppressing the secretion of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) from the pituitary gland. Without the surge in LH, ovulation does not occur.
  • • Option A
  • • Preventing ovulation by suppressing FSH and LH
  • • Option B . Destroying the ovum : COCs do not work by destroying the ovum. They primarily prevent the ovum from being released from the ovary.
  • • Option B
  • • Destroying the ovum
  • • Option C . Helping prevent implantation by suppressing development of the endometrium : While COCs do cause some thinning of the endometrium, making it less receptive to implantation, this is not their primary mechanism of action. It's more of a secondary effect that contributes to the contraceptive efficacy in case ovulation does occur.
  • • Option C
  • • Helping prevent implantation by suppressing development of the endometrium
  • • Option D. Hampering sperm transport by thickening cervical mucus : This is another secondary mechanism of action of COCs. The progestin component in the COCs thickens the cervical mucus, making it more difficult for sperm to travel through the cervix and into the uterus.
  • • Option D.
  • • Hampering sperm transport by thickening cervical mucus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary mechanism of action of combined oral contraceptives is the suppression of ovulation through the inhibition of the hormones FSH and LH. Secondary mechanisms, such as alterations in the endometrial lining and thickening of cervical mucus, further enhance their contraceptive effectiveness. Top of Form
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 398, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 398, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7 th edition

questions.question_text: Match the name of the contraceptive (as made available by the Govt of India) with the drug it contains?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The contraceptives marketed by the Govt of India are as follows
  • • Chhaya : Contains Ormeloxifene, a selective estrogen receptor modulator used as a non-hormonal, non-steroidal contraceptive, starting with twice a week for the first 12 weeks, followed by a maintenance dose of once a week from the 13th week onwards.
  • • Chhaya
  • • Antara : Contains Medroxyprogesterone acetate, a progestin used in injectable contraceptives. It is typically administered every three months and is a hormonal contraceptive method.
  • • Antara
  • • Mala N : Contains Levonorgestrel and Ethinyl Estradiol. Mala N is an example of a combined oral contraceptive pill that includes both estrogen and progestin.
  • • Mala N
  • • E-pill : Contains Levonorgestrel. This is used as an emergency contraceptive pill and is taken after unprotected sexual intercourse to prevent pregnancy.
  • • E-pill
  • • Based on this information, the correct matching is:
  • • B. 1c (Chhaya - Ormeloxifene), 2b (Antara - Medroxyprogesterone acetate), 3a (Mala N - Levonorgestrel + Ethinyl Estradiol), 4d (E-pill - Levonorgestrel).

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Ormeloxifene (Chhaya) is a non-hormonal option, Medroxyprogesterone acetate (Antara) is a hormonal injectable, Mala N is a combined oral contraceptive, and Levonorgestrel (E-pill) is used for emergency contraception.

questions.question_text: Combined oral contraceptive pills are associated with a decreased risk of all the following cancers except?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Oral contraceptives decrease the risk of 3 cancers Endometrial Ovarian Colorectal Oral contraceptives increase the risk of 2 cancers Breast Cervical (no clear association but some studies have observed a slight increase in the incidence) Slight increase in the risk of liver adenomas
  • • Oral contraceptives decrease the risk of 3 cancers Endometrial Ovarian Colorectal
  • • Endometrial Ovarian Colorectal
  • • Endometrial
  • • Ovarian
  • • Colorectal
  • • Oral contraceptives increase the risk of 2 cancers Breast Cervical (no clear association but some studies have observed a slight increase in the incidence) Slight increase in the risk of liver adenomas
  • • Breast Cervical (no clear association but some studies have observed a slight increase in the incidence) Slight increase in the risk of liver adenomas
  • • Breast
  • • Cervical (no clear association but some studies have observed a slight increase in the incidence)
  • • Slight increase in the risk of liver adenomas
  • • Let us look at each option separately:
  • • Option A . Cervical Cancer (Correct Answer): The use of COCs has been linked with an increased risk of cervical cancer. This risk appears to increase with the duration of COC use and declines after cessation of use. The increased risk is thought to be related to the role of human papillomavirus (HPV) in cervical carcinogenesis, with COCs possibly affecting the body's immune response to HPV or the progression of HPV infection to cervical cancer.
  • • Option A
  • • Cervical Cancer
  • • Option B. Colorectal Cancer : Several studies have shown a reduced risk of colorectal cancer in women who use COCs. The mechanism behind this protective effect is not fully understood .
  • • Option B.
  • • Colorectal Cancer
  • • Option C. Endometrial Cancer : COCs have been consistently associated with a reduced risk of endometrial cancer. This protective effect is believed to be due to the progestin component of COCs, which opposes the proliferative effect of estrogen on the endometrium and reduces the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and subsequent malignancy.
  • • Option C.
  • • Endometrial Cancer
  • • Option D. Ovarian Cancer : Use of COCs has also been linked to a decreased risk of ovarian cancer. The risk reduction appears to be substantial and increases with the duration of use. This protective effect is thought to be related to the suppression of ovulation that occurs with COC use, as each ovulation event is a potential opportunity for malignant transformation in the ovarian epithelium.
  • • Option D.
  • • Ovarian Cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Oral contraceptives decrease the risk of 3 cancers Endometrial Ovarian Colorectal Oral contraceptives increase the risk of 2 cancers Breast Cervical (no clear association but some studies have observed a slight increase in the incidence) Slight increase in the risk of liver adenomas
  • ➤ Oral contraceptives decrease the risk of 3 cancers Endometrial Ovarian Colorectal

  • ➤ Breast Cervical (no clear association but some studies have observed a slight increase in the incidence) Slight increase in the risk of liver adenomas

questions.question_text: A 35y old woman who has 2 children is seeking an effective contraceptive method. She has an asymptomatic subserous fibroid of 7 cm. She also has a history of DVT 3 years earlier. Which would be the most appropriate contraceptive for her?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • As there is a history of DVT, Estrogen containing contraceptives cannot be used. Both the vaginal ring and the transdermal patch contain estrogen and hence cannot be used in this patient. Male condom can be used but has a high failure rate LNG-IUS is the best option as Long acting The fibroid is not distorting the cavity (subserous) Effective
  • • As there is a history of DVT, Estrogen containing contraceptives cannot be used. Both the vaginal ring and the transdermal patch contain estrogen and hence cannot be used in this patient.
  • • Male condom can be used but has a high failure rate
  • • LNG-IUS is the best option as Long acting The fibroid is not distorting the cavity (subserous) Effective
  • • Long acting The fibroid is not distorting the cavity (subserous) Effective
  • • Long acting
  • • The fibroid is not distorting the cavity (subserous)
  • • Effective
  • • Let's look at each option separately:
  • • Option A. Vaginal Ring : The vaginal ring, such as NuvaRing, releases estrogen and progestin. Estrogen-containing contraceptives are generally not recommended for women with a history of DVT because estrogen can increase the risk of blood clots.
  • • Option A.
  • • Vaginal Ring
  • • Option B. Transdermal Patch : Similar to the vaginal ring, the transdermal patch (e.g., Ortho Evra) also contains estrogen. Therefore, it is not recommended for women with a history of thrombotic events like DVT due to the increased risk of clot formation.
  • • Option B.
  • • Transdermal Patch
  • • Option C. LNG-IUS (Levonorgestrel-releasing Intrauterine System) (Correct Answer): The LNG-IUS, such as Mirena, releases a small amount of progestin locally within the uterus. It does not contain estrogen and has a lower risk of thrombosis compared to systemic hormonal methods. Additionally, it can be beneficial in managing symptoms related to fibroids, such as heavy menstrual bleeding, though it does not reduce the size of the fibroid itself.
  • • Option C.
  • • LNG-IUS (Levonorgestrel-releasing Intrauterine System)
  • • Option D. Male Condom : While male condoms are a safe option for contraception and do not pose any risk of thrombosis, they are less effective than hormonal methods or intrauterine devices when considering typical use failure rates. They may not be the most effective choice for someone seeking highly reliable contraception.
  • • Option D.
  • • Male Condom

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ For a woman with a history of DVT and an asymptomatic subserous fibroid, a progestin-only method like the LNG-IUS is a suitable and effective contraceptive choice. Estrogen-containing contraceptives (such as the vaginal ring and transdermal patch) should be avoided due to the increased risk of thrombosis. The LNG-IUS provides effective contraception, has a lower risk of thrombosis, and can help manage symptoms associated with fibroids.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 393, 402, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 393, 402, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7 th edition

However, uncontrolled hypertension with BP 150/90 mmHg falls under Category 3, where the risks usually outweigh the benefits but may be considered if no better alternatives exist.

questions.question_text: A 24y woman visits the family planning clinic seeking contraceptive advice. She wants to know more about the non-contraceptive benefits of combined oral contraceptive pills. These are all except?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Non-contraceptive benefits of hormonal contraceptives include:
  • • Decreased risk of endometrial, ovarian and colorectal cancers Improved bone mineral density Reduction in anemia (Reduced menorrhagia) Menstrual cycle regularity Fibroid uterus (Reduced symptoms) Treatment of dysmenorrhea Treatment of endometriosis Treatment of premenstrual syndrome
  • • Decreased risk of endometrial, ovarian and colorectal cancers
  • • Improved bone mineral density
  • • Reduction in anemia (Reduced menorrhagia)
  • • Menstrual cycle regularity
  • • Fibroid uterus (Reduced symptoms)
  • • Treatment of dysmenorrhea
  • • Treatment of endometriosis
  • • Treatment of premenstrual syndrome
  • • **OCPS cause impaired glucose tolerance and increase the risk of Diabetes
  • • Let's review each option:
  • • Option A. Prevention of Ovarian Cancer : COCs have been shown to reduce the risk of ovarian cancer. This protective effect is believed to be due to the suppression of ovulation that occurs with COC use, as each ovulation event is a potential opportunity for malignant transformation in the ovarian epithelium.
  • • Option A.
  • • Prevention of Ovarian Cancer
  • • Option B . Reduction in Dysmenorrhea : COCs can alleviate menstrual pain (dysmenorrhea) by regulating menstrual cycles and reducing the volume of menstrual flow. The hormonal regulation provided by COCs can make periods more predictable and less painful.
  • • Option B
  • • Reduction in Dysmenorrhea
  • • Option C. Prevention of Anemia : By regulating menstrual cycles and reducing menstrual flow, COCs can help prevent iron-deficiency anemia in women who experience heavy menstrual bleeding.
  • • Option C.
  • • Prevention of Anemia
  • • Option D . Prevention of Diabetes (Correct Answer): There is no substantial evidence to suggest that COCs prevent diabetes. In fact, COCs can affect glucose metabolism and may not be the preferred choice in women with a history of diabetes or significant risk factors for diabetes.
  • • Option D
  • • Prevention of Diabetes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ While combined oral contraceptive pills offer several non-contraceptive health benefits, including reducing the risks of ovarian cancer and anemia, and alleviating dysmenorrhea, they do not provide a protective effect against the development of diabetes. In some cases, COCs can affect glucose metabolism and should be used cautiously in women with or at risk for diabetes.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 401, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7 th edition
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Page no 401, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7 th edition

The implant is off-white, non-biodegradable and 4 cm in length with a diameter of 2 Each implant consists of 68 mg of the synthetic progestin etonogestrel. Once inserted subdermally, the initial release rate is 60 to 70 mcg/day in Week 5 to 6 and decreases to approximately 35 to 45 mcg/day at the end of the first year Life span: 3 years Lowest failure rate amongst all contraceptives (0.05%)

  • • The implant is off-white, non-biodegradable and 4 cm in length with a diameter of 2
  • • Each implant consists of 68 mg of the synthetic progestin etonogestrel.
  • • Once inserted subdermally, the initial release rate is 60 to 70 mcg/day in Week 5 to 6 and decreases to approximately 35 to 45 mcg/day at the end of the first year
  • • Life span: 3 years
  • • Lowest failure rate amongst all contraceptives (0.05%)
  • • Let us look at each option:
  • • Option A . Desogestrel : This progestin is used in certain oral contraceptive pills but is not typically used in contraceptive implants.
  • • Option A
  • • Desogestrel
  • • Option B . Etonorgestrel (Correct Answer in Context): Etonorgestrel is the active ingredient in the Nexplanon implant, a commonly used contraceptive implant. Etonorgestrel is a synthetic form of progesterone and is effective in preventing ovulation.

  • • Option D. Norethisterone
  • • Norethisterone
  • • The Nexplanon implant, which contains etonorgestrel, is a long-acting reversible contraceptive that is inserted under the skin of the upper arm. It provides up to three years of contraceptive protection.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The contraceptive implant Nexplanon contains etonorgestrel, a synthetic form of progesterone, and provides long-acting contraception for up to three years. It is a convenient and effective contraceptive method, particularly for those seeking a long-term, reversible option.

questions.question_text: A 38y woman opts for LNG-IUS for contraception. After 6 months she reports back to the OPD with complaints of periods of amenorrhea with irregular spotting. She had previous regular cycles and a pap smear done prior to insertion of the LNG-IUS was normal. What is the best next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • LNG-IUS is a 3 rd generation Intrauterine device It contains levonorgestrel and mainly acts by causing endometrial atrophy A common side effect is amenorrhoea and irregular spotting for which only reassurance is required 80% of women are amenorrhoeic by the end of 1 year Effective life: 5 years Failure rate: 0.1%
  • • LNG-IUS is a 3 rd generation Intrauterine device
  • • It contains levonorgestrel and mainly acts by causing endometrial atrophy
  • • A common side effect is amenorrhoea and irregular spotting for which only reassurance is required
  • • 80% of women are amenorrhoeic by the end of 1 year
  • • Effective life: 5 years
  • • Failure rate: 0.1%
  • • **Since pap smear was normal 6 months back, there is no indication for a colposcopy
  • • ** There is no indication to remove the LNG-IUS
  • • **USG for endometrial thickness is not required as this is a known side effect of LNG-IUS
  • • Let us look at each option:
  • • Option A. Colposcopy : This is a diagnostic procedure to examine the cervix for signs of disease, typically indicated if there are abnormal findings on a Pap smear. Since the patient had a normal Pap smear prior to the insertion of the LNG-IUS and her current symptoms are related to menstrual changes, colposcopy is not indicated in this case.
  • • Option A.
  • • Colposcopy
  • • Option B . Remove the LNG-IUS : Removal of the LNG-IUS is generally reserved for situations where there are serious complications or persistent, unacceptable side effects. Irregular spotting and periods of amenorrhea are common and expected side effects of the LNG-IUS, especially in the first 6 to 12 months of use.
  • • Option B
  • • Remove the LNG-IUS
  • • Option C. Reassure the patient (Correct Answer): The most appropriate step in this scenario is to reassure the patient. The LNG-IUS releases levonorgestrel locally within the uterus, which can lead to thinning of the endometrial lining and result in changes to menstrual bleeding patterns, including lighter periods, irregular spotting, or amenorrhea. These changes are considered normal side effects of the LNG-IUS and often stabilize within the first year of use.
  • • Option C.
  • • Reassure the patient
  • • Option D . Ultrasound for Endometrial Thickness : While ultrasound can be used to assess endometrial thickness, it is not typically indicated in this scenario unless there are other symptoms or clinical findings suggestive of endometrial pathology.
  • • Option D
  • • Ultrasound for Endometrial Thickness

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Irregular spotting and episodes of amenorrhea are common side effects of the Levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system (LNG-IUS) and usually stabilize within the first year of use. These effects are due to the local action of levonorgestrel on the endometrium. Patients experiencing these changes without other concerning symptoms can generally be reassured about the normalcy of these side effects.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 403, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 403, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7 th edition

questions.question_text: An 18y unmarried girl has been using Mala N as a contraceptive method. She comes to the family planning OPD on Day 24 of her period with the complaint that she has missed taking the pills on Day 22 and 23. She is extremely worried and anxious about the risk of conceiving as she had unprotected intercourse on Day 6. What will you advise her?

options.A: Take both the missed tablets immediately, use additional contraceptive method for 7 days and advise emergency contraception
options.B: Take the last missed pill as soon as possible, use additional contraceptive for 7 days and omit the 7-day pill free period
options.C: Use emergency contraception and continue taking the remaining pills
options.D: Use emergency contraception and discard the remaining pills.

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Management of Missed Pill
  • • ** In this question, she has missed 2 pills in the 3 rd week. Hence, she should take the last missed pill, use additional contraception and omit the pill free interval and start the next pack immediately after finishing the current pack.
  • • Here's an explanation of the options:
  • • Option A. Take both the missed tablets immediately, use an additional contraceptive method for 7 days, and advise emergency contraception : Taking both missed pills at once is not necessary and may increase the risk of side effects like nausea. Emergency contraception is not typically recommended in this scenario.
  • • Option A.
  • • Take both the missed tablets immediately, use an additional contraceptive method for 7 days, and advise emergency contraception
  • • Option B . Take the last missed pill as soon as possible, use additional contraceptive for 7 days, and omit the 7-day pill-free period (Correct Answer): This is the recommended action for missing two consecutive pills in the third week of the cycle. She should take the most recently missed pill as soon as possible (even if it means taking two pills in one day) and then continue with the rest of the pack as normal, without taking a 7-day pill-free break. Using an additional contraceptive method, like condoms, for the next 7 days is important to ensure protection against pregnancy.
  • • Option B
  • • Take the last missed pill as soon as possible, use additional contraceptive for 7 days, and omit the 7-day pill-free period
  • • Option C. Use emergency contraception and continue taking the remaining pills : Emergency contraception is usually not necessary if the missed pills are managed correctly, as described in option B. However, if there is significant concern about pregnancy risk or if the guidance for missed pills is not followed correctly, emergency contraception could be considered.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Use emergency contraception and continue taking the remaining pills
  • • Option D . Use emergency contraception and discard the remaining pills : Discarding the remaining pills is not advised. Instead, she should continue taking her pills as per the guidance for missed pills to maintain contraceptive protection.
  • • Option
  • • D
  • • Use emergency contraception and discard the remaining pills

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the case of missing two consecutive combined oral contraceptive pills in the third week, the recommended approach is to take the last missed pill as soon as possible (ignoring the earlier missed pill), continue taking the remaining pills as scheduled, use an additional contraceptive method for the next 7 days, and skip the 7-day pill-free break. This approach helps maintain contraceptive protection and reduces the risk of pregnancy due to the missed pills. Emergency contraception is typically not necessary if these steps are followed.
  • ➤ Ref: Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Health Care Clinical Effectiveness Unit. CEU Statement (May 2011). Missed Pill Recommendations. 2011. http://www.fsrh.org/pdfs/CEUStatementMissedPills.pdf (Accessed 19th August 2021)
  • ➤ Ref: Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Health Care Clinical Effectiveness Unit. CEU Statement (May 2011). Missed Pill Recommendations. 2011.
  • ➤ http://www.fsrh.org/pdfs/CEUStatementMissedPills.pdf

questions.question_text: A 24y woman comes to the gyn OPD seeking contraceptive advice. She is married and has a 4-year-old son. She is a known epileptic and is on lamotrigine. Which of the following contraceptives will require you to increase the dose of lamotrigine?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Combined oral contraceptive pills induce lamotrigene metabolism, thereby reducing plasma levels. Women taking OCPs and on lamotrigene are advised to increase the dose of lamotrigine
  • • Combined oral contraceptive pills induce lamotrigene metabolism, thereby reducing plasma levels.
  • • Women taking OCPs and on lamotrigene are advised to increase the dose of lamotrigine
  • • Let us look at each option:
  • • Let us look at each option:
  • • Option A. Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills (Correct Answer) : Combined oral contraceptives (COCs) contain both estrogen and a progestin. Estrogen can increase the metabolism of lamotrigine, potentially lowering its levels in the blood and reducing its effectiveness. Therefore, if a woman on lamotrigine chooses to use COCs, her lamotrigine dosage may need to be adjusted to maintain seizure control.
  • • Option A.
  • • Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills (Correct Answer)
  • • Option B . Centchroman : This is a non-steroidal, non-hormonal contraceptive, known also as Ormeloxifene. It works as a selective estrogen receptor modulator and is unlikely to interact with lamotrigine.
  • • Option B
  • • Centchroman
  • • Option C . LNG-IUS (Levonorgestrel-releasing Intrauterine System) : The LNG-IUS, such as Mirena, releases levonorgestrel directly into the uterus. The systemic absorption of levonorgestrel is minimal compared to oral contraceptives, and it is unlikely to significantly interact with lamotrigine.
  • • Option C
  • • LNG-IUS (Levonorgestrel-releasing Intrauterine System)
  • • Option D . Depot Medroxyprogesterone Acetate (DMPA) : DMPA is a progestin-only injectable contraceptive. Progestin-only methods are less likely to interact with lamotrigine compared to estrogen-containing methods.
  • • Option D
  • • Depot Medroxyprogesterone Acetate (DMPA)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ In a woman with epilepsy on lamotrigine therapy, the use of combined oral contraceptive pills may necessitate an adjustment in the lamotrigine dosage due to estrogen-induced increased metabolism of lamotrigine. Non-hormonal methods like Centchroman or progestin-only methods like the LNG-IUS and DMPA are less likely to interact with lamotrigine and are generally safer options in terms of drug interactions for women with epilepsy.
  • ➤ Ref: Epilepsy in Pregnancy Green-top Guideline No. 68 June 2016 ( RCOG )
  • ➤ Ref: Epilepsy in Pregnancy Green-top Guideline No. 68 June 2016 ( RCOG )
