questions.question_text: A 23y woman is taking Oral Contraceptive Pills regularly since the past 2 years. She presents to the family planning OPD on Day 8 of her menstrual cycle with the complaint that she has missed taking the pill on Day 7. What will you advise her?

options.A: Take the missed pill as soon as possible and continue the remaining packet
options.B: Take the missed pill as soon as possible and offer her emergency contraception also
options.C: Take the missed pill as soon as possible and use additional contraception for 7 days
options.D: Take the missed pill as soon as possible, use emergency contraception and discard the remaining packet

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Management of Missed Pill
  • • Let's look at all the options:
  • • Option A. Take the missed pill as soon as possible and continue the remaining packet (Correct Answer): This is the recommended advice for a single missed pill. She should take the missed pill as soon as she remembers, even if this means taking two pills in one day. The risk of pregnancy is low with only one missed pill, especially if she has been taking the pills regularly for a long time. She can then continue taking the rest of the pills in the packet as usual.
  • • Option A.
  • • Take the missed pill as soon as possible and continue the remaining packet
  • • Option B. Take the missed pill as soon as possible and offer her emergency contraception also : Emergency contraception is not necessary for a single missed pill, provided she resumes taking her pills as advised.
  • • Option B.
  • • Take the missed pill as soon as possible and offer her emergency contraception also
  • • Option C. Take the missed pill as soon as possible and use additional contraception for 7 days : Using additional contraception for 7 days is the standard advice if two or more pills are missed consecutively, especially in the first week of the pack. However, for a single missed pill, this extra precaution is not typically necessary.
  • • Option C.
  • • Take the missed pill as soon as possible and use additional contraception for 7 days
  • • Option D . Take the missed pill as soon as possible, use emergency contraception and discard the remaining packet : This advice is excessive for a single missed pill. There is no need to discard the remaining pills or use emergency contraception.
  • • Option D
  • • Take the missed pill as soon as possible, use emergency contraception and discard the remaining packet

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ When a woman misses a single combined oral contraceptive pill, the best course of action is to take the missed pill as soon as possible and then continue taking the rest of the pills in the packet as scheduled. Additional measures such as emergency contraception or extended use of barrier methods are not necessary for a single missed pill.
  • ➤ Ref: Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Health Care Clinical Effectiveness Unit. CEU Statement (May 2011). Missed Pill Recommendations. 2011. http://www.fsrh.org/pdfs/CEUStatementMissedPills.pdf (Accessed 19th August 2021)
  • ➤ Ref: Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Health Care Clinical Effectiveness Unit. CEU Statement (May 2011). Missed Pill Recommendations. 2011.
  • ➤ http://www.fsrh.org/pdfs/CEUStatementMissedPills.pdf
  • ➤ (Accessed 19th August 2021)

questions.question_text: The image shown is of the transdermal contraceptive patch. The progesterone component in it is?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The transdermal contraceptive patch contains Ethinyl estradiol and Norelgestomin Each patch lasts for 1 week; 3 patches are required per cycle followed by a 1-week patch free interval They can be placed over the buttock or abdomen Should NOT be placed oved the breasts
  • • The transdermal contraceptive patch contains Ethinyl estradiol and Norelgestomin
  • • Each patch lasts for 1 week; 3 patches are required per cycle followed by a 1-week patch free interval
  • • They can be placed over the buttock or abdomen
  • • Should NOT be placed oved the breasts
  • • Let us look at each option :
  • • Option A . Desogestrel : This is a progestin used in certain types of oral contraceptive pills. It is not used in the transdermal contraceptive patch.
  • • Option
  • • A
  • • Desogestrel
  • • Option B . Etonogestrel : Etonogestrel is the active metabolite of desogestrel, and while it is used in contraceptive implants (like Nexplanon), it is not used in the transdermal patch.
  • • Option
  • • B
  • • Etonogestrel
  • • Option C . Levonorgestrel : This is another type of progestin commonly found in various contraceptive methods, including intrauterine devices and emergency contraceptive pills. However, it is not used in the transdermal patch.
  • • Option
  • • C
  • • Levonorgestrel
  • • Option D . Norelgestromin (Correct Answer): Norelgestromin is the progestin component in the transdermal contraceptive patch, such as the brand name Ortho Evra. The patch also contains ethinyl estradiol, a form of estrogen. Norelgestromin is a metabolite of norgestimate and is effective in preventing ovulation and altering the cervical mucus and endometrial lining.
  • • Option
  • • D
  • • Norelgestromin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The transdermal contraceptive patch uses norelgestromin as its progestin component, along with ethinyl estradiol. Understanding the hormonal components of contraceptive methods is crucial for healthcare providers to recommend the most appropriate contraceptive method for each individual, taking into account their medical history, preferences, and lifestyle.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 278, Shaw’s Textbook of Gynecology, 16 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 278, Shaw’s Textbook of Gynecology, 16 th edition

questions.question_text: Match the progesterone with the contraceptive choice:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • 3 rd generation intrauterine device (commonly available as MIRENA) contains Levonorgetrel and is known as LNG-IUS Vaginal contraceptive ring (available as Nuva ring) contains: ethinyl estradiol + Etonogestrel Transdermal contraceptive patch (Available as Ortho-EVRA): ethinyl estradiol + Norelgestromin Mini pill or progesterone only pills (POP) can contain Desogestrel (Available as Cerazette). They can also contain levonorgestrel OR norethindrone.
  • • 3 rd generation intrauterine device (commonly available as MIRENA) contains Levonorgetrel and is known as LNG-IUS
  • • Vaginal contraceptive ring (available as Nuva ring) contains: ethinyl estradiol + Etonogestrel
  • • Transdermal contraceptive patch (Available as Ortho-EVRA): ethinyl estradiol + Norelgestromin
  • • Mini pill or progesterone only pills (POP) can contain Desogestrel (Available as Cerazette). They can also contain levonorgestrel OR norethindrone.
  • • Based on this information, the correct matching is:
  • • B. 1c (3rd Generation IUD - Levonorgestrel), 2b (Vaginal Contraceptive Ring - Etonogestrel), 3a (Transdermal Contraceptive Patch - Norelgestromin), 4d (Mini Pill - Desogestrel).

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Different contraceptive methods use various types of progestins. Levonorgestrel is commonly used in IUDs, etonogestrel in vaginal rings, Norelgestromin in transdermal patches, and desogestrel in mini pills.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 278, Shaw’s Textbook of Gynecology, 16 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 278, Shaw’s Textbook of Gynecology, 16 th edition

questions.question_text: All are examples of Long-Acting Reversible Contraception (LARC) except?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Long-Acting Reversible Contraception (LARC) methods are defined as methods requiring administration less than once cycle/ month LARC methods include Intrauterine devices Progesterone implants Injectable contraceptives They require a single act of motivation for long term use eliminating adherence and user dependence
  • • Long-Acting Reversible Contraception (LARC) methods are defined as methods requiring administration less than once cycle/ month
  • • LARC methods include Intrauterine devices Progesterone implants Injectable contraceptives
  • • Intrauterine devices Progesterone implants Injectable contraceptives
  • • Intrauterine devices
  • • Progesterone implants
  • • Injectable contraceptives
  • • They require a single act of motivation for long term use eliminating adherence and user dependence
  • • Let us look at each option :
  • • Option A . CuT380A : This is a Copper T 380A intrauterine device (IUD), a type of LARC. It can provide up to 10 years of contraception. The device is placed inside the uterus and works by releasing copper, which is toxic to sperm.
  • • Option
  • • A
  • • CuT380A
  • • Option B . Depot Medroxyprogesterone Acetate (DMPA) : DMPA is an injectable form of contraception, commonly known as Depo-Provera. It is administered every three months and is considered a LARC because of its prolonged duration of action and the minimal requirement for user adherence.
  • • Option
  • • B
  • • Depot Medroxyprogesterone Acetate (DMPA)
  • • Option C . Norplant : Norplant, which is no longer available in many countries but has similar successors like Jadelle, consists of implantable rods that release a progestin. This method is a LARC, providing effective contraception for several years.
  • • Option
  • • C
  • • Norplant
  • • Option D . Triphasic Pill (Correct Answer): The triphasic pill is a form of combined oral contraceptive pill (COC). It is not a LARC; it requires daily administration and adherence by the user. The "triphasic" refers to the varying levels of hormones in the pills over the course of the cycle to mimic the natural menstrual cycle more closely.
  • • Option
  • • D
  • • Triphasic Pill

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Long-Acting Reversible Contraception (LARC) methods include devices and formulations like the CuT380A IUD, Depo-Provera injections, and implantable progestin rods (e.g., Norplant, Jadelle), which provide effective contraception for an extended period with minimal need for user action. In contrast, the triphasic pill, a type of combined oral contraceptive, requires daily administration and does not fall under the category of LARC
  • ➤ Ref: Page no. 697, JB Sharma’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 1 st edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no. 697, JB Sharma’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 1 st edition

questions.question_text: A 30-year-old P1L1 woman requests emergency contraception for unprotected intercourse. She is given a choice between the Levonorgestrel regimes versus the Yuzpe (combination oral contraceptive) regimen. Which of the following is the main effect of the progestin-only regimen as compared with the Yuzpe regimen?

options.B: Can be taken up to 120h of unprotected intercourse

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Emergency contraception methods include:
  • • Combined OCP /Yuzpe’s regime: COCs, taken as a split dose, one dose of 100 μg of ethinyl estradiol plus 0.50 mg of LNG, followed by a second dose of 100 μg of ethinyl estradiol plus 0.50 mg of LNG 12 hours later. The main disadvantage of this method is excessive nausea and vomiting. Levonorgestrel (LNG) alone: Single dose of 1.5 mg (or alternatively, LNG taken in 2 doses of 0.75 mg each, 12 hours apart). Nausea and vomiting occurred much less frequently than Yuzpe’s method. Main mechanism of action is delay in ovulation. Success rate is 95-97%. The earlier it is taken following unprotected intercourse, the higher the efficacy. Anti-progestins/ SPRMs Mifepristone 10 mg Ulipristal acetate 30 mg (As effective as LNG; can be used up to 120 h; also used in medical management of fibroid) Intrauterine copper device Highest efficacy amongst emergency contraceptives Can be used within 120h of unprotected intercourse. Useful if the woman wants a long-term contraceptive.
  • • Combined OCP /Yuzpe’s regime: COCs, taken as a split dose, one dose of 100 μg of ethinyl estradiol plus 0.50 mg of LNG, followed by a second dose of 100 μg of ethinyl estradiol plus 0.50 mg of LNG 12 hours later. The main disadvantage of this method is excessive nausea and vomiting.
  • • Levonorgestrel (LNG) alone: Single dose of 1.5 mg (or alternatively, LNG taken in 2 doses of 0.75 mg each, 12 hours apart). Nausea and vomiting occurred much less frequently than Yuzpe’s method. Main mechanism of action is delay in ovulation. Success rate is 95-97%. The earlier it is taken following unprotected intercourse, the higher the efficacy.
  • • Anti-progestins/ SPRMs Mifepristone 10 mg Ulipristal acetate 30 mg (As effective as LNG; can be used up to 120 h; also used in medical management of fibroid)
  • • Mifepristone 10 mg Ulipristal acetate 30 mg (As effective as LNG; can be used up to 120 h; also used in medical management of fibroid)
  • • Mifepristone 10 mg
  • • Ulipristal acetate 30 mg (As effective as LNG; can be used up to 120 h; also used in medical management of fibroid)
  • • Intrauterine copper device Highest efficacy amongst emergency contraceptives Can be used within 120h of unprotected intercourse. Useful if the woman wants a long-term contraceptive.
  • • Highest efficacy amongst emergency contraceptives Can be used within 120h of unprotected intercourse. Useful if the woman wants a long-term contraceptive.
  • • Highest efficacy amongst emergency contraceptives
  • • Can be used within 120h of unprotected intercourse.
  • • Useful if the woman wants a long-term contraceptive.
  • • Regarding the other options:
  • • Regarding the other options:
  • • Option A "Higher ectopic pregnancy rate," is not associated with either regimen, and it is not a characteristic difference between them. Option B : "Can be taken up to 120 hours of unprotected intercourse," is not true. It can be taken up to 72 hours (3 days) after unprotected intercourse and is more effective when taken earlier. Option D : "More liver dysfunction," is not a typical effect of either regimen. Both regimens are generally safe for most women and do not significantly impact liver function. OCPs can affect liver function, but significant liver dysfunction is a rare side effect.
  • • Option A "Higher ectopic pregnancy rate," is not associated with either regimen, and it is not a characteristic difference between them.
  • • Option A

  • • Option B
  • • Option D : "More liver dysfunction," is not a typical effect of either regimen. Both regimens are generally safe for most women and do not significantly impact liver function. OCPs can affect liver function, but significant liver dysfunction is a rare side effect.
  • • Option D

  • • Cervical cancer
  • • Endometrial cancer
  • • Distorted uterine cavity (Pre-existing uterine fibroids that distort the uterine cavity may be incompatible with insertion and proper placement of the IUD)
  • • PID
  • • Let us look at each option :
  • • Option A. Adenomyosis : Adenomyosis, a condition where the inner lining of the uterus (endometrium) breaks through the muscle wall of the uterus, is not a contraindication for IUD use, it helps in reducing the heavy menstrual bleeding associated with adenomyosis.
  • • Option A.
  • • Adenomyosis
  • • Option B . Large Submucosal Fibroid (Correct Answer): A large submucosal fibroid, which protrudes into the uterine cavity, can distort the uterine cavity and interfere with the proper placement and function of an IUD. This can increase the risk of expulsion, malposition, or even perforation, making it a contraindication for IUD use.
  • • Option B
  • • Large Submucosal Fibroid
  • • Option C . Simple Endometrial Hyperplasia : Simple endometrial hyperplasia without atypia is generally not a contraindication for IUD use. In fact, hormonal IUDs that release progestin can be part of the treatment plan for endometrial hyperplasia.
  • • Option C
  • • Simple Endometrial Hyperplasia
  • • Option D . Nulliparous Woman : While historically there was hesitation in using IUDs in nulliparous women, current evidence supports the safety and efficacy of IUDs in this population.
  • • Option D
  • • Nulliparous Woman

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Large submucosal fibroids that distort the uterine cavity are a contraindication for IUD use due to the potential for complications such as expulsion or perforation. Other conditions like adenomyosis, simple endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, or being a nulliparous woman are not contraindications for IUD use.
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of Gynecology 3 rd edition page 109
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of Gynecology 3 rd edition page 109

questions.question_text: What is the dose of Levonorgestrel recommended for emergency contraception?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 1.5 mg

Explanation:

  • • Emergency contraception methods include:
  • • Combined OCP /Yuzpe’s regime: COCs, taken as a split dose, one dose of 100 μg of ethinyl estradiol plus 0.50 mg of LNG, followed by a second dose of 100 μg of ethinyl estradiol plus 0.50 mg of LNG 12 hours later. The main disadvantage of this method is excessive nausea and vomiting.
  • • Levonorgestrel (LNG) alone: Single dose of 1.5 mg (or alternatively, LNG taken in 2 doses of 0.75 mg each, 12 hours apart). Nausea and vomiting occurred much less frequently than Yuzpe’s method. Main mechanism of action is delay in ovulation. Success rate is 95-97%. The earlier it is taken following unprotected intercourse, the higher the efficacy.
  • • Anti-progestins/ SPRMs
  • • Mifepristone 10 mg
  • • Ulipristal acetate 30 mg (As effective as LNG; can be used up to 120 h; also used in medical management of fibroid)
  • • Intrauterine copper device
  • • Highest efficacy amongst emergency contraceptives
  • • Can be used within 120h of unprotected intercourse.
  • • Useful if the woman wants a long-term contraceptive.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ref: Page 245, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 245, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th edition

questions.question_text: A 35-year-old multiparous lady with a history of double valve replacement (aortic & mitral) on warfarin comes to you for contraceptive counselling. Which of the following contraceptive options is most suitable for her?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • LNG IUS is Levonorgestrel containing intra-uterine system (Mirena) and as it is only progesterone containing contraceptive, it does not predispose to thrombo-embolism unlike estrogen containing contraceptives.
  • • LNG IUS is Levonorgestrel containing intra-uterine system (Mirena) and as it is only progesterone containing contraceptive, it does not predispose to thrombo-embolism unlike estrogen containing contraceptives.
  • • Let's evaluate each option:
  • • Option A . Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills : These pills contain both estrogen and progestin. Estrogen can increase the risk of thromboembolic events, which is a significant concern in a patient with a history of valve replacement and on anticoagulant therapy. Therefore, are not a suitable choice for this patient.
  • • Option A
  • • Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills
  • • Option B . Transdermal Patch and C. Transvaginal Ring : The transvaginal ring (e.g., NuvaRing) and patch both contain estrogen and progestin. The estrogen component increases the risk of thromboembolic events, making it inappropriate for this patient.
  • • Option B
  • • Transdermal Patch and C.
  • • Transvaginal Ring
  • • Option D . LNG IUS (Levonorgestrel Intrauterine System) (Correct Answer): The LNG IUS, such as Mirena, is a progestin-only contraceptive method. It releases levonorgestrel, a type of progestin, directly into the uterus. Since it does not contain estrogen, it does not increase the risk of thromboembolic events, making it a safer option for women with a history of valve replacement and those on anticoagulation therapy like warfarin.
  • • Option D
  • • LNG IUS (Levonorgestrel Intrauterine System)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ For women with a history of valve replacement and those on anticoagulation therapy, progestin-only contraceptive methods, such as the Levonorgestrel Intrauterine System (LNG IUS), are preferred over estrogen-containing contraceptives (combined oral pills, transdermal patch , transvaginal ring).
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 242, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 242, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15 th edition

questions.question_text: All are true regarding postpartum contraception except:

options.A: With full or near full breast-feeding, 70% of women remain amenorrheic through 6 months.
options.B: With partial feeding or no breast feeding, a contraceptive method should begin during the 3 rd postpartum week.
options.C: The progestin only minipill does not affect lactation.
options.D: The vaginal ring can be used effectively in breast feeding mothers as absorption of estrogen is minimal and does not affect lactation.

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The use of vaginal estrogen preparation is discouraged because absorption of estrogen can lead to inhibition of milk production.
  • • The use of vaginal estrogen preparation is discouraged because absorption of estrogen can lead to inhibition of milk production.
  • • Let us look at each option:
  • • Option A . With full or near full breast-feeding, 70% of women remain amenorrheic through 6 months : This is true. Lactational amenorrhea, is a common and natural form of contraception in the initial months postpartum. However, it's important to note that its effectiveness as a contraceptive method varies and should be considered in the context of exclusive breastfeeding and frequency of nursing.
  • • Option A
  • • With full or near full breast-feeding, 70% of women remain amenorrheic through 6 months
  • • Option B. With partial feeding or no breast feeding, a contraceptive method should begin during the 3rd postpartum week : This is generally correct. For women who are not fully breastfeeding, fertility can return earlier, and it's advisable to start a contraceptive method by the third postpartum week to prevent unintended pregnancy.
  • • Option B.
  • • With partial feeding or no breast feeding, a contraceptive method should begin during the 3rd postpartum week
  • • Option C . The progestin-only minipill does not affect lactation : True. Progestin-only contraceptives, like the minipill, are preferred during breastfeeding as they do not affect milk supply. These are safe to use in the postpartum period, including for women who are breastfeeding.
  • • Option C
  • • The progestin-only minipill does not affect lactation
  • • Option D . The vaginal ring can be used effectively in breastfeeding mothers as absorption of estrogen is minimal and does not affect lactation (Incorrect Statement): This statement is not accurate. The vaginal ring typically contains both estrogen and progestin. Estrogen-containing contraceptives, including the vaginal ring, can potentially reduce breast milk supply and are generally not recommended for breastfeeding mothers, especially in the early postpartum period. While the systemic absorption may be lower than oral methods, the potential impact on lactation is still a concern.
  • • Option D
  • • The vaginal ring can be used effectively in breastfeeding mothers as absorption of estrogen is minimal and does not affect lactation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ In postpartum contraception, it's important to choose methods that are safe and effective for the mother, especially if she is breastfeeding. Progestin-only methods like the minipill are preferred during lactation as they do not affect milk supply.
  • ➤ Ref: page no 878, Speroff’s Clinical Gynecological Endocrinology and Infertility
  • ➤ Ref: page no 878, Speroff’s Clinical Gynecological Endocrinology and Infertility

questions.question_text: Which of the following has the lowest Pregnancy rates?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D.  ML Cu 375

Explanation:

  • • 1 st generation Intra-uterine devices had a higher failure rate compared to 2 nd generation (copper containing) intra-uterine devices. Amongst the Cu containing devices, remember that Cu T380 A (available free by Govt of India) has the lowest failure rate followed by the Multiloads.
  • • 1 st generation Intra-uterine devices had a higher failure rate compared to 2 nd generation (copper containing) intra-uterine devices.
  • • Amongst the Cu containing devices, remember that Cu T380 A (available free by Govt of India) has the lowest failure rate followed by the Multiloads.
  • • Let us look at each option:
  • • Option A. Lippe's Loop : This is one of the earlier forms of IUDs. It's made of plastic and shaped like a loop. While it was effective in its time, the pregnancy rates with Lippe's Loop are generally higher compared to newer, more advanced IUDs.
  • • Option A.
  • • Lippe's Loop
  • • Option B . CuT 200 : This is a copper IUD, where copper is wound around the vertical stem of the T. CuT 200 has a relatively lower copper surface area compared to some other copper IUDs.
  • • Option B
  • • CuT 200
  • • Option C . Nova-T : This is a T-shaped IUD similar to CuT 200, but with slight variations in design. It's also a copper IUD, and its effectiveness is comparable to other copper IUDs but might not be as effective as the more advanced versions with higher copper content.
  • • Option C
  • • Nova-T
  • • Option D . ML Cu 375 (Correct Answer): The ML Cu 375 is a more modern copper IUD with a higher copper surface area than CuT 200 or Nova-T. The increased copper content generally correlates with higher efficacy and lower pregnancy rates. This makes ML Cu 375 one of the most effective copper IUDs currently available.
  • • Option D
  • • ML Cu 375

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Among the listed options, the ML Cu 375 intrauterine device has the lowest pregnancy rates due to its higher copper content, which enhances its contraceptive efficacy.

questions.question_text: Most common reason for discontinuation of IUCD use is?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Increased bleeding and pain are responsible for most intrauterine device removals (2 – 10/ 100 users in the 1 st year).
  • • Increased bleeding and pain are responsible for most intrauterine device removals (2 – 10/ 100 users in the 1 st year).
  • • Let's review the options given:
  • • Option A. Ectopic Pregnancy : While IUCDs, especially those without hormones, can slightly increase the relative risk of an ectopic pregnancy if a pregnancy occurs, the absolute risk is very low because IUCDs are highly effective at preventing pregnancy in the first place. Ectopic pregnancy is a rare complication and not the most common reason for discontinuation.
  • • Option A.
  • • Ectopic Pregnancy
  • • Option B . Uterine Rupture : Uterine rupture is an extremely rare complication associated with IUCD use and is not a common reason for discontinuation. It is more likely to be a concern in specific situations, such as during pregnancy or labor.
  • • Option B
  • • Uterine Rupture
  • • Option C . Abnormal Uterine Bleeding (Correct Answer): This is the most common reason for discontinuing IUCD use. Women may experience changes in their menstrual bleeding patterns, such as heavier or irregular bleeding, particularly with non-hormonal IUCDs like the Copper T (CuT). This can lead to discomfort and inconvenience, prompting some women to discontinue use.
  • • Option C
  • • Abnormal Uterine Bleeding
  • • Option D . Risk of Subsequent Infertility : There is a misconception that IUCDs cause infertility, but this is not supported by evidence. Modern IUCDs do not increase the risk of infertility after removal.
  • • Option D
  • • Risk of Subsequent Infertility

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The most common reason for discontinuing the use of an intrauterine contraceptive device is abnormal uterine bleeding, especially with non-hormonal IUCDs.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 683, JB Sharma’s Textbook of Obstetrics 1 st edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 683, JB Sharma’s Textbook of Obstetrics 1 st edition

questions.question_text: All the following can be used as emergency contraceptives except?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The following can be used as emergency contraceptives:
  • • Let us look at each option:
  • • Option A. Combined Oral Contraceptives : Certain combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs), which contain both estrogen and progestin, can be used for emergency contraception. This method, known as the Yuzpe regimen. It's less effective and has more side effects than other emergency contraceptive options.
  • • Option A.
  • • Combined Oral Contraceptives
  • • Option B . Levonorgestrel : This is a common and effective ingredient in many emergency contraceptive pills. It's a progestin-only pill taken as a single dose (1.5 mg) or in two doses (0.75 mg each, 12 hours apart) within 72 hours after unprotected intercourse. It's well-tolerated and has fewer side effects than the Yuzpe regimen.
  • • Option B
  • • Levonorgestrel
  • • Option C . Ulipristal Acetate : This is another effective option for emergency contraception. It's a single-dose pill (30 mg) that can be taken up to 120 hours (5 days) after unprotected intercourse. It's more effective than levonorgestrel and can be used for a longer window after intercourse.
  • • Option C
  • • Ulipristal Acetate
  • • Option D . Depot Medroxyprogesterone Acetate (DMPA) (Correct Answer): DMPA is a long-acting progestin contraceptive administered via injection and is not suitable for emergency contraception. It's designed for long-term birth control and does not have the immediate effect required for emergency contraception.
  • • Option D
  • • Depot Medroxyprogesterone Acetate (DMPA)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ For emergency contraception, options include certain combined oral contraceptives (Yuzpe regimen), levonorgestrel, and ulipristal acetate. Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate, however, is not an appropriate option for emergency contraception as it's a long-term contraceptive and does not provide the immediate effect necessary for this purpose.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 243, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 243, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15 th edition

questions.question_text: Seema, a 32-year mother of 2 children, has been on Mala N for contraception. After the end of the first strip. there was no withdrawal bleeding. It has now been 7 days since the last tablet and she visits you. What should be done?

options.A: Start next cycle of tablets immediately
options.B: Start next cycle from next day
options.D: Wait for another 1 weeks for period

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The first thing that needs to be ruled out is pregnancy. Hence UPT needs to be done. IF UPT is negative, she can start a new packet of OCPs,
  • • The first thing that needs to be ruled out is pregnancy.
  • • Hence UPT needs to be done.
  • • IF UPT is negative, she can start a new packet of OCPs,
  • • Let's explore the options:
  • • Option A . Start next cycle of tablets immediately : While it's generally recommended to start the next pack of pills after the usual pill-free interval (or placebo pill week), doing so without addressing the absence of withdrawal bleeding could potentially overlook an early pregnancy.
  • • Option A
  • • Start next cycle of tablets immediately
  • • Option B . Start next cycle from next day : Similar to option A, this does not address the underlying concern of potential pregnancy. It's important to rule out pregnancy before continuing with the next cycle of contraceptive pills.
  • • Option B
  • • Start next cycle from next day
  • • Option C . Urine Pregnancy Test (Correct Answer) : The absence of withdrawal bleeding at the end of a contraceptive pill cycle can be a sign of pregnancy, especially if the pills were not taken consistently or correctly. A urine pregnancy test (UPT) is a simple and effective way to rule out or confirm pregnancy before proceeding with further contraceptive use.
  • • Option C
  • • Urine Pregnancy Test (Correct Answer)
  • • Option D . Wait for another 1 week for period : While waiting could be an option, it might delay the identification of a potential pregnancy. Given that the patient is already at the end of her pill-free interval, it's more proactive to perform a pregnancy test to promptly address any potential pregnancy.
  • • Option D
  • • Wait for another 1 week for period

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ In cases where a woman on combined oral contraceptive pills does not experience withdrawal bleeding, a pregnancy test should be performed to rule out the possibility of pregnancy, especially if there is any chance of inconsistent pill use. This is a critical step before starting a new pack of contraceptive pills.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 488, DC Duttas textbook of gynecology, 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 488, DC Duttas textbook of gynecology, 6 th edition

questions.question_text: An intrauterine pregnancy of approximately 10 weeks gestation is confirmed in a 30-year-old gravida 5, para 4 woman with an IUD in place. The patient expresses a strong desire for the pregnancy to be continued. On examination, the uterus is 10 weeks size and the string of the IUD is noted to be protruding from the cervical os. The most appropriate course of action is?

options.A: Leave the IUD in place without any other treatment
options.B: Leave the IUD in place and start prophylactic antibiotics
options.D: USG to rule out ectopic pregnancy

questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ In a pregnant woman with an IUD in situ, if the IUD strings are visible and can be removed without disturbing the pregnancy, immediate removal of the IUD is recommended to reduce the risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes such as miscarriage and infection. However, if the strings are not visible or the IUD is embedded, the decision to remove the IUD should be carefully weighed against the potential risks of the removal procedure.

questions.question_text: A 34y man undergoes a no scalpel vasectomy. What is the post operative advise?

options.A: Does not need any additional contraceptive
options.C: Needs additional contraception till a semen analysis shows azoospermia

questions.explanation:
Ans. C.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • After vasectomy, clients can resume sexual activity as soon as it is comfortable for them. This usually takes at least two to three days after the procedure. Counsel clients that vasectomy does not work immediately, and they can still get their partners pregnant. Post vasectomy clients have to use condoms or their partners should use another family planning method consistently and correctly for at least three months. After three months, client should return to the clinic for a semen analysis to make sure that the vasectomy was successful. All vasectomy clients should be provided with instructions and practise on the correct use of condoms for use immediately after the vasectomy.

questions.question_text: Which method of tubal ligation is associated with maximum failure rate?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Discussing all the options:
  • • The following are the techniques used in tubal ligation in a laparotomy/ mini-laparotomy/ concomitant with cesarean section
  • • 1. Pomeroy (Option A): A loop is made at the isthmus and 1cm cut out. This is recommended by GOI. It has a low failure rate
  • • 2. Parkland (Option B): This is like a partial salpingectomy. More efficacious than Pomeroy as the ends are not brough together
  • • The tube is grasped with Babcock clamps.
  • • 3. Madlener (Option D): In this the tube is crushed. Not cut. Hence associated with a very high failure rate.
  • • 4. Uchida (Option C): As shown in image, fallopian tube is stripped off its serosa and cut, the proximal end is buried into the mesosalpinx and the distal end is ligated and turned away from the proximal end. Very low failure rate
  • • 5. Irving: Similar to Uchida: Very low failure rate;
  • • 6. Kroener: Fimbriectomy; very low failure rate
  • • 7. Aldridge: This is burying the fimbria in the meso-salpinx. It has a high failure rate and isn’t used.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Madlener method of tubal ligation is associated with a very high failure rate
  • ➤ Madlener method of tubal ligation is associated with a very high failure rate
  • ➤ Madlener method of tubal ligation is associated with a very high failure rate

questions.question_text: A resident is doing a tubal ligation for the 1 st time. She is unsure which part of the tube she needs to ligate. Which part of the tube is ligated?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Pomeroy’s Guidelines
  • • The operating surgeon should identify each fallopian tube clearly, following it right up to the fimbria. The site of the occlusion of the fallopian tube must always be within 2–3 cm from the uterine cornua in the isthmal portion (this will improve the possibility of reversal if required in the future) Care must be taken to avoid damage to the blood vessels, ovaries, and surrounding tissues Excision of 1 cm of the tube should be done. Use of cautery and crushing of the tube should be avoided. A loop is made using a Babcock’s forceps and ligated with catgut. A 1 cm loop is then cut The same is repeated on the other side
  • • The operating surgeon should identify each fallopian tube clearly, following it right up to the fimbria.
  • • The site of the occlusion of the fallopian tube must always be within 2–3 cm from the uterine cornua in the isthmal portion (this will improve the possibility of reversal if required in the future)
  • • Care must be taken to avoid damage to the blood vessels, ovaries, and surrounding tissues
  • • Excision of 1 cm of the tube should be done. Use of cautery and crushing of the tube should be avoided.
  • • A loop is made using a Babcock’s forceps and ligated with catgut.
  • • A 1 cm loop is then cut
  • • The same is repeated on the other side

questions.question_text: A 20y woman chooses the medical method of abortion for termination of pregnancy at 7 weeks pregnancy. After giving misoprostol, the woman should be called for follow-up on which day:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Procedure for medical MTP as per MOHFW (2016)
  • • On the 15th day (Follow up day), the following is done:
  • • 1. Note relevant history/check medical method of aborton (MMA) follow-up card
  • • 2. Carry out pelvic examination to ensure completion of abortion process/continuation of pregnancy
  • • 3. Reiterate contraceptive counselling and services
  • • 4. Advise USG if
  • • • complete expulsion of POC not confirmed
  • • • continuation of pregnancy suspected
  • • • bleeding continues
  • • 5. Ask the woman to report back if there are no periods within six weeks

questions.question_text: A 25-year-old G2P1L1 at 8 weeks pregnancy wants a medical termination of pregnancy for failure of contraception. She wants to know the advantages of medical abortion over surgical methods. All are true except?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Advantages of medical abortion:
  • • Lesser incidence of haemorrhage, PID, perforation, long term sequelae like subfertility, cervical insufficiency and Asherman syndrome Non invasive No anesthesia required
  • • Lesser incidence of haemorrhage, PID, perforation, long term sequelae like subfertility, cervical insufficiency and Asherman syndrome
  • • Non invasive
  • • No anesthesia required
  • • Disadvantages of medical abortion:
  • • 1. Success rate less than surgical abortion (95-99% with medical abortion; almost 100% with surgical evacuation)
  • • 2. Takes about 2 weeks for completion (Surgical procedure is quicker and gets done in a 15-30 minutes.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Less incidence of hemorrhage is an advantage of medical MTP Option C: Non invasive: is an advantage of medical MTP Option D: Less incidence of PID: Is an advantage of medical MTP
  • • Option A: Less incidence of hemorrhage is an advantage of medical MTP

The patient is otherwise hemodynamically stable. She immediately stops the procedure and informs her senior. What should be the next step in the management?

options.A: Complete the procedure under guidance of the senior obstetrician
options.B: Complete the procedure in the OT under laparoscopic guidance
options.C: Shift the patient to OT and immediately do a laparotomy and exploration
options.D: Observe the patient and complete the procedure after 2 weeks once the perforation has healed

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Management protocol of uterine perforation:
  • • Management protocol of uterine perforation:
  • • Whenever there is a suspected perforation while doing an D&C or a D&E, the procedure is stopped Observation Start Antibiotics If procedure is incomplete, d iagnostic laparoscopy to assess the perforation and complete the procedure under laparoscopy guidamce Sometimes, in the event of a lateral cervical tear which can enter the uterine arteries or causea a broad ligament hematoma: the patient rapidly goes into shock and a laparotomy + repair/ hysterectomy has to be done I n the question given, the best option is to complete the procedure under laparoscopy guidance

questions.question_text: A 28-year-old woman presents with infertility and is diagnosed with anovulatory cycles. Which of the following medications can be used for ovulation induction in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Both clomiphene citrate and letrozole

Explanation:

  • • A. Clomiphene citrate is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that blocks the negative feedback of estrogen on the hypothalamus, leading to increased production and release of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH). This promotes follicular growth and ovulation.
  • • B. Letrozole is an aromatase inhibitor that reduces the conversion of androgens to estrogen, leading to decreased estrogen levels and increased FSH production. It has been found to be equally effective or even superior to clomiphene citrate in some cases, particularly in women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
  • • Hence Option C (Option A + B) is the answer
  • • Hence Option C (Option A + B) is the answer
  • • Other Options
  • • Option D. Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists are not typically used for primary ovulation induction. They are more commonly used to suppress ovulation temporarily in certain fertility treatment protocols or for medical management of specific conditions, such as endometriosis.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Both letrozole and clomiphene citrate are commonly used ovulation induction agents. Gonadotropins (FSH and HMG) are 2nd line drugs. The choice between clomiphene citrate and letrozole may depend on various factors, including the patient's individual characteristics, response to prior treatments, and underlying conditions such as PCOS. In some cases, a healthcare provider may choose to use one medication over the other based on individual patient factors. Rememebr: If PCOS is mentioned, Letrozole would be the preferred agent for ovulation induction, even though clomiohene citrate can also be used

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a correct indication for the use of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists in gynecology?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Treatment of endometriosis

Explanation:

  • • Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists are commonly used in gynecology for the treatment of endometriosis. GnRH agonists work by initially stimulating the release of gonadotropins, which leads to an initial increase in estrogen production. However, with continued use, they suppress the production of gonadotropins, leading to a decrease in estrogen levels and subsequent reduction in the growth and symptoms associated with endometriosis. Other uses of GnRh agonists include Central precocious puberty IVF cycles (long protocol and also as a trigger in women at high risk of developing OHSS) Endometriosis Fibroid uterus AUB Hirsutism Pre-menstrual syndrome
  • • Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists are commonly used in gynecology for the treatment of endometriosis. GnRH agonists work by initially stimulating the release of gonadotropins, which leads to an initial increase in estrogen production. However, with continued use, they suppress the production of gonadotropins, leading to a decrease in estrogen levels and subsequent reduction in the growth and symptoms associated with endometriosis. Other uses of GnRh agonists include Central precocious puberty IVF cycles (long protocol and also as a trigger in women at high risk of developing OHSS) Endometriosis Fibroid uterus AUB Hirsutism Pre-menstrual syndrome

options.B: Ormeloxifene is primarily used as an emergency contraceptive
options.C: Ormeloxifene is approved for long-term contraception and the treatment of heavy menstrual bleeding

questions.question_text: In the management of endometriosis, which of the following is the primary mechanism of action of danazol?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Danazol is an isoxazole derivative of 17-alpha ethinyl testosterone. It is strictly anti-gonadotropin but acts as an androgen agonist. Mode of action: The mechanism of action is complex and includes the following: Acting on the hypothalamo-pituitary gonadal axis → depression of frequency of GnRH pulses → suppression of pituitary FSH and LH surge. There is, however, no change in the basal gonadotropin level while the estrogen levels are reduced. Reduces the liver synthesis of SHBG and as such, free testosterone is increased which in turn causes endometrial atrophy. Acts directly on the ovaries, inhibiting the enzymes responsible for steroidogenesis – reducing the estrogen level Binds with steroid receptors on the endometrium and also in the ectopic endometrial sites Immunologic effects of danazol include decrease in serum immunoglobulins, interleukin-1 and TNF production. This effect helps in the regression of endometriosis. The net result is production of an hypoestrogenic state Indications of use of Danazol: (Although it is now not very commonly used)

  • • It is strictly anti-gonadotropin but acts as an androgen agonist.

There is, however, no change in the basal gonadotropin level while the estrogen levels are reduced. Reduces the liver synthesis of SHBG and as such, free testosterone is increased which in turn causes endometrial atrophy. Acts directly on the ovaries, inhibiting the enzymes responsible for steroidogenesis – reducing the estrogen level Binds with steroid receptors on the endometrium and also in the ectopic endometrial sites Immunologic effects of danazol include decrease in serum immunoglobulins, interleukin-1 and TNF production. This effect helps in the regression of endometriosis.

questions.question_text: Which of the following medications can be added to improve the clomiphene response in women with PCOS?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Metformin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Many women with PCOS also have insulin resistance Insulin resistance leads to compensatory hyperinsulinemia and dyslipidemia. Interventions that reduce circulating insulin levels in women with PCOS may restore normal reproductive endocrine function. Insulin-sensitizing agents like Metformin help in the treatment of PCOS. Metformin administered to women with PCOS, increased the frequency of spontaneous ovulation, menstrual cyclicity, and ovulatory response to Clomiphene citrate
  • • Many women with PCOS also have insulin resistance
  • • Insulin resistance leads to compensatory hyperinsulinemia and dyslipidemia.
  • • Interventions that reduce circulating insulin levels in women with PCOS may restore normal reproductive endocrine function.
  • • Insulin-sensitizing agents like Metformin help in the treatment of PCOS.
  • • Metformin administered to women with PCOS, increased the frequency of spontaneous ovulation, menstrual cyclicity, and ovulatory response to Clomiphene citrate

questions.question_text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman with a history of hypertension presents to the antenatal clinic for a routine check-up. She is currently 24 weeks pregnant, and her blood pressure is well controlled on a combination of methyldopa and labetalol. She is concerned about the potential risks of these medications to her unborn baby. Which of the following statements about the use of methyldopa and labetalol in pregnancy is correct?

options.A: Methyldopa and labetalol are contraindicated in pregnancy due to their teratogenic effects.
options.B: Methyldopa and labetalol are safe choices for the management of hypertension during pregnancy
options.C: Methyldopa is safe, but labetalol should be avoided during pregnancy
options.D: Methyldopa and labetalol can cause intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) and should be used with caution.

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Methyldopa and labetalol are safe choices for the management of hypertension during pregnancy

Methyldopa and labetalol are safe choices for the management of hypertension during pregnancy: This is Correct . Methyldopa and labetalol are commonly used antihypertensive medications during pregnancy because they have a well-established safety profile for both the mother and the unborn baby. Option C. Methyldopa is safe, but labetalol should be avoided during pregnancy: This statement is Incorrect. Both methyldopa and labetalol are generally considered safe during pregnancy. Option D. Methyldopa and labetalol can cause intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) and should be used with caution: This statement INCORRECT. The benefits of controlling maternal hypertension often outweigh the potential risks of IUGR when these medications are used.

questions.question_text: A 34-year-old pregnant woman with a history of preterm labor is admitted to the hospital at 32 weeks gestation with regular uterine contractions. She is diagnosed with threatened preterm labor and tocolysis is initiated to delay delivery for corticosteroid administration for fetal lung maturity which among the following should not be used?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Indomethacin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that inhibits prostaglandin synthesis and reduces uterine contractions. However, its use is contraindicated after 32 weeks gestation due to the risk of premature closure of the ductus arteriosus in the fetus, leading to potential fetal harm. Therefore, it should not be used for tocolysis in this patient.
  • • Let's look at the other options:
  • • Let's look at the other options:
  • • Option A. Nifedipine : Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker used for tocolysis in some cases of preterm labor. Option B. Magnesium sulfate : Magnesium sulfate is often used for tocolysis, but it is typically preferred when the primary goal is neuroprotection for the preterm infant rather than delaying delivery for corticosteroid administration. Option C. Terbutaline : Terbutaline is a beta-agonist that can be used for tocolysis, but it is not the first-line choice in this scenario when the main objective is to delay delivery for corticosteroid administration.
  • • Option A. Nifedipine : Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker used for tocolysis in some cases of preterm labor.
  • • Option A.
  • • Nifedipine
  • • Option B. Magnesium sulfate : Magnesium sulfate is often used for tocolysis, but it is typically preferred when the primary goal is neuroprotection for the preterm infant rather than delaying delivery for corticosteroid administration.

  • • Option C. Terbutaline : Terbutaline is a beta-agonist that can be used for tocolysis, but it is not the first-line choice in this scenario when the main objective is to delay delivery for corticosteroid administration.

questions.question_text: A 28-year-old woman is in active labor at 40 weeks gestation. Oxytocin is administered to augment her labor progress. Which of the following is NOT a potential adverse effect associated with the use of oxytocin in labor augmentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Cord prolapse

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Adverse effects of oxytocin:
  • • Let's look at each option:
  • • Let's look at each option:
  • • Option A. Maternal hypotension: Oxytocin can sometimes cause maternal hypotension and tachycardia Option B. Fetal bradycardia : Fetal bradycardia (abnormally slow heart rate in the fetus) is a potential adverse effect of oxytocin administration. It can occur due to uterine hyperstimulation, which reduces fetal oxygen supply. Option C. Uterine rupture : It is a rare but serious complication associated with oxytocin use, especially when the uterus becomes hyperstimulated. It can lead to a tear or rupture in the uterine wall, which poses significant risks to both the mother and the baby. Option D. Cord prolapse: Cord prolapse occurs when the umbilical cord slips through the cervix and becomes compressed during labor. It is not directly related to the administration of oxytocin but is a potential obstetric emergency that can happen during labor.

questions.question_text: A 23y primi presents at 38 weeks with prelabor rupture of membranes. Her Bishop’s score is 6 and she is induced with oxytocin. Which is incorrect regarding oxytocin?

options.A: Oxytocin is discontinued if the number of contractions is > 5 in a 10-minute period or > 7 in a 15-minute period or with a persistent non-reassuring fetal heart rate pattern.
options.B: The uterus contracts within 3 to 5 minutes of beginning an oxytocin infusion, and a plasma steady state is reached in 40 minutes
options.C: When oxytocin is stopped, its concentration in plasma falls slowly because the half-life is long
options.D: Oxytocin is started at doses of 0.5 – 1.5 mIU/ml and gradually increased to a maximum of 48mIU/ml

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. When oxytocin is stopped, its concentration in plasma falls slowly because the half-life is long

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Let's look at each option:
  • • Let's look at each option:
  • • Option A: Oxytocin is discontinued if the number of contractions is > 5 in a 10-minute period or > 7 in a 15-minute period or with a persistent non-reassuring fetal heart rate pattern.: This statement is correct. Oxytocin is discontinued if there are excessive contractions or if there is a persistent non-reassuring fetal heart rate pattern to ensure the safety of the mother and the baby. Option B: The uterus contracts within 3 to 5 minutes of beginning an oxytocin infusion, and a plasma steady state is reached in 40 minutes: This statement is correct. Oxytocin typically starts to induce uterine contractions within a few minutes of administration, and it reaches a steady state in plasma relatively quickly. Option C : When oxytocin is stopped, its concentration in plasma falls slowly because the half-life is long: This statement is incorrect. Oxytocin has a very short half-life, typically in the range of 1-6 minutes. Therefore, its concentration in plasma drops rapidly after discontinuation. Option D : Oxytocin is started at doses of 0.5 – 1.5 mIU/ml and gradually increased to a maximum of 48mIU/ml: statement is generally accurate. Oxytocin is typically started at low doses and gradually increased to achieve the desired uterine contractions while avoiding excessive stimulation.
  • • Option A: Oxytocin is discontinued if the number of contractions is > 5 in a 10-minute period or > 7 in a 15-minute period or with a persistent non-reassuring fetal heart rate pattern.: This statement is correct. Oxytocin is discontinued if there are excessive contractions or if there is a persistent non-reassuring fetal heart rate pattern to ensure the safety of the mother and the baby.
  • • Option A:
  • • Option B: The uterus contracts within 3 to 5 minutes of beginning an oxytocin infusion, and a plasma steady state is reached in 40 minutes: This statement is correct. Oxytocin typically starts to induce uterine contractions within a few minutes of administration, and it reaches a steady state in plasma relatively quickly.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option C : When oxytocin is stopped, its concentration in plasma falls slowly because the half-life is long: This statement is incorrect. Oxytocin has a very short half-life, typically in the range of 1-6 minutes. Therefore, its concentration in plasma drops rapidly after discontinuation.
  • • Option C
  • • Option D : Oxytocin is started at doses of 0.5 – 1.5 mIU/ml and gradually increased to a maximum of 48mIU/ml: statement is generally accurate. Oxytocin is typically started at low doses and gradually increased to achieve the desired uterine contractions while avoiding excessive stimulation.
  • • Option D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Oxytocin is used for induction and augmentation of labor The goal of induction or augmentation is to effect uterine activity sufficient to produce cervical change and fetal descent, while avoiding development of a nonreassuring fetal status. In general, oxytocin is discontinued if the number of contractions persists with a frequency of more than five in a 10-minute period or more than seven in a 15-minute period or with a persistent non-reassuring fetal heart rate pattern. The uterus contracts within 3 to 5 minutes of beginning an oxytocin infusion, and a plasma steady state is reached in 40 minutes Oxytocin discontinuation nearly always rapidly lowers contraction frequency. When oxytocin is stopped, its concentration in plasma rapidly falls because the half-life is approximately 3 to 5 minutes. Uterine response to oxytocin increases from 20 to 30 weeks’ gestation and rises rapidly at term. Oxytocin Regimens:
  • ➤ Oxytocin is used for induction and augmentation of labor
  • ➤ The goal of induction or augmentation is to effect uterine activity sufficient to produce cervical change and fetal descent, while avoiding development of a nonreassuring fetal status.
  • ➤ In general, oxytocin is discontinued if the number of contractions persists with a frequency of more than five in a 10-minute period or more than seven in a 15-minute period or with a persistent non-reassuring fetal heart rate pattern.
  • ➤ The uterus contracts within 3 to 5 minutes of beginning an oxytocin infusion, and a plasma steady state is reached in 40 minutes
  • ➤ Oxytocin discontinuation nearly always rapidly lowers contraction frequency.
  • ➤ When oxytocin is stopped, its concentration in plasma rapidly falls because the half-life is approximately 3 to 5 minutes.
  • ➤ Uterine response to oxytocin increases from 20 to 30 weeks’ gestation and rises rapidly at term.

questions.question_text: What is CORRECT regarding this?

options.A: This is an intravaginal oxytocin release system
options.B: This is an intracervical oxytocin release system
options.C: This is an intravaginal PGE2 release system
options.D: This is an intracervical PGE2 release system

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. This is an intravaginal PGE2 release system

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is an intra-vaginal Dinoprostone (PGE2) system It contains 10mg of PGE2 Available by the names Cervidil and Propess Used for cervical ripening/ induction of labor Thin, flat, rectangular polymeric wafer held within a small, white, mesh polyester sac The sac has a long-attached tail to allow easy removal from the vagina. The insert provides slower release of medication—0.3 mg/hC Cervidil is used as a single dose placed transversely in the posterior vaginal fornix. Following insertion, the woman remains recumbent for at least 2 hours. The insert is removed after 12 hours or with labor onset and at least 30 minutes before the administration of oxytocin. Since the active drug is encased in a mesh sac, one benefit is the ability for removal if fetal heart rate abnormalities or tachysystole develop.
  • • This is an intra-vaginal Dinoprostone (PGE2) system
  • • It contains 10mg of PGE2
  • • Available by the names Cervidil and Propess
  • • Used for cervical ripening/ induction of labor
  • • Thin, flat, rectangular polymeric wafer held within a small, white, mesh polyester sac
  • • The sac has a long-attached tail to allow easy removal from the vagina.
  • • The insert provides slower release of medication—0.3 mg/hC
  • • Cervidil is used as a single dose placed transversely in the posterior vaginal fornix.
  • • Following insertion, the woman remains recumbent for at least 2 hours.
  • • The insert is removed after 12 hours or with labor onset and at least 30 minutes before the administration of oxytocin.
  • • Since the active drug is encased in a mesh sac, one benefit is the ability for removal if fetal heart rate abnormalities or tachysystole develop.
  • • Thus, option C: This is an intravaginal PGE2 release system is correct.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ This is an intra-vaginal PGE2 release system called Propess or Cervidil Intravaginal prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) release systems such as Cervidil are used in obstetrics to facilitate cervical ripening and induce labour when medically indicated.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a neonatal consequence of in utero exposure to non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs?

Explanation:

NSAIDs are associated with Early spontaneous abortions Small increased risk of cardiac malformations Ductus arteriosus constriction (Esp if used > 32 weeks) Neonatal pulmonary hypertension

questions.question_text: A 29-year-old multigravida presents at 15 weeks gestation to establish prenatal care. The patient’s first child had a neural tube defect. The patient did not know that she was pregnant till this week, so she asks you about starting folic acid as she was earlier counselled at the time of her 1 st pregnancy to take a higher dose of folic acid. Which of the following statements will you mention during counselling?

options.A: Starting folic acid is just as beneficial now and she should start immediately
options.B: The neural tube does not close until 21 weeks so she should start folic acid 4mg/ day in the next few days
options.C: The neural tube closes by 6 weeks so folic acid needs to be taken before 6 weeks
options.D: Having a prior child with a neural tube defect does not increase her risk so she need not worry

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. The neural tube closes by 6 weeks so folic acid needs to be taken before 6 weeks

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of options:
  • • Option A: Starting folic acid is just as beneficial now and she should start immediately: Incorrect. While starting folic acid at any point during pregnancy is beneficial for overall fetal development, it is particularly critical to take it before the neural tube closes, which occurs by approximately 6 weeks of gestation. Option B : The next few days: Incorrect. The neural tube closes much earlier, around 6 weeks, so it is essential to start folic acid supplementation before that time. Option C: The neural tube closes by 6 weeks, so folic acid needs to be taken before 6 weeks: This statement is correct. Folic acid supplementation is most effective in preventing neural tube defects when taken before conception and during the early weeks of pregnancy when the neural tube is forming. Option D: Having a prior child with a neural tube defect does not increase her risk, so she need not worry: Incorrect. A history of a previous child with a neural tube defect does increase the risk for future pregnancies, and women in this situation should take appropriate precautions, including starting folic acid supplementation before conception.
  • • Option A: Starting folic acid is just as beneficial now and she should start immediately: Incorrect. While starting folic acid at any point during pregnancy is beneficial for overall fetal development, it is particularly critical to take it before the neural tube closes, which occurs by approximately 6 weeks of gestation.
  • • Option A:
  • • Option B : The next few days: Incorrect. The neural tube closes much earlier, around 6 weeks, so it is essential to start folic acid supplementation before that time.
  • • Option B
  • • Option C: The neural tube closes by 6 weeks, so folic acid needs to be taken before 6 weeks: This statement is correct. Folic acid supplementation is most effective in preventing neural tube defects when taken before conception and during the early weeks of pregnancy when the neural tube is forming.
  • • Option C:
  • • Option D: Having a prior child with a neural tube defect does not increase her risk, so she need not worry: Incorrect. A history of a previous child with a neural tube defect does increase the risk for future pregnancies, and women in this situation should take appropriate precautions, including starting folic acid supplementation before conception.
  • • Option D:

questions.question_text: A 35y G4 presents to the emergency with eclampsia at 35 weeks. After initial management, MgSO4 is administered as per Pritchard regime, and she is induced. Following delivery, for how long should the maintenance dose of MGSO4 continue?

options.C: For 24 h if the BP is > 160/100 mmHg
options.D: Continue only if the patient has imminent symptoms of eclampsia

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. For 24 h

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • MgSO4 in Eclampsia
  • • MgSO4 in Eclampsia
  • • Preferred regime is Pritchard’s regime: 4 g of MgSO4 as a 20% solution @ 1g/ min + 10 g of 50% MgSO4 (5 g in each buttock) f/b maintenance dose of 5 g 50% MgSO4 on alternate buttocks every 4 h till 24 h after delivery/ last convulsion; whichever is later. If 20% not available, convert 50% to 20% by adding 1.5 times distilled water (1ml of 50% MgSO4 contains 0.5g MgSO4) i.e. to 8ml of 50% MgSO4 + 12ml of distilled water Check – RR, urine output and DTR before administering MgSO4 (Risk of toxicity) 1st to disappear in Mg toxicity: DTR Other regimes – Zuspan (Continuous IV regime); higher risk of Mg toxicity if Mg levels unchecked Antidote to MgSO4 is Calcium gluconate
  • • Preferred regime is Pritchard’s regime:
  • • 4 g of MgSO4 as a 20% solution @ 1g/ min + 10 g of 50% MgSO4 (5 g in each buttock) f/b maintenance dose of 5 g 50% MgSO4 on alternate buttocks every 4 h till 24 h after delivery/ last convulsion; whichever is later.
  • • If 20% not available, convert 50% to 20% by adding 1.5 times distilled water (1ml of 50% MgSO4 contains 0.5g MgSO4) i.e. to 8ml of 50% MgSO4 + 12ml of distilled water

  • • 1st to disappear in Mg toxicity: DTR
  • • Other regimes – Zuspan (Continuous IV regime); higher risk of Mg toxicity if Mg levels unchecked

questions.question_text: Which is correct regarding ectopic pregnancy?

options.A: The incidence of heterotopic pregnancy is decreasing due to early diagnosis
options.B: Atypical sites of ectopics are decreasing due to IVF
options.C: The incidence of an ectopic increases by about 50% following a history of ectopic
options.D: The relative incidence of ectopic pregnancy is increased with the use of intrauterine devices.

questions.explanation:
Ans. D.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Let’s Discuss all the options:
  • • Let’s Discuss all the options:
  • • Option A: The incidence of heterotopic pregnancy is decreasing due to early diagnosis: This is incorrect. The incidence of heterotopic pregnancy is increasing due to increasing incidence of Assisted Reproductive Techniques. Option B: Atypical sites of ectopics are decreasing due to IVF: This is also incorrect. Atypical sites of ectopic pregnancy like cervical pregnancy, ovarian pregnancy etc. are increasing due to IVF Option C: The incidence of an ectopic increases by about 50% following a history of ectopic. This is also incorrect as the incidence of an ectopic pregnancy increases by 10-15% following a prior ectopic. Option D: The relative incidence of ectopic pregnancy is increased with the use of intrauterine devices. This is correct. With use of intra-uterine devices, the overall pregnancy rate is reduced but if a woman conceives with an IUD, it is important to note that the ectopic rate is high.

questions.question_text: A 24y lady presented to the emergency with generalized pain and spotting PV. Her LMP was 2 months back and she has a history of irregular cycles. On examination, she is pale, her PR is 110/ min, BP is 80/60 mmHg. There is guarding and rigidity on abdominal examination and a vaginal exam reveals cervical motion tenderness. Her urine pregnancy test is weakly positive. What is the next best step?

options.B: Shift to the O.T. for an emergency laparotomy

questions.explanation:
Ans. B.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is most likely a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. A RUPTURED ectopic pregnancy is a clinical diagnosis. Whenever there is a ruptured ectopic pregnancy with the patient in shock (hypotension, tachycardia), no time is to be wasted and the patient should be shifted to the OT for an emergency laparoscopy/ laparotomy and salpingectomy.
  • • This is most likely a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. A RUPTURED ectopic pregnancy is a clinical diagnosis.
  • • Whenever there is a ruptured ectopic pregnancy with the patient in shock (hypotension, tachycardia), no time is to be wasted and the patient should be shifted to the OT for an emergency laparoscopy/ laparotomy and salpingectomy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Dilatation and evacuation: This is not done in an ectopic pregnancy Option C: Doing an ultrasound (no matter how urgently in a patient with shock) will cause a delay and worsen patient prognosis Option D: Beta hCG (even urgent will take a few hours) is not indicated in a ruptured ectopic. It only has a role in an unruptured ectopic
  • • Option A: Dilatation and evacuation: This is not done in an ectopic pregnancy

  • • Option D:

In this scenario there is pain and bleeding with a positive pregnancy test and on examination there is pallor, shock and intraperitoneal bleed which points to a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. options.A: Corpus luteal cyst, Circle of fire sign
options.B: Corpus luteal cyst, Ring of fire sign.
options.C: Unruptured ectopic pregnancy, Circle of fire sign
options.D: Unruptured ectopic pregnancy, Ring of fire sign

questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Unruptured ectopic pregnancy, Ring of fire sign

questions.question_text: What is the discriminatory zone for βhCG?

options.A: The level above which an ectopic gestational sac should be visualized
options.B: The level below which an ectopic gestational sac should be visualized
options.C: The level above which an intra-uterine gestational sac should be visualized
options.D: The level below which an intra-uterine gestational sac should be visualized

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. The level above which an intra-uterine gestational sac should be visualized

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Discriminatory Zone: This is the level of serum βhCG above which an intra uterine gestational sac should be seen, 1500 – 2000 IU/L for TVS 5000 – 6000 IU/L for TAS There is another concept of hCG called doubling time . This means that βhCG levels should double every 48h in early pregnancy in a normal intra-uterine pregnancy. Actually, doubling is a misnomer. The rise in βhCG should be >60% at least in 48h.
  • • Discriminatory Zone: This is the level of serum βhCG above which an intra uterine gestational sac should be seen, 1500 – 2000 IU/L for TVS 5000 – 6000 IU/L for TAS

questions.question_text: A 33-year woman comes to the OPD with amenorrhea of 6 weeks. Her urine pregnancy test is positive. A transvaginal ultrasound is done which shows normal uterus and adnexa. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Pregnancy of undetermined location

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is a PREGNANCY OF UNKNOWN LOCATION (PUL): No sign of an intra or extra uterine pregnancy on ultrasound despite a positive pregnancy test
  • • Let’s discuss all the options:
  • • Let’s discuss all the options:
  • • Option A: Complete abortion: This is unlikely a complete abortion as there is no history of vaginal bleeding or passage of a tissue. Option B: Ectopic pregnancy: This could be a possibility but there is nothing in the scenario which is suggestive of an ectopic pregnancy Option C: Pregnancy of unknown location: This is what this scenario is. A pregnancy of unknown or undetermined location (PUL) means the urine or serum bhCG is positive but the ultrasound does not show an intra uterine or extra uterine gestational sac. Option D: Pseudocyesis: This is phantom pregnancy. In this the urine pregnancy test will be negative.
  • • Option A: Complete abortion: This is unlikely a complete abortion as there is no history of vaginal bleeding or passage of a tissue.

questions.question_text: The drug of choice for medical management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Methotrexate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The drug of choice for treatment of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy is Methotrexate. MOA: Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase 2 protocols: Single dose and Multidose Usually, the single dose regime is sufficient, very rarely another dose is required.

  • • 2 protocols: Single dose and Multidose
  • • Usually, the single dose regime is sufficient, very rarely another dose is required.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B: Mifepristone: This is also known as RU486 and is a selective progesterone receptor modulator with strong anti-progestogenic action. It is commonly used in medical methods of termination of pregnancy along with misoprostol in 1 st and 2 nd trimester. Option C: Misoprostol: This is PGE1 and is a uterotonic. It induces uterine contractions and is therefore used in medical methods of termination of pregnancy, induction of labor and prophylaxis and management of atonic PPH. Option D: KCl: Ultrasound guided Intracardiac injection of Kcl is used in selective fetal termination in multifetal pregnancy reduction.

questions.question_text: Identify this procedure:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Culdocentesis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows the procedure of culdocentesis. In the absence of TVS and if the diagnosis of a ruptured ectopic is still in doubt: Culdocentesis can be done:
  • • The image shows the procedure of culdocentesis.
  • • In the absence of TVS and if the diagnosis of a ruptured ectopic is still in doubt: Culdocentesis can be done:
  • • Culdocentesis
  • • Simple technique Cervix pulled outward and upward (holding a tenaculum/ vulsullum) on the posterior cervix. 18-gauge needle is inserted in the posterior fornix Aspiration of non-clotting blood signifies hemoperitoneum A negative Culdocentesis does not rule out a ruptured ectopic pregnancy
  • • Simple technique
  • • Cervix pulled outward and upward (holding a tenaculum/ vulsullum) on the posterior cervix.
  • • 18-gauge needle is inserted in the posterior fornix
  • • Aspiration of non-clotting blood signifies hemoperitoneum
  • • A negative Culdocentesis does not rule out a ruptured ectopic pregnancy
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Endometrial biopsy: In this procedure, a sample is taken from inside the uterine cavity (endometrial) using an endometrial aspirator Option B. Cervical biopsy: In this a biopsy is taken from the cervix/ cervical growth using a punch biopsy forceps Option D. Pap smear: In this procedure, using an instrument called an Ayre’s spatula, a smear is taken from the ectocervix.
  • • Option A. Endometrial biopsy: In this procedure, a sample is taken from inside the uterine cavity (endometrial) using an endometrial aspirator
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Cervical biopsy: In this a biopsy is taken from the cervix/ cervical growth using a punch biopsy forceps
  • • Option B.
  • • Option D. Pap smear: In this procedure, using an instrument called an Ayre’s spatula, a smear is taken from the ectocervix.
  • • Option D.

questions.question_text: A 24y old lady with a history of a tubal sterilization is diagnosed to have an unruptured ectopic pregnancy of size 4 cm. Serum βhCG is 6000 IU/L. The preferred management option is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Laparoscopic salpingectomy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This woman is not a candidate for medical management as the size is > 3.5 cm and βhCG is > 3000 IU/L. She requires surgical management: In an unruptured ectopic: Laparoscopy is preferred and, in this woman, a salpingectomy (removing the tube) is preferred to a salpingostomy (conserving the tube) as the patient has a h/o tubal ligation.
  • • This woman is not a candidate for medical management as the size is > 3.5 cm and βhCG is > 3000 IU/L.

Option C: Inj Methotrexate single dose: This is also not preferred as in this scenario the beta hCG is > 5000 and the sac size is > 3.5 cm so she is not a candidate for medical management Option D: Inj methotrexate multiple doses: This is also not preferred as in this scenario the beta hCG is > 5000 and the sac size is > 3.5 cm so she is not a candidate for medical management whether single or multi dose.

  • • Option A: Expectant management is not preferred in a heterotopic pregnancy Option B: Medical management: Medical management with methotrexate is contra-indicated as it will kill the intrauterine pregnancy also Option D: Medical + Surgical: There is no role of both medical and surgical management in a heterotopic pregnancy
  • • Option A: Expectant management is not preferred in a heterotopic pregnancy
  • • Option A:
  • • Option B: Medical management: Medical management with methotrexate is contra-indicated as it will kill the intrauterine pregnancy also

questions.question_text: All are true regarding treatment of molar pregnancy except?

options.B: A baseline hemogram, TSH and Chest X-Ray is essential
options.C: Evacuation under ultrasound guidance is preferable
options.D: Inj. Anti-D in Rh negative women is not required

questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Inj. Anti-D in Rh negative women is not required

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Important points to note during suction evacuation of molar pregnancy:
  • ➤ Pre-operative Care Investigations Hemogram Baseline serum β-hCG TSH Blood group & Rh Chest X-Ray Intra-op Points to note Large bore IV Cannula as blood loss is anticipated Oxytocin 20 U in 1 L RL – continuous infusion; preferably start at the start of suction Use uterotonic agents (methergine, misoprostol, carboprost) Use a larger Karman’s cannula size (size 10-14) Under USG guidance Gentle curette with blunt end Post operative Points to note Anti-D given after procedure Initiate effective contraception Review histopathology report Serum β-hCG within 48 h of evacuation; then weekly till undetectable.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements regarding Hydatidiform mole is true?

options.A: The risk of progression to Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia is same for both complete and partial moles
options.B: The risk of progression to Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia is higher with partial mole
options.C: The risk of progression to Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia is higher with complete mole
options.D: There is no risk of progression to Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia following evacuation of either partial or complete mole.

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. The risk of progression to gestational trophoblastic neoplasia is higher with complete mole.
