questions.question_text: A 28-year-old obese female who is seeking pregnancy is recently diagnosed with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Which of the following should be recommended as first-line management for her anovulation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Letrozole

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • All the options mentioned will help in ovulation in PCOS Lifestyle management (Weight loss if BMI is high + exercise) is the PRIMARY mode of management The 1 st line ovulation induction agents are Letrozole Clomiphene citrate Amongst these 2, the recent ESHRE guidelines says that Letrozole is to be preferred over clomiphene in PCOS. Gonadotropins may be used as second line agents for ovulation induction after oral drugs. Insulin sensitizing agents such as metformin and myoinositol are also used in PCOS patients as adjunctive treatment.
  • • All the options mentioned will help in ovulation in PCOS
  • • Lifestyle management (Weight loss if BMI is high + exercise) is the PRIMARY mode of management
  • • The 1 st line ovulation induction agents are Letrozole Clomiphene citrate
  • • Letrozole Clomiphene citrate
  • • Letrozole
  • • Clomiphene citrate
  • • Amongst these 2, the recent ESHRE guidelines says that Letrozole is to be preferred over clomiphene in PCOS.
  • • Gonadotropins may be used as second line agents for ovulation induction after oral drugs. Insulin sensitizing agents such as metformin and myoinositol are also used in PCOS patients as adjunctive treatment.
  • • Let's review each option separately:
  • • Let's review each option separately:
  • • Option A. Gonadotropins : These are injectable hormones (FSH and LH) used to stimulate ovulation. While effective, they are typically not the first line of treatment for PCOS due to the increased risk of multiple pregnancies and ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. They are often considered when other treatments have failed.
  • • Option A.
  • • Gonadotropins
  • • Option B. Clomiphene Citrate : This is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that has traditionally been used as the first-line treatment for inducing ovulation in women with PCOS. It works by blocking estrogen receptors in the brain, which increases the release of FSH and LH, thereby stimulating ovulation.
  • • Option B.
  • • Clomiphene Citrate
  • • Option C. Letrozole (Correct Answer): Letrozole, an aromatase inhibitor, has recently become preferred over clomiphene citrate for the first-line management of anovulation in women with PCOS, particularly in obese patients. Studies have shown that letrozole is more effective in inducing ovulation in women with PCOS.
  • • Option C.
  • • Letrozole
  • • Option D. Insulin-Sensitizing Agents : These agents, such as metformin, are used to improve insulin resistance, a common feature in PCOS. While they can help in regulating menstrual cycles and improving the efficacy of ovulation-inducing agents, they are generally not used as a standalone first-line treatment
  • • Option D.
  • • Insulin-Sensitizing Agents

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Letrozole has emerged as a preferred first-line treatment due to its higher efficacy in inducing ovulation and also due to mono-follicular development compared to clomiphene citrate, especially in obese patients with PCOS.
  • ➤ Letrozole has emerged as a preferred first-line treatment due to its higher efficacy in inducing ovulation and also due to mono-follicular development compared to clomiphene citrate, especially in obese patients with PCOS.

questions.question_text: In women with hyperprolactinemia caused by a pituitary micro-prolactinoma, which of the following is true?

options.A: Surgical therapy is preferred over medical therapy.
options.B: During pregnancy, cabergoline is preferred over bromocriptine.
options.C: Clomiphene citrate may be ineffective for ovulation induction.
options.D: Dopamine-agonist therapy should be increased once pregnancy is achieved.

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Clomiphene citrate may be ineffective for ovulation induction.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • If hyperprolactinemia is found, then physiologic, pharmacologic, or other secondary causes of hormone hypersecretion are sought Dopamine agonists are the primary treatment of hyperprolactinemia. Surgical therapies are only considered with prolactin-secreting adenomas resistant to medical therapy. During pregnancy, if hyperprolactinemia is not associated with a pituitary lesion or a lesion is less than 10 mm (microadenoma), then dopamine-agonist therapy is stopped because the tumor expansion risk is low Bromocriptine is preferred in pregnancy.
  • • If hyperprolactinemia is found, then physiologic, pharmacologic, or other secondary causes of hormone hypersecretion are sought
  • • Dopamine agonists are the primary treatment of hyperprolactinemia.
  • • Surgical therapies are only considered with prolactin-secreting adenomas resistant to medical therapy.
  • • During pregnancy, if hyperprolactinemia is not associated with a pituitary lesion or a lesion is less than 10 mm (microadenoma), then dopamine-agonist therapy is stopped because the tumor expansion risk is low
  • • Bromocriptine is preferred in pregnancy.
  • • Let's evaluate each option:
  • • Let's evaluate each option:
  • • Option A. Surgical therapy is preferred over medical therapy : This is generally not true. Medical therapy, typically with dopamine agonists like bromocriptine or cabergoline, is the first-line treatment for hyperprolactinemia, including that caused by micro-prolactinomas. These medications are effective in reducing prolactin levels and often lead to tumor shrinkage. Surgical therapy is usually reserved for cases where medical therapy is ineffective or not tolerated.
  • • Option A.
  • • Surgical therapy is preferred over medical therapy
  • • Option B. During pregnancy, cabergoline is preferred over bromocriptine : Actually, bromocriptine is generally preferred over cabergoline during pregnancy. Bromocriptine has a longer track record and more data supporting its safety in pregnancy
  • • Option B.
  • • During pregnancy, cabergoline is preferred over bromocriptine
  • • Option C. Clomiphene citrate may be ineffective for ovulation induction (Correct Answer): This is true. Clomiphene citrate is an ovulation induction agent that works by blocking estrogen receptors, leading to an increase in the release of FSH and LH. However, in the presence of elevated prolactin levels, as seen in hyperprolactinemia, the effectiveness of clomiphene may be diminished. Therefore, normalizing prolactin levels with dopamine agonists is often necessary before or in conjunction with using clomiphene.
  • • Option C.
  • • Clomiphene citrate may be ineffective for ovulation induction
  • • Option D. Dopamine-agonist therapy should be increased once pregnancy is achieved : This is not typically recommended. In fact, dopamine agonist therapy is often discontinued once pregnancy is confirmed in women with micro-prolactinomas. This is because the risk of tumor growth during pregnancy is low, and the safety of continued use of these drugs during pregnancy is not fully established.
  • • Option D.
  • • Dopamine-agonist therapy should be increased once pregnancy is achieved

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ First-line treatment of hyper-prolactinemia with a mico-adenoma typically involves medical therapy with dopamine agonists, which are effective in lowering prolactin levels and can restore ovulatory function.
  • ➤ First-line treatment of hyper-prolactinemia with a mico-adenoma typically involves medical therapy with dopamine agonists, which are effective in lowering prolactin levels and can restore ovulatory function.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 450, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 450, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.question_text: Compared with clomiphene citrate therapy, gonadotropin therapy has which of the following characteristics?

options.D: Greater negative effect on the endometrium

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Higher ovulation rate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Gonadotropins are usually 2 nd line drugs for ovulation induction They are preferred in hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism They have a higher ovulation rate and a higher multiple pregnancy rate also. Women with PCOS have ovaries highly sensitive to gonadotropin stimulation. They have a higher risk of excessive ovarian response and of multifetal pregnancy than those with normal ovaries. Unlike clomiphene, they do not have a negative effect on the endometrium.
  • • Gonadotropins are usually 2 nd line drugs for ovulation induction
  • • They are preferred in hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism
  • • They have a higher ovulation rate and a higher multiple pregnancy rate also.
  • • Women with PCOS have ovaries highly sensitive to gonadotropin stimulation. They have a higher risk of excessive ovarian response and of multifetal pregnancy than those with normal ovaries.
  • • Unlike clomiphene, they do not have a negative effect on the endometrium.
  • • Let's examine each option separately :
  • • Let's examine each option separately :
  • • Option A. Higher Ovulation Rate (Correct Answer): This is because gonadotropins more directly stimulate the ovaries, whereas clomiphene citrate works indirectly by blocking estrogen receptors, which in turn promotes the release of FSH and LH.
  • • Option A.
  • • Higher Ovulation Rate
  • • Option B . Lower Multiple Pregnancy Rate : This is not true for gonadotropin therapy. In fact, gonadotropin therapy has a higher risk of multiple pregnancies compared to clomiphene citrate. This is due to the more potent and direct ovarian stimulation with gonadotropins, which can lead to the development of multiple follicles.
  • • Option B
  • • Lower Multiple Pregnancy Rate
  • • Option C. Lower Ovarian Hyperstimulation Rate : Gonadotropin therapy actually has a higher risk of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) compared to clomiphene citrate. The ovaries become swollen and painful, and it is more likely with stimulation of the ovaries by gonadotropins.
  • • Option C.
  • • Lower Ovarian Hyperstimulation Rate
  • • Option D. Greater Negative Effect on the Endometrium : Clomiphene citrate, not gonadotropin therapy, is more commonly associated with a negative effect on the endometrium.
  • • Option D.
  • • Greater Negative Effect on the Endometrium

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ref: Page 479, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 479, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.question_text: Which of the following is LEAST likely to be true regarding clomiphene citrate therapy?

options.A: The typical starting dose is 100 mg.
options.B: It is classified as a category X drug by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA).
options.C: It can be initiated on the second day of the menstrual cycle.
options.D: Most pregnancies will occur during the first three treatment cycles.

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The typical starting dose is 100 mg.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Clomiphene citrate is an anti-estrogen It is used in ovulation induction in anovulatory women (PCOS) It is given as a starting dose of 50mg from Day2 to Day 6 followed by an follicular imaging scan from the 10 th day of the period It is contra-indicated in pregnancy (FDA Category X)
  • • Clomiphene citrate is an anti-estrogen
  • • It is used in ovulation induction in anovulatory women (PCOS)
  • • It is given as a starting dose of 50mg from Day2 to Day 6 followed by an follicular imaging scan from the 10 th day of the period
  • • It is contra-indicated in pregnancy (FDA Category X)
  • • Let's evaluate each option:
  • • Let's evaluate each option:
  • • Option A. The typical starting dose is 100 mg (Correct Answer): This is the least likely to be true. The typical starting dose of clomiphene citrate is usually 50 mg per day, not 100 mg. The dose may be increased in subsequent cycles if there is no response, but starting at a higher dose increases the risk of side effects, including the chance of multiple pregnancies.
  • • Option A.
  • • The typical starting dose is 100 mg
  • • Option B. It is classified as a category X drug by the FDA : Clomiphene citrate is actually classified as FDA pregnancy category X, meaning that it should not be used during pregnancy. The drug is used to induce ovulation, but if a woman becomes pregnant, the use of clomiphene should be discontinued due to potential risks to the fetus.
  • • Option B.
  • • It is classified as a category X drug by the FDA
  • • Option C. It can be initiated on the second day of the menstrual cycle : This is true. Clomiphene citrate is often initiated on the second, third, fourth, or fifth day of the menstrual cycle.
  • • Option C.
  • • It can be initiated on the second day of the menstrual cycle
  • • Option D. Most pregnancies will occur during the first three treatment cycles : This is true. The majority of pregnancies achieved with clomiphene citrate occur within the first three cycles of treatment. If conception has not occurred after this time, the likelihood of success with continued use of clomiphene decreases, and other treatment options may be considered.
  • • Option D.
  • • Most pregnancies will occur during the first three treatment cycles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ref: Page 450, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 450, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.question_text: A 38-year-old with infertility secondary to tubal blockage just underwent in vitro fertilization (IVF). Her peak estradiol was 4500 pg/mL. Seventeen oocytes were retrieved, and two embryos were transferred. She conceived with a singleton gestation. She developed ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. Which of the following was a predisposing factor in developing ovarian hyperstimulation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Estradiol level

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Risk factors for OHSS include
  • • Young age (< 35y) Low BMI PCOS History of allergy/ atopy High serum estradiol Previous h/o OHSS Multiple follicles (PCOS) High dose/ repeated doses of hCG Pregnancy
  • • Young age (< 35y)
  • • Low BMI
  • • PCOS
  • • History of allergy/ atopy
  • • High serum estradiol
  • • Previous h/o OHSS
  • • Multiple follicles (PCOS)
  • • High dose/ repeated doses of hCG
  • • Pregnancy
  • • Let's examine each option in relation to the predisposition to OHSS:
  • • Let's examine each option in relation to the predisposition to OHSS:
  • • Option A . Her Age : While age can impact various aspects of fertility and responses to fertility treatments, it is not typically considered a direct predisposing factor for the development of OHSS. Women of varying ages can develop OHSS, and it's more related to the response to the ovarian stimulation rather than age per se.
  • • Option A
  • • Her Age
  • • Option B. Estradiol Level (Correct Answer): A high estradiol level is indeed a key predisposing factor for OHSS. A peak estradiol level of 4500 pg/mL, as mentioned in the scenario, is significantly high and can be associated with an increased risk of developing OHSS. This is due to the large number of growing follicles producing estradiol, which can lead to increased vascular permeability and the symptoms associated with OHSS.
  • • Option B.
  • • Estradiol Level
  • • Option C. Etiology of Her Infertility : The underlying cause of infertility (in this case, tubal blockage) is generally not a direct risk factor for OHSS
  • • Option C.
  • • Etiology of Her Infertility
  • • Option D. Number of Embryos Transferred : The number of embryos transferred does not directly predispose to OHSS. OHSS is related to the ovarian response to stimulation during the IVF cycle, not the embryo transfer process
  • • Option D.
  • • Number of Embryos Transferred

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 456, Williams Gynecology 3 rd editio
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 456, Williams Gynecology 3 rd editio

questions.question_text: Which of the following hormones is thought to play a major role in ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Human chorionic gonadotropin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • OHSS is characterized by multiple follicular development and ovarian enlargement following hCG stimulation. It occurs mostly in IVF due to controlled ovarian hyperstimulation (COH) but can also happen with simple ovulation induction It is an iatrogenic and potentially a life-threatening complication of COH hCG and VEGF have been implicated in the etiology of OHSS
  • • OHSS is characterized by multiple follicular development and ovarian enlargement following hCG stimulation.
  • • It occurs mostly in IVF due to controlled ovarian hyperstimulation (COH) but can also happen with simple ovulation induction
  • • It is an iatrogenic and potentially a life-threatening complication of COH
  • • hCG and VEGF have been implicated in the etiology of OHSS
  • • Let's review each option:
  • • Let's review each option:
  • • Option A. Progesterone : Progesterone is a hormone produced by the corpus luteum after ovulation and during pregnancy. While it plays a critical role in the menstrual cycle and maintaining pregnancy, it is not primarily implicated in the development of OHSS.
  • • Option A.
  • • Progesterone
  • • Option B. Luteinizing Hormone (LH) : LH is involved in the natural ovulation process. It triggers ovulation and the development of the corpus luteum. While controlled ovarian hyperstimulation often involves drugs that mimic LH action, LH itself is not the primary hormone implicated in OHSS.
  • • Option B.
  • • Luteinizing Hormone (LH)
  • • Option C. Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) (Correct Answer): hCG is the hormone primarily implicated in OHSS. In fertility treatments, hCG is often used to mimic the natural LH surge to trigger ovulation. However, its use, especially in high doses or in sensitive individuals, can lead to OHSS. hCG stimulates the ovaries to produce more estrogen, leading to ovarian enlargement and increased vascular permeability, which are key features of OHSS.
  • • Option C.
  • • Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG)
  • • Option D. Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH) : FSH is used in fertility treatments to stimulate the development of ovarian follicles. While it plays a role in controlled ovarian hyperstimulation, it is not directly responsible for the development of OHSS.
  • • Option D.
  • • Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ref: Page 456, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 456, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

@dams_new_robot

questions.question_text: If concern for ovarian hyperstimulation is present during ovulation induction, which of the following can be used to induce the endogenous luteinizing hormone (LH) surge?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • OHSS can be prevented by the following ways:
  • • Use of GnRH antagonists (instead of GnRH agonists) for down regulation Low starting dose of gonadotropins in high-risk women Metformin cotreatment during gonadotropin stimulation in women with PCOS or at high risk of OHSS Close monitoring of the superovulation cycles using TVS and serum estradiol estimation Replacing hCG with leuprolide (GnRH agonist) as a maturation trigger (i.e. induce the LH surge) To withhold ovulatory dose of hCG in susceptible cases and to cancel the cycle or to delay the dose of hCG injection (coasting) Cryopreservation of oocytes or embryos for future use Aspiration of immature oocytes and in vitro maturation (IVM) Progesterone should be used for luteal phase support instead of hCG Cabergoline and albumin have a role in reducing the incidence of OHSS in those at high risk
  • • Use of GnRH antagonists (instead of GnRH agonists) for down regulation
  • • Low starting dose of gonadotropins in high-risk women
  • • Metformin cotreatment during gonadotropin stimulation in women with PCOS or at high risk of OHSS
  • • Close monitoring of the superovulation cycles using TVS and serum estradiol estimation
  • • Replacing hCG with leuprolide (GnRH agonist) as a maturation trigger (i.e. induce the LH surge)
  • • To withhold ovulatory dose of hCG in susceptible cases and to cancel the cycle or to delay the dose of hCG injection (coasting)
  • • Cryopreservation of oocytes or embryos for future use
  • • Aspiration of immature oocytes and in vitro maturation (IVM)
  • • Progesterone should be used for luteal phase support instead of hCG
  • • Cabergoline and albumin have a role in reducing the incidence of OHSS in those at high risk
  • • Let's review each option:
  • • Let's review each option:
  • • Option A. Urinary Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) : This is commonly used to induce ovulation, as it acts like the body's natural luteinizing hormone (LH) surge. However, hCG can increase the risk of OHSS, especially in patients who are overly responsive to ovarian stimulation.
  • • Option A.
  • • Urinary Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG)
  • • Option B. Recombinant Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) : Similar to urinary hCG, recombinant hCG is used to induce ovulation but can also contribute to the development of OHSS. Both forms of hCG have a longer duration of action, which can exacerbate OHSS in high-risk patients.
  • • Option B.
  • • Recombinant Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG)
  • • Option C. Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH) Agonist (Correct Answer): In patients at risk for OHSS, a GnRH agonist can be used to trigger ovulation. Unlike hCG, GnRH agonists cause a shorter and more physiologic LH surge, which can induce ovulation with a lower risk of OHSS. This is particularly beneficial in patients undergoing controlled ovarian stimulation as part of an IVF cycle who have a high number of follicles.
  • • Option C.
  • • Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH) Agonist
  • • Option D. Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH) Antagonist : GnRH antagonists are used during ovarian stimulation protocols to prevent premature ovulation. They do not trigger the LH surge.
  • • Option D.
  • • Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH) Antagonist

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ref: Page 456, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 456, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.question_text: Which of the following infertility scenarios would warrant intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI)?

options.B: Infertility secondary to diminished ovarian reserve
options.C: Infertility secondary to bilateral distal fallopian tube occlusion
options.D: Infertility secondary to the male partner’s severe oligospermia

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Infertility secondary to the male partner’s severe oligospermia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • ICSI is intra cytoplasmic sperm injection It is a variation of IVF and is most applicable to male actor infertility. During the micromanipulation technique of ICSI, cumulus cells surrounding an ovum are enzymatically digested, and a single sperm is directly injected through the zona pellucida and oocyte cell membrane. Pregnancy rates with ICSI are comparable with those achieved with IVF or other causes of infertility.
  • • ICSI is intra cytoplasmic sperm injection
  • • It is a variation of IVF and is most applicable to male actor infertility.
  • • During the micromanipulation technique of ICSI, cumulus cells surrounding an ovum are enzymatically digested, and a single sperm is directly injected through the zona pellucida and oocyte cell membrane.
  • • Pregnancy rates with ICSI are comparable with those achieved with IVF or other causes of infertility.
  • • Let's review each option:
  • • Let's review each option:
  • • Option A. Infertility secondary to Anovulation : Anovulation, the absence of ovulation, is often treated with medications that induce ovulation, such as clomiphene citrate or gonadotropins. ICSI is not typically indicated in cases where the primary issue is anovulation, as the main challenge is to produce a viable egg, not the fertilization process itself.
  • • Option A.
  • • Infertility secondary to Anovulation
  • • Option B. Infertility secondary to Diminished Ovarian Reserve : While IVF may be recommended in such cases to maximize the chance of fertilization, ICSI is not necessarily indicated unless there is also a concurrent male factor infertility.
  • • Option B.
  • • Infertility secondary to Diminished Ovarian Reserve
  • • Option C. Infertility secondary to Bilateral Distal Fallopian Tube Occlusion : When the fallopian tubes are blocked, particularly at the distal end (farther from the uterus), IVF is the usual treatment of choice because it bypasses the fallopian tubes altogether. ICSI may be added if there is an additional factor of male infertility.
  • • Option C.
  • • Infertility secondary to Bilateral Distal Fallopian Tube Occlusion
  • • Option D. Infertility secondary to the Male Partner’s Severe Oligospermia (Correct Answer): Severe oligospermia, characterized by a very low sperm count, is a classic indication for ICSI. In such cases, the chances of sperm naturally fertilizing an egg are significantly reduced. ICSI addresses this by directly injecting a single sperm into the egg, thus bypassing the need for a large number of motile sperm.
  • • Option D.
  • • Infertility secondary to the Male Partner’s Severe Oligospermia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ ReF: Page 465, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ ReF: Page 465, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.question_text: Which of the following assisted reproductive technologies (ART) techniques is shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Embryo biopsy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is an image showing embryo biopsy which is done in pre-implantation genetic diagnosis During this technique, cells are removed from a developing embryo. Multiple options exist regarding biopsy timing and genetic material source. Biopsy of the first and second polar body has the advantage of avoiding cell removal from the developing embryo, but the disadvantage is that genetic abnormalities of paternal origin are not detected. Biopsy of cleavage-stage embryos (6- to 8-cell stage) allows evaluation of both maternal and paternal contribution to the genome Biopsy of tropho-ectoderm at the blastocyst stage
  • • This is an image showing embryo biopsy which is done in pre-implantation genetic diagnosis
  • • During this technique, cells are removed from a developing embryo.
  • • Multiple options exist regarding biopsy timing and genetic material source. Biopsy of the first and second polar body has the advantage of avoiding cell removal from the developing embryo, but the disadvantage is that genetic abnormalities of paternal origin are not detected. Biopsy of cleavage-stage embryos (6- to 8-cell stage) allows evaluation of both maternal and paternal contribution to the genome Biopsy of tropho-ectoderm at the blastocyst stage
  • • Biopsy of the first and second polar body has the advantage of avoiding cell removal from the developing embryo, but the disadvantage is that genetic abnormalities of paternal origin are not detected. Biopsy of cleavage-stage embryos (6- to 8-cell stage) allows evaluation of both maternal and paternal contribution to the genome Biopsy of tropho-ectoderm at the blastocyst stage
  • • Biopsy of the first and second polar body has the advantage of avoiding cell removal from the developing embryo, but the disadvantage is that genetic abnormalities of paternal origin are not detected.
  • • Biopsy of cleavage-stage embryos (6- to 8-cell stage) allows evaluation of both maternal and paternal contribution to the genome
  • • Biopsy of tropho-ectoderm at the blastocyst stage
  • • Let us look at each option separately:
  • • Let us look at each option separately:
  • • Option A. Embryo Biopsy : This technique involves removing one or more cells from an embryo to test for genetic conditions before transferring the embryo to the uterus. It is often used in conjunction with preimplantation genetic testing (PGT) to identify embryos with genetic abnormalities or specific inherited disorders.
  • • Option A.
  • • Embryo Biopsy
  • • Option B. Assisted Hatching : This technique involves making a small hole in the zona pellucida (the outer layer of the embryo) to assist the embryo in breaking free during the process of implantation. It's sometimes used to improve the chances of implantation, particularly in certain groups of patients such as older women or those with previous failed IVF cycles.
  • • Option B.
  • • Assisted Hatching
  • • Option C. Oocyte In Vitro Maturation (IVM) : In this process, immature eggs are collected from the ovaries and matured in the laboratory. This is different from conventional IVF, where medication is used to mature the eggs inside the ovaries before they are collected.
  • • Option C.
  • • Oocyte In Vitro Maturation (IVM)
  • • Option D. Intracytoplasmic Sperm Injection (ICSI) : ICSI involves injecting a single sperm directly into an egg to achieve fertilization. It's used especially in cases of severe male factor infertility, where sperm may have difficulty penetrating the egg on their own.
  • • Option D.
  • • Intracytoplasmic Sperm Injection (ICSI)

  • ➤ Educational Objective

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an indication for gestational surrogacy
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mullerian agenesis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Mullerian agenesis is an example of absolute uterine factor infertility which is an indication for gestational surrogacy. Gestational surrogacy is a variation to IVF in which a fertilized egg is placed into the uterus of a surrogate rather than into the “intended mother.” Indications: Women with uncorrectable uterine factors Those in whom pregnancy would pose significant health risks h/o repetitive unexplained abortions
  • • Mullerian agenesis is an example of absolute uterine factor infertility which is an indication for gestational surrogacy.
  • • Gestational surrogacy is a variation to IVF in which a fertilized egg is placed into the uterus of a surrogate rather than into the “intended mother.”
  • • Indications: Women with uncorrectable uterine factors Those in whom pregnancy would pose significant health risks h/o repetitive unexplained abortions
  • • Women with uncorrectable uterine factors Those in whom pregnancy would pose significant health risks h/o repetitive unexplained abortions
  • • Women with uncorrectable uterine factors
  • • Those in whom pregnancy would pose significant health risks
  • • h/o repetitive unexplained abortions
  • • Thus, option B: Mullerian agenesis is an indication for surrogacy.
  • • Thus, option B: Mullerian agenesis is an indication for surrogacy.
  • • Let's review each option to determine the most appropriate indication for gestational surrogacy:
  • • Let's review each option to determine the most appropriate indication for gestational surrogacy:
  • • Option A. Tubercular Salpingitis : This condition involves inflammation of the fallopian tubes due to tuberculosis, which can lead to infertility. Women with tubercular salpingitis may be treated with anti-tubercular therapy and potentially IVF if the fallopian tubes are significantly damaged.
  • • Option A.
  • • Tubercular Salpingitis
  • • Option B. Mullerian Agenesis (Correct Answer): Mullerian agenesis, also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome, is a condition where a woman is born without a uterus or with an underdeveloped uterus. Since these women cannot carry a pregnancy themselves, gestational surrogacy is a viable option for them to have a child genetically related to them (using their own eggs, if ovaries are functional, and a partner's or donor's sperm).
  • • Option B.
  • • Mullerian Agenesis
  • • Option C. Azoospermia : This is a male infertility condition where there is no sperm in the ejaculate. Azoospermia itself is not an indication for gestational surrogacy but rather for male fertility treatments, such as surgical sperm retrieval combined with IVF/ICSI (Intracytoplasmic Sperm Injection).
  • • Option C.
  • • Azoospermia
  • • Option D. Premature Ovarian Failure : This condition occurs when a woman's ovaries stop functioning normally before the age of 40. While it can lead to infertility, it's not a direct indication for gestational surrogacy. Women with premature ovarian failure may consider options like IVF using donor eggs.
  • • Option D.
  • • Premature Ovarian Failure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Gestational surrogacy is particularly relevant for women who are unable to carry a pregnancy, such as those with Mullerian agenesis. In contrast, conditions affecting the fallopian tubes, male factor infertility, or ovarian function may require different assisted reproductive technologies, but not necessarily surrogacy.
  • ➤ Gestational surrogacy is particularly relevant for women who are unable to carry a pregnancy, such as those with Mullerian agenesis.
  • ➤ In contrast, conditions affecting the fallopian tubes, male factor infertility, or ovarian function may require different assisted reproductive technologies, but not necessarily surrogacy.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 465, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 465, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.question_text: A patient comes to your OPD for infertility treatment. Her HSG shows the following picture. What would be the best management for her?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hysteroscopic bilateral tubal cannulation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is an HSG showing a bilateral cornual block (block at the proximal portion as the tubes cannot be seen at all). Cornual block (proximal tubal obstructions) can be managed with proximal tubal catheterization and cannulation (via hysteroscopy or HSG) with 85% success in restoring tubal patency. Distal tubal occlusion is usually secondary to inflammatory conditions, endometriosis and previous h/o surgery. If < 35y, microsurgery can be considered (Tuboplasty). IF > 35 y, IVF should be considered. The choice of treatment largely depends on the specific findings of the HSG:
  • • This is an HSG showing a bilateral cornual block (block at the proximal portion as the tubes cannot be seen at all).
  • • Cornual block (proximal tubal obstructions) can be managed with proximal tubal catheterization and cannulation (via hysteroscopy or HSG) with 85% success in restoring tubal patency.
  • • Distal tubal occlusion is usually secondary to inflammatory conditions, endometriosis and previous h/o surgery. If < 35y, microsurgery can be considered (Tuboplasty). IF > 35 y, IVF should be considered. The choice of treatment largely depends on the specific findings of the HSG:
  • • Let us look at each option
  • • Let us look at each option
  • • Option A. IVF (In Vitro Fertilization) : IVF is often considered when there are severe tubal abnormalities (such as bilateral tubal blockage), severe male factor infertility, or when other fertility treatments have failed. If the HSG shows severely damaged or blocked fallopian tubes that are unlikely to be successfully treated with surgery, IVF may be the recommended option.
  • • Option A.
  • • IVF (In Vitro Fertilization)
  • • Option B. Tuboplasty : This surgical procedure is used to repair or reconstruct the fallopian tubes. It's considered in cases where there's tubal damage or blockage that is amenable to surgical correction. The success of tuboplasty depends on the location and extent of the tubal damage.
  • • Option B.
  • • Tuboplasty
  • • Option C. Hysteroscopic Bilateral Tubal Cannulation : This procedure is used in cases of proximal tubal blockage (blockage near the uterus). It involves the use of a hysteroscope and a cannula to open up the blocked segments of the fallopian tubes. If the HSG shows proximal tubal blockage, this procedure can be an effective treatment.
  • • Option C.
  • • Hysteroscopic Bilateral Tubal Cannulation
  • • Option D. Ovulation Induction : This treatment is used when the primary cause of infertility is anovulation. If the HSG shows that the fallopian tubes are open and the main issue is a lack of ovulation, ovulation induction might be the appropriate treatment.
  • • Option D.
  • • Ovulation Induction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ HSG is a valuable diagnostic tool in evaluating the fallopian tubes and the uterine cavity, and its findings are critical in guiding the appropriate management approach, whether surgical or medical. Hysteroscopic Bilateral Tubal Cannulation is used in cases of proximal tubal blockage (blockage near the uterus).
  • ➤ HSG is a valuable diagnostic tool in evaluating the fallopian tubes and the uterine cavity, and its findings are critical in guiding the appropriate management approach, whether surgical or medical.
  • ➤ Hysteroscopic Bilateral Tubal Cannulation is used in cases of proximal tubal blockage (blockage near the uterus).
  • ➤ Hysteroscopic Bilateral Tubal Cannulation
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1158, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th edition

questions.question_text: Which of the following is true regarding semen analysis parameters?

options.B: For semen analysis, abstinence of 4-5 days is a must
options.C: In healthy semen, morphologically normal sperms should be > 32%
options.D: Sperm morphology is the best parameter for assessing sperm function

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sperm morphology is the best parameter for assessing sperm function

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The single most important investigation is Semen Analysis The WHO has defined semen analysis parameters which were recently revised in 2020. These are important to know.
  • • The single most important investigation is Semen Analysis
  • • The WHO has defined semen analysis parameters which were recently revised in 2020. These are important to know.
  • • The WHO recommends an abstinence of 2-7 days prior to collection for standard semen evaluation Sperm morphology is the best parameter for assessing sperm function.
  • • The WHO recommends an abstinence of 2-7 days prior to collection for standard semen evaluation
  • • Sperm morphology is the best parameter for assessing sperm function.
  • • Let's review each option separately:
  • • Let's review each option separately:
  • • Option A. Sperm Count < 50 million/ml is Oligospermia : According to the World Health Organization (WHO) standards, oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration lower than 15 million/ml.
  • • Option A.
  • • Sperm Count < 50 million/ml is Oligospermia
  • • Option B. For Semen Analysis, Abstinence of 4-5 Days is a Must : The WHO recommends an abstinence period of 2 to 7 days before semen analysis. While 4-5 days is within this range and often advised, it's not an absolute "must”
  • • Option B.
  • • For Semen Analysis, Abstinence of 4-5 Days is a Must
  • • Option C. In Healthy Semen, Morphologically Normal Sperms Should be > 32% : According to the WHO’s latest criteria, a sample is considered normal if 4% or more of the sperm have normal morphology.
  • • Option C.
  • • In Healthy Semen, Morphologically Normal Sperms Should be > 32%
  • • Option D . Sperm Morphology is the Best Parameter for Assessing Sperm Function : The ability of sperm to fertilize an egg depends on a combination of factors, including count, motility (movement), and morphology (shape). A comprehensive evaluation of all these factors is generally needed.
  • • Option D
  • • Sperm Morphology is the Best Parameter for Assessing Sperm Function

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Sperm count, morphology, and motility are all important aspects of the analysis. It's important to note that a comprehensive approach, considering all semen parameters, is crucial in assessing male fertility Sperm Morphology is the Best Parameter for Assessing Sperm Function : The ability of sperm to fertilize an egg depends on a combination of factors, including count
  • ➤ Sperm count, morphology, and motility are all important aspects of the analysis. It's important to note that a comprehensive approach, considering all semen parameters, is crucial in assessing male fertility
  • ➤ Sperm Morphology is the Best Parameter for Assessing Sperm Function : The ability of sperm to fertilize an egg depends on a combination of factors, including count

questions.question_text: A 28-year women with history of an ectopic pregnancy presents with subfertility of 3 years. She complains of recurrent vaginal discharge. A transvaginal ultrasound reveals the following. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hydrosalpinx

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The above scenario is that of a hydrosalpinx. Points in favor of this are:
  • • H/o ectopic pregnancy H/o subfertility Recurrent discharge PV USG showing a retort shaped hypoechoic collection suggestive of hydrosalpinx
  • • H/o ectopic pregnancy
  • • H/o subfertility
  • • Recurrent discharge PV
  • • USG showing a retort shaped hypoechoic collection suggestive of hydrosalpinx
  • • Let's review each option in the context of the provided information:
  • • Let's review each option in the context of the provided information:
  • • Option A. Ovarian Malignancy : This diagnosis would be suggested by the presence of complex masses or irregularities in the ovaries. However, ovarian malignancies often present with additional clinical signs and symptoms, and they might have more complex features on ultrasound than what is typically seen in cases of hydrosalpinx.
  • • Option A.
  • • Ovarian Malignancy
  • • Option B. Chocolate Cyst (Endometrioma) : A chocolate cyst or endometrioma is associated with endometriosis and typically appears as a cystic ovarian mass with homogenous, low-level internal echoes on ultrasound, due to the presence of old blood.
  • • Option B.
  • • Chocolate Cyst (Endometrioma)
  • • Option C. Hydrosalpinx (Correct Answer): Hydrosalpinx refers to the accumulation of fluid in a fallopian tube, often resulting from past infection or inflammation, such as from an ectopic pregnancy. On ultrasound, it appears as an elongated, fluid-filled sac typically adjacent to the ovary. Given the patient's history of ectopic pregnancy and the description of the ultrasound findings, hydrosalpinx is the most likely diagnosis.
  • • Option C.
  • • Hydrosalpinx
  • • Option D. Broad Ligament Fibroid : A fibroid in the broad ligament would typically appear as a solid mass on ultrasound, often with a characteristic whorled pattern. It is distinct from a fluid-filled structure like a hydrosalpinx.
  • • Option D.
  • • Broad Ligament Fibroid

questions.question_text: A 28-year-old P1L1 woman complains of significant dysmenorrhea & dyspareunia. She has menses every month & has no past history of any abdominal surgery or any vaginal infection. Which of the following tests would most likely identify the etiology of the infertility in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Laparoscopy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is likely a case of endometriosis Regular periods rules out ovarian causes like PCOS; hence basal body temperature and progesterone assay are not essential to identify pathology in this patient HSG is useful for tubal pathology, but endometriosis is best diagnosed by laparoscopy C/F of endometriosis are: 5 D’s Dysmenorrhea Dyspareunia Dull aching abdominal pain Dysfertility (Infertility) Dyschezia
  • • This is likely a case of endometriosis
  • • Regular periods rules out ovarian causes like PCOS; hence basal body temperature and progesterone assay are not essential to identify pathology in this patient
  • • HSG is useful for tubal pathology, but endometriosis is best diagnosed by laparoscopy
  • • C/F of endometriosis are: 5 D’s Dysmenorrhea Dyspareunia Dull aching abdominal pain Dysfertility (Infertility) Dyschezia
  • • 5 D’s
  • • Dysmenorrhea Dyspareunia Dull aching abdominal pain Dysfertility (Infertility) Dyschezia
  • • Dysmenorrhea
  • • Dyspareunia
  • • Dull aching abdominal pain
  • • Dysfertility (Infertility)
  • • Dyschezia
  • • Let's review each option separately:
  • • Let's review each option separately:
  • • Option A. Laparoscopy : Given the symptoms of significant dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia, with a normal menstrual cycle and no history of abdominal surgery or vaginal infection, endometriosis is a likely differential diagnosis. Laparoscopy is the gold standard for the diagnosis of endometriosis. It allows direct visualization of the pelvic organs and the identification, biopsy, and potentially treatment of endometriotic lesions
  • • Option A.
  • • Laparoscopy
  • • Option B. Basal Body Temperature Chart : While a basal body temperature chart can help in understanding ovulation patterns, it is less likely to identify the cause of dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia.
  • • Option B.
  • • Basal Body Temperature Chart
  • • Option C. Hysterosalpingogram (HSG) : It can be used to identify uterine abnormalities or tubal blockage but is less effective in diagnosing conditions like endometriosis, which more commonly cause dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia.
  • • Option C.
  • • Hysterosalpingogram (HSG)
  • • Option D. Progesterone Assay : This test measures the level of progesterone to confirm ovulation, but it would not directly identify the cause of her pain or infertility, especially in the context of a regular menstrual cycle.
  • • Option D.
  • • Progesterone Assay

questions.question_text: 22-year-old woman is anxious to conceive and is recently married since a few months. Her menstrual cycle ranges from 30-35 days. She explained the fertile period. In addition, which test will help her determine when she is ovulating?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Urine LH

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Tests for Ovulation are:
  • • Basal body temperature Progesterone causes an increase in 0.5 - 1 ° F Inexpensive Limitation: It is a retrospective diagnosis Cervical mucus Under the influence of progesterone, the cervical mucous becomes thick and sticky called “Spinnbarkeit” LH monitoring 2 hours following serum LH surge, urinary LH is detected Commercially available urinary LH kits can detect urinary LH by ELISA Once LH surge detected; ovulation occurs within 48 h Midluteal serum Progesterone Done on Day 21; >10 ng/ml – confirms ovulation Transvaginal ultrasound Serial scans from Day 10; Dominant follicle when it is 18-20 mm Endometrial biopsy Secretory changes in the endometrium indicate ovulation Done between Day 24-28 Invasive so not preferred

  • • Under the influence of progesterone, the cervical mucous becomes thick and sticky called “Spinnbarkeit”

  • • Let's review each option separately:
  • • Let's review each option separately:
  • • Option A. Serum FSH : Follicle-stimulating hormone is important for the growth and maturation of ovarian follicles. While FSH levels rise at the beginning of the menstrual cycle, they are not typically used to predict ovulation .
  • • Option A.
  • • Serum FSH
  • • Option B. Serum LH : Luteinizing hormone surges in the bloodstream just before ovulation, triggering the release of a mature egg from the ovary. Measuring serum LH can indicate impending ovulation, but blood tests are not as practical for routine ovulation tracking.
  • • Option B.
  • • Serum LH
  • • Option C. Urine LH (Correct Answer): Urine LH tests, often known as ovulation predictor kits are a practical and widely used method to detect the surge in LH that precedes ovulation by about 24-36 hours. These home tests are user-friendly and allow women to track their most fertile days with good accuracy.
  • • Option C.
  • • Urine LH
  • • Option D. Urine FSH : Similar to serum FSH, urine FSH is not typically used to predict ovulation.
  • • Option D.
  • • Urine FSH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The use of ovulation predictor kits that measure LH in urine is a practical and effective method for women to identify their fertile window.

questions.question_text: A 35-year woman was planned to undergo a laparoscopic tubal ligation. The instrument shown below was used to create pneumoperitoneum. All are signs that carbon dioxide is in the peritoneal cavity except?

options.A: A drop of saline on the hub of the needle is sucked in if the needle is in the peritoneal cavity
options.B: On pushing saline, the fluid can’t be aspirated if it is in the peritoneal cavity
options.C: The pressure in the peritoneal cavity will be > 10 mmHg, if the needle is in the peritoneal cavity.
options.D: Obliteration of liver dullness if gas is intraperitoneal

questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An important part of laparoscopic surgeries is creation of pneumoperitoneum The image shows a Verres needle which is used to create a pneumoperitoneum. It is typically inserted at the level of the umbilicus as there is no fat of muscle at this site. Palmer’s point is preferred if adhesions are anticipated. This point is 3 cm below the left costal margin in the mid-clavicular line. Intraperitoneal placement of the needle is confirmed by Drop test: place a drop of saline on the hub of the needle and life the abdominal wall; the drop is sucked in The insufflator will show a reading of intraperitoneal pressure < 10 mmHg (single digit reading) Push 5 ml of saline in the peritoneal cavity and then attempt to aspirate it. No fluid can be aspirated if the needle is in the peritoneal cavity. Liver dullness is obliterated if CO2 is flowing intra-peritoneally.
  • ➤ An important part of laparoscopic surgeries is creation of pneumoperitoneum
  • ➤ The image shows a Verres needle which is used to create a pneumoperitoneum.
  • ➤ It is typically inserted at the level of the umbilicus as there is no fat of muscle at this site.
  • ➤ Palmer’s point is preferred if adhesions are anticipated. This point is 3 cm below the left costal margin in the mid-clavicular line.
  • ➤ Intraperitoneal placement of the needle is confirmed by Drop test: place a drop of saline on the hub of the needle and life the abdominal wall; the drop is sucked in The insufflator will show a reading of intraperitoneal pressure < 10 mmHg (single digit reading) Push 5 ml of saline in the peritoneal cavity and then attempt to aspirate it. No fluid can be aspirated if the needle is in the peritoneal cavity. Liver dullness is obliterated if CO2 is flowing intra-peritoneally.
  • ➤ Drop test: place a drop of saline on the hub of the needle and life the abdominal wall; the drop is sucked in The insufflator will show a reading of intraperitoneal pressure < 10 mmHg (single digit reading) Push 5 ml of saline in the peritoneal cavity and then attempt to aspirate it. No fluid can be aspirated if the needle is in the peritoneal cavity. Liver dullness is obliterated if CO2 is flowing intra-peritoneally.

questions.question_text: The following instruments are required for an IUCD insertion except?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Steps of IUCD insertion:
  • ➤ The posterior vaginal wall is retracted with Sim’s speculum and the anterior lip of cervix is held with the Vulsellum The cervix is cleaned with a betadine swab (on a sponge holding forceps) Uterine sound is introduced and the uterocervical length is measured. The horizontal limbs of the CuT are inserted into the inserter using a no-touch technique The tip of the plunger is placed in contact with the end of the vertical limb of the CuT The whole assembly is placed in the uterine cavity till the guard is in contact with the external os The plunger is stabilized, and the inserter is withdrawn to release the CuT and then both plunger and inserter are withdrawn together The threads are trimmed to about 1 inch from the external os with a suture cutting scissors.
  • ➤ The posterior vaginal wall is retracted with Sim’s speculum and the anterior lip of cervix is held with the Vulsellum

  • ➤ The tip of the plunger is placed in contact with the end of the vertical limb of the CuT
  • ➤ The whole assembly is placed in the uterine cavity till the guard is in contact with the external os
  • ➤ The plunger is stabilized, and the inserter is withdrawn to release the CuT and then both plunger and inserter are withdrawn together

questions.question_text: A 32-year-old primigravida woman at 39 weeks gestation is admitted to the labor and delivery unit in active labor. She has been progressing well, but there is delayed progress in the 2nd stage of labor. The obstetrician decides to use vacuum extraction to assist with the delivery. The appropriate application of ventouse in this scenario involves:

options.A: Placing the cup on the fetal occiput and applying traction during maternal contractions
options.B: Placing the cup on the fetal occiput and applying continuous traction until delivery
options.C: Placing the cup on the fetal forehead and applying continuous traction until delivery
options.D: Placing the cup on the fetal forehead and applying traction during maternal contractions

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The vacuum cup is to be applied as close to the occiput as possible. This is the flexion point (3cm anterior to the posterior fontanellae) and traction on this point encourages flexion. Traction is applied during the contractions whilst encouraging the mother also to bear down.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B: Placing the cup on the fetal occiput and applying continuous traction until delivery. This is incoorect as although placement is correct, traction is not continuois and only with uterine contractions
  • • Option B:
  • • Option C: Placing the cup on the fetal forehead and applying continuous traction until delivery: This is incoorect as the cup placement has to be near the occiput. By placing the cup on the forehead, extension will happen which is not a favoured attitude. Also continuous traction is NOT applied.
  • • Option C:
  • • Option D: Placing the cup on the fetal forehead and applying traction during maternal contractions. This is incorrect as the cup placement has to be near the occiput. By placing the cup on the forehead, extension will happen which is not a favoured attitude
  • • Option D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Application of Vacuum Application of the cup The cup is lubricated and introduced into the vagina The center of the cup should be placed over the sagittal suture as close to the posterior fontanelle as possible (FLEXION POINT) The Flexion point is a point 3 cm anterior to the post fontanellae Traction at this point causes flexion of the head Creation of the vacuum First feel all around the cup to see that no maternal tissue is stuck in the cup Cup is connected to the suction machine and vacuum till 0.8 kg/cm 2 is created. Traction Traction is applied at right angles to the cup Traction is applied intermittently with uterine contraction Direction of traction: Along the pelvic curve (First downwards then horizontal then upwards)
  • ➤ Application of Vacuum Application of the cup The cup is lubricated and introduced into the vagina The center of the cup should be placed over the sagittal suture as close to the posterior fontanelle as possible (FLEXION POINT) The Flexion point is a point 3 cm anterior to the post fontanellae Traction at this point causes flexion of the head Creation of the vacuum First feel all around the cup to see that no maternal tissue is stuck in the cup Cup is connected to the suction machine and vacuum till 0.8 kg/cm 2 is created. Traction Traction is applied at right angles to the cup Traction is applied intermittently with uterine contraction Direction of traction: Along the pelvic curve (First downwards then horizontal then upwards)
  • ➤ Application of Vacuum
  • ➤ Application of the cup The cup is lubricated and introduced into the vagina The center of the cup should be placed over the sagittal suture as close to the posterior fontanelle as possible (FLEXION POINT) The Flexion point is a point 3 cm anterior to the post fontanellae Traction at this point causes flexion of the head Creation of the vacuum First feel all around the cup to see that no maternal tissue is stuck in the cup Cup is connected to the suction machine and vacuum till 0.8 kg/cm 2 is created. Traction Traction is applied at right angles to the cup Traction is applied intermittently with uterine contraction Direction of traction: Along the pelvic curve (First downwards then horizontal then upwards)

questions.question_text: Which is INCORRECT regarding the following instrument?

options.A: It is used to remove retained products of conception
options.B: It does not have a lock to enable a faster procedure time
options.C: It can be used in places where a vacuum aspirator is not available
options.D: The end is “egg-shaped” to collect and remove tissue

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Let's discuss all the options:
  • • Option A: It is used to remove retained products of conception: This is correct. An ovum forceps is used to remove retained products of conception in incomplete and missed abortions and also in surgical MTP Option B: I t does not have a lock to enable a faster procedure time: This is incorrect. The reasonf ro not having a lock is to avoid inadvertent injury to the uterus Option C: It can be used in places where a vacuum aspirator is not available: This is correct. Evacuation of products can be done either by a manual or electrical vacuum aspirator or by an ovum forceps Option D: The end is “egg-shaped” to collect and remove tissue: This is also correct. The end is egg shaped; hence the name ovum. The reason for this is to collect tissue within the endometrial cavity.

questions.question_text: A 23-year primi presents with watery vaginal discharge which wet her clothes at 32 weeks pregnancy. There is no abdominal pain and she appreciates fetal movements well. Abdominal exam reveals a 32 weeks uterus with a live fetus in cephalic presentation. Which instrument will you use to confirm if the patient has ruptured her membranes?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Preterm Prelabor Rupture of Membranes (PPROM) presents as sudden vaginal watery discharge To confirm PPROM or PROM, a speculum exam is done Ideally, a Sim’s speculum is inserted into the vagina and pooling of liquor on the blade of the speculum confirms the diagnosis
  • • Preterm Prelabor Rupture of Membranes (PPROM) presents as sudden vaginal watery discharge
  • • To confirm PPROM or PROM, a speculum exam is done
  • • Ideally, a Sim’s speculum is inserted into the vagina and pooling of liquor on the blade of the speculum confirms the diagnosis
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Cuscos speculum: This can be used to look for vaginal leaking but the preferred instrument is the Sims speculum as pooling of fluid can be seen in the central groove of the speculum Option C: Fetoscope: This is used to auscultate the fetal heart rate Option D: Hysteroscope: This is a scope to look inside the uterine cavity and is used for diagnostic procedures like AUB and operative procedures like Ashermam syndrome or hysteroscopic polypectomy. It is contra-indicated in pregnancy
  • • Option A: Cuscos speculum: This can be used to look for vaginal leaking but the preferred instrument is the Sims speculum as pooling of fluid can be seen in the central groove of the speculum
  • • Option A:
  • • Option C: Fetoscope: This is used to auscultate the fetal heart rate
  • • Option C:
  • • Option D: Hysteroscope: This is a scope to look inside the uterine cavity and is used for diagnostic procedures like AUB and operative procedures like Ashermam syndrome or hysteroscopic polypectomy. It is contra-indicated in pregnancy
  • • Option D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Sims speculum is the preferred instrument used to look for pooling of liquor in a patient with suspected PROM or PPROM
  • ➤ Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics
  • ➤ Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics

options.D: A grating sensation on all 4 uterine walls

questions.explanation:

questions.question_text: True about breech presentation?

options.A: Incidence is about 7% at term pregnancy
options.D: External cephalic version increases incidence of breech presentation

questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The incidence of breech at term is 3-4% (At 28 weeks it is 25%) Etiology of Breech Presentation Prematurity: MC cause Factor preventing spontaneous version: Breech with extended legs, twins, Oligohydramnios; Congenital malformation of uterus such as septate or bicornuate uterus; Short cord & IUD of the fetus Favourable adaptation: Hydrocephalous; Placenta previa Contracted pelvis &Cornu-fundal attachment of the placenta Undue mobility of fetus: Hydramnios & Multipara with lax abdominal wall Fetal abnormalities: Trisomy 13, 18, 21; Anencephaly &myotonic dystrophy due to alternation of fetal muscular tone & mobility External Cephalic Version It has been considered from 36 weeks Success rate of version is about 50-60% Benefit Reduction in the incidence of breech presentation at term Reduction in the incidence of breech delivery & associated complication. questions.question_text: In the pelvic inlet, which is the shortest anteroposterior diameter?
questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Diameters of the Pelvic Inlet
  • ➤ Diameters of the Pelvic Inlet
  • ➤ Anteroposterior (AP) Diameter
  • ➤ Anteroposterior (AP) Diameter
  • ➤ True (anatomical) conjugate (11 cm): Extends from uppermost margin of symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory. Obstetric conjugate (10 cm): It is the shortest AP diameter of the pelvic inlet and hence obstetrically most important. It is measured from the middle of sacral promontory to symphysis pubis. It cannot be measured directly on clinical examination. It is calculated by subtracting 1.5 cm from diagonal conjugate. Diagonal conjugate (12.5 cm): It is measured from tip of sacral promontory to the lower margin of pubic symphysis. It is the only diameter that can be assessed clinically.
  • ➤ True (anatomical) conjugate (11 cm): Extends from uppermost margin of symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory.

options.B: A G2A1 at 37 weeks with preeclampsia
options.C: 39y primigravida at 34 weeks with FGR and reversal of umbilical artery flow

questions.question_text: According to WHO guidelines on management of labor, which of the following is true about management of second stage of labor?

options.B: Episiotomy should be performed as a routine
options.C: A warm cloth should be applied to the perineum to prevent trauma
options.D: Delivery should be ideally performed in a lithotomy position

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. A warm cloth should be applied to the perineum to prevent trauma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ As per WHO recommendations of 2018,
  • ➤ As per WHO recommendations of 2018,
  • ➤ As per WHO guidelines on intrapartum care for a positive birth experience (2018), these are the recommendations in 2 nd stage
  • ➤ As per WHO guidelines on intrapartum care for a positive birth experience (2018), these are the recommendations in 2 nd stage
  • ➤ Definition and duration of the second stage of labor: The second stage is the period of time between full cervical dilatation and birth of the baby, during which the woman has an involuntary urge to bear down, as a result of expulsive uterine contractions. In first labors, birth is usually completed within 3 hours whereas in subsequent labors, birth is usually completed within 2 hours. Recommended Birth position (for women with or without epidural analgesia) For women without epidural analgesia, encouraging the adoption of a birth position of the individual woman’s choice, including upright positions, is recommended. Method of pushing Women in the expulsive phase of the second stage of labor should be encouraged and supported to follow their own urge to push. Method of pushing (for women with epidural analgesia) For women with epidural analgesia in the second stage of labor, delaying pushing for one to two hours after full dilatation or until the woman regains the sensory urge to bear down is recommended in the context where resources are available for longer stay in second stage and perinatal hypoxia can be adequately assessed and managed. Techniques for preventing perineal trauma. For women in the second stage of labor, techniques to reduce perineal trauma and facilitate spontaneous birth (including perineal massage, warm compresses and a “hands on” guarding of the perineum) are recommended, based on a woman’s preferences and available options. Episiotomy policy Routine or liberal use of episiotomy is not recommended for women undergoing spontaneous vaginal birth. Fundal pressure Application of manual fundal pressure to facilitate childbirth during the second stage of labor is not recommended.

questions.question_text: A midwife at a PHC is monitoring pregnancy and maintaining the WHO modified partograph of pregnancy progression. At how much cervical dilation should the partograph plotting be started?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 4 cm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Partograph is a graphical representation of progress of labor, which is depicted using cervical dilatation and descent of head against the duration of labor. It is used for early detection of abnormal labor patterns for timely intervention. In a partograph the active phase of labor starts when the cervix is 4 cm dilated. In active phase, cervix should dilate at the rate of 1 cm/hr. (Alert Line) Partograph has two lines for assessment of progression of dilation Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate) A ction line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.
  • ➤ Partograph is a graphical representation of progress of labor, which is depicted using cervical dilatation and descent of head against the duration of labor.
  • ➤ It is used for early detection of abnormal labor patterns for timely intervention.
  • ➤ In a partograph the active phase of labor starts when the cervix is 4 cm dilated.
  • ➤ In active phase, cervix should dilate at the rate of 1 cm/hr. (Alert Line)
  • ➤ Partograph has two lines for assessment of progression of dilation Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate) A ction line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.
  • ➤ Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate) A ction line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.
  • ➤ Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate)
  • ➤ A ction line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.
  • ➤ Remember that in the modified partograph, plotting starts at 4 cm onward, and the 1 st mark is always put on the alert line If asked, when does plotting start in the Labor care guide (Next generation partograph), then the answer is 5cm
  • ➤ Remember that in the modified partograph, plotting starts at 4 cm onward, and the 1 st mark is always put on the alert line
  • ➤ If asked, when does plotting start in the Labor care guide (Next generation partograph), then the answer is 5cm
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 212, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma 3 rd edition

questions.question_text: All are components of active management of the third stage of labor except?

options.A: Uterotonic agent within 1 minute of birth

questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Early cord clamping

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Active Management of 3 rd Stage of Labor
  • ➤ Active Management of 3 rd Stage of Labor
  • ➤ Described by the WHO in 2007 Involves mainly 3 basic steps. Administering a uterotonic Controlled cord traction Uterine massage AMTSL prevents atonic PPH. In 2012, the WHO issued new guidelines for AMTSL which essentially emphasized the main 3 things but with additional information which was Oxytocin is the uterotonic of choice for AMTSL (10 IU IM/IV) Do Controlled cord traction only if a skilled birth attendant is present. Sustained uterine massage is not recommended for all women who’ve received uterotonic; instead; postpartum uterine tone assessment for early identification of uterine atony is done. Delayed cord clamping (performed after 1 to 3 minutes after birth) is recommended for all births while initiating simultaneous essential newborn care (This is not to prevent atonic PPH but was introduced along with AMTSL to ensure it is followed) In 2018, the WHO issued further guidelines on which other uterotonics can be used for AMTSL. These include: Oxytocin (10 IU IM/IV) Carbetocin (100 mcg IM/IV) Misoprostol (400 OR 600 mcg PO – to be used where Skilled birth attendant isn’t available) Ergometrine/methylergometrine (200 mcg IV EXCEPT in hypertensive women)) Oxytocin and ergometrine fixed-dose combination (5 IU/500 µg, IM) Injectable prostaglandins (carboprost or sulprostone) are not recommended for the prevention of PPH AMTSL decreases Incidence of PPH. Length of third stage of labor. Percentage of third stages of labor lasting longer than 30 minutes. Need for blood transfusion. Need for uterotonic drugs to manage PPH

questions.question_text: A 22-year primigravida is in labor and on examination, the cervix is 2cm dilated. The fetal heart rate is 148bpm and rises to 156 bpm for 20 seconds then falls to 142 bpm. This type of presentation is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. It’s a normal pattern

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Baseline FHR — 110-150 bpm. Baseline variability — 5-25 bpm Acceleration — 2 in 20 min Deceleration — None or early Baseline FHR is the mean level of FHR between the peaks and the depressions in beats per minute (bpm) Baseline variability is the oscillation of baseline FHR excluding the accelerations and decelerations. A baseline variability of 5-25 bpm is a sign of fetal wellbeing. Accelerations are increase in FHR by 15 bpm or more lasting for at least 15 secs. Denotes healthy fetus. Deceleration is decrease in FHR below the baseline by 15 bpm or more. Three basic types of decelerations are observed:
  • ➤ Baseline FHR — 110-150 bpm.
  • ➤ Baseline variability — 5-25 bpm
  • ➤ Acceleration — 2 in 20 min
  • ➤ Deceleration — None or early
  • ➤ Baseline FHR is the mean level of FHR between the peaks and the depressions in beats per minute (bpm)
  • ➤ Baseline variability is the oscillation of baseline FHR excluding the accelerations and decelerations.
  • ➤ A baseline variability of 5-25 bpm is a sign of fetal wellbeing.
  • ➤ Accelerations are increase in FHR by 15 bpm or more lasting for at least 15 secs. Denotes healthy fetus.
  • ➤ Deceleration is decrease in FHR below the baseline by 15 bpm or more. Three basic types of decelerations are observed:
  • ➤ Non-stress test (NST): continuous electronic monitoring of fetal heart
  • ➤ Reactive (Reassuring): 2 or more contractions of more than 15 bpm above the baseline and longer than 15seconds in duration are present in a 20-minute observation. Non-Reactive (Non-Reassuring): absence of fetal reactivity, Perinatal death rate of 40/1000.
  • ➤ Reactive (Reassuring): 2 or more contractions of more than 15 bpm above the baseline and longer than 15seconds in duration are present in a 20-minute observation.
  • ➤ Non-Reactive (Non-Reassuring): absence of fetal reactivity, Perinatal death rate of 40/1000.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1138, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1138, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.question_text: Which are features of false labor? Steady intensity of pain Cervical dilation Discomfort is in the back and abdomen Intervals remain long Discomfort usually is relieved by sedation

  • • Explanation
  • • Characteristic of True & False Labor
  • • Characteristic of True & False Labor
  • • True Labor
  • • True Labor
  • • Contractions occur at regular intervals. Intervals gradually shorten. Intensity gradually increases. Discomfort is in the back and abdomen. Cervix dilates. Discomfort is not stopped by sedation.
  • • Contractions occur at regular intervals.
  • • Intervals gradually shorten.
  • • Intensity gradually increases.
  • • Discomfort is in the back and abdomen.
  • • Cervix dilates.
  • • Discomfort is not stopped by sedation.
  • • False Labor
  • • False Labor
  • • Contractions occur at irregular intervals. Intervals remain long. Intensity remains unchanged. Discomfort is chiefly in the lower abdomen. Cervix does not dilate. Discomfort usually is relieved by sedation.
  • • Contractions occur at irregular intervals.
  • • Intervals remain long.
  • • Intensity remains unchanged.
  • • Discomfort is chiefly in the lower abdomen.
  • • Cervix does not dilate.
  • • Discomfort usually is relieved by sedation.
  • • Thus A, D and E are seen in false labor correct answer is option B) A, D, E

questions.question_text: A midwife at a PHC is monitoring pregnancy and maintaining the partograph of progression of labor of a 22y primigravida. At how much cervical dilation should the WHO modified partograph plotting be started?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 4 cm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Partograph
  • ➤ Partograph
  • ➤ The WHO modified Partograph is a graphical representation of progress of labour, which is depicted using cervical dilatation and descent of head against the duration of labour. It is used for early detection of abnormal labour patterns for timely intervention. In a partograph the active phase of labour starts when the cervix is 4 cm dilated. In active phase, cervix should dilate at the rate of 1 cm/hr. Partograph has two lines for assessment of progression of dilation. Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate) Action line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.
  • ➤ The WHO modified Partograph is a graphical representation of progress of labour, which is depicted using cervical dilatation and descent of head against the duration of labour.
  • ➤ It is used for early detection of abnormal labour patterns for timely intervention.
  • ➤ In a partograph the active phase of labour starts when the cervix is 4 cm dilated. In active phase, cervix should dilate at the rate of 1 cm/hr.
  • ➤ Partograph has two lines for assessment of progression of dilation. Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate) Action line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.
  • ➤ Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate) Action line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.
  • ➤ Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate)
  • ➤ Action line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.
  • ➤ The WHO has now introduced the WHO Labor care guide in 2018 where several changes have been made. This is also called the “Next generation partograph”. In this, the active labor starts at 5cm.
  • ➤ The WHO has now introduced the WHO Labor care guide in 2018 where several changes have been made. This is also called the “Next generation partograph”. In this, the active labor starts at 5cm.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 213 JB Sharma’s Textbook of Obstetrics 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 213 JB Sharma’s Textbook of Obstetrics 3 rd edition

questions.question_text: A 48y woman comes to the clinic due to dyspareunia which has worsened over the last 4 months. Five years ago, she underwent chemoradiation for stage 2 cervical cancer. She has only recently resumed sexual activity after a gap of about 5 years. Despite over the counter use of lubricants, she is till having pain. There is no postcoital bleeding. She is amenorrhoeic since the chemoradiation. On examination, the vaginal introitus is narrow and the vagina is pale. The cervix appears scarred but there is no growth or ulcer and does not bleed on touch. What is the likely cause of her dyspareunia?

Progestogen replacement is generally added 1–2 years after starting estrogen or upon breakthrough bleeding.

She does not give a history of heavy bleeding but only that her undergarments are stained with blood. She attained menopause at the age of 52 and she had hot flushes and night sweats for which she was started on the transdermal estrogen patch and progesterone only pills. She has been consistently using the estrogen patches but stopped the progesterone in view of severe nausea. She has no significant medical history. She is on regular HPV screening and her last HPV was done 2 year earlier which was normal. Speculum exam reveals a normal cervix and vagina with minimal blood in the upper vagina. Bimanual exam reveals a small uterus with no adnexal mass. What is the next best step in management?

questions.question_text: A 32-year-old woman complains that she has not had a period for 3 months. Four home pregnancy tests have all been negative. She started her periods at the age of 15 years and until 30 years she had a normal 28-day cycle. She had one daughter by normal delivery 2 years ago, following which she breast-fed for 6 months. After that she had normal cycles again for several months and then her periods stopped abruptly. She was using the progesterone only pill for contraception while she was breastfeeding and stopped 6 months ago as she is keen to have another child. She reports symptoms of dryness during intercourse and has experienced sweating episodes at night as well as episodes of feeling extremely hot at any time of day. The only medical history of note is that she has been hypothyroid for 10 years and takes thyroxine 100 mg per day. She does not take any alcohol, smoke or use recreational drugs. On lab investigation FSH level is 45 IU/L. what is the diagnosis?

options.A: Delay in return of fertility after contraception

Ans. C. Premature ovarian failure
