questions.question_text: While evaluating a 30-year-old woman for infertility, you diagnose a bicornuate uterus. You explain that additional testing is necessary for one organ system because of the woman’s increased risk of congenital anomalies. Which is that organ system?
questions.explanation:
Ans. ‘C’ Urinary

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Failed fusion of the Mullerian ducts can give rise to several types of uterine anomalies, e.g., bicornuate uterus. This condition is associated with a higher risk of obstetric complications, such as an increase in the rate of second-trimester abortion and premature labor. An intravenous pyelogram or urinary tract ultrasound is mandatory in patients with Mullerian anomalies, since approximately 30-40%% of patients with Mullerian anomalies have coexisting congenital urinary tract anomalies. Other associated abnormalities: skeletal (!2%)

  • • MR imaging is currently preferred or imaging complex defects MR imaging provides clear delineation of both the internal and external uterine anatomy and has a reported accuracy of up to 100 percent in the evaluation of Müllerian anomalies Moreover, complex anomalies and commonly associated secondary diagnoses such as renal or skeletal anomalies can be concurrently evaluated. questions.question_text: A 22-year-old G3P0 presents to your office as a new patient for consultation regarding her history of multiple miscarriages. Her gynecologic history is otherwise unremarkable. During physical examination, you note that the uterus is markedly deviated to the left. Transvaginal sonography is performed, and three-dimensional images reveal a single uterus that is deviated and has a banana-shaped cavity, as shown below? What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This is a patient with unicornuate uterus. With Unicornuate uterus, a functional uterus, normal cervix, and normal round ligament and fallopian tube are found on one side. On the contralateral side, Müllerian structures develop abnormally, and agenesis or more frequently a rudimentary uterine horn is identified. A rudimentary horn may communicate or more commonly not communicate with the unicornuate uterus. In addition, the endometrial cavity of the rudimentary horn may be obliterated or may contain some functioning endometrium. Active endometrium in a noncommunicating horn will eventually be symptomatic with cyclic unilateral pain and possibly with hematometra.
  • • This is a patient with unicornuate uterus.
  • • With Unicornuate uterus, a functional uterus, normal cervix, and normal round ligament and fallopian tube are found on one side.
  • • On the contralateral side, Müllerian structures develop abnormally, and agenesis or more frequently a rudimentary uterine horn is identified.
  • • A rudimentary horn may communicate or more commonly not communicate with the unicornuate uterus.
  • • In addition, the endometrial cavity of the rudimentary horn may be obliterated or may contain some functioning endometrium.
  • • Active endometrium in a noncommunicating horn will eventually be symptomatic with cyclic unilateral pain and possibly with hematometra.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Septate uterus: This presents as poor reproductive outcome. On an HSG, the 2 uterine horns, the angle will be < 75 degree Option B: Bicornuate uterus: This presents as a wide intercornual angle on the HSG Option C: Didelphys: This presents as 2 completely seprate uterine covities which are far apart

Compared with the unicornuate uterus, although the potential or uterine growth and capacity appears similar, uterine didelphys probably has an improved blood supply from collateral connections between the two horns.

questions.question_text: When should surgical reconstruction of a bicornuate uterus (Strassman metroplasty) be performed?

options.B: In all women with the diagnosis of bicornuate uterus
options.C: Strassman metroplasty is not performed for repair of bicornuate uterus
options.D: For women in whom recurrent pregnancy loss occurs with no other identifiable cause except their uterine anomaly

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Surgical reconstruction of the bicornuate uterus is infrequently done in bicornuate uterus (Strassman metroplasty) and is been advocated in women with multiple spontaneous abortions in whom no other causative actors are identified. Strassman described the surgical technique that unified equal-sized endometrial cavities. Reproductive outcome after unification generally has been good. As in surgery or uterine didelphys, metroplasty is reserved or women in whom recurrent pregnancy loss occurs with no other identifiable cause.

questions.question_text: Which of the following are seen in offspring of women who took diethylstilbestrol (DES)? Impaired conception rates in female offspring Cryptorchidism, testicular hypoplasia, and malformations of the penis in male offspring T-shaped uterus “Cockscomb” cervix Increased rates of clear cell adenocarcinoma in female offspring
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Diethylstilbestrol (DES), a synthetic nonsteroidal estrogen, was prescribed to an estimated 3 million pregnant women in the United States from the late 1940s through the early 1960s. The drug was used in treating abortion, preeclampsia, diabetes, hot flushes, and preterm labor. DES exposure in utero has been linked to the development of a “T-shaped” uterus An increased incidence of clear cell adenocarcinomas of the vagina and cervix. Vaginal and cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, Genitourinary malformations following DES exposure in utero have also been noted and include those of the cervix, vagina, uterine cavity, and fallopian tubes. transverse septa, circumferential ridges involving the vagina and cervix, and cervical collars (“cockscomb cervix”) have been found. Fallopian tube abnormalities include shortened and narrowed dimensions and absent fimbria. Males exposed to DES in utero also have structural abnormalities. Cryptorchidism, testicular hypoplasia, microphallus, and hypospadias have been reported.

questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laparoscopic surgery involves creating pneumo-peritoneum wherein CO2 gas is introduced in the peritoneal cavity. At the beginnng of laparoscopic surgery, CO2 is insufflated to 25-30 mmHg for positioning of ports. This reduces the chance of trauma to the bowel or post abdominal wall as there is more gas inside the abdomen. After placement of cannulas, the pressure should be dropped to 10-15 mmHg. This reduces the risk of hypercarbia .
  • ➤ Laparoscopic surgery involves creating pneumo-peritoneum wherein CO2 gas is introduced in the peritoneal cavity.
  • ➤ At the beginnng of laparoscopic surgery, CO2 is insufflated to 25-30 mmHg for positioning of ports. This reduces the chance of trauma to the bowel or post abdominal wall as there is more gas inside the abdomen.
  • ➤ After placement of cannulas, the pressure should be dropped to 10-15 mmHg. This reduces the risk of hypercarbia .

questions.question_text: A 23y primigravida is undergoing an elective LSCS for breech presentation. What is the ideal timing of cesarean section?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 39 Weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ideal timing for elective cesarean sections should consider the balance between fetal maturity and the avoidance of complications associated with preterm or post-term birth. In the case of a primigravida with a breech presentation, scheduling the cesarean section around 39 weeks of gestation is often recommended to optimize the baby's readiness for birth while minimizing the risk of neonatal complications.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1412, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.question_text: Prerequisite for outlet forceps application are all except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Station 0 or +1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ It's important to assess the engagement of the fetal head, cervical dilation, the presence of uterine contractions, and the station of the baby's head to determine the appropriate timing for forceps application during childbirth. The outlet forceps are applied when station of fetal head is ≥ +3 station and not at 0 or +1.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1367, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1367, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.question_text: A 39 y primigravida female presents in labor with breech presentation at 38 weeks. She has conceived via IVF. She has multiple large fibroids in the anterior lower uterine segment. The most appropriate management is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Classical cesarean

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A cesarean section is often recommended for breech presentations, especially in primigravida women, as it reduces the risks associated with delivering a baby in a breech position. When the lower uterine segment is not approachable due to multiple large fibroids in the lower segment, classical cesarean section (upper segment cesarean) may be done. Indications for a classical cesarean section include: Large fibroid in the lower segment Dense adhesions in the lower segmenr Placenta accreta syndrome Carcinoma cervix Perimortem cesarean section
  • ➤ A cesarean section is often recommended for breech presentations, especially in primigravida women, as it reduces the risks associated with delivering a baby in a breech position.

questions.question_text: Which structure is NOT cut in a mediolateral episiotomy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Obturator muscles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In summary, the structure that is NOT cut in a mediolateral episiotomy is B, the Obturator Muscles. These muscles are located deeper and more laterally in the pelvis and are not involved in the episiotomy incision. The purpose of a mediolateral episiotomy is to enlarge the vaginal opening for childbirth, involving an incision through the perineal skin and potentially affecting the bulbospongiosus and transverse perineal muscles.

Following delivery, you notice that the uterine incision has extended and is bleeding profusely having caused avulsion of the uterine arteries. Which instrument will you use to hold the angles of the uterine incision?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Green Armitage Forceps

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Green-Armitage Forceps are specially designed for situations encountered in obstetric surgery, such as holding the angles of a uterine incision during a cesarean section with complications like extended incisions and bleeding. They provide the necessary grip and stability to manage the surgical field effectively and safely.

questions.question_text: A 1 st year resident is doing a cesareans section for the 1 st time. How will you help her identify the lower uterine segment?

options.A: It appears slightly more pink than the upper segment
options.B: It lies under the loose uterovesical fold of peritoneum
options.C: It is just below the round ligaments
options.D: It is where the presenting part can be palpated

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. It lies under the loose uterovesical fold of peritoneum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The lower uterine segment in a cesarean section is best identified as the area lying under the loose uterovesical fold of peritoneum. This anatomical landmark provides a reliable guide for surgeons to make a safe and effective incision, minimizing the risk of injury to the bladder and ensuring optimal surgical outcomes.

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The Fetal Pillow, is an instrument used to elevate the fetal head in a difficult cesarean section where the head is deeply engaged. This tool is part of various methods employed to facilitate the safe and efficient delivery of the baby, especially in challenging situations where there is a risk of extension of incisions and bleeding

questions.question_text: What is the first structure to be sutured following a median episiotomy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Mucosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The correct approach to suturing an episiotomy involves starting with the vaginal mucosa, followed by the muscle layer, and finally the skin. This method ensures effective hemostasis, alignment for optimal healing, and restoration of anatomical and functional integrity of the perineal region. The suture material used is often a rapidly absorbable suture like Vicryl rapid or catgut, which reduces the need for suture removal and provides comfort to the patient
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1306, Williams Obstetrics, 26 th edition

questions.question_text: A lady underwent vaginal hysterectomy for Carcinoma cervix. Following the surgery after her urethral catheter was removed, she complained of leaking of urine. Methylene blue dye was instilled in her bladder through her urethra, and she was given oral Phenazopyridine dye. After some time, her pads were checked and it showed yellow staining at the top most pad, while the middle or bottom pads were unstained. She is likely to have?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Ureterovaginal fistula

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • In this patient methylene blue dye was instilled in bladder and she was given oral phenazopyridine dye. Pad showed yellow staining at the top portion, but not the middle or bottom portions. She is likely to have Ureterovaginal fistula. The urine, which is being brought by ureters is yellow due to oral intake of phenazopyridine which stains the urine yellow. The methylene blue which is in the bladder is not staining the swab as there is no Vesico or urethero-vaginal fistula.
  • • In this patient methylene blue dye was instilled in bladder and she was given oral phenazopyridine dye. Pad showed yellow staining at the top portion, but not the middle or bottom portions. She is likely to have Ureterovaginal fistula.
  • • The urine, which is being brought by ureters is yellow due to oral intake of phenazopyridine which stains the urine yellow.
  • • The methylene blue which is in the bladder is not staining the swab as there is no Vesico or urethero-vaginal fistula.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A: Urge Incontinence: This is a type of urinary incontinence in adults, which involves sudden compelling urges to void and results in involuntary leakage of urine Option C: Neurogenic bladder: This presents as urgency, frequency or even as continuois urinary incontience. However as there is no fistula, on the 3 swab test, there will be no staining or wettingof the swabs Option D: Urinary tract infection: This will present as frequency and burning micturition. It can also present as fever, flank pain and constitutional symptoms in pyelonephritis.
  • • Option A: Urge Incontinence: This is a type of urinary incontinence in adults, which involves sudden compelling urges to void and results in involuntary leakage of urine

  • • Option D: Urinary tract infection: This will present as frequency and burning micturition. It can also present as fever, flank pain and constitutional symptoms in pyelonephritis.
  • • Option D: Urinary tract infection:

questions.question_text: Spontaneous healing of a genitourinary fistula via continuous bladder drainage using an indwelling urinary catheter is more likely to happen in which of the following settings?

options.A: The fistula is large, greater than 2 cm.
options.B: The fistula is small, 2 to 3 mm.
options.C: The fistula is related to pelvic radiation
options.D: The catheter is left in place for a minimum of 8 weeks

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. The fistula is small, 2 to 3 mm

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Occasionally, genitourinary fistulas may spontaneously close during continuous bladder drainage using an indwelling urinary catheter. Urinary fistulas close spontaneously after 2 to 8 weeks of transurethral catheterization, especially if the fistula is small (2- to 3-mm diameter).
  • • Occasionally, genitourinary fistulas may spontaneously close during continuous bladder drainage using an indwelling urinary catheter.
  • • Urinary fistulas close spontaneously after 2 to 8 weeks of transurethral catheterization, especially if the fistula is small (2- to 3-mm diameter).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: The fistula is large, greater than 2 cm: Large fistulas are unlikely to heal spontaneusly Option C: The fistula is related to pelvic radiation: Post Radiotherapy fistulas heal poorly Option D: The catheter is left in place for a minimum of 8 weeks: If the fistula is small, urinary fistulas close spontaneously after 2 to 8 weeks of transurethral catheterization
  • • Option A: The fistula is large, greater than 2 cm: Large fistulas are unlikely to heal spontaneusly

  • • Option D: The catheter is left in place for a minimum of 8 weeks: If the fistula is small, urinary fistulas close spontaneously after 2 to 8 weeks of transurethral catheterization

questions.question_text: Which of the following diagnostic tools or techniques would help identify a ureterovaginal fistula?

options.D: “Three-swab” or tampon test with diluted solution of methylene blue instilled (retrograde) into the bladder

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Intravenous pyelogram

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • For ureterovaginal fistulas,the investigation of choice is a CT urography as CT urography will clearly show extravasaton from the ureter and the site of injury. However since this is not there in the option and the closest option to a CT urography is an intravenus pyelogram which will also demonstrate extravasation of contrast from ureter with mild to moderate hydro-uretero nephrosis. Also it is important to remember that the pr esence of contrast in the vagina gives a typical cup and saucer sign in vesico-vaginal fistula.
  • • For ureterovaginal fistulas,the investigation of choice is a CT urography as CT urography will clearly show extravasaton from the ureter and the site of injury.

questions.question_text: When the patient’s history suggests an overlap in both stress and urge incontinence symptoms, which of the following terms is used?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Mixed urinary incontinence

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Urinary incontinence is defined as involuntary leakage of urine. Stress urinary incontinence (SUI) is the involuntary leakage of urine with increases in intraabdominal pressure. Urgency urinary incontinence (previously “urge” urinary incontinence) is the involuntary leakage accompanied or immediately preceded by a perceived strong imminent need to void. A related condition, overactive bladder, describes urinary urgency with or without incontinence and usually with increased daytime urinary frequency and nocturia When both stress and urgency symptoms are present, it is called mixed urinary incontinence.
  • • Urinary incontinence is defined as involuntary leakage of urine.
  • • Stress urinary incontinence (SUI) is the involuntary leakage of urine with increases in intraabdominal pressure.
  • • Urgency urinary incontinence (previously “urge” urinary incontinence) is the involuntary leakage accompanied or immediately preceded by a perceived strong imminent need to void. A related condition, overactive bladder, describes urinary urgency with or without incontinence and usually with increased daytime urinary frequency and nocturia
  • • When both stress and urgency symptoms are present, it is called mixed urinary incontinence.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A: Overflow incontinence: Overflow urinary incontinence is the involuntary leakage of urine from an overdistended bladder due to impaired detrusor contractility and/or bladder outlet obstruction. Neurologic diseases such as spinal cord injuries, multiple sclerosis, and diabetes can impair detrusor function. Bladder outlet obstruction can be caused by external compression by abdominal or pelvic masses and pelvic organ prolapse, among other causes. Option C: Complex urinary incontinence: There is no such terminology Option D: Augmented urinary incontinence: There is no such terminology

Bladder outlet obstruction can be caused by external compression by abdominal or pelvic masses and pelvic organ prolapse, among other causes.

questions.question_text: In the POP-Q system of uterine prolapse classification, how many fixed points are there?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 6

Explanation:

  • • POP-Q is Pelvic Organ Prolapse – Quantification System. The hymen acts as the fixed point of reference. There are 6 defined fixed points for measurement in this system Anterior: Aa, Ba, C Posterior: Ap, Bp, D Three other landmarks are described: Genital hiatus (gh) Total vaginal length (tvl) Perineal body (pb) Each of these 3 measurements is measured in cm above or proximal to the hymen (negative) or below/ distal to the hymen (positive) with the plane of the hymen as zero (0)

questions.question_text: Match the scenario with the preferred surgical intervention
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The 1 st scenario is of a woman with family probably complete (She has 3 children) but is quite young (27y). Prolapse in such a patient can be treated by Manchester repair (which involves cervical amputation with plication of the cardinal ligaments over the cervical stump) The 2 nd scenario is one of nulliparous prolapse. This can be treated with sling surgeries and nowadays, hystero-sacropexy/ cervico-sacropexy (laparoscopic or laparotomy) is done. Another procedure called cervico-pectopexy is done (the cervix is attached to the iliopectineal ligaments) The 3 rd scenario is a peri-menopausal woman with prolapse. Here Ward Mayo is preferred. This includes vaginal hysterectomy with anterior colporrhaphy and posterior colpo-perineorrhaphy
  • • The 1 st scenario is of a woman with family probably complete (She has 3 children) but is quite young (27y). Prolapse in such a patient can be treated by Manchester repair (which involves cervical amputation with plication of the cardinal ligaments over the cervical stump)
  • • The 2 nd scenario is one of nulliparous prolapse. This can be treated with sling surgeries and nowadays, hystero-sacropexy/ cervico-sacropexy (laparoscopic or laparotomy) is done. Another procedure called cervico-pectopexy is done (the cervix is attached to the iliopectineal ligaments)
  • • The 3 rd scenario is a peri-menopausal woman with prolapse. Here Ward Mayo is preferred. This includes vaginal hysterectomy with anterior colporrhaphy and posterior colpo-perineorrhaphy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Surgeries for uterine prolapse include:
  • ➤ Surgeries for uterine prolapse include:
  • ➤ If family complete and elderly/ postmenopausal: Vaginal hysterectomy with anterior colporrhaphy (cystocele repair) and posterior colpoperineorrhaphy (rectocele repair) If family complete and young: Manchester repair/ Fothergill repair or Shirodkar modification of Manchester If young and nulliparous: Sling surgeries or hysteropexy surgery If old and unfit for major surgery: Colpocleisis
  • ➤ If family complete and elderly/ postmenopausal: Vaginal hysterectomy with anterior colporrhaphy (cystocele repair) and posterior colpoperineorrhaphy (rectocele repair)
  • ➤ If family complete and young: Manchester repair/ Fothergill repair or Shirodkar modification of Manchester
  • ➤ If young and nulliparous: Sling surgeries or hysteropexy surgery
  • ➤ If old and unfit for major surgery: Colpocleisis
  • ➤ Ref: Page 211, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition

questions.question_text: How is a 3 rd degree prolapse differentiated from a 4 th degree prolapse (procidentia)?

options.A: Passing a sound through the cervix

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • As per the Shaw’s classification of utero-vaginal prolapse, there are 4 degrees of prolapse Stage 0 – No prolapse Stage I – Descent of the cervix into the vagina Stage II – Descent of the cervix up to the introitus Stage III – Descent of the cervix outside the introitus Stage IV / Procidentia – whole of the uterus is outside the introitus Now on inspection, stage 3 and 4 will appear the same like this:
  • • As per the Shaw’s classification of utero-vaginal prolapse, there are 4 degrees of prolapse Stage 0 – No prolapse Stage I – Descent of the cervix into the vagina Stage II – Descent of the cervix up to the introitus Stage III – Descent of the cervix outside the introitus Stage IV / Procidentia – whole of the uterus is outside the introitus
  • • Stage 0 – No prolapse Stage I – Descent of the cervix into the vagina Stage II – Descent of the cervix up to the introitus Stage III – Descent of the cervix outside the introitus Stage IV / Procidentia – whole of the uterus is outside the introitus
  • • Stage 0 – No prolapse
  • • Stage I – Descent of the cervix into the vagina
  • • Stage II – Descent of the cervix up to the introitus
  • • Stage III – Descent of the cervix outside the introitus
  • • Stage IV / Procidentia – whole of the uterus is outside the introitus
  • • Now on inspection, stage 3 and 4 will appear the same like this:
  • • They are differentiated by approximating the thumb and finger of the examining hand at the introitus over the swelling If the thumb and finger approximate, this means it is a procidentia i.e. the thumb and finger are able to get above the uterine fundus If the thumb and finger don’t approximate, it is a 3 rd degree uterine prolapse
  • • They are differentiated by approximating the thumb and finger of the examining hand at the introitus over the swelling
  • • If the thumb and finger approximate, this means it is a procidentia i.e. the thumb and finger are able to get above the uterine fundus
  • • If the thumb and finger don’t approximate, it is a 3 rd degree uterine prolapse
  • • Other options
  • • Other options
  • • An ultrasound (trans-perineal or trans-vaginal) does not help in determining the degree of prolapse A uterine sound helps in differentiating between a chronic uterine inversion and a prolapse
  • • An ultrasound (trans-perineal or trans-vaginal) does not help in determining the degree of prolapse
  • • A uterine sound helps in differentiating between a chronic uterine inversion and a prolapse

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding development of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis in the female fetus and neonate?

options.A: The gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) “pulse generator” remains functionally dormant until shortly after birth.
options.B: By 5 months’ gestation, 6 to 7 million oocytes have been created from accelerated germ cell division.
options.C: At birth, follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) concentrations rise and remain high during the first 3 months of life.
options.D: Neonatal breast budding, minor uterine bleeding, and transient ovarian cysts may occur as a normal response to initially high gonadotropin levels.

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • A carefully orchestrated cascade of events unfolds in the neuroendocrine system and regulates development of the female reproductive system. In utero, gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) neurons develop in the olfactory placode. These neurons migrate through the forebrain to the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus by 11 weeks’ gestation. Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), a decapeptide, is influenced by higher cortical centers and is released from these neurons in a pulsatile fashion into the pituitary portal plexus. As a result, by mid gestation, the GnRH “pulse generator” stimulates secretion of gonadotropins, that is, follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH), from the anterior pituitary. In turn, the pulsatile release of gonadotropins stimulates ovarian synthesis and release of gonadal steroid hormones. Concurrently, accelerated germ cell division and follicular development begins, resulting in the creation of 6 to 7 million oocytes by 5 months’ gestation. By late gestation, gonadal steroids exert negative feedback on secretion of both hypothalamic GnRH and pituitary gonadotropins. During this time, oocyte number decreases through a process of gene related apoptosis to reach a level of 1 to 2 million by birth At birth, FSH and LH concentrations rise abruptly in response to the fall in placental estrogen levels and are highest in the first 3 months of life. This transient rise in gonadotropin levels is followed by an increase in gonadal steroid concentrations, which is thought to explain instances of neonatal breast budding, minor bleeding from endometrial shedding, short-lived ovarian cysts, and transient white vaginal mucous discharge. Following these initial months, gonadotropin levels gradually decline to reach prepubertal levels by age 1 to 2 years. The childhood years are thus characterized by low plasma levels of FSH, LH, and estradiol. Estradiol levels typically measure < 10 pg/mL, and LH values are < 0.3 mIU/mL.

questions.question_text: During the past several decades, the ages at which girls experience thelarche and menarche have shown which of the following trends?

options.D: No clear trend has been observed

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Earlier trends of puberty are now being experienced In most girls, breast budding, termed thelarche, is the first physical sign of puberty and begins at approximately age 10 years Following breast and pubic hair growth, adolescents undergo an accelerated increase in height, termed a growth spurt, during a 3-year span from ages 10.5 to 13.5 years. Higher BMI correlates with earlier pubertal development. The mean age o menarche in white girls is 12.7 years and 6 months earlier, or 12.1, in black girls

questions.question_text: A 33-year-old female is being followed for a 5-mm prolactin-producing pituitary adenoma, which is well controlled on bromocriptine 0.5 mg orally daily. She presents with a positive pregnancy test result. What is the next best step?

options.C: Check a prolactin level and if it is elevated, continue bromocriptine therapy
options.D: Obtain magnetic resonance (MR) imaging of the brain and base decisions on these findings

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The pituitary gland enlarges during pregnancy, primarily due to hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the lactotrophs in response to elevated serum estrogen levels. Although the tumor can enlarge during pregnancy, the risk of clinically significant growth is small. Significant expansion may lead to headaches or compression of the optic chiasm and blindness, visual field testing is considered in every trimester or women with macroadenomas. Dopamine agonist therapy has been associated with an increased risk of spontaneous abortion, preterm deliveries, and recommendations are that dopamine agonist therapy be discontinued during pregnancy when possible.
  • • The pituitary gland enlarges during pregnancy, primarily due to hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the lactotrophs in response to elevated serum estrogen levels.
  • • Although the tumor can enlarge during pregnancy, the risk of clinically significant growth is small.
  • • Significant expansion may lead to headaches or compression of the optic chiasm and blindness, visual field testing is considered in every trimester or women with macroadenomas.
  • • Dopamine agonist therapy has been associated with an increased risk of spontaneous abortion, preterm deliveries, and recommendations are that dopamine agonist therapy be discontinued during pregnancy when possible.

questions.question_text: Meiosis I of the oocytes is completed at which of the following times?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Primary oogonia enter meiosis in utero (in fetal life) to become primary oocytes. These oocytes are arrested in development at prophase during the first meiotic division. Meiotic progression resumes each month in a cohort follicle. Meiosis I is completed in the oocyte destined for ovulation in response to the LH surge. Meiosis II begins, and the process is arrested, this time in the second meiotic metaphase. Meiosis II is completed only if the ovum is fertilized
  • • Primary oogonia enter meiosis in utero (in fetal life) to become primary oocytes.
  • • These oocytes are arrested in development at prophase during the first meiotic division.
  • • Meiotic progression resumes each month in a cohort follicle.
  • • Meiosis I is completed in the oocyte destined for ovulation in response to the LH surge.
  • • Meiosis II begins, and the process is arrested, this time in the second meiotic metaphase.
  • • Meiosis II is completed only if the ovum is fertilized

questions.question_text: Images A and B, respectively, correspond to which of the following menstrual cycle phases?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Proliferative phase: straight to slightly coiled, tubular glands are lined by pseudostratified columnar epithelium with scattered mitoses. Early secretory phase: coiled glands with a slightly widened diameter are lined by simple columnar epithelium with clear subnuclear vacuoles. Stroma is variably edematous in the secretory phase. Late secretory phase: serrated, dilated glands with intraluminal secretion are lined by short columnar cells. Menstrual phase: fragmented endometrium with condensed stroma and glands with secretory vacuoles are seen in a background of blood.

questions.question_text: A 7-year girl is brought to the OPD. Her mother has noted vaginal bleeding for 2 days which is small in quantity staining her undergarments. She shows no signs of pubertal development. The cause of the bleeding is not apparent during physical examination, and the decision is made to proceed with examination under anesthesia and saline vaginoscopy. What is the most likely finding?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Neonates may present with vaginal bleeding during the first week of life due to the withdrawal of maternal hormones at birth and this b leeding typically resolves after a few days. Prepubertal bleeding in a child, however, merits careful evaluation Most instances of vaginal bleeding in these girls are due to local causes and can be elucidated with a simple history and physical examination. Occasionally, an examination under anesthesia with saline vaginoscopy is required to rule out a foreign body in the upper vagina
  • • Neonates may present with vaginal bleeding during the first week of life due to the withdrawal of maternal hormones at birth and this b leeding typically resolves after a few days.
  • • Prepubertal bleeding in a child, however, merits careful evaluation
  • • Most instances of vaginal bleeding in these girls are due to local causes and can be elucidated with a simple history and physical examination.
  • • Occasionally, an examination under anesthesia with saline vaginoscopy is required to rule out a foreign body in the upper vagina
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B: Atrophic vaginitis: This is a common cause of bleeding in the post-menopausal age group Option C: Endocervical polyp: This is a common cause of inter-mentrual bleeding in the reproductive age group and less common in children Option D: Sarcoma botryoides: This is a malignant tumor that arises from the immature skeletal muscle cells (rhabdomyoblasts) of hollow organs like the vagina or bladder or biliary tract. It most commonly affects children < 4y and classically presents as a mass resembling a bunch of grapes.
  • • Option B: Atrophic vaginitis: This is a common cause of bleeding in the post-menopausal age group

questions.question_text: A 30y G2 presented to the emergency with a history of seizures. On admission she is noted to be 36 weeks pregnant, and her BP is 170/100 mmHg. A diagnosis of eclampsia is made, she is administered MgSO4, and antihypertensives and labor is induced. She delivers a live 1.8kg female baby. She is admitted in the ICU post-delivery as she continues to have high BP and is finally discharged on the 5 th postnatal day with advice to follow up after 1 week. You are asked to help in preparing an audit of the Dept of OBG at the month end. This case is an example of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Near-miss maternal mortality

questions.question_text: You are called to the postnatal ward to see a patient who has delivered a 3.4kg boy 1 day earlier by a vaginal delivery. She was a known case of gestational diabetes mellitus. She is anxious as she is having mild bleeding. On examination she is afebrile. PR is 80/ min. BP is 110/70 mmHg. On abdominal exam, the uterus is just below the umbilicus and on local examination, the episiotomy appears healthy and the pad is stained with blood. There is no foul smell. What is the next best step in management ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C.  Reassurance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The normal discharge following delivery is called Lochia
  • ➤ Lochia is of 3 types
  • ➤ 1. Lochia Rubra: lasts for 5-7 days, red in color
  • ➤ 2. Lochia serosa: lasts for 7-10 days, pinkish-yellow
  • ➤ 3. Lochia alba: lasts for 10-25 days, white in color
  • ➤ Ref: Page: 636-637 Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page: 636-637 Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.question_text: A 32-year-old woman, P2L2, gave birth to a healthy baby girl. She is breastfeeding and is concerned about her postpartum contraception options. What is the most suitable method for postpartum contraception during lactation for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Progestin-only contraceptives

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • During lactation, progestin-only contraceptives are generally the most suitable method as they do not interfere with breastfeeding and have a lower risk of side effects compared to combined oral contraceptives.
  • • During lactation, progestin-only contraceptives are generally the most suitable method as they do not interfere with breastfeeding and have a lower risk of side effects compared to combined oral contraceptives.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option. A. Combined oral contraceptives: Combined oral contraceptives (COCs) contain both estrogen and progestin. These are not typically recommended for breastfeeding women, especially in the immediate postpartum period, because estrogen can reduce milk supply. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends avoiding these during the first six months postpartum for women who are breast feeding Option B. Withdrawal method: is a natural method wit very high failure rate and hence not preferred Option D. Barrier methods : Barrier methods include condoms, diaphragms, and cervical caps. These do not interfere with breastfeeding. However, they are generally less effective at preventing pregnancy than hormonal methods or IUDs
  • • Option. A. Combined oral contraceptives: Combined oral contraceptives (COCs) contain both estrogen and progestin. These are not typically recommended for breastfeeding women, especially in the immediate postpartum period, because estrogen can reduce milk supply. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends avoiding these during the first six months postpartum for women who are breast feeding
  • • Option. A. Combined oral contraceptives:
  • • Option B. Withdrawal method: is a natural method wit very high failure rate and hence not preferred
  • • Option B. Withdrawal method:
  • • Option D. Barrier methods : Barrier methods include condoms, diaphragms, and cervical caps. These do not interfere with breastfeeding. However, they are generally less effective at preventing pregnancy than hormonal methods or IUDs
  • • Option D. Barrier methods
  • • Thus, while breastfeeding, progestin-only contraceptives are considered the most appropriate option due to their minimal impact on milk production and safety for the infant

questions.question_text: A 26-year-old woman, P1L1, is attending her postpartum visit. She gave birth vaginally four weeks ago. Her vital signs are stable, and she has no complaints. What is the most important component of the postpartum visit for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Contraceptive counseling

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Contraceptive counseling is a crucial component of the postpartum visit, ensuring that the patient is informed about and has access to appropriate birth control methods to prevent unintended pregnancies.
